HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK;
How Priceless Time Flies

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. Lisa Belkin's e-mail address is Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TIME, according to commercials from at least one credit card company, is priceless. What costs is the stuff we fill it with. Airlines, on the other hand, can tell us the exact price of our time. Or, more specifically, the price of a Saturday night.
Not long ago, my work required a five-night trip to Seattle; I would arrive late Monday and take the red-eye home on Friday so I could spend Saturday with Bruce and our boys. The friendly ticket agent explained that since I had called too late (by 12 hours) to qualify for a seven-day advance purchase, the fare would be $1,898. I, in turn, explained that I wanted to buy a seat, not the entire plane. Sounding a touch less friendly, she clicked her keyboard for a while, then asked if I might consider staying over until Sunday morning. That fare would be $366. 
 Thankfully, it was not my money I was spending, it was my employer's, and though I do not waste anyone's money easily, at least I had the option of booking the high-priced ticket. But because big businesses are able to pay, small businesses are in turn forced to pay, and the smallest business people have no choice but to give up their Saturday nights. One friend, who is completing a book, schedules all his out-of-town interviews on weekends, constantly weighing the savings in air fare against the days lost with his family. The paradox, he says, is that flying out on a Thursday and home on a Monday costs hundreds of dollars less than flying out on a Monday and back on a Thursday -- even though he is still taking up a (cramped) seat on Thursday and Monday.
Business travel is hardly the only facet of life where time can be traded for money. But most of the others make sense. Pay a few dollars more to an overnight delivery service and the package actually arrives first thing the next morning. Pay $1,532 more to an airline, and you don't get there any faster, nor is there any decrease in the level of abuse.
In the last few weeks, many airlines have announced that they will start giving "full economy" passengers a whopping three to seven more inches of legroom, and I will believe that when I see it. But even in the bigger seats, I'll bet that lunch will still be served (squashed) in a paper bag, headphones will still cost extra, and though you will get frequent-flier miles for your loyalty and your trouble, you won't get any more than the guy next to you, whose flight you are subsidizing. And just wait until it's time to redeem those miles. In early December, I tried to book our summer vacation. I was told the frequent-flier allotment of seats was already sold out on every flight to Shannon, Ireland, for the last two weeks in July.
True, if you pay a full coach fare or have enough of those hard-earned miles, there are ways of finagling your way into first class; but lately those upgrades are as hard to come by as my reward tickets to Ireland.
And true, if you have earned enough miles, the rules say you may board the plane early, meaning you might find a place for your overhead luggage; but this, too, is more theory than not. "We are pleased to preboard our Elite Card holders," the flight attendant says, and everyone in the waiting area stands up. In front of me on the "preboard" line recently was a man whose Oxford insurance card was more or less the same color as the airline's membership card. He flashed it and ambled on.
You do get two things, however, for the extra money you pay for a full coach fare. First, the fare is fully refundable. In other words, for $1,532 more, they generously allow you to cancel the flight. In the case of my Seattle trip, this was no small benefit because the person I was supposed to interview there backed out at the last minute and I had to scramble to reschedule.
The second perk is even more important. I learned about it on a January flight to San Francisco when head winds meant the plane had to take on extra fuel and the airline had to bump 30 passengers to allow for the added weight. All around me, people were outraged. "For $700, you'd think they'd treat you better." Or, "They bumped us because we're flying on a $539 fare." I had paid $1,600 for my ticket, and when I checked in, the agent did not even mention the weight restrictions. She certainly never mentioned the idea of giving up my seat.
Pay them enough money and you are actually permitted to board the plane. Now that's priceless.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
Help for the Manager's Spouse Who Slurps Soup

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
The corporate executive was seeking help from Charles Sacarello, a Manhattan consultant who specializes in brushing up the images of the upwardly mobile.
The executive had a problem that threatened to derail his career: his socially inept wife. 
 Only a few months earlier, the client had been on the fast track. As a candidate for a seat on his company's board, he had been invited with his wife for dinner and drinks at the home of another senior executive. The top brass were all there.
The result was a disaster. First, his wife told some off-color jokes. Then, embarrassed by the icy response, she gulped down several drinks. The evening ended when she fell, fully dressed, into the host's swimming pool.
Not long after that, the board position fell through and the executive was told that he had gone as far in the company as he ever would. He found a new job, and now he wanted his wife to be coached on how to act like a business partner. "It became obvious to both of them that they were on display," said Mr. Sacarello, who is 45. Happily, he added, "the marriage survived."
Executives' wives -- and husbands -- are on Mr. Sacarello's mind a lot these days. Most corporate managers are used to taking courses and reading books on how to get ahead. But the advice they get usually centers on exploiting their own skills and resourcefulness.
Mr. Sacarello, though, sees a huge need for managers to pay more attention to their spouses' appearance and behavior. In his 15 years as an image consultant, he has encountered too many career stoppers, from husbands or wives with abysmal table manners to those who show up for social weekends with five suitcases.
His firm, Charles & Associates, recently rolled out a program to polish corporate spouses' public persona by teaching them everything from Continental table manners and how much jewelry to wear ("Don't look like a Christmas tree," he advises) to finding the right phrase to break the ice in awkward moments.
Other image consultants say he is on to something. They point to the growing diversity in executive suites. More women are breaking through the glass ceiling, for example, meaning that husbands as well as wives need help. And more power couples with modest economic backgrounds are sailing up the corporate ladder together, meaning that sometimes both spouses could use a little enhancement of their social graces.
Moreover, the consultants say, with the line between work and home increasingly blurring, more corporate mates are getting caught in the limelight than ever.
Scott Scanlon, an executive search consultant in Stamford, Conn., said he had noticed that spouses now receive more attention than in the past during the recruitment process. And Debra Lund, a spokeswoman for the Franklin Covey Company, a professional services firm in Salt Lake City, says that more of the companies that hire her firm to give training seminars are extending them to spouses and other family members.
"Companies are recognizing that they have more stakeholders than the people who work immediately within the walls of their companies," Ms. Lund said.
When it comes to rehabilitating wayward spouses, however, some image consultants think companies should do more.
"I think there is an undisclosed need for this type of help that hasn't been tapped, with both companies and senior managers reluctant to talk about it," said Don Kaufman, who runs an image-consulting firm in Philadelphia with his wife, Karen Kaufman.
Camille Lavington, an image consultant in Manhattan, says most corporate spouses that she takes on as clients are women and they can become unnerved by the social demands thrust upon them as their husbands rise rapidly in the ranks.
"Unless they've been exposed to heavy socialization, the average wife is so afraid that she will do something to impede her husband's success that she turns reticent and doesn't make an effort to get involved, or charitable," she said. "They're so self-conscious that they don't know how to make the other person feel comfortable."
Corporate husbands can also feel self-conscious. According to Bill Higgins, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a retired Navy captain, they can feel the need for guidance as well.
For the last 12 years, Mr. Higgins has been married to Barbara Corcoran, the founder of the Corcoran Group real estate firm. Mr. Higgins sold his own real estate business in 1997, and although he still has business interests of his own, about a year ago he began carrying a business card labeled "spouse," to give him an identity, he said. Last month, he went one step further and formed a club made up of husbands like him; four members showed up at the kickoff meeting. And he has just started a Web site, www.spouseclub.com, to provide guidance to corporate spouses.
"I don't want to be a marriage counselor," Mr. Higgins said, "but I do want to help the person whose wife is in a corporate position and who finds himself having to play the support role."
Ms. Lavington says empathy is the first thing she teaches her clients, so they can put other people at ease -- an important asset in business. And Mr. Sacarello of Charles & Associates thinks the key often is simply to bolster a spouse's self-esteem. As an example, he cited a client who held a blue-collar job and who, in the past, had made virtually no effort to provide support for his executive wife, who worked for a company that required her to socialize a lot.
"We taught this individual to value himself for what he did, and we made a list of his positive traits, like the fact that he has a good brain, personality, and can sustain a conversation, as well as hold a drink," Mr. Sacarello said. "Now his attitude is completely different, and he and his wife come across as a couple. Our goal is that when two people walk into a room, nobody needs to know who the highflier is or isn't."

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Is Lower But Remains Near Record Level

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
With interest rates and gasoline prices rising, consumer confidence slid in February from its record-setting level of January.
Still, confidence remained high, at levels last seen in the boom of the late 1960's, suggesting that consumer spending will continue to fuel economic growth. 
 The Conference Board said yesterday that its consumer confidence index dipped to 141.8 in February from a record high of 144.7 in January. It was the first decline since October, but the reading remained above the 141.7 of December.
The results were lower than the 143 that Wall Street analysts had expected, helping cool inflation jitters, but economists still expect the Federal Reserve to push interest rates higher in March to keep the economy from overheating.
Lynn Franco, director of the board's research center, said the February figures reflected declining consumer expectations of business and job opportunities in the next six months.
"Consumer attitudes will bear watching over the next few months to gauge the impact of rising interest rates and relatively high gas prices," she said. "As for now, the index is signaling further economic growth ahead."
The index, based on a monthly survey of 5,000 American households, is closely watched because consumer spending makes up about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Most analysts expect the economy to begin slowing some this quarter because the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates four times since June to try to slow the economy and head off inflation.
In addition, rapidly rising prices for crude oil have sent heating oil prices soaring and gasoline costs surging to record levels, affecting fuel-reliant industries like airlines and trucking.
The latest consumer confidence reading "may indicate a little bit of fear that higher gas costs are here for a while, maybe a little bit of fear about what the Fed might do and the stock market might do," said Bryan Jordan, an economic analyst at Banc One Investment Advisors. But "consumers are still very confident," Mr. Jordan said. "They're still out there spending, even on autos and homes which are interest-rate sensitive."

HEADLINE: Economists Readjust Estimate Of Overstatement of Inflation

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29

 BODY:
More than three years after concluding that the Consumer Price Index overstated inflation by 1.1 percentage points a year, a group of prominent economists says changes made to the index since then have narrowed the overstatement to about eight-tenths of a percentage point a year.
Their estimate is included in a report prepared for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, by the General Accounting Office, which conducts investigations and audits for Congress. The report is to be released publicly on Wednesday. 
 The economists were the members of a commission established by Congress to study the price index, which is widely used not just as a barometer of inflation but to set wages in union agreements and to recalculate tax brackets and Social Security benefits each year.
The commission, headed by Michael J. Boskin of Stanford University, spent 18 months studying the index. In December 1996, the commission's five members reported that a variety of statistical problems had created an upward bias in the price gauge of between 0.8 and 1.6 percentage points annually, with their best guess being 1.1 percentage point.
Since then, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics has made seven changes in the way it calculates the index. In a letter accompanying the accounting office's report, Katharine G. Abraham, the commissioner of labor statistics, said the agency was continuing to develop and evaluate improvements to the index, but that it did not think it possible to put a specific number on the degree to which the index overstates inflation.
At Mr. Moynihan's request, the accounting office went back to the commission members and asked for their current estimates of the upward bias in the index. In addition to Mr. Boskin, whose estimate was 0.8 to 0.85 percentage point, the other members were Ellen R. Dulberger of I.B.M., who estimated 0.8 percentage points; Robert J. Gordon of Northwestern University, who estimated 0.73 percentage point; and Dale W. Jorgenson of Harvard, who estimated 0.9 percentage point. The fifth member of the commission, Zvi Griliches of Harvard, died in November.
Because of the ways in which the price index is used, even modest reductions in any upward bias could result in smaller wage increases for some workers, lower payments to Social Security recipients and higher tax bills for some people.
Mr. Moynihan used the results to buttress his case for holding cost-of- living increases for Social Security beneficiaries to a rate below the rise in the Consumer Price Index. Such a change, he said, would go far toward putting Social Security's finances on sound footing for the long run.
Reducing the cost-of-living increases by eight-tenths of a percentage point would eliminate more than half of Social Security's projected shortfall over the next 75 years, Mr. Moynihan said.
In its original report, the Boskin commission said that the overstatement of inflation in the price index stemmed from a variety of problems. One was the inability of the index to fully capture decisions by consumers to switch from one variety of a product to another when prices rise -- from Red Delicious to Granny Smith apples, for example.
Another was the difficulty of accounting for choices by consumers to avoid rising prices by switching from one type of product to another -- renting a video, for example, rather than going out to see a movie.
The biggest single problem identified by the commission was adding popular new products like computer and cell phones to the index soon enough after their introduction to capture declines in their prices, and to find a way of accounting for quality improvements.

HEADLINE: Afghan Heroin Feeds Addiction In Region, U.N. Report Declares

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 29

 BODY:
The United Nations Drug Control Program says in a report made public today that Afghanistan is now not only the largest producer of opium but is also becoming a major manufacturer of heroin, which is contributing to a rise in addiction throughout the region.
The report, prepared for a meeting here on Monday of Afghanistan's six neighbors plus the United States and Russia, says that Pakistan and Iran now have some of the world's highest rates of addiction to heroin, which is derived from opium. "Central Asian countries show alarming signs of fast-increasing abuse rates," it says. 
 Afghanistan is encircled by Pakistan, Iran, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and a far-western corridor of China.
"The number of heroin addicts in the region exceeds that of Western Europe and is still on the increase," says the report, prepared by Pino Arlacchi, executive director of the United Nations office for drug control and crime prevention. The report adds that communities of addicts in the region are seen as easy targets for organized crime and vectors for the spread of AIDS.
The report says that there is no evidence to support charges that drug profits are going either to leaders of the Taliban, who control most of Afghanistan, or to the Northern Alliance, the remains of the former government. Both forces impose taxes on traders, however, with the Taliban earning $10 million to $30 million a year, according to varying estimates, the report says. It says no estimates are available of the alliance's earnings from this source.
As a country, the report says, Afghanistan receives only about 1 percent of the global profits of the opium and heroin originating there. Poor farmers with no other easy way to earn an income do most of the cultivation, turning over crops to local traders.
The United Nations report links the increase in narcotics production in Afghanistan with the economic, political and social collapse caused by decades of civil war.
"Like viruses thrive best in frail bodies," it says, "illicit drugs prosper best in regions that are in internal turmoil with weak or nonexistent government structures and controls." Taliban leaders say that until they get help in building an economy, they cannot ask farmers to forgo the only income they have.

HEADLINE: Economic Rally Began With Reagan

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (column, Feb. 23) attacks our conclusion that the United States' economic rally began in the early 1980's with Ronald Reagan, not in the early 1990's with Bill Clinton. Our premise that Reaganomics -- lower taxes, sound money, free trade and smaller government -- deserves a lot of the credit for our prosperity has been validated by the National Bureau of Economic Research, which concludes that except for a seven-month recession in 1990, the period of 1982 to 2000 has been one of prolonged high employment, low inflation and bull-market expansion. 
 Mr. Krugman asks how we can possibly credit the fast growth since 1995 to Reagan policies. We have five answers: a reduction in the capital gains tax, welfare reform, three free-trade agreements signed by President Clinton, a decline in government spending to 19 percent of gross domestic product from 22 percent, and Alan Greenspan's anti-inflationary monetary policy. These sound an awful lot like supply-side economic policies to us.
 
STEPHEN MOORE
LAWRENCE KUDLOW
Washington, Feb. 29, 2000
 
The writers are, respectively, director of fiscal policy studies at the Cato Institute and chief economist at Schroder & Company. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Yes, It's Still the Economy, Stupid, but With an Asterisk

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 29

 BODY:
If Vice President Al Gore has counted on anything in this tumultuous political season, it is that the strong economy will give him the upper hand in the general election should he win the Democratic presidential nomination.
The economy remains as strong as ever. But Mr. Gore's strategy for using it to his advantage would have to change -- and could in the end prove to be less potent -- if his Republican opponent turned out to be Senator John McCain rather than Gov. George W. Bush. 
 To Mr. Gore's team, Mr. Bush, who until a few weeks ago seemed to have a lock on his party's nomination, is in many ways the ideal rival. The centerpiece of the Texan's campaign has been his big tax cut, a proposal that Mr. Gore's advisers are certain they could label fiscally irresponsible, a threat to Social Security and a gamble with the current prosperity.
When it comes to economic issues, Mr. McCain presents a smaller, more elusive target. While he supports tax cuts, they are of a scale closer to those advocated by Mr. Gore. Like President Clinton and the vice president, Mr. McCain emphasizes that saving Social Security is his first goal. And like the administration, he promotes the long-term benefits of reducing the national debt.
"McCain is not challenging the basic framework of the Clinton-Gore administration," said Will Marshall, president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a research organization created by centrist Democrats. "That will make it tougher for Gore to find points of contrast if McCain turns out to be the Republican nominee."
To Mr. McCain's supporters, his middle-of-the-road approach on economic policy is a crucial element of a driving force behind his candidacy: his argument that he is more electable than Mr. Bush.
"What McCain talks about in policy is politically doable within Washington, and it insulates him and puts him in a position of strategic advantage relative to Gore should he face him in the fall," said Representative Mark Sanford, a Republican from South Carolina who backs Mr. McCain.
"What Democrats have beaten Republicans over the head with -- with great success -- was the notion that we wanted big tax cuts to the exclusion of Social Security and Medicare," Mr. Sanford said. "McCain's plan allows us to say we agree that Social Security ought to be first, and here's how we propose to do it."
Perhaps just as important, or more so, neutralizing the economic issue could give Mr. McCain a chance to move the campaign to the ground on which he feels strongest: character and reform. Indeed, relative to either Mr. Gore or Mr. Bush, he has little interest in the details of economic policy.
"It won't be a battle over who's a better wonk," said Marshall Wittman, director of government relations at the conservative Heritage Foundation, who supports Mr. McCain. "The battle would be over who do you trust, and that's where McCain has the edge."
Mr. Gore's campaign, of course, does not see it that way. Advisers to the vice president said they would make a case that Mr. McCain is just as conservative as Mr. Bush. They also said they viewed Mr. McCain as open to attack on some critical issues, especially Social Security. Mr. McCain advocates using a big chunk of the projected federal budget surplus to create private investment accounts within the retirement system. Most Democrats have long said such a step would leave the elderly vulnerable to the volatility of Wall Street and divert money from debt reduction.
"If the issue is, as it should be, who can keep the economic prosperity going," said Chris Lehane, Mr. Gore's spokesman, "then the fact that Al Gore has been a major player in an administration that has created the longest economic expansion on record is going to be the main factor."
It is still unclear whether Mr. McCain's moderate stance on fiscal policy will win the day in the Republican primaries. Mr. Bush has not wavered in his advocacy of sweeping tax cuts as the best way to stimulate growth and, as he puts it, to keep politicians in Washington from squandering the surplus on wasteful government spending.
"People say, 'Well, your tax cut plan isn't taking hold, the exit polls don't show anything, you must abandon it,' " Mr. Bush said after his defeat in Michigan last week. "I'm not going to abandon the tax cut plan."
Mr. Bush is using Mr. McCain's moderate position on taxes to lump him with Mr. Gore and Democrats generally, and is trying to block Mr. McCain's efforts to claim the mantle of Ronald Reagan as the true conservative in the race.
"It's important for Senator McCain and Vice President Gore to hear this important fact: that taxes on working people in America are at the highest level they've been since World War II," Mr. Bush told a rally in Virginia last Friday.
In response, Mr. McCain has emphasized his conservative credentials, especially his advocacy of slashing pork-barrel spending and ending corporate tax subsidies and loopholes. His argument is that it is more conservative to keep spending in check, reduce the national debt and shore up Social Security than to enact a tax cut that would go mostly to the wealthy -- a sharp jab at Republican orthodoxy.
"There's no doubt that the Democrats will try to make John McCain carry all the baggage of his party," said Mr. Marshall, of the Progressive Policy Institute. "The question is whether this campaign will be for McCain what Bill Clinton's 'different kind of Democrat' campaign did for him in 1992, which was to show that you couldn't put him into the old categories."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Cap Gemini to Acquire Ernst & Young's Consulting Business

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 29

 BODY:
In a move to create a global computer services consulting firm, Cap Gemini S.A. of France announced today that it was acquiring the consulting practice of Ernst & Young, one of the world's largest accounting firms, in a deal worth $11.1 billion.
Cap Gemini said it would pay 375 million euros, or $362 million, in cash and issue up to 43.5 million new shares, if all the consulting businesses of Ernst & Young accept the offer. 
 The stock will be divided among Ernst & Young's 1,000 consulting partners, who will then work for Cap Gemini, and the 4,000 accounting and tax partners that will remain with the auditing firm. About a third of the shares will go to the consulting partners and another third to the accounting and tax partners, who must sell their stock within five years. The remainder will go to finance Ernst & Young's pension plan and to pay for a variety of other expenses, including tax bills and transaction costs.
The deal represents the latest attempt by the accounting industry to try to address competitive pressures facing consultants and to allay regulators' concerns about the integrity of corporate audits. If it succeeds, it will be the first time one of the largest accounting firms has sold its major consulting business and will afford Cap Gemini, the biggest European computer services company, a major entry into the United States.
Paul Hermelin, a Cap Gemini director, said the combined companies would transform Cap Gemini into a "real global firm." Combined revenue, he said at a news conference to announce the deal, would amount to as much as $7.5 billion.
Philip A. Laskawy, chairman and chief executive of Ernst & Young who will remain as the head of the auditing practice, said the companies complemented one another "from a strategic and geographic perspective" and were equally committed "to the development of e-offerings."
In recent years, the world's biggest accounting firms have come under growing pressure to separate their accounting and consulting businesses. The latter has become their most profitable and fastest-growing area, but friction between consultants and accountants has grown. The consulting business requires significantly more capital than a firm's traditional auditing practice, and firms have scrambled to retain and attract their consulting employees. The Securities and Exchange Commission has also been pressing firms to avoid the conflicts of interest that come when supposedly independent auditors are tempted to make compromises in reviewing a company's books rather than risk losing lucrative consulting contracts.
Earlier this month, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which advises and audits many of the world's biggest corporations, said it planned to separate its auditing and consulting practices into two or more separate entities. Its biggest rivals, including KPMG, Arthur Andersen and Deloitte & Touche, are all trying to devise other solutions.
While the sale by Ernst & Young represents a possible answer to the problem of auditor independence, the transaction has not yet been approved by the S.E.C.
Ernst & Young's audit partners will still own a sizable piece of Cap Gemini, and regulators may view the arrangement as one that continues to pose a conflict of interest for the firm's auditors.
The move will catapult Cap Gemini into the big league of global computer service consultants, a field now dominated by American giants like I.B.M., Electronic Data Systems, Andersen Consulting and Computer Sciences. Pierre Hessler, president of Gemini Consulting, said he expected the combined group to generate roughly a fourth of its revenue from Internet companies this year, up from about 16 percent in the past. The deal will also strengthen Cap Gemini's position in the United States, which will account for about a third of the group's revenue, and reinforce its status in Germany, another major market.
But some industry analysts say Cap Gemini may face a challenge in keeping Ernst & Young's clients happy. In the United States, Cap Gemini's image was bruised recently after several major computer installations failed to live up to expectations. In January, the company reached an amicable settlement with the United Way of America over a failed $12 million project; last summer, the United States Chamber of Commerce canceled a $75 million contract with Cap Gemini, contending that one of its systems failed to deliver what was promised.
Still, Cap Gemini's bid would create a consulting giant with a strong position in the financial and insurance industries, as well as in the media and telecommunications businesses.
Analysts said that the combination made sense, given Cap Gemini's strong presence in Europe, while Ernst & Young has a solid position in the United States and Germany, a European market where Cap Gemini has been struggling to develop a significant presence. Moreover, the alliance would enable both companies to provide better service to the Internet economy, which is enjoying sustained growth and strong profitability.
Investors appeared to agree. Cap Gemini shares soared almost 14 percent at the start of trading in Paris today, to a record 291.9 euros, or $283.14. The price has risen almost 50 percent since early December, when the companies began serious talks.
The deal with Cap Gemini involves its consulting practices in the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Spain, countries where Ernst & Young generates roughly 85 percent of its total consulting revenue of $3.4 billion. Other countries are expected to be included later, including Belgium, the Netherlands, much of Scandinavia, Australia and New Zealand. The deal requires the approval of Ernst & Young's partners, who will vote country by country in coming weeks. The results are expected in April. Cap Gemini shareholders will then vote on the arrangement.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq Index to Another Record

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices staged a broad, sharp advance in heavy trading yesterday. Demand for technology stocks was especially intense, and the Nasdaq composite index rose to a record.
Led by networking and computer-related stocks, the Nasdaq jumped 118.84 points, or 2.6 percent, to 4,696.69. 
 The gain capped an amazing month for the index: in February, the Nasdaq rose more than 19 percent. For the year, the index is up 15.4 percent.
"Technology, telecommunications and biotechnology are areas where it is hard to argue with a good story and big promises," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading for Credit Suisse First Boston. "The market loves the story, the growth and the promise."
The gains were not limited to stocks listed on the Nasdaq.
For a second consecutive session, blue-chip stocks moved higher.
The Dow Jones industrial average, helped by big gains in Hewlett-Packard, AT& T and General Electric, rose 89.66 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,128.31.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 18.37, or 1.4 percent, to 1,366.42, led by big gains in Texas Instruments, Motorola and Oracle.
The Russell 2000 index of small- cap stocks soared and set a record.
Demand for small but fast-growing technology and biotechnology companies helped to propel the Russell 2000 index by 20.03, or 3.6 percent, to a record 577.71. The Russell's technology index has jumped 39 percent this year.
Trading was heavy. Volume on the Nasdaq stock market set a record yesterday, at 2.07 billion shares. On the New York Stock Exchange 1.2 billion shares changed hands.
Faced with the specter of additional moves by the Federal Reserve Board to raise short-term interest rates, most analysts said gains in sectors of the market that are sensitive to rising rates are likely to be somewhat limited.
"We have been in a trading range on the Dow of between 10,000 and 12,000 for much of the last year, " said Philip Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. "We are likely to stay within that band for a while longer."
Mr. Orlando said that recently he had been a buyer of stocks like Wal-Mart, International Paper, General Electric and Johnson & Johnson.
Micron Technology, the biggest domestic maker of computer memory chips, surged 17 15/16, to 96, encouraged by a 10 percent rise in chip prices over the last week.
Motorola, which signed a licensing deal with Psion P.L.C., Europe's largest maker of palmtop computers, gained 12, to 170 1/2. The company later announced a three-for-one stock split.
3Com, another contributor to the S.& P. 500's advance, jumped 18 15/16, to 98.
The stock, which has been a big winner so far this year, soared again yesterday in advance of the initial public offering of its Palm division.
Biotechnology shares were higher.
Genentech rose 11 3/8, to 192 7/8. Immunex closed at 197 7/16, up 6 11/16. And Biogen gained 3 1/16, to 107 5/16.
Oil stocks also did well. Exxon Mobil rose 11 13/16, to 75 5/16. Among oil service stocks, Halliburton was up 3 5/16, to 38 3/16. Schlumberger gained 4 33/64, to 73 55/64. And BJ Services closed at 57 1/16, up 4 1/4.
Retailing stocks, which have been under selling pressure so far this year, did better. Wal-Mart, a Dow component, gained 2 3/4. to 48 7/8. Staples was up 2 1/8, to 27. And Circuit City rose 4 5/8, to 40 7/16.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Rise
 
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices rose yesterday as investors added longer-term debt to portfolios to mirror changes in a benchmark index, while notes fell a second day as stocks advanced.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 22/32, to 101 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.14 percent from 6.19 percent on Monday. Money managers matched an extension in duration in the Lehman Brothers Treasury Index for March, analysts said.
"You have some index rebalancing for March," said Ted Neild, who helps invest $40 billion at the Nuveen Advisory Corporation in Chicago. "People look to the easiest place" to reconfigure their portfolio, and that's the 30-year bond, he said.
Two-year Treasuries, which are most vulnerable to interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve, led notes lower. Its price fell 1/32, to 99 31/32, while its yield rose to 6.52 percent from 6.50 percent. Many investors expect the Fed to raise rates next month to slow the economy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Corporate Raider of 80's Quits as Chief of Insurer
Saul P. Steinberg, one of the best-known corporate raiders of the 1980's, stepped down as the chief executive of Reliance Group Holdings, the troubled insurance company. Mr. Steinberg will remain chairman and will focus on the company's e-commerce strategy. 
 The company also posted another quarter of disappointing earnings and agreed to sell one of its units to Travelers Property Casualty for $580 million. Page C11.
 
Mirage Rejects Bid by MGM Grand
Mirage Resorts rejected a $3.3 billion takeover bid from casino rival MGM Grand as inadequate. But Mirage, which is run by casino mogul Stephen A. Wynn, said it would be willing to consider a transaction at a higher price. Before Mirage made its announcement, its shares fell 18.75 cents, to $15.75, while MGM Grand declined 31.25 cents, to $19.875. C11.
 
Nasdaq Sets Record in Sharp Rally
Stock prices staged a broad advance in heavy trading with the Nasdaq composite index rising to a record. The Nasdaq gained 118.84 points, or 2.6 percent, to 4,696.69. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 89.66 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,128.31, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.37 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,366.42. C18.
 
Helping the Spouse in Business, Too
Charles Sacarello, a consultant, sees a huge need for managers to pay more attention to their spouses' appearance and behavior. His firm recently rolled out a program to polish spouses' public persona. Management. C12.
 
Sotheby's Alters Commission Rates
Three weeks after Christie's changed its commission rates because of a federal antitrust investigation, Sotheby's revised its rates. C2.
 
Lawmakers Question AOL Merger
The proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner drew skeptical questioning from the Senate Judiciary Committee as lawmakers challenged a new pledge by the companies to open Time Warner's cable television system to other Internet service providers. C2.
 
Lazard Executive Is Stepping Down
Steven Rattner, the deputy chairman of Lazard Freres, is leaving and plans to join three other Lazard bankers in starting Quadrangle Group, a firm that plans to invest privately in media and telecommunications companies. People who know Mr. Rattner, who is close to Vice President Al Gore, had speculated he would go to Washington, possibly as a cabinet member, if Mr. Gore became president. But this move makes that possibility more remote. C14.
 
C.P.I. Is Said to Be More Accurate
More than three years after concluding that the Consumer Price Index overstated inflation by 1.1 percentage points a year, economists say changes made to the index have narrowed the overstatement to about 0.8 of a percentage point a year. C14.
 
No Source of Web Attacks Identified
The official in charge of the government's cybercrime-fighting unit told a Congressional panel that the F.B.I. was uncertain whether more than one group was responsible for the recent attacks on e-commerce sites. A16.
 
Tampa Electric to Upgrade Plant
The government's campaign to make seven utilities bring old coal-fired electric plants up to modern pollution standards showed its first results when Tampa Electric in Florida agreed to spend about $1 billion to switch one plant to natural gas and make significant changes at a second. A21.

HEADLINE: India Increases Its Military Budget by 28 Percent

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 29

 BODY:
With relations between the bitter foes India and Pakistan at their worst point in three decades, New Delhi announced a 28.2 percent increase in military spending today. It is the largest single-year increase in the nation's history.
"We shall not shrink from making any sacrifice to guard and protect every inch of our beloved motherland," Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha said in presenting the country's annual budget to Parliament. 
 The announcement comes less than three weeks before President Clinton is scheduled to arrive in New Delhi on a mission that is at least partly intended to ease the strain between the world's two newest nuclear weapons states.
A big jump in military spending is no surprise. It has been expected since India fought intense battles with Pakistani-backed forces in the frigid mountains of Kashmir six months ago. The Indians drove off the invaders, but the incursion revealed weaknesses in the nation's defenses. The military complained that a decade of belt-tightening had left it without needed funds for basic supplies, surveillance equipment and upgraded weapons.
Tensions have only grown worse. Pakistan's military overthrew the elected government. Guerrilla attacks have become epidemic in Kashmir. India blamed Pakistan for the hijacking of an Indian airliner on Christmas Eve.
"India is sending a message with the new budget," said George Perkovich, author of the new book "India's Nuclear Bomb" (University of California, 1999). "It's saying to Pakistan, 'O.K., you may want to use a bellicose strategy against us, but you're broke and we're not. We're going to spend 28 percent more. Can you match that?' "
Indeed, Pakistan is deeply in debt. But India, too, has a ballooning fiscal deficit. The budget for the year beginning April 1 calls for tax increases on higher-income people, a review of state subsidies and cuts in the government payroll.
Manpower cuts will not include the military, which will now have an allowance of $13.5 billion. Nearly half the money will go to the army. It is unclear how much will be devoted to nuclear weapons, though the Pakistanis will no doubt fear the worst.
"It's really mind-boggling how a country could increase a budget 28 percent if it was just for conventional forces," said a spokesman for Pakistan, Maj. Gen. Rashid Qureshi.
In May 1998, India tested a nuclear device and Pakistan followed 17 days later. Ever since, there has been fear of an arms race.
The rise in India's military budget is a victory for the nation's hawks, who want to beef up the armed forces. However, it is also a repudiation of their earlier views, when they argued that nuclear weapons would buy a better defense for less money.
Others see a bigger military budget as an overdue payment. "India has a one-million-man army, a two-fleet navy and a 35-combat-squadron air force -- and that takes money," said Uday Bhaskar, deputy director of the Institute for Defense Studies and Analyses in New Delhi.
In 1990, when India was experiencing a financial crisis, the military budget was cut back as a percentage of the gross domestic product, Mr. Bhaskar said.
The decline largely continued, though the largest increase in recent years was 14 percent in 1998.
Fighting last summer in Kashmir was a jolting reminder, Mr. Bhaskar said. "All that's happening now is that we're catching up," he said.

HEADLINE: Nassau to Reassess Property, Treading Political Minefield

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Feb. 29

 BODY:
Faced with a fiscal meltdown and a major lawsuit challenging Nassau County's antiquated property tax system, two Republican county officials reversed course today and agreed to press for the reassessment of all 415,000 residential and commercial properties in the county.
The reversal by the officials, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and Charles O'Shea, chairman of the Board of Assessors, makes reassessment, a longstanding political hot potato that recently won the support of the Democrat-led County Legislature, a near certainty. And it sets in motion what is likely to be a long, politically perilous process that will increase taxes in many of the wealthiest areas of the county. 
 Until now, reassessment had been considered too politically risky, largely out of fears that it would raise property taxes, especially those of wealthy homeowners who vote, leading them to take out their anger at the polls.
But the county's continuing financial crisis, which has led rating services to downgrade the county's bonds to a level just above junk, and a lawsuit challenging the current assessments as racially discriminatory forced the county to act. The county's budget deficit is estimated at $100 million to $190 million this year.
Residents of wealthy communities along the North Shore of Long Island, including Great Neck, Manhasset and Port Washington, stand to see tax increases, officials say. Homeowners in poorer areas along the South Shore, like Roosevelt, Freeport and Hempstead, will probably see their taxes fall.
But the political fallout remains unclear because both Democrats and Republicans now have their fingerprints on the reassessment proposal, and because the process, which is expected to take at least two years, will not be completed before November 2001, when all 19 county legislators and the county executive are up for re-election.
A study by the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee, a nonprofit fiscal watchdog group, found that roughly a third of county taxpayers would see their taxes rise, a third would see their taxes fall and a third would see no change.
Right now, houses in Nassau County are assessed based on land costs from 1964 and earlier and building costs from 1938 -- before the Long Island Expressway was built, before acres of farmland were sold to developers, and before the construction of Levittown ushered in a new era in suburban living.
Those tax assessments have remained the same ever since, even though houses in wealthy, mostly white areas have increased in value much more than houses in poorer, mostly black and Hispanic areas. The result is that the owner of a $300,000 house in Garden City can pay the same $8,000 in property taxes as the owner of a $110,000 house in Roosevelt.
Mr. O'Shea made his call for reassessment less than a month after defending the current system as "fair" before a County Legislature hearing. He explained his switch by saying that members of a commission he formed last year to study the system recently told him that while their work was not done, they had concluded that reassessment was overdue. "Reassessment will give fiscal stability to Nassau County by putting into place a modern assessment system that takes into account changes in property values," he said.
His announcement led to an even more stunning turnabout, as Mr. Gulotta said for the first time in his 13-year tenure that he would strongly support reassessment. "While I have traditionally opposed reassessment," he said in a statement, "the county's fiscal condition mandates we stop the hemorrhaging and undertake reassessment with procedures that provide maximum protection for our homeowners."
Judith A. Jacobs, presiding officer of the legislature, said she believed that the newly elected Democratic majority, which took over in January for the first time in 80 years amid voter dissatisfaction over the county's finances, paved the way for today's announcement by calling for a reassessment in January.
She praised some of her Democratic colleagues for calling for reassessment even though they represent communities along the North Shore where taxes could go up. "This system is literally bleeding the county," she said. "We should be thrown out of office if we don't do this."
But Republican legislators, who blame their party's losses at the polls largely on two tax increases they passed before the election, took a more wait-and-see approach.
Peter J. Schmitt, the minority leader, said he wanted more details from Mr. O'Shea before making up his mind. "If he can come up with a proposal that saves this county money," said Mr. Schmitt, who represents Massapequa, "then I'm for it. If he comes up with a proposal that saves the county money at the expense of people in my district, I'm not for it."
The announcement came less than a month before opening arguments are scheduled in a lawsuit filed by the New York Civil Liberties Union, the state attorney general's office and the Justice Department. The suit charges that the current tax system discriminates against black and Hispanic residents. While the town has said that residents are free to challenge their tax assessments, lawyers for the minority homeowners say only the wealthy have the time and resources to do so.
County officials said they were not admitting that the current system was discriminatory.
Leon Friedman, a lawyer working on the case, said he wanted to make sure that the reassessment proposal was fair before he and his colleagues agreed to a settlement.
The county's financial problems are compounded each year when it refunds roughly $100 million to residents and businesses that successfully challenge their tax assessments. Those payments have been cited as a major drain on the county's coffers by the state and county comptrollers and by Wall Street bond-rating agencies.
Mr. O'Shea's announcement raised almost as many questions as it did answers. He offered few specifics about how the reassessment would work and did not say whether it would be based on the full current market value of a property or a fraction of its current market value. He did say that his office was preparing to seek bids from assessors and that he would soon ask the legislature to appropriate money for the job.
Reassessing the county could cost between $30 million and $50 million, officials said. But Ms. Jacobs said it would more than pay for itself in the first year after it was complete, when the county would not face tens of millions of dollars in tax challenges.
The costs of the current system have been high. In 1999, the county borrowed $95 million to pay back homeowners and businesses that had successfully challenged their property taxes, according to figures from the county comptroller's office. The county paid $47 million more in debt service on its debt of $831 million in bonds issued to cover tax refunds.
But elected officials have long feared the political costs of reassessment. "It takes political courage," said Neal Lewis, executive director of the Long Island Neighborhood Network, an advocacy group. "Clearly the type of people who go to political fund-raisers and contribute to campaigns are likely to have more valuable homes that could see an increase. But I believe that people are willing to pay their fair share."
News of the reassessment plan made some North Shore residents nervous. "I'm very negative," said Jack Brown, 34, an investment fund manager who moved with his wife into a $400,000 house in Great Neck three years ago. Mr. Brown said his property taxes, at $5,300 a year, are low for the area. "But if they went to $7,000, that's $150 a month. That's real money."
In Freeport, meanwhile, homeowners were hopeful. Walton Bird, 38, who makes $18,000 a year, said he pays $4,000 to $5,000 in taxes on a house that is worth about $130,000. "I feel that the poor neighborhoods and the poor people are getting the worst end of the stick," he said.

HEADLINE: Gary Journal;
City Known for Trouble Sees Hope in a Pageant

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Feb. 29

 BODY:
Better known for violence, rust and urban decay than as a destination for beautiful women wearing sequins and gold lame, Gary, Ind., an aging, gritty city just east of Chicago, entered a contract today to be the site of the nationally televised Miss USA Pageant.
The announcement that the pageant would be held here for three years starting in February 2001 was seized on as another sign of hope by a town sometimes known to its detractors as Scary Gary. Eleven days ago, Mayor Scott King signed an agreement to bring a Continental Basketball Association team, Steelheads, here beginning in November. Two months earlier, Pan American Airlines began daily service to Orlando and Portsmouth, N.H., from the Gary/Chicago Airport, which for years did not provide commercial flights. And Gary is negotiating with minor league baseball officials to bring a team here in 2002. 
 The turnaround is occurring as Gary, a city of 114,256 that Money magazine in 1998 named the most dangerous city in the United States, is making inroads against crime. In 1993, 1995 and 1996, Gary tallied more homicides per capita than any other American city.
Homicide is down 24 percent from 1997 through 1999, from 98 to 74 killings. For the same period, rape fell 81 percent, armed robbery decreased 24 percent and aggravated battery declined 62 percent.
Among those killed last year was Mayor King's 17-year-old nephew, shot after a fistfight with another youth. Nonetheless, the mayor is encouraged by the drop in crime, and is quick to attribute much of the decline to an F.B.I.-led anti-gang unit sent in 1997 by Attorney General Janet Reno. The unit has made more than 500 arrests and federal prosecutors have won more than 200 convictions.
Although Gary has become safer, it has not become much prettier.
The main thoroughfare, Broadway, is 45 blocks of mostly abandoned buildings and boarded-up storefronts. Nearly three downtown blocks are entirely vacant, the result of a fire in 1996 that leveled churches, stores and an auditorium. Wide swaths of the city are dotted with abandoned housing.
But Mr. King, two months into his second four-year term, said he believed Gary was about to rebound from the hard times wrought by the 1980's recession in the steel industry that left thousands here without jobs and the crime wave wrought by street gangs in 1990's fighting for control of the crack trade.
Unemployment in Gary, 8.2 percent in 1999, is still above the state average of 3.2 percent, but less than half of the 17.8 percent high in 1989.
"We've built a solid foundation," Mr. King said. "Now we need to put up the framing."
Maureen J. Reidy, the president of the Miss Universe Organization, which produces the Miss USA pageant, said Gary's past troubles had no impact on selecting it over 11 other cities -- including Branson, Mo., and Shreveport, La. -- to play host to the pageant. Ms. Reidy, who was at Mr. King's side during a news conference today, said she was "pleasantly surprised" by the city.
Though Gary offered the best financial package -- the city will pay $1.2 million in travel, lodging, and other pageant costs -- it was not solely money that helped tip the scales in Gary's favor. Donald J. Trump owns one of the city's two casinos. The Miss Universe Organization is co-owned by Mr. Trump and CBS, which broadcasts the show.
City officials said they did not know how much money the pageant might attract. It may be hard to persuade those who know Gary only from its violent image to visit, said Spero Batistatos, the president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau of Lake County, which includes Gary. Though the pageant will be held in the city's 6,000-seat Genesis Convention Center, pageant workers and visitors probably will stay in hotels up to an hour's drive away because Gary has only one 200-room hotel.
"There will be some bumps along the way," Mr. Batistatos said. "You're talking about a solid 30 years of brainwashing by the media about the negatives in the city. A lot of those negatives are gone. As good as this is, it's going to take some time to change those perceptions."

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
D.O.A. at the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Nothing in the bylaws of the International Monetary Fund says that its managing director has to be European. Still, there is a long tradition to that effect -- part of a gentlemen's agreement that gives the considerably less critical directorship of the World Bank to an American.
But on Monday, when European Union finance ministers formally endorsed Caio Koch-Weser -- a Brazilian-born German official who has spent most of his career at the World Bank -- the United States promptly and bluntly rejected that choice. 
 To appreciate why the Americans decided to be so ugly, you need to understand that the head of the I.M.F. is one of the most crucial economic officials in the world, right up there with the chairman of the Federal Reserve and the U.S. Treasury Secretary. The managing director not only needs to be smart and experienced; he also needs to be diplomatically forceful. It's not a job for an ordinary bureaucrat.
Unfortunately, people who should know regard Mr. Koch-Weser as, well, an ordinary bureaucrat. He is, by all accounts, intelligent and likable. But he has spent his career at the wrong kind of institution; the World Bank is not a place to get experience in financial firefighting. More important, insiders I spoke to described Mr. Koch-Weser as someone who got along by going along -- someone who never expressed strong ideas of his own, who always seemed to say what he thought his superiors wanted to hear. That's not exactly the kind of man you want in the hot seat when the next global crisis breaks out.
So why did the Europeans select such a weak candidate? That's where the story gets awfully funny -- that is, it's funny, but it's also awful.
The problem begins with the French. France has long been an ardent advocate of the idea of Europe -- a Europe led by Frenchmen. And Paris has been ruthless in its determination to put its nationals in charge of everything from the I.M.F. to the European Central Bank.
At some point, however, Europe's largest nation was going to demand its turn. Given that a Frenchman has headed the I.M.F. for the last 22 years (and for 32 of the last 37 years!), the Germans figured that it was about time they got a chance. The trouble was that they didn't have any qualified candidates.
No, they aren't a nation of dummkopfs; it's a question of background. Germany does not have an elite civil service like the French or the British; nor does it have the kind of cross-pollination among business, academia and government that produces a Robert Rubin or Larry Summers. Nobody I talked to could come up with any German candidate he regarded as suitable for the job. Mr. Koch-Weser was the best Germany could find -- and he wasn't good enough.
Even the British and the French made their disappointment clear, withholding their endorsement for three months after the German government began pushing Mr. Koch-Weser. What finally concentrated their minds was the horrifying prospect that the job might actually go to the right person.
Last week a coalition of developing countries forced the issue by formally nominating Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director. Mr. Fischer (a former teacher and colleague of mine) has every conceivable qualification but one. An eminent economist, he is also an experienced policy maker -- he was the point man in the Asian crisis -- who has been noteworthy for his tact, discretion and ability to stay cool under fire. Even those who have criticized some of the I.M.F.'s decisions regard him as perfect for the job. But though born in what is now Zambia, Mr. Fischer is a naturalized U.S. citizen.
That apparently does not bother the African, Latin American and Middle Eastern (!) nations that have championed his candidacy. But the Europeans want a European, though most of them don't really want Mr. Koch-Weser. (Everyone suspects that Britain and maybe even France were willing to give lip service to an unsatisfactory candidate only because they counted on the Clinton administration, which is having trouble defending the I.M.F. against a hostile Congress in any case, to veto him.)
Now the truth is that there are plenty of qualified Europeans; there are citizens of Britain, Italy, Sweden, Poland who could do the job. Still, one wonders: Is it too late for Mr. Fischer to acquire a German passport?

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CONTEXT;
McCain Again Falters Within Party

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 29

 BODY:
Whatever else Senator John McCain of Arizona achieved in his short, sharp foray into Virginia this week, he certainly moved no closer to the Republican presidential nomination. His long-shot attack on the leaders of the religious right bore no immediate fruit.
Today's primary here was a victory for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in more than one sense. 
 He piled up an imposing margin and took all 56 delegates in the nation's 12th-most-populous state -- a Southern state, like South Carolina, where Mr. Bush won just 10 days ago, but a much less provincial one, with huge military installations as well as wealthy Washington suburbs where some of the nation's fastest-growing high-technology companies are based.
The triumph was the Texan's first in a large, economically and politically diverse state with aspirations to national leadership.
More important, he once again denied Mr. McCain the kind of showing among Republican voters that the Arizonan desperately needs. Mr. McCain took only 26 percent of the Republican vote in South Carolina and only 29 percent last week in Michigan; after a week of proclaiming himself "a proud Reagan Republican" in television advertisements, he did no better in Virginia.
In a state where 55 percent of the voters described themselves as conservatives, Mr. McCain did poorly among them. Twice as many self-described conservatives voted for Mr. Bush as for Mr. McCain.
Adherents of the religious right were not so numerous in Virginia as in South Carolina, accounting for only about 20 percent of the electorate, but they exerted a potent influence on the outcome. Mr. Bush won the backing of an overwhelming percentage of them -- almost 8 of 10, according to the exit polling -- while he and Mr. McCain ran even among voters who said they did not identify with Christian conservatism.
Mr. McCain did well, and Mr. Bush badly, among Democrats and independents who crossed over into the Republican primary. That brought no cheer to Bush backers, because the Texan has been striving to picture himself as the man who can lead the Republicans to victory in November.
Governor Bush seems unable to break out of a right-wing box, even though he has begun re-emphasizing "compassionate conservatism." Tonight, however, in a victory speech delivered in Cincinnati, he asserted that "we are expanding our base without destroying our foundation."
No doubt Mr. McCain has galvanized much of the country, including many people who have been alienated from politics in recent years. His national approval rating in the most recent ABC News/Washington Post poll has risen to 60 percent, from 36 percent at the end of October, while Mr. Bush's has been slipping. He is well situated for a general election contest.
But as Prof. Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia commented: "You can't possibly win the Republican nomination with just Democratic and independent votes. You need Republican as well as Democratic and independent support."
Moreover, Democrats and independents will be barred from voting for Mr. McCain (or any other Republican) in the New York primary on Tuesday or in California's delegate-selection election on the same day.
Polls show Mr. McCain trailing in both of those states, as well as in Texas and Florida, which will vote on March 14. Those four states, the nation's four most populous, will among them choose more than 45 percent of the 1,034 delegates needed for the Republican nomination.
The week between the Michigan primary and the voting today -- the state of Washington also held a primary, and North Dakota held caucuses -- was marked by frantic repositioning efforts. Mr. McCain tried hard to counter suggestions that he was insufficiently or unreliably conservative, and Mr. Bush struggled against suggestions that he was anti-Catholic.
But not much changed in the pattern of voting. The same acute ideological split that has shown up elsewhere was evident in Virginia, with Mr. Bush winning most of those who oppose abortion and attach great importance to moral issues, for example, and Mr. McCain winning most of those who back abortion rights and care more deeply about taxes and foreign policy.
Some of Mr. McCain's supporters had suggested that his speech on Monday in Virginia Beach, in which he denounced Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jerry Falwell, two of the Christian right's best-known leaders (and both Virginians), would prompt an outpouring of liberal and moderate Republicans in his behalf. According to exit polls, nothing like that happened; indeed, of the small number of voters who said they had decided at the last minute, most went to Governor Bush.
Others in the McCain camp hinted that the senator had been looking beyond Virginia to New York and California, hoping to win the backing of the numerous centrist voters there who object to the religious right. From that perspective, it is too early to evaluate the Virginia Beach speech.
The debates over which candidate was the real reformer and which was more honest, so steamy only a few days ago, seemed not to have fazed most Virginians. They said both were reformers and both talked straight.
Mr. McCain had hoped for a victory here to build upon his Michigan upset, and if he had brought it off it could have demoralized the Bush campaign on the eve of the biggest test of the year, the voting next Tuesday, which will include primaries in Ohio, Georgia, Massachusetts, Missouri and other states as well as California and New York. But no Republican has won on two big election nights in succession this year, and the pattern held.
With the backing of Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d and Senator John W. Warner, Mr. Bush was always the clear favorite; indeed, before Michigan, Mr. McCain had seemed ready to give Virginia a pass. By not doing so, he made the contest seem more important than it otherwise would have.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The Election Day poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters leaving voting stations throughout Virginia yesterday. The poll was conducted by Voter News Service, an organization created by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, Fox News, NBC News, and The Associated Press.
The results are based on 1,832 Republican primary voters in 35 randomly selected sites across the state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by no more than plus or minus three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all primary voters who turned out yesterday.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, like the reluctance of some voters to take time to fill out a questionnaire, may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Racial Bias in Public Schools

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Black students in public schools across the country are far more likely than whites to be suspended or expelled, and far less likely to be in gifted or advanced placement classes, according to a study of 12 large public school districts released yesterday by the Applied Research Center, a left-leaning nonprofit public policy group in Oakland, Calif.
The study, which comes at a time of heightened attention to racial differences in education, found inequalities in the districts studied: Austin, Tex., Boston, Chicago, Denver, Durham, N.C., Los Angeles, Miami, Columbia, S.C., San Francisco, Missoula, Mont., and Providence, R.I. 
 "Parents often feel that these are individual issues," said Libero Della Piana, a senior researcher at the center and a co-author of the report, "that it's just their kid having a problem, that it's about this teacher or that administrator, but when you look at the data, you see it's a systemic issue along race lines."
In every district studied except Missoula, Mont., where the data were unavailable, black students were suspended or expelled at a higher rate than their white peers. In Los Angeles, for example, black students made up 14 percent of the student body, but 30 percent of those suspended or expelled. The study did not offer details about whether students at the same school received similar punishments for similar acts.
Last fall, the racial skew in expulsion rates became a national issue after six black students in Decatur, Ill., were expelled following a brawl in the bleachers at a high school football game, and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson's Rainbow/Operation PUSH Coalition filed a civil-rights lawsuit. The case was dismissed and the expulsions upheld, but the testimony showed that blacks accounted for more than 80 percent of the district's expulsions over the last four years, even though they make up less than half of the student body.
That kind of racial skew is common in several aspects of education, the study found. In all nine districts that provided statistics on academic placement by race, the study found, white students were disproportionately represented in advanced placement and gifted programs, and minority students underrepresented.
In San Francisco, the study found that blacks and Latinos make up 42 percent of the student body, but only 14 percent of those in advanced placement and gifted programs. And in Durham, N.C., where blacks and Latinos make up 62 percent of the students, they represent only 27 percent of the students in academically advanced classes. While few of the districts studied had large Asian-American populations, the Asian-American students in most districts were overrepresented in advanced classes and underrepresented among those who were disciplined.
The study asserts that the disparities amount to "a deep pattern of institutional racism." But many education experts took issue with that conclusion. While the inequalities described in the study are distressing, they say, those differences, like the well-documented racial gap on test scores, do not necessarily add up to institutional racism.
"Unfortunately, we have a lot of history and evidence that schools tend to reproduce the economic and social disparities of the larger society," said Robert B. Schwartz, president of Achieve, a school reform group made up of governors and corporate executives. "We look to schooling to be this great equalizing engine, but history hasn't been terrific on that score. Can one deny that racism persists? Of course not. But I think it's more complicated than racism alone. Obviously, class plays into this, and other factors."
The study examined 10 indicators, including the dropout rate, graduation rate, suspensions and expulsion, advanced and gifted classes, college admissions and the racial demographics of the teachers compared with those of the students.
In all the districts, the percentage of white teachers was higher than the percentage of white students, often by a huge margin. In Denver, more than three-quarters of the teachers, but less than one-quarter of the students, were white. And in Los Angeles and Chicago, about half the teachers, but only about one in 10 students, were white.
While federal regulations require the reporting of some data, including the racial makeup of the student body, there is no nationwide mandate to keep other statistics, like expulsions and suspensions, or the number of students admitted to a college, by race. And of the 12 districts included in the study, 9 either did not keep, or would not disclose, all the data requested. For example, 3 of the 12 districts did not report data on the racial makeup of their advanced placement and gifted classes.
But more data by race may be forthcoming. Partly because of the experience in Texas, where school results have improved since achievement was tracked by race, many legislators, both Democrats and Republicans, are supporting efforts to tally education statistics by race.
"Texas has been an important model for this," said Gary Orfield, a professor of education at Harvard. "Requiring more data by race doesn't produce a solution, but it means the problems can't be covered up."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA;
SEIZURE POSSIBLE IN THAI BANKRUPTCY

BYLINE: By Wayne Arnold 

 BODY:
A dispute between Thailand's biggest corporate debtor, Thai Petrochemical, and its creditors has raised doubts about repayment of billions of dollars of bad debt in the country despite economic improvements since the Asian financial crisis in 1997. Thai Petrochemical has balked at an agreement to restructure $3.5 billion in debt. The creditors, including the World Bank's International Finance Corporation and the United States Export-Import Bank, have petitioned Thailand's bankruptcy court to declare the company insolvent and allow them to take it over. A hearing is set to begin today. Wayne Arnold

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Campaign Briefing

 BODY:

THE REPUBLICANS
 
BOB JONES RESPONDS -- Bob Jones University, the fundamentalist Christian institution that has become a lightening rod since Gov. George W. Bush of Texas visited it during the South Carolina campaign, has responded on its Web site to attacks against it. The university described Senator John McCain of Arizona, Vice President Al Gore and former New Jersey Senator Bill Bradley, as "the political 'three tenors,' " who together "sing the same off-pitch tune of the liberal left." The university previously declined to respond to requests for comment. "Isn't it really a compliment to Bob Jones University that the likes of John McCain, Al Gore and Bill Bradley seethe and fulminate against us?" the statement said. The university said its policy against interracial dating was based on its understanding of the story of the Tower of Babel. "The university wishes to give God the benefit of the doubt and avoid pursuing any direction that would give assistance to the renewed efforts of man to create a one-world community, consisting of one religion, one economy, one government, and one race," the statement said. The university denied that it hates Catholics, saying instead it believes it had a biblical mandate to preach salvation by faith alone to Catholics, Jews, Buddhists, Mormons, Muslims, atheists and "unbelieving and religiously liberal Protestants." The statement said it regarded Catholicism on theological grounds as "false." Gustav Niebuhr (NYT) 

BETWEEN GOVERNORS -- Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma has some neighborly advice for Mr. Bush. Mr. Keating, a devout Roman Catholic and early supporter of Mr. Bush, has suggested that the Bush campaign schedule a speech at a major Catholic university to counter any hint of anti-Catholic bias that might have emerged after Mr. Bush's appearance at Bob Jones University in the South Carolina primary campaign. Noting that Mr. Bush was at a Catholic center in Cleveland yesterday, Ari Fleischer, a campaign spokesman, said, "We do appearances at faith-based organizations all the time, so we rule nothing out." Ross E. Milloy (NYT)
 
THE DEMOCRATS
 
GORE IN LOS ANGELES -- Campaigning in Los Angeles today, Vice President Al Gore referred only briefly to his rival, former Senator Bill Bradley, criticizing his health care plan. He had an interview with Univision, which he was asked to conduct in Spanish. He declined, saying, though, that he once "was completely fluent." At a fund-raiser where he raised $100,000, he paid homage to the "wonderful mosaic" in the audience of Indians, Pakistanis, Jews, Koreans and Latinos. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)
 
THE POLLS
 
OHIO LEANS TO BUSH -- In Ohio, the first independent statewide poll of likely Republican voters taken since the primaries in South Carolina and Michigan showed Mr. Bush ahead of Mr. McCain, 53 percent to 36 percent. The poll of 386 likely Republican voters, questioned on Wednesday through Sunday, was released on Tuesday by the Institute for Policy Research at the University of Cincinnati. A similar poll of likely Democratic voters showed Mr. Gore ahead of former Mr. Bradley, 66 percent to 22 percent. The margin of error is plus or minus five percentage points. In Maryland, another state with a March 7 primary, Mr. Bush led Mr. McCain 47 percent to 40 percent in a Potomac Survey Research poll of likely voters for The Baltimore Sun. The poll, released yesterday, showed Mr. Gore ahead 58 percent to 23 percent. The margin of error was plus or minus five percentage points. David E. Rosenbaum (NYT)
 
THE WEST
 
GAY MARRIAGE OPPOSED -- Most Californians support a proposition to keep the state from recognizing same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. The latest Field Poll found 53 percent of respondents favored the ballot measure and 40 percent were opposed. Seventy-seven percent of Republicans supported it, 16 percent were opposed. Forty-two percent of Democrats supported it, 45 percent opposed it. James Sterngold (NYT)
