HEADLINE: A Theater Goes the Way of Arenas, With an Airline Name

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Broadway's historic theaters have been named for actors and actresses, playwrights and critics, producers and patrons of the arts. Not until today have any of them been named for airline companies.
But in an $8.5 million dollar deal that may well foreshadow the corporate renaming of a host of Broadway houses, the nonprofit Roundabout Theater Company is rechristening the venerable Selwyn Theater on 42nd Street the American Airlines Theater. 
 Meanwhile, the Winter Garden Theater, where "Cats" is expected to close in June after nearly 18 years, may soon become the Cadillac Theater or the Cadillac Winter Garden. The Shubert Organization, which owns the theater, has been in discussions with General Motors about the possibility of such a deal.
And with some trepidation over whether widespread corporate renaming will cheapen the theater district, officials at Broadway's two other major chains say they are open to putting the logos of corporations and products on their theaters as well.
Traditionalists may shudder at the thought of corporations' buying their way onto the marquees, but theater owners and marketing experts say these alliances will grow and could become a widespread and lucrative practice.
"It's going to change both the face and the economics of Broadway," said Lindsey Gruson, the president and chairman of STET, a marketing group that has been advising the Shuberts on the Cadillac deal. "It's a marriage made in heaven."
But even among some of those who would stand to benefit financially there is uneasiness. "The name of the game is maximizing the value of your assets and branding them," said Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn, which owns five Broadway theaters. "But if you take a long-term view of our properties, we certainly have other interests besides that, like maintaining the dignity and quality of the experience of going to the theater and protecting the buildings and protecting the American theater.
"We're not just marketers," Mr. Landesman continued. "We're also producers and custodians of a proud theatrical tradition. The Walter Kerr still sounds a lot better to me than 'the AT&T.' "
The interest has arisen since Times Square's recent transformation into a family-friendly destination as well as a wave of corporate namings of sports stadiums, bowl games, shopping centers and out-of-town theaters that left the historic Broadway houses, almost all of which have official New York City landmark status, intact. Only 42nd Street's combined and rebuilt Lyric and Apollo playhouses took on a corporate name -- the Ford Center for the Performing Arts -- when Livent Inc., opened the house with "Ragtime" in early 1998.
Money, of course, is driving the naming trend. Roundabout's deal with American provides for the airline -- represented by the marketing firm Entertainment Management Group (EMG), which has handled several musical tours and Broadway productions -- to contribute $850,000 a year to the theater over a period of 10 years. The funds will help underwrite the operations of the 35-year-old Roundabout, which has an annual budget of about $20 million. The Selwyn, which was built in 1918 by Edgar and Arch Selwyn, has been renovated at a cost of $21 million over the last two years. To date the company has raised about $17.5 million from donors including the city, board members and subscribers. It will open for use on April 11 with previews of a new production of Chekhov's "Uncle Vanya."
American's name will remain on the marquee for the duration of the partnership as well as on other materials associated with theater, including all tickets and advertising.
Todd Haimes, the artistic director of the Roundabout company, said that naming the refurbished house the American Airlines Theater seemed no different to him than naming it for an individual benefactor, as the company did when it named a theater after Laura Pels.
"I think it's wonderful that a major corporation would support the arts and want their name on our theater," Mr. Haimes said. "I don't have a philosophical problem with it."
An executive at American, which has attached its name to sports arenas in Miami and Dallas, said the naming would underscore its presence in New York, where it has begun construction on a $1.3 billion terminal at John F. Kennedy Airport. "It's one of our most important markets," said Tom Gleason, the regional vice president for American's eastern division. "We wanted to look at a different way of being part of the community."
The theater's focus on classics and musical revivals already reduces the risk of controversial content, but what happens if the Roundabout's artistic content comes into conflict with the airline's corporate agenda?
"We certainly made it completely clear that we have to have complete control over what appears on our stage," Mr. Haimes said. "And they were completely comfortable with that."
Jack Birch, a senior vice president at Octagon Marketing in Stamford, which has been working with the Shuberts, said that Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert organization, had been urged by his friend Mr. Gruson, a former correspondent for The New York Times, to reach out for corporate alliances.
Mr. Schoenfeld said the deal was nowhere near consummation and declined to discuss details. "This is a matter that has to be submitted to the board here," he said. "I cannot tell you anything now."
Mr. Birch said he was fairly certain that the Shubert partnership with General Motors would come to pass, though he said he suspected that the Shubert Organization would leave the names of most of its 16 theaters intact.
"I think they're going to do it," Mr. Birch said. "You never know what's going to happen, but we have met about it a few times and it's clear that the concept works."
Mr. Birch said that the theater in general offers corporations an attractive group of upscale, cultured consumers. "I think they realize that theater is a great target market and it's relatively uncluttered," Mr. Birch said of Cadillac.
Gust Kouvaris, a managing director at GM R*Works, a promotion and special events company, who has been involved in the discussions, did not return calls.
He added that the Shubert organization was a particularly attractive partner because in addition to its theaters it owns Telecharge, the telephone ticket service. "They own a lot of terrific, leverageable assets," he said.
This, Mr. Birch said, means that Shubert has a direct line to theatergoers by mail and telephone, providing a company like General Motors with easy access to potential customers. "One could ask them, 'Would you be willing to take a test drive of an automobile to get a free ticket along with one you buy?' " he said.
To some extent, these developments are a logical extension of the growing corporate presence on Broadway, which includes new producers like Disney, Cablevision and SFX Entertainment, which about a year ago renamed the Palace Theater in Chicago the Cadillac Palace. Livent, which had a short life on Broadway, led the corporate naming drive by setting up Ford Centers not only in New York but in Chicago, Vancouver and Toronto.
Even the Broadway establishment has turned increasingly to a corporate marketing. The League of American Theaters and Producers has established partnerships with as the "official airline of Broadway" and with Visa U.S.A. as the "preferred card of Broadway."
At the Minskoff theater, where "Saturday Night Fever" is playing, the Nederlanders have made a deal with Mercedes-Benz to place a car in the lobby.
"The whole issue of sponsorship is becoming an active conversation for all theater owners," said Nick Scandalios, executive vice president of the Nederlander Organization.
Mr. Scandalios said his company would nevertheless tread lightly in deciding whether to rename any of its nine theaters. "It's always a tricky thing," he said. "We certainly aren't going to look at renaming the Richard Rodgers and put a beer title over it. You have to look at the value of a name."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 3, 2000, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about renaming the Selwyn Theater for American Airlines omitted the name of another air carrier promoted as the "official airline of Broadway" in a deal with the League of American Theaters and Producers. It is Continental Airlines.
A picture caption with the article misidentified a building that is being renovated. It is the former Selwyn Office Building, not the Selwyn Theacalled the New 42nd Street Studios and will house the entrance to the theater, which is behind it.

HEADLINE: Agony of Domestic Violence at the Office

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
After her husband smashed the liquor bottle over her head, after the blood dried and her two young sons stopped crying, Rosa Schirripa realized the marriage was over. Although she got emotional support from her friends, she was afraid to approach the one person who might have given her the most practical help: her boss.
She said she feared that he would view her as weak or stupid for staying with her husband for so long and that he would try to get rid of her. Eventually she did talk to him and, to her surprise, he gave her a few days off, at his convenience. Before that talk, however, she felt she had nowhere to turn for advice and protection. Instead, she spent a lot of time sobbing in the office bathroom and asked her colleagues to cover for her when the divorce lawyers called. Anything so her boss would not know. 
 Ms. Schirripa, a 38-year-old New Yorker whose ordeal ended in divorce two years ago, said she knew of other people who stayed in abusive relationships because they were afraid to go to their boss. "They're afraid of the stigma," she said, "afraid that they'll be replaced."
That attitude appears to be changing, though, as more companies become aware of how domestic abuse affects workplace morale and productivity, and as more cities and states consider legislation to protect victims against discrimination.
A decade ago, only a handful of companies in the United States had formal policies to help employees deal with domestic violence, but today hundreds do, said Donna Norton, manager of the Workplace Resource Center in San Francisco.
The Philip Morris Companies, with 57,000 employees, has been active in the campaign for greater awareness of the problem, holding workshops and conferences around the country. Last spring, it joined with Liz Claiborne Inc., the American Express Company and the Bell Atlantic Corporation to sponsor Safe at Work, a coalition of companies, labor unions and government agencies that seeks to spread the word about domestic violence and its effect on the workplace.
A number of state and local governments have also taken action. Since 1998, Rhode Island and California have enacted laws prohibiting employers from terminating employees who take time off to get restraining orders against abusive partners. Similar legislation is pending in Congress.
Maine and Dade County in Florida enacted legislation last year to provide unpaid leave for domestic violence victims. Ten states, including California, Connecticut, New York and New Jersey, recently passed legislation making victims eligible for unemployment insurance if they lose their jobs. Mark Green, New York City's public advocate, says he plans to introduce a bill soon to broaden the rights of city employees in the event of domestic violence.
When it becomes known that employers cannot retaliate, "more women will come forward," Mr. Green said.
Domestic violence is probably a greater drain on productivity than most employers realize. Ten years ago, the Bureau of National Affairs, a private company that monitors workplace trends, estimated the cost of domestic violence in lost output at $3 billion to $5 billion a year. And a study commissioned by Liz Claiborne in 1994 estimated that family disputes, including domestic violence, kept a million Americans off the job every day. Last year, Victim Services, a nonprofit assistance agency in Manhattan, received 95,000 calls from women who needed help because of abusive partners.
"Many of the callers talk about issues at work, because for women that's a prime place where domestic violence happens," said Bea Hanson, a director at Victim Services. "We get calls from women who are being stalked by their boyfriend or husband at their job, or they've gotten repeat phone calls that prevent them from focusing on their work. We get calls from women whose partners come in unannounced and demand they leave. Most women don't feel safe to talk about this issue at work, so it's important for women to know they can disclose this information and not lose their job."
That sort of uncertainty once haunted Brooke McMurray. Ms. McMurray, a vice chairwoman of Victim Services, worked at Time Inc. for more than 20 years before leaving in January. She was in an abusive relationship for 12 of those years, she says, but never sought help at work. "You didn't talk about it then," said Ms. McMurray, who is 50. "The guy operating the freight elevators was the only one I told," and that was because she used the freight elevator for years when her husband used to wait in the lobby for her. Time does not have a formal domestic-violence policy, a spokesman said, but it does now have an employee-assistance program that can help victims.
Such a self-imposed wall of silence as Ms. McMurray's can come tumbling down at a company that advertises its eagerness to help people in her predicament. Janice Munson, a Philip Morris employee in upstate New York, says the company's policy helped save her sanity. Shortly after joining Philip Morris in 1990, she was divorced. Abusive calls and letters kept coming in, she says, but in the open atmosphere at Philip Morris she was able for the first time to talk to her superiors about her plight and to get help. She was encouraged to supply a description of her former husband to the security desk. She even got the mailroom to throw out letters from him so she wouldn't have to see them.
Ms. Schirripa, the woman who was hit over the head with a liquor bottle, is now a full-time administrative assistant at the College of Staten Island and is taking courses in social work there. She also makes speeches and works as needed for Mr. Green's office as an advocate for more enlightened workplace policies.
"Let the employer give the employee a chance, let her get on her own two feet," Ms. Schirripa said. Unpaid leaves are a big help, she said. Speaking for victims of violence, she added: "I'm not even asking for pay. I'll lose the money, but if I lose my job I lose my lifeline."

HEADLINE: GAME THEORY;
It's a Video Game, Certainly, but Is It Art?

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY

 BODY:
AS entertainment, it has faced its share of criticism: that it is all technological gimmickry, a useless diversion for people with nothing better to do than sit for hours in front of a screen.
A movie screen, that is. For that is how some critics described the fledgling motion picture industry at the turn of the last century. But by the 1920's, movies were being seriously discussed as an art form. And the discussion hasn't stopped. 
 Are video games, now at the quarter-century mark themselves, at the same crossroads, between developing into a widely appreciated art and remaining an amusement for a select group? Henry Jenkins, director of the comparative media studies program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, would say they are. Dr. Jenkins has spent 15 years studying the cultural and historical relationships among film, television and, more recently, digital media. At a recent conference on the future of video games he organized at M.I.T., he proposed that the time had come to discuss video games as an important art form.
Dr. Jenkins argues that this digital pastime will soon shake off its label as a diversion for adolescent boys. In 1999, according to the Interactive Digital Software Association, about 69 percent of PC gamers and 54 percent of console game users were 18 or older. Women accounted for 43 percent of PC video game players, a bigger percentage than ever before.
The industry is already recognized in terms of money. It was a $6.1 billion business last year, up from $5.5 billion the previous year and almost double what it was in 1995. According to the software association, the day is not long off when money spent on video games will be on a par with money spent on movie tickets.
For 1999, domestic box office revenues totaled $7.3 billion, while video game software sales brought in $6.2 billion.
And so, Dr. Jenkins says, it is time to give Pokemon, Super Smash Brothers and Spyro the Dragon -- three of the best-selling games of the last year -- some respect for their aesthetic and cultural value.
As a media researcher, Dr. Jenkins has only to look at his students, the first generation of adults who grew up playing video games, to see the influence of Pac-Man and Frogger. Ten years ago, most of his students wanted to direct films. "Right now, he said, "more of them are interested in being game designers than movie makers." They discuss game strategy "the way a decade ago students were talking about David Lynch or Peter Greenaway."
But many things need to happen before video games reach the same artistic level of movies, Dr. Jenkins said. Like video games, many of the first movies revolved around action -- car chases, pratfalls and pies in the face. But cinema quickly "developed a sense of the richness of its own formula," Dr. Jenkins said, something the digital medium is still struggling with. Human emotion, for example, is still limited in games to expressions like the grunt of the football player who fumbles or the yelp of joy of a warrior who captures the enemy flag.
"I rarely play a video game that makes me cry," Dr. Jenkins said.
Other aesthetic improvements might be easier to achieve. Music, which is now used as little more than background noise in games, will be used to provide tension, much as it does in movies. When a group of Dr. Jenkins's students presented a 30-minute montage of video game clips at the conference, it felt a lot like a movie trailer, complete with operatic soundtrack.
Perhaps the measure of whether video games have come of age is how deeply they have embedded themselves in our culture. The students presented game clips that traced the evolution of video games through games that included Pong and Myst. The clips began with the plain text "you are standing in an open field west of a white house," the opening line of the Zork I text adventure game, circa 1981. The phrase elicited the same nostalgic murmuring from the audience that the words "a long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away" would from film enthusiasts.
The grip that video games and their characters have on their fans mirrors the way movies and their stars mesmerize their audiences. Just as Clara Bow was proclaimed the first silver screen star to have "it," or sex appeal, Tomb Raider's Lara Croft is the "it" girl of the digital age.
But where are the German Expressionists of the game world? And the Charlie Chaplins? And can game creators overcome the inherent repetition in their work, perhaps through advances in artificial intelligence?
Dr. Jenkins talks about creating a critical vocabulary to discuss these questions. Right now, the only term he sees in that lexicon is "violence," a word that was often linked to video games in the wake of the Columbine High School shootings.
"It is the predominant story out there today about this form, whether or not this game or that game is violent," said Dr. Jenkins, one of the few defenders of video games at a hearing on Capitol Hill last spring. "There is a huge universe of important questions that need to be addressed about this medium precisely because of its economic importance, its cultural importance, its social importance. If the only articles ever written about cinema were 'all movies are violent,' we would think the critics, the journalists, had missed something that was vital about the emergence of that form."
Dr. Jenkins's point is that sociologists might find more to study in video games than a possible link to aggressive behavior. Geoffrey Goldstein, a psychology professor at the University of Utrecht in the Netherlands who has studied video games, said at the conference that video play was not a sport for loners because even if people don't play together, they discuss playing with friends. It turns out to be not just a phenomenon among competitive little boys, Dr. Goldstein said. In a study in which he asked women in a nursing home to play video games, he soon found them bragging about their Tetris scores every day over lunch.
Maybe it will be the grandmothers who pull gaming into the circle of social respectability and push newspapers to review games alongside films and television shows on their culture pages. Without some helping hand, the games could just as easily go the way of comic books, which came of age in the 1920's. They are another popular entertainment, but they have never expanded their niche market much beyond the backs of adolescent boys' closets.

HEADLINE: TURF;
Banks Ease Pain of Handyman Specials

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
ONE family bought a $2.25 million five-story brownstone on the Upper West Side -- and then had to find $800,000 more to fix it up.
Another family closed on a $632,500 colonial-style wreck in Scarsdale, N.Y., and then had to figure out how to borrow $200,000 to make it livable. 
 A couple with three children wanted to move to a bigger house but couldn't find anything they thought was a good investment, so they decided to put a $200,000 addition onto the house they already owned. The traditional solution -- refinancing the house -- would have been a disaster at today's higher interest rates.
Until recently, all these would-be renovators would have been in a heap of trouble.
For the first time in bankers' and mortgage brokers' memories, some banks in the Northeast are writing separate mortgages based not on the current value of the property but on its future value. That is, the loans are based on the enhanced value of the property when the renovations are done. And banks are writing them as second mortgages, even if another bank holds the first mortgage.
"We're frankly looking for the business," said Douglas Bowman, vice president of wholesale lending at Webster Bank. Mr. Bowman said his bank decided this week to start advertising the new second mortgages for renovations, which it has quietly been writing for at least a year. Several other banks are writing the loans, although they are not advertising the practice, said Melissa Cohn, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, one of New York State's largest mortgage brokers.
Because of the rise in rates, banks have been dreaming up new ways to entice customers, who are now paying more than a percentage point above what they might have been paying just a year ago. The construction second mortgages are just the banks' latest trick.
But beware: there is a price for separating out the renovation segment. The interest on the special second mortgages averages about half a point higher than on normal purchase mortgages.
Even so, Ms. Cohn said, they are rising in popularity. "I would say I'm writing five times the number of these loans as I did last year," she said. "As people are discovering them, they're becoming more prevalent."
It's not only that homeowners and buyers are discovering them. It's that they're needing them.
With the prices of apartments and houses so high -- and no relief in sight -- many homebuyers are looking at wrecks in fancy neighborhoods. Although places needing T.L.C. no longer offer the huge savings of a decade ago, the savings may be enough to let buyers move into a neighborhood they can't otherwise afford. Or to add an extra bedroom.
Until a year or so ago, banks would not have written two different loans for someone to buy and to improve a property.
The homeowner trying to add on may be even more grateful for the new loan. Until recently, somebody trying to find the money for an addition would have been forced to take out a home improvement or home equity loan, or to refinance the whole house.
But refinancing works only if the value of the house has increased substantially since it was bought. For example, if a couple took a 30-year, $200,000 mortgage to buy a house four years ago, they might be paying 6 or 7 percent interest. But if they wanted to put on a $75,000 addition, they would have an unpleasant surprise: they might have to take out a new mortgage -- at 8 5/8 percent, the going rate.
But under the new loan programs, the rate of 8 5/8 percent plus half a point would apply only on the $75,000, saving them close to $200 a month.
The new second mortgages are different from home equity loans in two important respects. First, the home equity loan is based on the current value of the home. And second, the Internal Revenue Service lets you deduct the interest only on the first $100,000 of a home equity loan. With the new renovation loans at Webster, Mr. Bowman said, you can borrow up to $450,000, and because it's a mortgage, the interest is usually fully deductible.
Home improvement loans have disadvantages, too. First, they are smaller: most lenders limit them to $25,000. Second, they are similar to installment loans, lasting no more than 10 or 15 years. And last, they cost more: 10 to 11 percent, these days.
Naturally, when you apply for the new kind of second mortgage, the banks won't take your word for what your property will be worth after the work is finished. They use appraisers trained in estimating the future value of the property, based on your plans. And needless to say, you'll pay for the appraisals, which cost $225 at Webster. But you would have to get a new appraisal if you refinanced, too.
And as with any construction loan, the bank will monitor your construction -- very carefully. In fact, as the job progresses, it will probably dole the payments out to the general contractor.
So you might have to kiss your trip to the Riviera goodbye.

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
From 'Elektra' to Electric, Throngs Come Out in Sydney

BYLINE: By John Shaw

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 1

 BODY:
This city's summer festival season opened to the conventional crescendos of grand opera and will close on Saturday with a three-hour gay and lesbian parade.
After two weeks of performances by Vladimir Ashkenazy, Philip Glass, the Netherlands Dance Theater, the Royal Court Theater and 30 other mainstream performers, the city's gays have taken over with a three-week Mardi Gras, a collection of 130 diverse events including body piercing and concerts by performers in drag. 
 That prompted the city's Anglican and Roman Catholic archbishops to issue a joint statement last week denouncing the celebration as "an exercise in gross exhibitionism that promotes a homosexual lifestyle and does not merit our presence or support."
The president of the Madri Gras, David McLachlan, replied that he was raised as a Catholic and that for him "it was sad to see how out of touch these church leaders are in helping people deal with their sexuality."
For the mainstream Sydney Festival, which ended on Jan. 31, about 130,000 tickets were sold, bringing in $2 million, and a million or more other spectators attended free concerts and exhibits. A light show bathed the sail-shaped roof of the Sydney Opera House with kaleidoscopic colors each night.
The Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, which has a budget of about $3 million, has brought in some $750,000 in theater and party tickets, and about 250,000 people attended free events, said its general manager, Mark Goggin.
About 600,000 spectators are expected to line the two-mile downtown route to watch the 200 floats and 6,000 costumed participants in the festival's finale on Saturday. Television and Internet rights to the parade, including live and recorded coverage, have been sold in Australia, the United States and Europe for a total of $350,000.
Sydney is bursting with crowd-attracting festivities this year. The Summer Olympics, which start here on Sept. 15, will have their own cultural festival.
During the Sydney Festival the Berlin State Opera's high-energy production of Richard Strauss's "Elektra" filled a 2,000-seat theater at premium prices, said the festival's director, Leo Schofield. The Netherlands Dance Theater was another box-office success, and the London production of "The Weir" by the Irish writer Conor McPherson was sold out.
Three local plays gave the festival some Australian flavor. In "Small Poppies" Geoffrey Rush depicted a 5-year-old's first day at school. Six untitled sketches presented by Daniel Keene and Arielle Taylor recalled the Beckett style, with bleak urban tales played in half-light. "The Sunshine Club" was a feel-good musical about interracial dating and dancing in the 1940's.
Mr. Schofield said Sydney's January season of music and drama, which he has directed for three years, was similar in some ways to the Lincoln Center Festival. An added attraction is this city's 25-year tradition of free evening concertsin the Domain, a 100-acre downtown park ringed with giant fig trees. About 80,000 people turned out with hampers and wine for an 11-group night of jazz; a Sydney Symphony Orchestra program of undemanding favorites, including the "Tannhauser" and "1812" Overtures, attracted about 140,000 under a full moon.
Perhaps the major event of the Sydney Festival was an exhibition of 242 drawings of the human figure, "Michelangelo to Matisse," which was held over through Tuesday so more people could view it.
The city's Mardi Gras has evolved from a kind of civil rights march to an Australian institution that bills itself as the world's largest gay carnival. This year's program emphasizes spectacle and sponsors more than it does slogans, although social concerns underlie the frills and frivolity.
Critics of Mardi Gras, including the Council of Churches, oppose the increasing involvement of public institutions like Sydney's main museum. The museum has organized an exhibition of body art that is considered the festival's most controversial event.
Some activists regard the criticism as a remnant of intolerance. Tony Knight, a longtime Mardi Gras participant who supervises the acting program at the National Institute of Dramatic Art, said: "Mardi Gras has become an institution, but it remains a political statement. Rights have been won, but there is no cause for complacency. Prejudice still exists."
The glossy 140-page Mardi Gras catalog, paid for by sponsors in the travel, media and liquor businesses, lists camp comedy, feminist concerts, "queer culture, soft-porn exhibitionism, artful bad taste," social satire, sidewalk painting and plays with messages from the gay world's frontiers.
The 5,000 Americans visiting Sydney for the festival will see some familiar acts, among them New Yorkers like Lypsinka, the drag diva, and Patty Chang, a performance artist, as well as Randall Wong, a male soprano from San Francisco.
All this, taken in laconic stride, seems remote from the Sydney of 1978, when homosexuality was illegal here (with penalties ranging to 14 years in prison). Demanding changes in the law, about 1,000 gay Sydney men staged a a street demonstration that year. Police officers arrested 53 of the marchers, but the courts dismissed the charges. The protest developed into an annual rally in a campaign that led to decriminalization of homosexuality in 1984.
Sydney, a multilingual melting pot of immigrant cultures, is now considered a notably tolerant city. "Inclusivity through diversity" is the buzz phrase here and the theme chosen this year by the Mardi Gras artistic director, Jonathan Parsons.
Still, acceptance of Mardi Gras is far from unanimous. Australia's prime minister, John Howard, declined to issue a message of support for the celebration. But Sydney politicians praise the carnival for contributing to acceptance and harmony, not to mention generating about $60 million for the city's economy this year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Shares Produce Modest Gain for Blue Chips

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Soaring telecommunications and technology stocks pushed the Nasdaq composite index further into record territory yesterday and helped the Dow Jones industrials eke out a modest gain.
The technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index rose 87.39 points, to 4,784.08, topping the closing record of 4,696.69 it set Tuesday. 
 The Dow Jones industrials added 9.62 points, to 10,137.93. The blue-chip Dow index has risen in three consecutive sessions -- the first such performance since Jan. 12 to 14. But yesterday's slim advance came after the Dow spent much of the session in negative territory.
Broader stock indicators were mostly higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 12.77 points, to 1,379.19.
After two days of relatively broad gains on Wall Street, the market reverted to its familiar divergent pattern, with technology stocks leaping higher while old-line industrial stocks slid.
Lucent Technologies rose sharply on the New York Stock Exchange after announcing plans to spin off the units that sell corporate phone systems and make wire cabling for office networks. Analysts said the spinoff would allow Lucent to focus on its fast-growing fiber optics and Internet equipment businesses.
On the Nasdaq, 3Com and Sun Microsystems rose, as did biotechnology companies, including Chiron.
Technology stocks gave the Dow its only real spark. SBC Communications rose on rumors the company would combine its wireless phone operations with those of BellSouth. That would allow the companies to compete with rivals with nationwide wireless networks. BellSouth also rose on the Big Board.
"These companies are going to be real players in the new economy, which depends on technology," said Barry Hyman, senior equity analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum in New York. "People are willing to pay up for tech stocks because that's where the growth is."
Apart from SBC, most Dow components were lower as investors remained wary of the prospects of blue-chip companies in an environment of rising interest rates. Home Depot and Merck fell.
The Federal Reserve has raised interest rates four times since June, hoping to slow economic growth enough to stave off inflation. After the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, suggested last month that central bankers remained poised to raise rates further, investors found little reason to buy blue chips, analysts said.
"His hawkish interest rate comments have folks running from stocks that borrow a lot of money and are heavily affected by overall economic activity," said Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. "This depression among the old-economy stocks has caused the manic buying of the new-economy stocks."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe Plans to Collect Tax on Some Internet Transactions

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 1

 BODY:
Testing the ability to enforce national tax laws in cyberspace, the European Commission is planning to collect sales taxes on music and software delivered over the World Wide Web.
Though not yet complete, the proposals would eliminate what European officials view as a big loophole that benefits American companies. 
 Some of those American companies have already begun to complain that they would be saddled with onerous responsibilities that could stifle electronic commerce in Europe.
But the debate has also exposed practical difficulties in adapting national taxes to a world in which music and art fly across borders.
Under proposals developed by the European Commission in Brussels, companies would have to collect what is known as a value-added tax, a type of sales tax, on products they sell and distribute over the Internet.
At issue are products like computer software, music and videos that can be turned into digital code and downloaded by customers anywhere.
Value-added taxes are a major source of revenue for most European governments, and tax rates vary by country from about 12 percent to more than 20 percent.
When it comes to physical goods, like books or clothes, the taxes have been collected by stores and mail-order companies or by customs officials if the products were to be shipped across national boundaries.
In those transactions, the tax rate is based on the rate of the country where the product originated.
But "virtual" products defy that system, because they can be sent just as easily from the United States or an off-shore tax haven like the Cayman Islands as they can from a local store in France.
European officials say that this gives American software companies an unfair advantage over European competitors. They are also worried that online vendors of all types will shift growing volumes of sales from sources outside the European system for tax collection.
Under proposals that officials are debating in Brussels, products sold in digital form would be taxed based on the rate in the customer's country, meaning that companies operating in the United States would have to collect the taxes on all sales to European customers.
"Without any changes, American companies would unquestionably have an unfair advantage," said Oliver Sume, a director of the Electronic Commerce Forum, an industry association in Cologne, Germany.
"This is a step in the right direction, toward a global framework for electronic commerce."
But American companies say efforts to extend the existing tax system will prove extremely complicated and prove unenforceable anyhow.
"This is an area that is still developing, and Europeans should not rush in to develop a solution right away," said Howard Liebman, a lawyer who heads up a working group on tax issues at the American Chamber of Commerce in Belgium.
Among other things, Mr. Liebman said, companies would have to determine where a customer actually lives, distinguish between 15 tax regimes and differentiate between private individuals and companies, because the two types of customers are treated differently for tax purposes.
To make things easier for businesses, some European officials have suggested requiring companies to register for business in one European country and turn their tax receipts over to that country.
But that idea is opposed by many European financial ministers, because it raises difficulties of distributing the tax money back to the correct countries.
Experts on both sides of the Atlantic warn that an overly demanding system could backfire, because many companies will simply ignore the tax rules altogether and run their Internet sales operations from offshore tax havens.
"There may be requirements, but this is still a system based on voluntary compliance," said Volker Kebish, a senior researcher on tax law at the University of Munster in Germany, who is part of an advisory group to the European Commission. "Increasing the complexity could discourage businesses outside the European Union from complying."
I.B.M. is lobbying against the tough new proposals. Smaller dot-com companies are worried as well.
"Everyone says that to grow e-commerce they need to increase market access, but I fear that this would be an impediment to market access," said Peter Harter, a vice president at EMusic.com Inc. of Redwood City, Calif., which sells music over the Internet and owns 20 percent of Crunch.com, a British music distributor. "It would be very invasive for us to track down where all our customers are."

HEADLINE: In Congress, Scorn for U.S. Oil Diplomacy

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson faced sharp questions today over the high price of oil products as legislators heaped scorn on his cautious forecast that oil-exporting countries would increase production later this month and reverse a steep yearlong climb in fuel costs.
Testifying before the House International Relations Committee, Mr. Richardson rejected calls from lawmakers to draw down emergency government oil reserves, a move that advocates say would lower prices. He said, however, as President Clinton did on Tuesday, that that option was still "on the table." 
 With the price of oil nearly tripled, to $31.77 a barrel in the last year, and with drivers facing $2-a-gallon prices at the gasoline pump this summer, the administration is under increasing pressure to dip into the 600 million barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve in Louisiana and Texas.
But Mr. Richardson repeatedly urged patience while talks continued with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and other important producers like Mexico.
"We've got to be prudent and not overreact," he said, pointing out that the emergency stocks were meant to be used only when national fuel supplies were disrupted.
"I'm guardedly optimistic that OPEC will increase production when it meets on March 27," Mr. Richardson said, noting that the Mexican oil minister said today in Paris that he favored a production increase.
OPEC is considering increases of 1.2 million to 3.1 million barrels a day, an about-face from production cuts of 4.3 million a day that began in 1998 after the financial collapse in Asia. The cartel now produces about 26 million barrels a day, or 35 percent of the world's oil production.
But lawmakers, mainly from the Northeast, Midwest and California, dismissed the encouraging statements that Mr. Richardson had elicited in talks with oil officials from Kuwait, Mexico, Norway, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela on a weeklong trip.
"Bill, you came back with nothing," said Representative Donald Manzullo, an Illinois Republican. "You got no promises."
"Congressman, I came back with quite a bit," Mr. Richardson, a former Democratic representative from New Mexico, replied. "Thirty days ago, OPEC was saying its production cuts would continue. Now, key members are saying they'll consider increases."
Even if OPEC votes to raise output at its March meeting, the big questions are when and by how much. Typically, it takes six weeks for production in the Middle East to pass through refineries and reach local gas stations. "We're running out of time," said Representative Bill Delahunt, a Massachusetts Democrat.
Several Democrats and Republicans expressed frustration that Mr. Richardson apparently did not use at least the threat of tapping the strategic reserves to wring concessions from oil producers.
"Why on God's green earth didn't you add to your leverage by opening that spigot?" demanded Representative Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut, the panel's ranking Democrat.
"Because using the Strategic Petroleum Reserve means intervening and manipulating the market," responded Mr. Richardson, who said earlier that the negotiations were meant to "convince, not coerce."
"What makes sense," he said, "is to let the results of our energy diplomacy work."
Mr. Gejdenson retorted: "This isn't the marketplace at work. This is OPEC flexing its muscle."
Some lawmakers, like Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a California Republican, criticized Kuwait and Saudi Arabia for cutting back output and driving up prices at a time when United States forces are protecting those countries.
"How can we keep troops in these countries when they're part of an international price-fixing conspiracy to shaft the people of the United States?" Mr. Rohrabacher said.
Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a New York Republican who heads the committee, announced that he would introduce legislation this week that would require the president to cut off arms sales and other United States aid to any oil-producing country that was engaged in price-fixing.
As he fended off verbal volleys from the legislators, Mr. Richardson underscored efforts that the administration took in recent weeks to soften the blow of the soaring fuel costs.
Last month, for instance, President Clinton said he would order that the remaining $125 million in a low-income home energy assistance program be made immediately available. That is on top of $200 million already released. Mr. Clinton said he would ask Congress for $600 million in additional emergency funds for states hardest hit by the winter cold.

HEADLINE: Notes From 1994 Show Fed's Inner Workings

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve began its last big round of interest rate increases, in 1994, without any clear sense of how strong the economy was, how many rate increases would be needed or how the stock and bond markets would react, according to transcripts released today of the central bank's policy meetings for that year.
The transcripts show the sway held over the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee by the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and reveal how concerned Mr. Greenspan was even then with the possibility that stock prices were becoming out of hand. 
 After five years in which the Fed had cut rates and then held them at low levels to nurse the economy through a downturn, Mr. Greenspan recommended a quarter-point increase in the benchmark federal funds target rate in February 1994, to 3.25 percent, to forestall the threat that a recent surge in growth would generate inflation.
He immediately came under pressure from interest rate "hawks" to approve a half-point rate increase. But Mr. Greenspan pressed the committee to go along with him, warning about the perils of a split within the Fed and saying too big a move would destabilize the financial markets.
In the end, the committee voted unanimously to raise rates by a quarter-point, as Mr. Greenspan wanted. It went on to raise rates six more times in the next year, doubling the federal funds rate to 6 percent.
Even then, nearly three years before Mr. Greenspan began worrying publicly about "irrational exuberance" in the stock market, the Fed chairman was clearly concerned that investors were creating a bubble in stock prices.
Indeed, when both the stock and bond markets fell sharply after the February rate increase, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed had "partially broke the back of an emerging speculation in equities."

HEADLINE: Auto Sales in February Near Monthly Record

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 1

 BODY:
The United States auto industry is poised to have its second-best month for sales ever after the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and DaimlerChrysler A.G. reported higher vehicle sales for February today.
The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate is expected to be about 19 million cars and light trucks when the few remaining companies report sales on Thursday. That would put February sales in second place after September 1986, when the rate was 21.2 million vehicles. 
 Every automaker that reported February sales today posted an increase, and most set February records. A half-dozen companies, including BMW and the smaller Asian carmakers, are scheduled to report sales Thursday.
G.M. had its best February since 1988, with vehicle sales totaling 467,010 cars and light trucks, up 16.1 percent, compared with results in the month a year earlier. Trucks led the way, rising 20.9 percent, to 223,503 units. Car sales increased 12.1 percent, to 243,507 vehicles. G.M.'s sales were lifted partly by a $500 loyalty coupon offered to current owners on the purchase of a new vehicle. The coupon expired on Tuesday and will not be extended.
Ford reported it sold 348,510 cars and light trucks, an increase of 3.9 percent from the month a year earlier. Car sales increased to 4.6 percent, to 146,074 vehicles. Truck sales climbed 3.3 percent, to 202,436.
DaimlerChrysler said it sold 250,230 cars and light trucks in February, an increase of 5.5 percent compared with sales in the month a year earlier. The automaker sold 168,813 light trucks, up 9 percent. Car sales fell 1.1 percent, to 81,417 units, because of decreases in the sales of the Chrysler group cars. Mercedes-Benz car sales increased.
Likewise, Toyota Motor, Honda Motor and Mitsubishi Motors set February sales records. Volkswagen had its best February since 1975. Nissan Motor, Subaru and Isuzu Motors also reported higher sales.
Auto analysts pointed to the strong economy and increasing consumer wealth as factors keeping vehicle sales humming in early 2000 after a record-setting 1999.
At a news conference, Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director of market and industry analysis, also attributed higher sales to the affordability of vehicles. Intense competitive pressures have prevented price increases and have led manufacturers to offer attractive incentives, including cash rebates and low-interest loans.
Gas prices, which hit record levels during the month, and climbing interest rates appeared to have no effect on vehicle sales. Sales of vehicles like full-size pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles that use gas heavily as well as luxury automobiles, were brisk during the month. Ford's F-Series pickup trucks and its sport utility vehicles had their best February in history. G.M. broke records in every truck segment, including pickups, sport utility vehicles and vans.
Forecasters expect the pace of vehicle sales to slow somewhat from February's scorching rate. Still, they predict the final tally for 2000 car and truck sales to rival the 1999 record of nearly 17 million vehicles.

HEADLINE: 2 New Signs Of Hot Pace In Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The nation's factories stepped up production in February and construction spending on homes and highways surged as an economy entering its record 108th month of expansion showed little sign of cooling, according to reports issued today.
"The economy's a hot house," said Tim O'Neill, chief economist with the Bank of Montreal and Harris Bank in Toronto. Federal Reserve policy makers will meet on March 21 and are widely expected to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said today that its factory index rose to 56.9 in February from a January reading of 56.3, where analysts had expected it to remain. An index on prices paid by factories for materials like plastics jumped to a five-year high of 74.1, pressuring companies to charge consumers more.
A reading higher than 50 on the factory index means that most companies surveyed reported improved business. The index has been at 50 or higher for 13 months. Economic growth overseas has helped fuel already strong demand.
In another report, the Commerce Department said that construction spending rose 2.7 percent in January after increasing 2.1 percent in December. The gain in January was paced by work on houses and apartments and an 11.4 percent surge in road building. The increase in overall spending was the largest since June 1998.
The factory report showed companies were feeling the pinch of rising costs for energy and materials. The rise in the index of prices paid, to 74.1 in February from 72.6 in January, indicates that more companies reported price increases during the month. The January index was the highest since a 74.5 reading in April 1995.
Though productivity gains and competition have eased the impact, some companies have begun to pass along cost increases. Goodyear Tire and Rubber, the world's largest tire manufacturer, said early last month that it would raise prices this year because it is paying more for materials like rubber and oil.
The Commerce Department said spending on construction of houses, town houses and apartments rose 2.5 percent in January after a 1.3 percent increase the month before. "This underscores the risk that higher interest rates are not generating the needed response from the economy's most interest-rate sensitive sector -- housing," said Hai Hoang, an economist at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco.
Nonresidential commercial projects rose 3.2 percent, the biggest rise since a 3.9 percent increase in June 1998. Spending on publicly financed construction rose 3.2 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Supply Is Low As Gas and Oil Prices Increase

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
THE price of crude oil jumped 4 percent yesterday, to more than $31 a barrel, and gasoline prices leaped 6 percent. What is more, inventories of both are so low that a moderate increase in output from major crude oil producers would provide only a little price relief.
If crude oil prices stay over $30 a barrel, the Clinton administration might finally pump some out of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, as members of Congress are urging. Though that would not bring immediate relief for drivers, who are paying 53 percent more at the gasoline pump than they were last year, it might send an unmistakable signal to major oil producers that they have strained the patience of the United States. 
 Energy Secretary Bill Richardson opposed such a move yesterday, saying at a Congressional hearing that it would be unwise to tap the petroleum reserve while major oil producers were still discussing production increases ahead of a March 27 meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Still, he warned that the world is consuming about two million barrels more a day than it is producing. "We cannot sustain this imbalance between supply and demand without risking serious repercussions for the world economy," he said.
Two wisps of bad news about petroleum supplies helped push up prices yesterday. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for April delivery rose $1.34, to $31.77 a barrel, while the April gasoline futures contract jumped 5.80 cents, to 99.38 cents a gallon. It was the highest price for crude oil since January 1991, at the time of the Persian Gulf war, and the highest for gasoline futures since October 1990.
The first problem came in the form of fresh reports from the American Petroleum Institute and the government's Energy Information Administration that showed declines in gasoline inventories, which are now down 15 percent in the last year by the petroleum institute's estimate. The institute also reported that crude inventories had fallen, while the energy administration's report showed a slight increase. But both reports show crude inventories down 12 percent to 13 percent from a year earlier.
The second piece of bad news was a denial of reports that Venezuela and Saudi Arabia, two leading producers in OPEC, had agreed with Mexico, a major producer not in OPEC, to raise crude oil output.
Early in the day, several news services reported that the three countries had agreed to propose a production increase effective April 1. The amount of the increase ranged from 1 million to 1.4 million barrels a day in the reports. But later in the day, a Venezuelan oil official said there was no such agreement.
Such talk of increases in crude oil production has come and gone for weeks. In fact, the Mexican energy minister issued a statement yesterday saying that Mexico and Norway, another non-OPEC producer, thought that a production increase should be discussed. He gave no indication of the size of any increase.
But analysts and government officials say they expect major producers to start pumping more oil soon. Mr. Richardson, who has just returned from lobbying for more oil in Kuwait, Mexico, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, said, "I believe the odds are good for production increases to take place."
Michael Rothman, the senior energy analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that he also expected an increase but that OPEC ministers "will keep their cards close to their vests to the last moment" before their meeting on March 27.
Despite these expectations of increased production, crude oil and gasoline prices are moving higher. That is because a million or so more barrels a day will not be enough to rebuild global inventories to a comfortable level. At the end of last year, Mr. Rothman said, inventories of crude oil and products for the 29 countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development had fallen to 2.53 billion barrels, a level that he said was 99 million barrels below normal.
Oil production would have to increase more than 10 percent to ease the price pressure, he said. That would mean an increase in daily production of crude oil of 1.7 million barrels, effective in April, followed by an increase of 1.5 million barrels after OPEC oil ministers meet again in September.
Oil traders, Mr. Rothman said, "see the impending squeeze that is already there."
The euro did something unusual yesterday. It rallied against the dollar, rising to 97.48 cents from 96.55 cents on Tuesday.
But it is not clear if the euro has reached the bottom of a 14-month month slide that has erased 16.4 percent of its value. And it is getting harder and harder to explain.
Nicholas P. Sargen, the global market strategist for private clients of J. P. Morgan, says one would have expected the euro to rally this year. After all, European economies are finally turning around, and their stock markets are outperforming the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
He suspects that one reason for the decline is that the 11 nations behind the euro, which was introduced in January 1999, have no one person to speak for the currency. Usually, a country's finance minister does the job. But 11 finance ministers cannot speak together, and they often contradict each other.
So, traders have been looking to Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, as the substitute. Mr. Duisenberg, who has also sent some mixed signals, could show that someone cared about the beleaguered euro, Mr. Sargen says. How? The central bank could raise its interest rate target at its meeting today.

HEADLINE: Despite Criticism, Giuliani Pursues Ballparks as Economic Catalysts

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
In Coney Island, the steel skeleton of the Parachute Jump stands like a 250-foot-tall grave marker to bygone glory. On Staten Island, a muddy parking lot sits at the water's edge next to the dilapidated St. George ferry terminal.
In each place, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to build a publicly financed minor league baseball stadium: a $31 million ballpark in Brooklyn for the Mets and a $71 million complex on Staten Island for the Yankees. 
 With a combined 72-game home schedule each season, the mayor says, the stadiums would revive these faded or rundown neighborhoods with relatively inexpensive family entertainment and draw newcomers to the area.
The two stadiums would stand as the Giuliani administration's most visible effort to generate economic development in the boroughs outside Manhattan.
Yesterday, even as city officials continued to negotiate the terms of a lease with the Mets, the City Planning Commission approved zoning changes for the Coney Island stadium, on a grassy field bound by Surf Avenue and the Coney Island Boardwalk, between West 16th and West 20th Streets. The proposal will now go to the City Council for a final vote.
The Staten Island proposal already has Council approval. Both projects, however, have provoked criticism from economists and urban planners who reject the notion that the sports teams would spawn new business, especially ones that play fewer than 40 games each during a three-month season, and in the case of the Mets, battle with community groups.
Economists said that the mayor's $112 million initiative, which includes spending more than $10 million on temporary ballparks to house the teams, was expensive and unlikely to produce new private investments in Coney Island or on Staten Island.
The city, they said, would be far better off creating back-office space on the waterfront in Brooklyn and Queens to stem the loss of companies to Jersey City, or industrial parks for technology companies at the old Navy base on Staten Island or on Governors Island.
"Baseball stadiums don't really have much of an economic impact," said Ronnie Lowenstein, chief economist for the city's Independent Budget Office. "Some restaurants or retail stores may shift around, but they generally don't lead to the creation of new hotels, office towers or what any of us would think of as economic development."
But the Giuliani administration contends that a Coney Island stadium, like the one on Staten Island, could be a boon to the community, both as a magnet for new visitors and projects and as a resource for high school and college baseball teams, concerts and fairs.
Coney Island could again be a recreational mecca, city officials said, much as it was in the 1940's, before it succumbed to urban redevelopment and competition from Jones Beach. "Coney Island is an underutilized asset that greatly needs a shot in the arm," said Michael G. Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "The stadium could serve as a catalyst for further economic development along the Boardwalk. It could be the precursor to a lot of private development."
The minor league stadium initiative sprang not from the mayor's economic advisers, from a public cry for more baseball or from demands by the teams themselves.
"It's an initiative the mayor seized upon," Mr. Carey said. "The mayor sees it as a way to extend the benefits of baseball to Coney Island. The Mets see it as an opportunity to expand their fan base."
Cities and towns eager to capture a professional sports team almost always grant generous terms, but most economists contend that the sports deals generally provide a meager return for such a large subsidy from taxpayers in a project that will have limited use.
In New York, Mayor Giuliani has proposed building new stadiums for the Yankees, the Mets and possibly the Jets football team, as well as the minor league stadiums.
The minor league stadium for the Mets still faces a potential lawsuit from residents who live next to St. John's University in Queens, where the city wants to build a temporary ballpark, and opposition in Coney Island, where some residents fear that the mayor's proposed stadium would displace a long-planned amateur sports complex.
In recent days, the administration has worked on a compromise that it hopes will sidestep opposition from the Brooklyn borough president, Howard Golden.
Under the terms of a tentative deal with the Mets, which does not require City Council approval, the Mets would pay a modest rent and control the 6,500 seat stadium year-round. The city would have the right to hold at least 20 public events at the stadium, but the Mets, like the Staten Island Yankees, would get all the ticket and parking revenue, half the advertising revenue and 70 percent of the revenue from events booked into the stadium during the nine months of the year the team would not play there. The two sides are negotiating the split on concessions.
The city has said that non-baseball events would also attract new visitors and generate tax revenue and new businesses on Surf Avenue, where flea markets, the Cyclone roller coaster and a dwindling number of other rides are all that remain of the once-bustling amusement district.
"This will be an asset the city, and the Mets will seek to generate as much activity as possible," Mr. Carey said.
Minor league ballparks have drawn new fans because of their small, intimate settings and the ability of young fans to talk to players between innings. According to the city's environmental impact statement, the Mets' ball club would draw a total of 210,000 fans to 38 games, an ambitious goal that would establish the club as the most popular of the 40 teams in the short-season Class A league. (Last year, the Staten Island Yankees drew 120,954 playing at the College of Staten Island.)
The team would pay $350,000 in rent and create the equivalent of 57 full-time jobs.
The city estimates that each fan would spend about $18.71, including the price of admission, at a game, and less than half that outside the stadium. Most fans, however, would come from among the half-million people who already head to the Coney Island beach on summer weekends.
"The incremental impact is probably so small it doesn't make any difference," said Robert A. Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College in Illinois who is an expert in sports franchises. "We're talking about a neighborhood team. I doubt very much that with all the entertainment options in New York, you'll see people traveling from other boroughs to see a minor league team.
"Rather than utilizing fewer facilities more often, you're building more facilities and using them less often. It's the opposite of sound economics."
In what is the city's best deal with professional sports, the United States Tennis Association built a $234 million stadium and 15 new tennis courts, albeit with $150 million in tax-exempt bonds, at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.
The complex, which is open to the public 300 days a year, paid $6.4 million in rent and fees to city over 10 years ending in 1998, the last year for which figures are available. But at Yankee Stadium, the team controls the ballpark, where the city did a $120 million renovation in the 1970's, and paid a net rent of $5.4 million in the same period, under a lease that allows the team to deduct maintenance costs from the rent.
There is little question that the waterfront in Coney Island could use Mr. Carey's shot in the arm. And Mayor Giuliani has gone to great lengths to put a minor league club there. First he had to forge a peace treaty between the Yankees and the Mets, so that neither side used its territorial rights against the other, as when the Yankees prevented the Mets from putting a team on Long Island.
Despite a $71 million price tag, the plan to build the most expensive minor league stadium in the country on Staten Island provoked little public opposition. But the Coney Island plan collided with a 15-year effort to build an amateur sports complex on the same site, the former Steeplechase amusement park.
The local community board and Mr. Golden, the borough president, complained that Brooklyn deserved both the sports complex and a higher-caliber minor league team, which would play more games and have a greater economic impact. Mr. Golden, who has questioned the mayor's decision to deal exclusively with the Mets and the Yankees, said that two independent minor leagues, which play more than 70 home games a season, have expressed interest in Brooklyn.
"The mayor's proposal not only jeopardizes the sportsplex," Mr. Golden said, "but it doesn't provide the greatest economic benefit for Brooklyn and the city."
But in the tangled web of Brooklyn politics, Janis Leibowitz, co-chairwoman of a Coney Island civic group, said her organization favored the stadium, whose use would be consistent with the seasonal nature of Coney Island amusements, over the complex, which, she said, would draw too many people to the area.
Mr. Golden blocked the Giuliani administration from building a temporary ballpark for the Mets at the parade grounds near Prospect Park, even after the mayor promised to spend $12 million cleaning up the site.
In January, the administration abruptly switched to St. John's University in Queens, where it plans to build a temporary ballpark on school land. But now, the residents of Jamaica Estates are preparing their own legal challenge.
In recent weeks, the Giuliani administration has quietly negotiated with members of the City Council on a Coney Island compromise that could leave Mr. Golden out in the cold. According to people involved in the talks, city officials said that the administration might back the sports complex if the foundation sponsoring the project removed its chairman, Peter J. Kiernan, who had been critical of the Giuliani effort. With no fanfare, Mr. Kiernan, who did not return telephone calls requesting comment, stepped down on Feb. 15.
Rather than Mr. Golden, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, and Herbert E. Berman, who heads the Brooklyn Council delegation, would be able to take credit for a modified complex if they were able to strike a deal with the Giuliani administration.
Still, the cost of Mr. Giuliani's plan to build two minor league stadiums has tripled since his original $40 million estimate.
"As a Dodger fan in the 1950's, I love the thought of baseball returning to Brooklyn," said Mark Green, the city's public advocate. "But the city can't offer a blank check when we are faced with crumbling schools and increasing budget shortfalls."

HEADLINE: Jobs Data for 1999 Paint a Rosier Picture for Upstate New York

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
Upstate New York, where the economy remained bleak even as an economic boom swept the rest of the nation, suddenly spurted ahead of much of the country in terms of job creation, according to new data for 1999 released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor.
And because job growth in and around New York City continued at a white-hot pace last year, employment in New York State as a whole grew faster than the national average for the first time since 1983, state officials said yesterday. 
 The number of private-sector jobs upstate grew by 2.5 percent last year, while downstate -- in the city, Long Island and the northern suburbs -- private-sector employment jumped 3.2 percent. Nationally, jobs grew by 2.3 percent.
New York State added almost 200,000 jobs last year, and is now ranked seventh in terms of employment growth, behind Sun Belt states like Nevada and Florida, but ahead of Texas, state officials said.
Those rankings are subject to change, economists cautioned, as other states revise their 1999 economic figures to take account of new data. It was just such a revision that pushed New York's numbers up so sharply; in January, state data suggested that employment in New York was still growing more slowly than the national average.
The new jobs numbers could change the political climate in the state, because the woes of the upstate economy have already become an issue in the race for the United States Senate.
Just last month, Hillary Rodham Clinton said, "If upstate New York State were an independent state, it would consistently rank in the bottom fifth of job growth." In 1998, the number of jobs upstate grew by just 1.7 percent, while nationally jobs grew by 2.8 percent.
Using the new 1999 data, upstate would rank about 13th, said Stephen Kagann, chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki. At a news conference yesterday, the governor called the new data "clear proof that this state is back."
The huge divide between upstate and downstate may also be closing, at least economically. While New York City's job creation and its suburbs continued at rates not seen since the 1950's, the city's growth was outpaced last year by much of the Hudson Valley and by Utica. The number of jobs increased in every major metropolitan area, and the only city reporting slower growth than in 1998 was Elmira.
"There used to be a big dichotomy, but there's more of a convergence now," said Jason Bramm, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Exactly why or how the upstate economy has improved remains unclear, although Governor Pataki suggested that his administration's tax cuts and regulatory reductions had played an important role.
Manufacturing, which is extremely important to cities like Buffalo and Rochester, continued to decline last year, cutting almost 19,000 jobs statewide, or 2.1 percent. But service businesses, whose employees range from computer technicians to security guards, added 124,000 positions, an increase of 4.4 percent. And construction has been particularly strong, Mr. Kagann said.
Despite the huge revision -- the department of labor has increased the job count for last year by about 60,000 from its preliminary number, released in January -- economists generally consider jobs data to be fairly reliable. Information is collected from 18,000 companies around the state, and later replaced with complete figures culled from records for the unemployment insurance tax.
The biggest revisions were in upstate cities like Buffalo, Rochester and Albany, Mr. Bramm said. "Has upstate suddenly staged a rebound? No," he said. "We suddenly realized upstate has staged a rebound."
Economists are less confident in unemployment figures, which are based on a far smaller survey and cannot be crosschecked against tax records. In recent years, the unemployment data have not tracked the job creation figures, either nationally or in New York.
For example, despite the big increase in new jobs last year, unemployment upstate has not budged from the 4.1 percent level, adjusted for seasonal factors, reported in January of 1999. In New York City, by contrast, the unemployment rate has fallen to 6.1 percent from 7.4 percent during the last 12 months.
Nationally, unemployment averaged 4.0 percent in January, down slightly from 4.3 percent a year ago. In New Jersey, the unemployment rate in January fell to 3.9 percent, from a revised 4.6 percent in January 1999.
