HEADLINE: HOUSE BACKS END TO EARNINGS LIMIT ON SOCIAL SECURITY

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The House voted 422 to 0 today to allow most Social Security recipients for the first time to earn as much money as they want without sacrificing any of their retirement benefits, repealing a Depression-era policy intended to discourage older people from holding jobs so younger workers would have a chance.
The unanimous vote was a rare display of bipartisanship, and reflected a consensus that the earnings limits placed on Social Security recipients had long since become counterproductive. 
 The Senate, where there is broad support for the change, plans to take up a similar measure soon. President Clinton has said he would sign the legislation, which would not have any long-term effect on the financial health of the Social Security program. Under current law, people 65 through 69 years old lose $1 of their Social Security benefits for every $3 they earn above $17,000. A 67-year-old man who earned $20,000 last year, for example, would have lost $1,000 of his Social Security retirement benefits.
The earnings limit, which does not apply to people 70 and oldler, is already scheduled to rise to $30,000 in 2002, but the legislation passed today by the House would eliminate the limit altogether.
If enacted under the terms of the House bill, the change would apply retroactively to earnings since the beginning of this year.
About 800,000 people 65 or older lost some or all of their benefits last year because they earned more than the limit, according to the Social Security Administration.
Those people would benefit immediately from the change, and other people might decide to remain in or re-enter the work force because of the opportunity to hold a job without sacrificing any of their benefits. But the real significance of the shift might emerge only over the next few decades as the 76 million baby boomers grow older, creating a vast new pool of retirement-age people more willing and able than previous generations to continue working.
Republicans have long sought repeal of the earnings limit, saying it amounts to a tax. They were blocked for decades by Democrats, who at various times have cited objections from labor unions, the costs and the fact that relatively well-off people would be the biggest winners.
But opposition from Democrats has melted away over the years as the population has aged and the economy has grown healthier. The two parties agreed in 1996 to raise the earnings limit, and Mr. Clinton called last year for the limit to be repealed.
The bill's sponsors said repealing the earnings limit would benefit the entire economy right away by removing a disincentive to work at a time when the unemployment rate, at 4 percent, is so low that employers are having trouble filling all the jobs they are creating.
They said the change also reflected increases in life expectancy and the fact that more and more people 65 and older continue to work at least part time by choice or necessity. But they said the main justification for the change was simple fairness, calling it unconscionable for the government to deny workers benefits they had earned over their careers because they chose to work.
"Why in the world would we want to discourage any American -- whether they're 17 or 67 -- from working?" said Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. "Americans are living longer now," Mr. Archer said. "Older Americans can work, they want to work and they shouldn't be punished by an outdated law if they choose to work."
Researchers have found evidence that raising or eliminating the earnings limit will bring more people into the work force and lead older people who already have jobs to work more. But there is disagreement over how much of an effect any change has, with some economists saying repeal could create a huge new pool of available labor and others saying the effects would be negligible.
"There is only a limited amount of evidence on the overall effect" on the labor supply from repealing the limit, Kenneth S. Apfel, the Social Security commissioner, told Congress last month. But, Mr. Apfel said, it was plausible that eliminating the limit would "lead to a modest increase in work activity."
Even as they voted for the bill, some Democrats said they were troubled by the fact that it would help relatively high-earning people while doing nothing for retirees who subsist entirely on their Social Security benefits. And some members of both parties said they hoped that today's action would not be a substitute for addressing the long-range financial problems of the retirement system.
The provisions that the bill would repeal are more complex than today's debate on the House floor would suggest.
While Social Security recipients lose some of their benefits in years in which they earn more than the limit, they get some or all of the reduction back after age 70, when their benefits are readjusted to reflect their decision to continue working.
Moreover, the change would not apply to people who take early retirement benefits from Social Security, which they can do at 62 at a reduced rate. These people, 62 through 64, would continue to be subject to a strict earnings limit, losing $1 in benefits for every $2 in earnings above $10,080 a year. About 230,000 people in that age category lost all or part of their benefits last year because earnings exceeded the limit.
Both parties agreed to leave the earnings limit in place for early retirees -- effectively encouraging people not to take Social Security before 65 -- because research has shown that people who take a reduced Social Security benefits at age 62 are more likely to end up in poverty than those who work to full retirement age. The problem strikes particularly hard at widows of men who retired early and who rely on their late husbands' benefits.
Some members of both parties acknowledged that they found it uncomfortable to be enacting what amounted to an election-year benefits increase in Social Security for some people at the same time that Congress and the Clinton administration are deadlocked over how to assure the retirement system's long-term solvency. Without any changes, Social Security is projected to run short of money to pay benefits starting in 2033.
Under an earlier set of changes made in the 1980's to help bolster Social Security's financial condition, the age at which workers can claim full retirement benefits is already increasing gradually over the next few decades to 67. Many of the proposals to put Social Security on sounder footing call for further increases in the retirement age.
Repeal of the earnings limit would cost Social Security $22.7 billion in additional benefit payments over the next decade. But it would not have an effect on the retirement system's financial condition over the long run.That is because the benefits increases would eventually be offset by a reduction in the deferred benefits that would have been paid to workers starting at age 70 to make up for the reductions in benefits paid from age 65 through 69.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
PepsiCo calls on J. Walter Thompson to develop a $10 million campaign for its bottled water.

BYLINE: By Constance L. Hays

 BODY:
WITH bottled water -- no color, no flavor, no image to speak of -- turning out to be one of its star performers, growing far faster than colas and other carbonated soft drinks, PepsiCo plans to spend millions of dollars to promote its Aquafina brand in the coming year.
Signaling the next stage of the bottled water wars, Pepsi chose the J. Walter Thompson agency, a part of the WPP Group, to develop a campaign, expected to include television and print ads and a new tag line, for Aquafina, which Pepsi began selling nationwide a little more than two years ago. The size of the campaign, estimated at $10 million and announced in December, shows how rapidly bottled water has gained the respect of Pepsi executives and how big the expectations are for Aquafina's expansion. 
 "Having been in the lucky position of being the No. 1 water, we are trying to lead the movement back toward branding and fewer, bigger brands dominating the business," said Dawn Hudson, Pepsi's senior vice president for strategy and marketing, noting that marketing budgets for most water brands have been $2 million or less, until now. "It will go from being a commodity business to a branded business."
In the fourth quarter of last year, sales of Aquafina rose 75 percent, compared with declining sales of Pepsi-Cola and a lower double-digit growth rate for Mountain Dew. That was accomplished with next to no marketing, compared with the millions spent on advertising the soft-drink brands. In a conference call with analysts last month, Roger A. Enrico, PepsiCo's chairman, said the company wanted to increase supermarket sales, adding to its success in vending machines and convenience stores, where people tend to buy just a bottle at a time.
"We're just now in the process of getting the creative concepts together," a Pepsi spokesman, Larry Jabbonsky, said of the ads, which are expected to be on the air by summertime -- prime water-selling season. "They will focus on Aquafina's purity and its approachability, with a humorous edge."
These won't be the first ads for Aquafina. Pepsi briefly broadcast a television spot last year that showed a well-sculptured runner, implicitly an imported-water drinker, who comes to an untimely end against the side of a truck. Meanwhile, two "regular guys" are shown drinking Aquafina. It was supposed to underscore the generic appeal of the brand. The Aquafina tag line, "Take me to the water," is likely to be replaced, Mr. Jabbonsky added.
Across the United States, which only recently embraced bottled water as an alternative to soda, sales of the nonsparkling variety have soared, from 750 million gallons in 1997 to more than 1.2 billion gallons last year. The annual growth rate over the last five years has been about 30 percent. "Even the very strong 1990's U.S. stock market performance pales in comparison," said Michael Bellas, chief executive of Beverage Marketing, a firm that tracks beverage sales. He called bottled water in containers of 1.5 liters or less "the star category of not only the bottled water industry, but also the entire beverage industry."
Water has been good for Pepsi. Aquafina is now the top-selling brand in the small-bottle category, although it accounts for only about 80 million cases a year, compared with about 1.4 billion for Pepsi-Cola. The company makes money from each sale through royalties paid by its bottlers. Using its existing distribution network, Pepsi shipped Aquafina to the thousands of convenience stores and gas stations where it already delivered other Pepsi products, and its sales spiraled upward.
Coca-Cola noticed the trend, too, and put its own bottled water, Dasani, on the market last spring. The structure is different, however; Coke sells packets of mineral additives, which are added to the water, to its bottlers. But like Pepsi, Coke gets most of its raw material from municipal water sources, not any fancy-sounding natural spring. Between their distribution systems and their choice of sources, both Coke and Pepsi are likely to have the biggest-selling national water brands within the next year or so, analysts say.
A Coke spokesman said the company planned a print campaign for Dasani this year, emphasizing relaxation and gardening. The ads will appear in women's magazines.
Meanwhile, consolidation and other changes are shaking up the bottled water market. In January, Groupe Danone, which owns the Evian and Dannon brands, announced it was buying the San Francisco-based McKesson Water Products Company, makers of Sparkletts, Alhambra and other brands, for $1.1 billion. Naya Inc., which has a popular water that was distributed for years by Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coke's chief United States bottler, declared bankruptcy in December, although it continues to sell its product. The company's problems were largely caused by a drop in sales that came when it lost its Coca-Cola Enterprises distribution a few months before Coke rolled out Dasani.
"We think the top four or five companies are going to control 80 percent of the market," Mr. Bellas said. "It's changing now to the marketing wars."
Ms. Hudson said Pepsi's efforts would go beyond the ad campaign. "It's not just about advertising," she said. "It's presence marketing, getting into more locations, having more types of packages available, being part of more sports events." She called water "the ultimate thirst quencher" and said Pepsi's goal was "to sustain the momentum of the brand as the No. 1 brand."
Back in 1994, when Pepsi put an initial toe into the market by testing Aquafina in Wichita, Kan., it was considered a risky move. After all, what's the point of offering consumers water if you can get them to drink higher-margin Pepsi or Mountain Dew? And to make matters worse, Pepsi practically bragged about the fact that Aquafina came not from an exotic-sounding mountain spring but was simply tap water, cleaned up in a bottling plant. Where was the appeal?
It turns out American consumers don't really care about the source. And if bottlers don't have a Coke or Pepsi brand to sell, they will find some other brand to meet the demand for water. "What Pepsi taught the industry was that coming from a spring was not a requirement," said Jennifer Solomon, a beverage analyst for Salomon Smith Barney. "It was a big gamble, and it paid off."
It's not clear whether bottled water is capturing market share that once belonged to sodas or whether it is displacing tap water that people used to drink. Either way, "Coke and Pepsi's entry into this business is going to have a profound impact," said John D. Sicher, editor of Beverage Digest, an industry newsletter. "In the years to come, a lot of the smaller regional spring waters will have a more difficult time competing, even regionally, with the big brands. The big ones will be marketed more heavily, and consumers will demand them, and they will take up more and more shelf space."
But there may be one niche market that the biggest players are overlooking, said Scott Wilkins, a beverage analyst for Deutsche Bank. "If you buy into this health-conscious movement, which is pretty well documented, there will be a market for nonpurified, spring-based water that neither Coke nor Pepsi is addressing," he said. "Maybe the economics don't work for them to buy a source, but Perrier and Danone are doing it all over the world."

HEADLINE: HEAVY POSTURING SEEN IN I.M.F. RIFT

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
When President Clinton pledged this week to block a German finance ministry official from assuming the top post at the International Monetary Fund, in effect vetoing the man the European Union had chosen for the job, he seemed to risk a diplomatic confrontation across the Atlantic.
What really happened, Clinton administration and some European officials now say, is that the president agreed to play the heavy because both American and European diplomats had trouble communicating across the Rhine. 
 For four months Germany aggressively promoted the official, Caio Koch-Weser, to take over at the I.M.F., ending with formal endorsement by the 15-nation European Union. But during that time, officials from the United States, Britain, Italy and France had regular conversations in which they agreed broadly on two things: The next head of the I.M.F. should be a European, and that the European should not be Mr. Koch-Weser, several Clinton administration officials and European diplomats said.
Both American and European officials said that Mr. Koch-Weser, a genial 55-year-old state secretary in Germany's finance ministry, lacked the gravitas and financial expertise to lead the I.M.F. at a time when it was arguably more powerful than ever before. The problem for fellow Europeans, and later for Americans, was that Germany ignored some early signs of unease with Mr. Koch-Weser and started the nation's most aggressive diplomatic campaign in years to install him as head of the monetary fund.
"By choosing to peddle politeness as openness," said a senior administration official, "they backed us into a corner."
That description of events serves United States interests, of course, by cloaking an unusual and potentially explosive decision in the garb of a broader diplomatic imperative. It also contradicts public statements that European ministers have made in recent days, including several comments chastising Washington for its hubris.
But European officials confirmed in interviews that they supported Mr. Koch-Weser mainly to preserve European unity in the face of an unyielding German campaign rather than because they agreed he should head the I.M.F., a post held by a European since the institution was created just after World War II.
Moreover, even as they publicly rallied behind Mr. Koch-Weser, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France and Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema of Italy have been calling each other to discuss new candidates for the job, diplomats told about the conversations said.
"The tradition in Europe is solidarity on decisions of this kind," one European diplomat said. "But there is also an understanding of the position of the United States. There is certainly no crisis."
Though the world often has a hard time selecting leaders for the main international institutions -- successions at the United Nations and the World Trade Organization have been contentious as well -- the search for a head of the monetary fund shows how diplomatically delicate, and deeply flawed, the search process has become, administration officials and outside experts say.
If there is a single lesson from the search, it is that the current process, whereby interested countries nominate their own citizens for crucial posts and then use their diplomatic influence to support them, needs fixing.
The United States rejection of Mr. Koch-Weser -- and its decision at this stage not to back anyone else -- means that when the monetary fund conducts an informal vote on Thursday, there will almost certainly be no winner. Aside from Mr. Koch-Weser, there are two other candidates. Stanley Fischer, the American who serves as the I.M.F. deputy managing director, was nominated by a group of 20 African and Arab countries. Japan has nominated Eisuke Sakakibara, a former finance ministry official.
What happens after that is uncertain. Clinton administration officials and European officials say that they hope German officials will realize after the straw poll, if they have not already, that the nomination of Mr. Koch-Weser was a mistake. That would clear the way for other possible European candidates, including the British and Italian finance ministers and the head of the Bank for International Settlements, who are more likely to generate broad support, according to American and European officials.
The search for a new I.M.F. leader began last October, when it became clear to top financial officials that Michel Camdessus of France, who led the monetary fund for 13 years, planned to retire two years before the end of his term. The post immediately attracted several potential European candidates. But the strongest push came from Germany, which had made clear its intention of taking a larger role in international institutions and felt that the French, who have named most I.M.F. directors, should not claim this one.
The Germans immediately put forward Mr. Koch-Weser. On paper, at least, he had the perfect resume. An economist who worked for a quarter-century at the World Bank, Mr. Koch-Weser had extensive contacts in financial circles around the world, spoke six languages and was perhaps the most cosmopolitan of Germany's financial bureaucrats. Mr. Koch-Weser also had good political ties at home, people who worked with him said. He left the World Bank in Washington, where he had risen to managing director, one of the five most senior posts, to return to Germany soon after the election of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder. The new chancellor named him state secretary at the finance ministry, the No. 2 position.
But Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers made clear from the start, including in conversations with Mr. Koch-Weser during meetings in Europe and Tokyo, that he did not favor the German's bid. The two had known each other when both were working at the World Bank in the early 1990's. Mr. Summers's main concern was that Mr. Koch-Weser was a specialist in poverty relief and had no expertise in finance. Moreover, the German was seen as a go-along-get-along type, who thrived at the World Bank by working well with the bureaucracy, not by leading it, administration officials said.
Initially, Mr. Koch-Weser's candidacy did not ring alarm bells at the Treasury Department. Administration officials said the European reaction to Mr. Koch-Weser was even cooler than their own. He was given low odds.
The United States was drawn directly into the European fray by Mr. Schroder himself. Early last month, he called Mr. Clinton and lobbied him directly. Mr. Clinton used diplomatic language to convey to Mr. Schroder that Mr. Koch-Weser had not demonstrated that he had broad support. Yet, in part because administration officials still believed Mr. Koch-Weser's chances of getting European backing were slim, Mr. Clinton assured Mr. Schroder that the United States had no objections to a German candidate per se.
Germany began promoting Mr. Clinton's friendly words as a tacit endorsement, administration officials said. Mr. Schroder promptly flew to Paris to meet with President Jacques Chirac and Mr. Jospin. The French, who had been the only Europeans publicly to challenge Mr. Koch-Weser's qualifications, were told that Mr. Clinton had no objection to Mr. Koch-Weser provided he became the unified European choice, according to people told about Mr. Schroder's conversation with the French.
As the campaign gathered steam, Clinton administration officials began fretting that they had been too passive early on. Mr. Summers; Gene Sperling, the president's national economic adviser; Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser; and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had a series of phone calls to debate strategy. Sensing a confrontation with Germany might be inevitable, Mr. Berger and Mr. Sperling began doing their own research on Mr. Koch-Weser. If they were going to risk German ire, they wanted to be certain that Treasury's opinion of Mr. Koch-Weser was right, officials said. Both Mr. Sperling and Mr. Berger ended up agreeing with the Treasury view, administration officials said.
Mr. Berger was the most reluctant of Mr. Clinton's top advisers to risk a diplomatic split with Germany, administration officials said. But as the European Union endorsement became inevitable last week, he agreed that it was better to try to stop the candidacy now than to stay silent and possibly set off a bigger, public confrontation later.
This time, President Clinton initiated a call to Mr. Schroder. The message was unmistakable: The United States wants a European for the job, but not Mr. Koch-Weser.

HEADLINE: Money Laundering Prompts U.S. Drive For a Tougher Law

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Clinton administration plans to ask Congress for sweeping new powers to combat money laundering including the authority to ban financial transactions between United States banks or brokerage houses and off-shore financial centers, administration officials said today.
The request is the centerpiece of administration efforts to tighten money-laundering laws after the Bank of New York was found to have served as a conduit for about $7 billion in Russian money, some of which investigators believe was derived from illegal activities. The administration has also been searching for ways to make it harder for drug traffickers to funnel their profits through American banks. 
 Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers plans to announce proposed legislation in a speech to bankers on Thursday, officials said. The legislation would give his department a broad range of powers to investigate and in serious cases forbid transactions between American financial institutions and individual foreign banks or entire foreign countries.
Administration officials say that current laws do not provide enough authority to fight money laundering, the practice of filtering profits from illegal activities through banks to disguise their origin. Short of having Congress declare emergency sanctions against countries deemed to be a national security threat, the officials said, they are mostly confined to waving a finger at nations that tolerate money laundering and urging American banks to be wary of doing business with such places.
"The issue of money laundering is so prominent and public that it can't be ignored anymore," a senior official said. "We need to be able to target the root problems without unnecessarily hindering legitimate economic activity."
The effort to seek new powers is clearly a response to Russia, where financial mismanagement has been a problem for the Clinton administration and the International Monetary Fund. Some analysts and members of Congress have complained that widespread corruption in that country -- helped in part by the ease of transferring funds abroad -- undermined multibillion-dollar foreign aid programs and left one of the administration's top foreign policy priorities a shambles.
The proposed legislation also appears to be an attempt to broker a compromise between Congressional proposals and private financial companies. Both the House and the Senate are weighing bills that would impose draconian restrictions on foreign banks that hide money and, in some cases, new enforcement duties on domestic banks and brokerage houses. Financial companies have complained that such laws threaten to make them uncompetitive against foreign rivals.
Members of Congress had a mixed response to the Treasury's proposal after briefings by Clinton administrations officials today. Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and chairman of the House Banking Committee, said the Treasury proposals were exactly what he had been seeking. He said he would introduce the bill as his own when it is sent to Congress next week.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York and a member of the Senate's banking committee, was less enthusiastic. He said the Treasury proposals were a watered-down version of legislation he has introduced that would mandate the isolation of foreign banks that make hiding money their forte.
"When you leave this up to their discretion, diplomacy will prevail over cutting off money laundering," Mr. Schumer said. "The Treasury seems to be taking a step in the right direction. But we are going to toughen it up."
The new legislation would give the Treasury Department the right to take any number of steps, along a progressive scale, to fight laundering. On the light end of the spectrum, the department wants the power to ask American companies to collect data on all kinds of transactions with an off-shore bank or financial company. That would help law enforcement officials track suspicious activity, and would also make American banks wary of doing business with such places, officials said.
In cases where foreign governments stubbornly shield their banks from prying eyes and act as havens for criminal funds, the department wants the power to simply cut them off from the American financial system, without seeking Congressional approval for such action each time.
Although that would not necessarily force those nations to tighten enforcement, the loss of access to the American market would cripple any legitimate banking activity there and make it a much less attractive destination for criminal elements as well, the officials said. Moreover, officials hope that the United States action in such cases will serve as a model for other developed countries, putting further pressure on the laundering haven.
Ever since the act of money laundering first became a crime, in 1986, Treasury officials have often been sympathetic to private sector concerns that the old way of fighting money laundering -- putting a burden on banks and brokerage houses to police their clients -- might simply drive banking business to nations that do not demand as much. But the rise of multilateral efforts to counter illicit flows of money through the international banking system in recent years has made it possible to tighten restrictions at home without driving too much legitimate banking activity abroad, officials said.
Treasury officials already have sought to step up antilaundering activities through the one tool they now have in their arsenal: moral suasion, or as the Treasury calls it, name and blame. When a foreign bank or nation repeatedly refuses to abide by generally accepted standards to make sure they are not being used by criminals to launder money, Treasury has made that known to domestic banks, usually through advisories. Those put the banks on notice that they should be wary of money that flows into their coffers from such sources. The advisories do not have the force of law.
Legislation before Congress would add processing the proceeds of official corruption to the list of foreign crimes that fall under the money-laundering statute. American financial institutions are now barred from handling the proceeds from a narrow group of offenses committed abroad, including drug trafficking, kidnapping and bank fraud.
An advance copy of a speech Mr. Summers prepared for delivery on Thursday identifies several countries that have served as either sources of illicit money or havens for bank secrecy and laundering.
Russia, Colombia, and Nigeria, he says, are among the biggest sources of such funds. The islands of Dominica, Nauru and Antigua are among the biggest destination spots, with laws that make it possible or actively encourage criminals to do business there.
Administration officials said they believed that such moral suasion works. Antigua, Nauru, Russia and Colombia are all working with the United States to toughen their laws, Mr. Summers says in his address. After Clinton administration officials raised public concerns about Nauru earlier this year, citing its role as a chief haven for Russian money laundering, some American banks decided on their own to stop doing financial-correspondent business with banks chartered in that country.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE EVALUATION;
For McCain, It Was Black Tuesday

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Va., March 1

 BODY:
Before Washington State's votes rolled in late Tuesday, aides to Senator John McCain tried to minimize Gov. George W. Bush's victory in Virginia, which had reported earlier.
The only place Mr. Bush had shown any strength, McCain aides said, was in the most conservative section of the country, the South, with victories in South Carolina 10 days earlier and now Virginia. Mr. McCain himself chimed in, "Seems as if he has a Southern strategy here." 
 But in fact Mr. McCain was comprehensively beaten on Tuesday: in a big Southern state with one foot in the mid-Atlantic region, Virginia; in a small, isolated Midwestern state whose economy is based on agriculture, North Dakota, and in a Northwestern state with a progressive tradition, Washington.
It was by some margin the biggest wipeout of the Republican presidential campaign, and it came just one week before 13 states hold Republican primaries and caucuses in what may prove to be the decisive moment of the fight for the party's nomination.
New polls taken in a number of those states since Mr. McCain's victory in Michigan a week ago, but before Mr. Bush's sweep on Tuesday, show tough going ahead for the Arizonan. He has taken a narrow lead, within the margin of error, in three New York surveys, and he has an enormous lead of 36 points in Massachusetts. But he trails Mr. Bush by 21 points in the latest Los Angeles Times poll of Republican voters in California, the nation's most populous state, and Mr. Bush also holds double-digit leads in Maryland, Missouri and Ohio.
A week ago Mr. Bush's campaign looked wobbly. Now he has regained the initiative, and he said he felt a spring in his step this morning as he began campaigning in Georgia.
Senator McCain's biggest problem is his inability to shake Mr. Bush's hold on Republican loyalists, whose votes will decide the allocation of New York and California delegates.
"What the Washington primary tells me," said David Olsen, a political science professor at the University of Washington, "is that Bush has done what he needed to firm up his base, but the cost may be the election in November. Bush had to move so far to the right he may have trouble getting back to the center in the fall."
Clearly, Mr. Bush is having problems in attracting crossover votes, which he would need to beat the Democrats. But he has months to try to overcome that shortcoming; Mr. McCain has only a week left to woo Republicans.
"It looks like neither Bush nor McCain made much headway here on the other guy's turf," said Stuart Elway, an independent pollster in Seattle. "It was the same old stalemate that we have seen in the other states."
In the popularity contest in Washington, which was open both to Republicans and to independents, Mr. Bush led Mr. McCain by only 9,000 votes, with more than 200,000 absentee ballots still to be tallied. But among Republicans, whose votes were the only ones counted in selecting delegates, Mr. Bush trounced his rival, 58 percent to 38 percent, gaining 7 of the 12 delegates at stake. Mr. McCain took 5. Twenty-five more will be named in caucuses next week.
Mr. McCain made his strongest showing in King County (Seattle).
The Washington system is similar to that in California, where some politicians have suggested that Mr. McCain will do well in the popularity contest while Mr. Bush gets most of the 162 delegates, the largest bloc at the Republican convention.
North Dakota uses a caucus system, and the turnout was small on a frosty night. But Mr. Bush thoroughly trounced the field, beating Mr. McCain by 76 percent to 19 percent and taking 14 delegates to 4 for Mr. McCain and 1 for Alan Keyes, the former State Department aide who has hung on doggedly.
In Virginia as in Washington, it was the Republicans who propelled Mr. Bush to victory, which gave him a fat packet of 56 delegates. Mr. McCain prevailed among Democrats in the Old Dominion, 87 percent to 11, and among independents, 64 percent to 31. But Republicans constituted more than 60 percent of the electorate in the primary, and Mr. Bush took the votes of two-thirds of them.
The disparity was even more marked between voters who identified themselves with the religious right, fully 80 percent of whom went for Mr. Bush, and those who did not, who opted for Mr. McCain by a narrow margin, 52 percent to 45 percent. Mr. McCain certainly did not help himself, and may have damaged his chances, with his attack on Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the two Virginians who are among the most prominent Christian conservative leaders.
When voters were asked, without any particular target specified, whether Senator McCain had made unfair attacks, almost half said he had, and Mr. Bush won the votes of three-quarters of them. Only a third said Mr. Bush had made unfair attacks.
The figures on the religious right came from an exit poll by a consortium of the television networks and The Associated Press. No comparable figures were available for Washington, where no such poll was taken. So it is difficult to judge what effect, if any, Mr. McCain's harsh criticism will have in the Northern industrial states with no particular affinity for the religious right whose primaries are scheduled next Tuesday.
Mr. McCain raised the stakes in Virginia by spending heavily in its most expensive media market, the Washington suburbs, and making several campaign stops in the state. From that perspective, his showing was a disappointment, and Gov. James S. Gilmore III, who backed Mr. Bush, gloated that Mr. McCain's campaign bus, the Straight Talk Express, "ran out of gas in Virginia."
But with the entire Republican establishment arrayed against him, and with a very late start in organization, Mr. McCain made a contest of it. He lost by nine percentage points, considerably less than the polls had suggested, and he did very well in Norfolk, Virginia Beach and the rest of the Hampton Roads area, where several vast military installations are situated. He carried Charlottesville, home of the University of Virginia, and the Virginia suburbs of Washington, including Arlington, Alexandria and Fairfax County.
That was not enough, though, in the face of huge Bush majorities in the suburban Richmond counties of Henrico and Chesterfield.
Virginia is a must-win state for the Republicans in November, and one party leader here said on Tuesday night: "Clinton lost the state by only a couple of points four years ago. I worry that if McCain and Bush keep battering each other, the way Reagan and Ford did in 1976, the result will be the same. They let Jimmy Carter in, and these guys may end up electing Al Gore."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC DEBATE;
Gore and Bradley Sing in Harmony in Latest Meeting

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 1

 BODY:
Meeting in their last debate before more than a dozen states vote in primaries and caucuses on Tuesday, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley appeared uncharacteristically harmonious together tonight, going out of their way to agree on virtually every issue and avoiding the kind of attacks that characterized their raucous debate just over a week ago in Harlem.
Mr. Bradley signaled early that he would barely criticize Mr. Gore when he passed up a chance to fault the vice president, as he usually does, as failing to do more to combat racial profiling, and they both then talked about their own proposals, forgoing their usual potshots at each other. 
 Tonight's was the most conciliatory of their encounters, reflecting the recognition of both that, with Mr. Bradley's failure to win a single primary contest so far, the race was likely to end soon.
In one poignant moment, Mr. Bradley was asked what mistake in his life had taught him the most. A Rhodes Scholar and Olympic gold medalist before he was 22, Mr. Bradley talked about how he learned about failure from his rookie year with the New York Knicks, when he had been heralded as the team's savior, only to be booed and spit on by fans when he played poorly. Some of his supporters have likened that traumatic year to the dismaying struggles of his current campaign.
"I knew I wouldn't save the Knicks," he said. "It caused me to ask myself really, well, you have to come to terms with this. That meant I worked harder in order to achieve things. It also meant I began to see that life is not all good, not all bad, that individuals are not all good or all bad."
Mr. Gore, revising his answer after Mr. Bradley answered, said his biggest mistake was not being kind.
With both reining in the harshness that has for so long characterized their campaign, the two revealed just how ideologically similar they are. Both were given a chance to condemn the evangelical right wing, which they did. Both called for legal recognition for gay partners, although both oppose legalizing gay marriage. Both condemned racial profiling. Both praised their wives.
And both defended the Rev. Al Sharpton, who has been criticized by some people as divisive.
Eight times Mr. Gore said he agreed with Mr. Bradley.
For those who have watched any of the eight previous meetings between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley, many topics might have seemed familiar, even if they answered the questions less combatively. Last week in Harlem, for instance, Mr. Bradley said that the vice president had shown a lack of leadership by not pressing President Clinton to sign an executive order to ban racial profiling by federal law-enforcement agencies.
But when the question was raised tonight, Mr. Bradley avoided conflict. "I believe that this is the civil rights issue of our time," he said, not mentioning Mr. Gore. "It is no longer blocking people from schools. It is no longer trying to eat in a restaurant. It is having the justice system in this country finally provide equal justice for all."
Mr. Gore agreed. "I think it has to stop. I want to be tough on crime. I want to be tough on discrimination, too."
Mr. Bradley also passed on the opportunity to criticize Mr. Gore for sending mixed signals on whether to allow China to join the World Trade Organization. A few days ago, the former senator asserted that the vice president had put "the nail in the coffin" of the treaty that would bring China into the trade group when Mr. Gore suggested to A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials that he might renegotiate the treaty if elected president.
But tonight, Mr. Bradley declined to make that argument when a question was asked about China and Taiwan relations.
And though he has repeatedly criticized Mr. Gore as a "risk" to the Democratic Party because of his role in the campaign fund-raising abuses of the 1996 presidential campaign, Mr. Bradley did not even mention Mr. Gore's problems tonight, though his aides view it as the vice president's Achilles' heel.
Instead, when a question about money in politics was asked, Mr. Bradley spent more time talking about the differences between himself and Senator John McCain, the Republican presidential candidate who has made an overhaul of the system a centerpiece of his campaign. He noted that Mr. McCain was a conservative on issues like abortion or the environment.
Once again, Mr. Gore agreed, saying, "It is one of the major issues in this campaign." Then, apparently secure that Mr. Bradley was on his side, Mr. Gore tried to use the issue to present a united front against the Republicans. "It unites us, but it divides the two Republican candidates," he said. Mr. McCain's opponent, Gov. George W. Bush, opposes revamping the finance rules.
The tone of the debate was so amicable that Mr. Bradley was asked if he was repudiating his relentless criticism of the past against Mr. Gore's congressional voting record, particularly against federal funding for abortion, against certain gun control measures and in favor of tobacco subsidies. He replied that Mr. Gore's record could be used against him by the Republicans.
"He has evolved, I'm glad he has evolved," Mr. Bradley said.
Later, in the only rancorous exchange, Mr. Bradley said that Mr. Gore's record of voting to support tax-exemption for religious institutions like Bob Jones University would make it hard for the Democrats to criticize Republicans like Mr. Bush for visiting that college, where interracial dating is prohibited. "I guarantee we should be attacking them for that," Mr. Bradley said. But, he continued, "then they're going to come right back and point to those votes and it's going to be very difficult.
Mr. Gore then squabbled with Mr. Bradley over what exactly he had voted for, but the moment only highlighted how they otherwise so thoroughly agreed.
Just minutes before the debate started, the Rev. Jesse Jackson announced that he was endorsing Mr. Gore, whom he called "the most qualified and experienced candidate in a generation." "The Clinton-Gore team has sparked the greatest economic boom in the history of this country," Mr. Jackson said. "Therefore, the vice president is perfectly positioned to continue this growth."
The endorsement ends months of courtship by the two Democratic candidates for his support. And while it is not clear how many voters he might sway on his own, his endorsement is just one of several by high-profile Democrats in recent days that have added to the impression that the vice president has united the party behind him.
Mr. Jackson declined to urge Mr. Bradley to quit the race, praising him for having raised important issues in the campaign and having recruited athletes, including Michael Jordan, into the party fold.
Mr. Jackson has his own history of bitterness with Mr. Gore. In 1988 when both men ran for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Gore and his supporters criticized Mr. Jackson's position on Israel, and other issues, prompting Mr. Jackson to accuse Mr. Gore of negative campaigning.

HEADLINE: Oil, Politics And a Blacklist

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Standing in a light rain under the watchful eye of police, the protesters waved signs and shouted: "Aliyev is a murderer! Aliyev is a dictator! Aliyev, go home!"
But inside a lecture hall here last month, Heydar Aliyev, the president of Azerbaijan, could not hear a word of it. Showing multicolored maps on an overhead projector to demonstrate what he called Armenia's aggressive ways, Mr. Aliyev, a former Soviet deputy premier and leader of the local K.G.B., held court over an assembly of influential foreign policy experts. Without a doubt, he seemed to have the upper hand over his opponents outside. 
 In reality, however, it was the band of protesters who had the political muscle behind them, frustrating Mr. Aliyev's recent attempts to end a Congressional ban on United States government aid to Azerbaijan, a measure passed to punish the country for its blockade of Armenia.
Azerbaijan has been on a government blacklist since 1992 -- the only former Soviet republic to be punished in this way -- thanks to a well-coordinated lobbying effort by Armenian-Americans and a strong coalition of supporters of Armenia in Congress.
But the Azerbaijanis are pushing back. Mr. Aliyev himself has engaged in face-to-face lobbying, and some high-powered hired professionals are doing the same behind the scenes. Adding to the effort, some of the most powerful American oil companies have been acting quietly on Azerbaijan's behalf.
Most of this country's big oil companies have an interest in the energy-rich region. Three American companies, Exxon Mobil, Unocal and Pennzoil-Quaker State, are part of the Azeri International Operating Company. Other companies, like Chevron and Texaco, are active in other parts of the Caspian Sea region.
One United States oil company executive, who spoke only on the condition that he not be identified, said the restrictions on government assistance to Azerbaijan were interfering with the efforts of American companies to develop oil there. At the same time, the oil companies have sought to avoid becoming involved in the Azerbaijan-Armenia conflict, he said.
The U.S.-Azerbaijan Business Council, a group that promotes business ties between the two countries, has worked to overturn the restrictions. Jayhun Mollazade, president of the council, said that the restrictions were a "political irritant between Azerbaijan and the United States" and that they also interfered with business. Mr. Mollazade said his group received some financing from oil companies but has much broader support.
Despite these efforts on Azerbaijan's behalf, the restrictions on aid remain in place. The Armenian-American community, which numbers about a million people, is well organized in its support for the restrictions. Bound together by remembrances of the 1915 massacre of a million Armenians by the Turks, Armenian-Americans are wise to the ways of grass-roots activism: letters to lawmakers, campaign contributions and even protests in the rain.
Mr. Aliyev made his case directly to President Clinton last month during a 45-minute meeting at the White House that included both Mr. Aliyev's entourage and Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy advisers.
If Mr. Clinton's view had been the only one that mattered, Mr. Aliyev would have accomplished his mission. The White House contends that the ban on American assistance to Azerbaijan is counterproductive and ought to be lifted. But despite entreaties from administration officials, the majority of Congress has a different view.
What makes the conflict so important to Washington policy makers is the strategic importance of Azerbaijan, which shares borders with Iran on the south and Russia on the north. To the American business community, the geography that matters most is Azerbaijan's claim over vast oil reserves in the adjacent Caspian Sea.
In an interview during his visit, Mr. Aliyev showed the volatile nature of the country he rules. He accused the Russian intelligence service of masterminding a string of assassination attempts against him, including failed attacks on his presidential aircraft and a bridge he was crossing.
Mr. Aliyev also expressed interest in someday shipping oil through Iran, an alarming idea for United States officials backing a route that sticks to nations friendly to the West.
Flanking Mr. Aliyev at a long conference table during the interview was Hafiz Pashayev, Azerbaijan's ambassador to the United States, and the president's son, Ilham Aliyev, who is first vice president of the state-run oil company. There is open speculation in Baku, Azerbaijan's capital, that Mr. Aliyev, who is 77 and underwent quadruple bypass surgery last year, is grooming his son to succeed him. The president's trip to the United States mixed official business with cataract surgery.
Mr. Aliyev reassured Mr. Clinton during his meeting, according to aides to both men, that he continues to stand behind the development of a pipeline that would ship oil from Baku through Georgia and Turkey to the Mediterranean port of Ceyhan. Clinton aides see the ban on aid to Azerbaijan as a hindrance to their efforts to ensure an oil pipeline route that will not give Iran or Russia a chokehold.
"We would have major concerns about Azerbaijan looking south" to Tehran, an administration official said, stressing that such a notion never came up in his discussion with Mr. Clinton.
The ban on American assistance stems from the bitter conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of ethnic Armenians in southern Azerbaijan that has been seized by the Armenians. The two sides reached a cease-fire in 1994 and despite flare-ups continue to engage in peace talks.
"I think he's serious about coming to a peaceful settlement to the conflict," said Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat from New York and co-chairman of the 89-member Congressional caucus on Armenian issues.
But despite Mr. Pallone's view of Mr. Aliyev's good intentions, the congressman contends that the restrictions ought to remain in place until Azerbaijan lifts the blockade on its rival.
Armenian officials agree. Armen Kharazian, deputy chief of mission at the Armenian Embassy, argued that lifting the aid restrictions would send the wrong message to Azerbaijan. The two neighboring countries have no trade or diplomatic relations, Mr. Kharazian said, noting that the border is closed and most railroads and pipelines between the two states are shut down.
Mr. Aliyev demonstrated clearly that hard feelings remain. After the White House meeting, he told reporters that he was working to reach a settlement with the Armenians but vehemently argued that the aggressors were the Armenians.
"Over one million citizens of Azerbaijan have been ousted forcibly from the occupied lands and they have been living in hard circumstances in tents," Mr. Aliyev said, a contention that Mr. Kharazian of Armenia dismissed as "propaganda."
In the White House meeting, Mr. Clinton repeated his opposition to the restrictions on aid, known as Section 907 of the Freedom Support Act. But Mr. Clinton also let his counterpart know that his hands were tied.
Mr. Clinton could waive the restrictions if he made a finding that Azerbaijan had made progress toward ending the blockade. But mindful of the strong opposition among Armenian-Americans, he has left it to Congress to lift the ban.
"They haven't wanted to take the heat," said Charles H. Fairbanks Jr., an expert on the region who heads the Central Asia-Caucasus Institute at Johns Hopkins University.
The standoff leaves Mr. Aliyev -- who came to power in 1993 after a military coup and won election in 1998 in a contest the State Department said was "marred by irregularities" -- with an up-close look at democracy in action. In the interview, Mr. Aliyev expressed both an understanding of, and an annoyance with, Congress.
After his White House visit, Mr. Aliyev stood in the driveway outside and railed against what he regarded as an "unfair, unjust law passed by the Congress." But showing an understanding of how lawmaking operates here, Azerbaijan has also hired two lobbying firms to press its case on Capitol Hill.
Edwin C. Graves, who calls Mr. Aliyev "a real source of stability in the region," is a sole practitioner who receives $36,000 every six months to push for the repeal of Section 907. Baker, Donelson is a law firm that represents the Azerbaijan government on legal and political matters. George Cranwell Montgomery, the firm's managing partner, arranged a dinner last April for Mr. Aliyev to meet leading senators, according to his filing with the Justice Department made under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.
The dinner came just before a crucial Senate vote that nearly toppled the restrictions. Senator Sam Brownbeck, a Kansas Republican who has been a strong backer of the Azerbaijanis' cause, attached the measure ending the ban on Azerbaijani aid to a spending bill for foreign operations. But advocates of Armenia rounded up the votes to defeat the effort, and legislative aides expect no follow-up measure in either chamber any time soon.
The Azerbaijanis are mulling their next move. They intend to continue pressing for a lifting of the ban, but they have as their fallback position more relaxed restrictions. Already, humanitarian assistance has been exempted and oil companies have successfully pushed through provisions to allow for some government aid -- through the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Trade Development Agency -- aimed at helping American companies doing business in Azerbaijan.
During his Washington visit, Mr. Aliyev made a point of condemning what he called the outsized influence of the Armenian lobby. But Mr. Aliyev's vehemence did not sit well with a member of that lobby, Ross Vartian.
"We're impassioned and focused, clearly," agreed Mr. Vartian, who is executive director of the Armenian Assembly of America, a Washington-based nonprofit group that pushed for the ban on aid to Azerbaijan. "But I wouldn't call us formidable. Yeah, we have a large grass-roots operation. But we also have the facts on our side.
"We're the David in this," Mr. Vartian added. "We aren't the Goliath."

An article in Business Day on March 2 about Azerbaijan's attempts to end restrictions on United States aid referred incorrectly to a company that is part of a consortium of oil corporations, which have an interest in the energy-rich region. The company is a former operation of Pennzoil that was sold to the Devon Energy Corporation but still uses the name; it is not Pennzoil-Quaker State.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Legendary Filmmaker, But Without His Camera

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
"Drawing and dancing are branches of the same tree," wrote the Russian filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein (1898-1948). "Of course, they are just two varieties of the same impulse." It was the movement of line in the two disciplines that excited his imagination.
He was not very good at dancing, he confessed (except for one fox trot, which, though jerky, he had performed he said "with great panache" in Harlem). But at drawing, entirely self-taught, he excelled. If the stage and then the cinema had not claimed him, he could surely have made it as a graphic artist. 
 As it was, he drew -- in a wide range of styles, from caricature to Cubo-Futurism to Expressionism to Surrealism, and sometimes all at once -- for most of his life, even while pursuing weighty film projects like "Alexander Nevsky" (1938). For him drawing came as easily as talking. What he saw in his head begged to be embodied. "I form very sharp pictures of what I am reading or thinking about," he wrote. "These acutely visual images cry out intensely and painfully to be expressed on the page."
It was the same thrust that led to filmmaking. Like many of his cinematic colleagues, he sketched sets and lines of action on paper, but most of his drawings, from caricatures to erotic jokes to spiritual and religious imagery, did not relate directly to his films. They are vital artworks in their own right.
Some 5,000 of Eisenstein's drawings belong to the Russian State Archives of Literature and Art in Moscow, which has lent most of the more than 100 on view in "The Body of the Line: Eisenstein's Drawings," at the Drawing Center in SoHo. Also included are designs for costumes and sets from a private collection assembled by Lydia Naumova, a member of the production crew for Eisenstein's "Ivan the Terrible" (1946).
Ranging from student sketchbooks through the fruits of an ebullient Mexican period to his last works on paper, this exhibition gives Eisenstein's drawings their first museum exposure in the United States. It was produced by the Daniel Langlois Foundation for Art, Science and Technology in Montreal, and organized by Jean Gagnon, curator. (Lincoln Kirstein assembled a smaller show in a New York gallery in 1932.)
As a youth in Riga, the son of prosperous parents, Eisenstein made impish observations in line, like "Petrograd's Animals" (1915), a panel of cartoons with sardonic captions. In one, next to a drawing of a slumbering sloth and referring to the local government, he wrote: "They are found mainly in the Duma of the city and generally in places where there is a lot of work to be done." An accompanying parrot, a stand-in for journalists, is described as trying "to awaken the sloth in vain."
After studying architecture and engineering, Eisenstein served in the Red Army during the revolution, decorating propaganda trains, then gravitated to Moscow, where he worked to impressive effect with several theater groups as a designer and producer. His vivacious sketches for productions from 1918 through 1922 range from an Indian and clowns for an adaptation of Jack London's story "The Mexican" to a plump, snooty Polish grande dame in a ball gown and an architectural hairdo for a production of the Offenbach opera "Tales of Hoffmann."
A seven-year break in his drawing occurred between 1924-31, a period devoted largely to making films: "Strike" (1924), "The Battleship Potemkin" (1925), "Ten Days That Shook the World" (1928) and "Old and New" (1929). But in 1931, on a trip to Mexico, he took it up again. His drawing, he wrote, "underwent an internal catharsis, striving for mathematical abstraction and purity of line." But sensuality, too, played an important role.
Stimulated by Mexican art -- from Mayan reliefs to the popular illustrations of Jose Guadalupe Posada -- and what he described as the "actual, astonishing linear structure of the Mexican landscape," he made renditions of bulls and toreadors, Virgins and Christs spring to life on the page. In one, "Viva Christo Rey," a grotesque, Picassoid Jesus hangs from the cross; in another, "The Pardon," a crucified bull bends down to kiss a humbled toreador who kneels, hands bound, before him. At its best, Eisenstein's agile line glides fluently in its delineation of contour and its interlocking of shapes to produce strong, complex motifs.
Old Testament scenes also entered his repertory. In "Salome" (1932), the proud perpetrator admires the head of John the Baptist as his discarded body sits wanly in a corner. That same year Eisenstein drew a bizarre "Self-Portrait" whose double heads and torsos proclaim him half man, half woman, one head kissing the other as the crucified Christ and a Virgin figure stand nearby and a shrouded body lies on the floor.
The vigor of this portrait is balanced by several other images suggesting the malaise of a creative artist, perhaps occasioned by his struggles with Stalin's regime. (Until he made "Nevsky," the pressure of his work was compounded by carping at his lack of true revolutionary fervor.)
In "May It Die, This Dumb Nothingness" (1937), robotic dancers cavort on a round table, supported on the shoulders of one of them whose head pokes through a hole in the table's center. "I Look Into Nothingness," done the same day, portrays another robot bending over to examine a big, empty balloon.
In a lighthearted way, he contemplated death. Four drawings done in a single day in 1939 deal with the subject of life leaving the body. In one, life -- in the form of a skinny but vibrant creature with bright eyes above a functioning heart -- casts off a limp form that resembles a rag doll more than a human being. And yet his strength is reasserted in earthy drawings of performers, like the cartoony "Unemployed Circus Workers" (1943) and the sinuous "Harlem Snake Dancer" (1944).
In his 40's Eisenstein developed coronary problems; he died of a heart attack at 50. In some of his last drawings, too weak to pursue film projects, he seemed to muse on the, well, ineffable lightness of being. One day in December 1947, less than two months before his death, stroking the paper gently but firmly, he drew some sprightly individual nudes, each reaching up to catch a symbol of nature -- an apple, a butterfly, a dragonfly. Delicate as the drawings are, they convey a spirited affirmation.
 "The Body of the Line: Eisenstein's Drawings" is at the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166, through March 18.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Putting the Nation on Trial For a 19th-Century Rampage

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Potent history doesn't always make compelling drama, but in the case of "Defending the Light" the blood of the drama runs hot with issues and lessons that resonate across the decades of American life since the horrific events of the night of March 12, 1846.
In the premiere production, by Woodie King Jr.'s New Federal Theater, the playwright Ron Milner speaks to today's America through a murderous rampage carried out by a black man against a white family in Auburn, N.Y. 
 Part history, part tract, part sociological portrait, part courtroom drama, "Defending the Light," based on the Earl Conrad novel "Seward for the Defense," proves never less than interesting and thought-provoking, even though its cargo of combined relevance, injustice, controlled rage and questions about responsibility falls shy of theatrical combustion.
Mr. Milner, the author of such plays as "Checkmates" and "What the Wine Sellers Buy," invokes historical figures like William Seward, a former governor of New York and later Lincoln's Secretary of State, and the New York State Attorney General, John Van Buren, son of the former President, Martin Van Buren, in telling the story of the arrest and trial of the accused murderer, a young black named William Freeman. In so doing, Mr. Milner tries a nation on charges of extinguishing the bright lights among its young blacks, depriving them of education and hope of equality and condemning many of them to brutal prisons to nurture the economies of towns like Auburn, rife with discrimination and the impulse to impose death, lawfully or by lynching.
Mr. Milner asks: Could not such treatment by such a society drive a man mad? Does not such treatment hold a mirror to the society that inflicts it? Then as now the insanity defense proves controversial, and Seward, an outspoken liberal lawyer and political hopeful, risks his future in raising it when he comes to Freeman's defense.
In the smooth staging by Jay Broad on Robert Joel Schwartz's two-level planked set, which conveys 19th-century rusticity while it serves as various homes, clubs and the courtroom, "Defending the Light" uses flashbacks as it tells Freeman's story. Noteworthy performances are contributed by Eddie Robinson as Freeman, Ned Coulter as Van Buren, Lex Monson as the majestic Patriarch of the black community and Kathleen Turco-Lyon as the quick-witted and supportive Mrs. Seward.
The drama plays itself out in the context of its time and the political rivalry between the abolitionist Seward (James Kiberd) and the populist Van Buren. By all accounts, including those of the members of Auburn's black community, Freeman was a bright and industrious child with a yearning for knowledge and a promising future. As the old Patriarch says, he had the light: "He saw things in things."
But as a young man Freeman was sent to prison on flimsy evidence for a crime he swore he never committed, stealing a horse. By the time he emerged, after beatings, whippings and hours under torrents of frigid water, he was not the same. He was deaf, unable to find steady work and ranting about wanting to be paid.
When captured after the fatal knifings of a white man and the man's wife, mother-in-law and baby son, Freeman was a constantly smiling, hunched and twitching figure who said he did not believe that the law covered people like him. "The law is for everyone," Seward insists. "No one is outside the law."
"Defending the Light" suggests that this premise remains unresolved.
 
DEFENDING THE LIGHT
 
By Ron Milner; adapted from the novel "Seward for the Defense" by Earl Conrad. Directed by Jay Broad; production stage manager, Jacqui Casto; assistant stage manager, Toni Marie Davis; sets by Robert Joel Schwartz; lighting by David Segal; costumes by Michael Alan Stein; technical director, Green Turtle Productions; sound by Jairous L. Parker Sr.; fight director, B. H.Barry; assistant to Mr. Barry, Ian Marshall; property mistress, Maria Delgado-Hoffman. Presented by the New Federal Theater, Woodie King Jr., producing director. At TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street, TriBeCa.

WITH: Ned Coulter (John Van Buren), James Kiberd (William Seward), Victoria G. Platt (Deborah DuPuy), Eddie Robinson (William Freeman), Lex Monson (Patriarch) and Kathleen Turco-Lyon (Mrs. Seward).

HEADLINE: NEW VIDEO RELEASES

 BODY:

A Hundred and One Nights
Conjuring grand allusions, Agnes Varda's film salutes 100 years of movies with scores of clips from films and reflections from the stars.
For example, Marcello Mastroianni argues about bathtub scenes with Michel Piccoli (left), who presides over the film in a baronial chateau. 
 One of the odder movie bits shows Robert De Niro floating along in a swan boat with Catherine Deneuve to the tune of "Sentimental Journey."
Nevertheless, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, "whenever Ms. Varda galls her audience with such fluff, all she needs is a clip from 'Pickpocket' or 'The General' to make things right."
 
1995. Winstar. $89.98; DVD, $89.98. 101 minutes. French with English subtitles. No rating.
 
The Best Man
Harper (Taye Diggs) is the kind of novelist who has his book chosen by Oprah Winfrey's book club and floats in a candlelit bath full of rose petals. Titled "Unfinished Business," his novel has a character closely resembling an old flame (Nia Long), whom he re-encounters and has a tryst with in New York. Back home, his loyal love (Sanaa Lathan) stays true blue, demonstrating that "current movies about upscale black characters have much more solid traditional values than ones about catty white teenagers" (Maslin).
 
1999. Universal. $107.37; DVD, $24.98. 118 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
 
A Dog of Flanders
Missing no opportunity to oversentimentalize, Kevin Brodie's adaptation of the children's tale by Ouida, set in 19th-century Flanders, takes a poor boy named Nello (Jesse James as a 7-year-old and Jeremy James Klissner in later years) and his shaggy sheep dog, Patrasche, on a bumpy trip to the realization that Nello may be a rich kid after all. After an unpromising apprenticeship hauling milk for his grandfather (Jack Warden), Nello is taken in hand by the painter Michel La Grande (Jon Voight), who sees artistic promise in the lad. But a charge of arson and eviction into a blizzard don't make the going easier in a film "clogged with sticky-sweet pieties cooed to saucer-eyed tots" (Stephen Holden).
 
1999. Warner. $19.98. 90 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: March 7.
 
Sitcom
Francois Ozon's film begins promisingly with the sounds of screaming and gunfire disturbing the suburban calm. It seems the Father (Francois Marthouret) is displeased with his surprise birthday party. Through flashbacks we meet the Mother (Evelyne Dandry), a fusser and fretter, and their son (Adrien De Van), who declares himself gay, and daughter (Maria De Van), who has an erotic encounter with a rat, jumps out a window and becomes a paraplegic dominatrix. Though filmed with the look of a television comedy, "Sitcom" can't conceal "a sour streak that eventually poisons its humor" (Maslin).
 
1999. New Yorker. $94.98. 80 minutes. French with English subtitles. No rating. Release date: March 7.

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF

BYLINE: By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:

How About McGarden?
The Winter Garden Theater won't be changing its name after all.
Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, which owns the theater, said yesterday that his company had ended discussions with General Motors about changing the name of the Winter Garden, home to "Cats," to the Cadillac Winter Garden, or some variation thereof, in exchange for corporate sponsorship. 
 No explanation was given for the abrupt end to the discussions, which had been continuing for about three years and which seemed to be close to fruition.
The announcement came just a day after the Roundabout Theater Company announced it was selling off the name of the historic Selwyn Theater, its new home, to American Airlines, a deal that was greeted on Broadway with a mix of approval and skepticism. The airline will pay $8.5 million (and, one would hope, a lifetime supply of free peanuts).
As for the Winter Garden, Mr. Schoenfeld offered no additional comment, and a call to General Motors was not immediately returned.
 
Vamoose, 'Vanya'
The new name notwithstanding, it's apparently taking a little longer than expected to get the Selwyn -- er, the American Airlines Theater -- ready for takeoff.
The theater formerly known as the Selwyn, at 229 West 42nd Street, is in the midst of a $21 million overhaul but nonetheless was scheduled to open its doors on April 11 for the first preview of "Uncle Vanya."
Now comes word that the construction isn't proceeding as quickly as expected, and that the company is in discussions with the Nederlander Organization to shift the run of "Vanya" to the Atkinson Theater.
Todd Haimes, the artistic director of the company, said that the possible move was a precautionary measure to assure that the show opens by the Tony deadline, which is May 3.
A shift would not be completely unexpected; the company has delayed the opening once. Still, it is sure to be a disappointment for the Roundabout, which had planned an array of events around its opening. The timing, too, is not ideal, coming just after the American Airlines deal.
The prospective shift of "Vanya" is made possible by another production decision: "Enigma Variations," which opened on Feb. 24 in Toronto, will not come to Broadway this season. The production had mainly favorable reviews in Toronto, but its producer, Emanuel Azenberg, has decided to pass on bringing the show to the Atkinson, where it was tentatively scheduled to open, opting instead to take it to London. "The economics over there are stultifyingly different," he said.
London productions are generally much cheaper than those in New York, owing to Broadway's steep labor and landlord costs. Mr. Azenberg said he was considering a possible autumn run in the United States.
 
Welcome to the Club
The staff of the Manhattan Theater Club can be excused for feeling a little emotionally drained. In the last six weeks, after all, it has closed one production ("Y2K"), transferred a second to a commercial run ("Fuddy Meers") and watched as the prospects of a third ("The Wild Party") were dashed by a round of sub-par reviews.
Still, Tuesday night's opening of "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife" provided a spurt of invigorating energy for many at the theater club. The play, an urban comedy by Charles Busch, received a round of strong notices.
Particular praise was saved for Linda Lavin, who plays Marjorie Taub, the Sartre-quoting depressive at the play's center. It is a character that this veteran New York actress says she understands instinctively. "This woman loves the drama of her life," Ms. Lavin said, adding with a laugh, "I know this woman."
The drama of Ms. Lavin's life may get even more high-stakes in coming weeks. The reviews for "Allergist" have given rise to talk of a longer run, with producers reportedly inquiring about two midsize Broadway houses where the current tenants are doing moderate business.
Whether those rumors pan out or not, Ms. Lavin is expected back on Broadway next spring in rotating revivals of Neil Simon's "Brighton Beach Memoirs" and "Broadway Bound," reprising her Tony-winning turn as Kate Jerome, the narrator's long-suffering mother.
 
Coming Attractions
Two ambitious additions to the spring schedule were announced this week.
Both are Off Broadway. At the New York Theater Workshop the artistic director, James C. Nicola, said two newly rewritten works by John Guare would be performed in repertory in May. They are the plays formerly known as "Gardenia" and "Lydie Breeze," first produced in 1982 and both about the lives of a group of friends in a 19th-century utopian commune.
Neither was well liked then, but Mr. Nicola said that after directing a well-received version of both plays in Washington in 1983 he had become convinced that they constituted "a 20th-century American classic."
Now the plays are being combined into one cohesive five-hour script, reworked by Mr. Guare, to be played over two nights, and renamed "Lydie Breeze, Part 1: Bulfinch's Mythology" and "Lydie Breeze, Part 2: The Sacredness of the Next Task." (There will be a quiz.)
Another surprise reprise is under way at the Irish Repertory Theater, where the artistic director, Charlotte Moore, announced that "Our Lady of Sligo," a hit at the Royal National Theater in London in 1998, would arrive in April.
The play, by Sebastian Barry, is part of a series of biographical works about his family. The "Lady" in question is Mr. Barry's grandmother, a part to be played by the Irish star Sinead Cusack. Max Stafford-Clark will direct.
Speaking from London, Ms. Cusack described the character as "damaged and damaging," traits familiar to characters of many recent Irish dramas. Why are her countrymen so ripe for humor and pain? "I think that's a universal condition," Ms. Cusack said. "The Irish are just more overt."
