HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
European Central Bank Holds Interest Rates Steady for Now

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 2

 BODY:
Despite worries about inflation and the euro's slump to a record low this week, the European Central Bank decided today not to raise interest rates, while warning that it would probably do so soon.
"The risks are increasing," said Wim Duisenberg, the president of the central bank, after a meeting here of the board of governors. "There can be no doubt in anybody's mind about the direction of monetary policy." 
 Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged that he was concerned about the euro, the single currency adopted a year ago by 11 European countries. Though conceived in part as a rival to the American dollar, the value of the euro has tumbled from $1.18 at its debut to 96.63 cents today.
On Monday, the euro dropped to nearly 94 cents before recovering a bit amid speculation -- apparently wrong -- that the central bank had intervened on its behalf.
European leaders insist they have no intention of propping up the euro through direct intervention, and Mr. Duisenberg explicitly denied the central bank had moved into currency markets on Monday.
But the persistent decline of the new currency has been disheartening, and Mr. Duisenberg said he was troubled by it on two counts.
The first concern, he said, is that the currency weakness will generate inflationary pressures by increasing the prices of imported goods. A second concern, he continued, is about "possible psychological effects" on the credibility of the currency itself.
The main reason for the decline against the dollar, most economists agree, is that the American economy is growing so much faster than that of Europe.
On top of that, the United States Federal Reserve has raised American interest rates more rapidly in recent months than the European Central Bank.
Mr. Duisenberg is now caught at one of the trickiest junctures he has faced since the introduction of the euro on Jan. 1, 1999.
The anemic growth in Europe's biggest economies has finally improved, and conditions are among the best they have been in years. At the same time, however, inflationary pressures are clearly building. Across the 11 euro nations, consumer prices climbed at an annual rate of 2 percent in January. That is right at the limit of what the European Central Bank considers acceptable.
Prices are climbing considerably faster than that in Europe's smaller but faster growing countries. Inflation is running at 4.4 percent a year in Ireland, while in Spain the rate is 2.9 percent. Italy, one of Europe's biggest yet weakest economies, has a rate of about 2.2 percent. Much of that reflects the surge in oil prices.
The European Central Bank has come under increasing criticism for sending mixed signals about its priorities. Until recently, many economists were convinced that it would raise interest rates today in another pre-emptive strike against rising prices.
Part of that expectation came from hawkish statements in the most recent monthly bulletin of the central bank. But in a newspaper interview published Monday, the bank's vice president, Christian Noyer, cautioned that people were reading too much into its bulletin and hinted that the bank was not yet ready to become more tightfisted.
"It seems like they are aiming at a broad consensus of all the members of the governing board," said Elga Bartsch, an economist with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in London.
In the 14 months since it assumed control of monetary policy for the euro countries, the European Central Bank has struggled to maintain its credibility in global markets even as it has watched the euro decline steadily the entire time.
Initially determined to run a hard-nosed policy aimed at preventing inflation above all else, it was forced to open its spigots last year, when European growth stalled as a result of financial crises in Asia, Russia and Latin America.
Last November it swung back to a hard-line stance, raising interest rates by half a percentage point, to 3 percent. In January, it followed up with a second increase, to 3.25 percent.
That still leaves baseline interest rates in Europe well below those in the United States, though its inflation rate is slightly lower as well.
At the moment, all signs point to a strong rebound in European growth. Germany, Europe's biggest economy but also its most sluggish, is growing at an annual rate of more than 2.5 percent -- a big improvement from 1999, when it grew a total of 1.5 percent.
For the euro zone as a whole, economists predict that growth will average about 3 percent in 2000, and perhaps slightly more.
"Economic conditions and perspectives in the euro area appear to be better at present than at any time in the past decade," Mr. Duisenberg said today, a sign that he is not worried that a tougher policy will put Europe back into a tailspin.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Fall 4.2%, To Lowest Level in Four Months

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell to the lowest level in four months in January, government figures showed today, signaling that higher borrowing costs are starting to discourage buyers.
Sales declined 4.2 percent in January, to an annual rate of 882,000 homes, after rising 4 percent in December, the Commerce Department said. The number of homes for sale, 326,000 at an annual rate, was the highest in more than three years, and the average price, $154,400, was the lowest in a year. 
 Higher interest rates "may have kept housing from getting stronger," said Tim McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank Ltd. in New York. Still, overall consumer spending is growing as "the wealth created by the stock market has been enough to offset the moderate rise in rates over the last year," he said.
The Conference Board, the business-financed research group based in New York, said today that its index of leading economic indicators rose in January -- a sign that the nation's economic expansion, now in a record 108th month, will continue. The index increased 0.3 percent, the same as in the previous month.
January's rate of new-home sales was the lowest since 848,000 in September, with sales falling in the Midwest, the West and the South and rising in the Northeast.
The average price of a home in January declined to $154,400 from $164,000 in December.
"Interest rates have led to the flattening of the housing market the last few months," said Greg Jones, chief economist at Briefing.com in Jackson, Wyo.
Mortgage rates, which are often tied to the 10-year Treasury yield, are already higher after four rate increases by the Federal Reserve since June. This week, the average interest rate on a 30-year fixed home mortgage fell to 8.27 percent, still close to a 3 1/2-year high of 8.42 percent, according to Freddie Mac, the buyer of United States mortgages. Since reaching a recent low of 7.67 percent on Nov. 12, the mortgage rate has risen 60 basis points.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Some Oil Producing Countries Agree Output Should Rise

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 2

 BODY:
With the high cost of oil and gasoline spreading alarm through Western economies, oil ministers from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico -- all among the world's major exporters -- met here today and agreed that production should be increased to stabilize prices, but they declined to make firm commitments on the timing or the amount.
Oil traders interpreted the absence of such commitments as an indication that producers might not meet demands by the United States and other oil-consuming nations for a substantial increase in output. 
 Oil prices, which have risen to nine-year highs in recent weeks and jumped 4 percent on Wednesday, ended little changed today on the vague outcome of the oil ministers' meeting in London. The London price of Brent crude for April delivery rose to $29.47 a barrel before settling back to $29.22, up 10 cents. In New York, oil for April delivery briefly rose to $32.15 a barrel before retreating to settle at $31.69, down 8 cents.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to meet in Vienna on March 27 to decide whether to increase production or to maintain the present reduced output, as some exporters led by Iran, Libya and Algeria are demanding.
"OPEC still has moderates and still has price hawks," said Peter Gignoux, an oil analyst with Salomon Smith Barney here. "We still need to get a consensus. I think we are looking at high oil prices for a bit to come."
The Saudi oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, acknowledged today that "there is need for additional production," adding, "The issue is when and how much."
"Uppermost in our minds is to maintain stability in the market," he said, but refused to specify the likely scope of a production increase. "I think the number will be put forward when we finish our consultation with all other members.
"If you are seeking the number, you are not going to get it today," he told reporters. He also declined to say whether he was aiming at a specific price level and would not comment on suggestions that producers want oil prices in the United States to sink below $25 a barrel. "We are going to leave that up to the market for now," he said.
Delegates at the discussions here have said privately they expect production to be increased next month by 1 million or 1.2 million barrels a day; the United States would like to see production increase by 2 million to 3 million barrels a day.
World oil consumption runs at around 77 million barrels a day but, since OPEC agreed to deep production cuts last March, output has dropped to 75 million barrels a day. The shortfall of two million barrels a day has tripled oil prices since December 1998, when they had fallen to $10, the lowest in 12 years.
Retail gasoline prices have reached an average of $1.421 a gallon in the United States, the world's biggest oil consumer, and there is some expectation prices will reach $2 by the summer driving season, when demand is highest.
The United States energy secretary, Bill Richardson, who has just returned to Washington after a visit to major oil producers, has called the rising prices and dwindling supplies a threat to global economic growth.
Those views were echoed today by the French industry minister, Christian Pierret, who also warned producers that high prices would strangle their own markets in the West. "As far as France is concerned, the persistence of high prices could affect world economic growth and weigh on the inflationary pressures that might appear," he said.
OPEC's production cuts are set to expire on March 31. Historically, however, demand for oil falls in the second three months of the year with the arrival of spring in the Northern Hemisphere, and prices tend to weaken. That cyclical shift has provided OPEC's hawks with the argument against increased production.
"I accept that oil prices are high at the moment, but they will fall in the second quarter when we expect demand to drop by 2.8 million barrels per day," said Hossein Kazempour Ardebili, an Iranian oil ministry official. "If we increase output while demand is falling, it will be detrimental to prices."
Iran has previously called for the OPEC production cuts to be maintained through September and the official's remarks seem to signal continued deep division within OPEC about raising production levels.
"There's clearly no decision taken yet," said Frederic Lassere, an analyst at Societe Generale in Paris, who argued that of the three oil producers meeting here, Mexico was probably under greatest pressure from the United States to increase output.
Mexico is not a member of OPEC, which accounts for around one-third of worldwide oil production, but has agreed to cooperate with the group's decision at its Vienna meeting later this month. "We will wait to see this consensus before making our independent decision," the Mexican oil minister, Luis Tellez, said.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Spending Spree Continues Online and in Stores

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Even though the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, oil prices increased and the stock market grew more volatile, American consumers continued their spending spree in stores and on the Internet, two reports showed yesterday.
Rushing to stores to buy their jean jackets and tropical-print spring fashions early, shoppers gave merchants a stronger-than-expected month. Sales in stores open more than a year, a key industry measurement, rose 5.1 percent in February, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index. 
 "There were enough factors that together they could have caused the train to go off the track," said Jeff Feiner, a retail analyst for Lehman Brothers, "but consumer confidence has remained high, and we are optimistic about the first quarter."
The other good news came as the Commerce Department released its first official estimate of electronic commerce retail sales, which had previously been included with overall sales. The study found that $5.3 billion worth of goods and services were sold online in the fourth quarter of 1999. Although that number accounted for only 0.64 percent of the total retail economy of $821 billion for the quarter, the data confirmed sharp growth in Internet commerce.
The Commerce Department based its numbers on a survey of 12,000 Internet merchants selling products as diverse as cars, furniture and groceries. But the survey did not include travel services, financial brokers and dealers and ticket sales -- categories consulting firms often included in online predictions.
February is not a significant month on the retail calendar, accounting for only about 6 percent of sales in a year. As a result, most analysts were not adjusting profit predictions for the companies despite the results. "Even though most of my companies have outperformed, I am not changing earnings estimates," said George Strachan, a Goldman, Sachs retail analyst.
Retailers that performed strongest last month were at opposite ends of the price spectrum. On the luxury side were Saks Inc., whose sales rose 8 percent, and Neiman Marcus, up 11.2 percent. Among the discounters, Costco continued its red-hot streak, with an increase of 13 percent.

HEADLINE: James J. O'Leary, 85, an Economist

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
James J. O'Leary, an economist and a former vice chairman of the U.S. Trust Corporation, died Monday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 85.
Dr. O'Leary was vice chairman of U.S. Trust, a money management company based in New York, from 1970 until 1980. 
 He also served on the board of the National Bureau of Economic Research and was its chairman from 1976 to 1980.
Born in Manchester, Conn., on May 7, 1914, Dr. O'Leary graduated from Wesleyan University, where he also earned a master's degree. He received his doctorate from Duke University.
During World War II, he taught at Wesleyan and at the Air Navigation Flight Preparatory School in Middletown, Conn.
After the war, Dr. O'Leary became a consultant for the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, taught briefly at Duke and served in various positions with the Life Insurance Association of America.
He was also chairman and chief economist at Lionel D. Edie & Company from 1967 to 1969, the year he joined U.S. Trust as an executive vice president and economist. After his 10 years with U.S. trust, he was an economic consultant.
In 1992, Dr. O'Leary published the book, "Stagnation or Healthy Growth?: The Challenge to the United States in the 90's" (University Press of America).
His wife, Rita, died in 1997. He is survived by three sons, James P., of Goshen, Conn.; Paul H., of Fairport, N.Y.; and Mark E., of Montauk, N.Y.; a daughter, Martha E. O'Leary of Garden City, N.Y.; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Saul Steinberg: A Model for Today's Internet Barons

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
HOT stocks traded for hundreds of times their earnings, if they had any. Companies with concepts that caught the eye of eager investors could acquire companies many times their size. Public enthusiasm for stocks was higher than at any time since the 1920's.
The late 1960's, memorably termed the Go-Go Years by the great financial writer John Brooks, are largely forgotten now. They shouldn't be. 
 No man better exemplified that era than Saul P. Steinberg. He was the survivor, a man wise enough in his youth to both come up with a concept that would captivate investors and then to realize that the riches bestowed upon him would be ephemeral if he did not use his ridiculously overvalued stock to buy something that had real value.
Mr. Steinberg, now just 60 years old, announced this week that he is stepping down as chief executive of Reliance Group Holdings, the insurance company that he took over in 1968, although he is staying on as chairman.
His departure is not exactly being mourned, for Reliance is in dreadful shape, with its stock trading as if its remaining insurance operations were worth less than nothing. He did far better for himself, taking generous salaries and bonuses, than he did for Reliance's public shareholders. He was much better at identifying values than he was at running companies.
But it is not for what he did lately that Mr. Steinberg will be best remembered. It was in 1961, at the tender age of 22, that he pioneered the computer leasing business. I.B.M., which made the computers, was not interested in offering long-term leases, and Mr. Steinberg saw a niche. Whether or not that business would be profitable in the long run depended on how well old computers would hold their value, but with the right accounting assumptions his company, named Leasco, could and did show instant profits. It went public in 1965 and the stock zoomed. Three years later, that hot stock enabled Leasco to take over Reliance, a dull but prosperous insurance company that was nearly 10 times its size.
Leasco, it turned out, was not worth anything close to what Wall Street thought it was. But Reliance was a real asset, and Mr. Steinberg had an operation that would keep him in business even when that era vanished.
The beginning of the end of the Go-Go Years may, in fact, be dated to Mr. Steinberg's disastrous 1969 attempt to have Leasco take over Chemical Bank of New York, then the sixth-largest bank in the United States. Suddenly Leasco's inflated stock came under attack, and Mr. Steinberg had to withdraw his offer as Leasco's share price withered. "I always knew there was an Establishment," he said later. "I just used to think I was part of it." Within a few years the country was in recession, the stock market had collapsed, and the public had lost interest in stocks.
In later years, Mr. Steinberg tried more raids, but the really big targets, such as Disney before Michael Eisner turned it around, eluded him. He took his empire private in 1982, when stock prices were very low, and then sold stock in Reliance to the public in 1986, when the bull was roaring.
It is not easy for a company with a sizzling stock to go against the Wall Street grain and use those shares to buy an unloved company. Some America Online owners are outraged that its Internet operations will be diluted by boring assets, and AOL is down 24 percent since it agreed to buy Time Warner. But the people running many a hot Internet company now would do well to ponder Saul Steinberg's staying power, and to follow his example.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE;
A Luxury Condo Project on Fifth Avenue Is Attracting Buyers

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Scaffolding covers a former 11-story office building at 838 Fifth Avenue and East 65th Street as it is transformed into one of Manhattan's newest and more expensive condominiums, complete with separate staff apartments and wine and storage units.
When work is finished in a year, the building will have 10 condominium apartments, including a penthouse, ranging from 4,522 to 5,423 square feet and from $9 million to $18 million. To make apartments of the desired size possible, the developers are expanding the landmark limestone building, built in 1950 for the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, by adding one floor and a 10-story addition along 65th Street. 
 The building will have seven ground-floor studio apartments for staff members, measuring 257 to 339 square feet and selling -- but only in conjunction with the purchase of a larger apartment -- for an average of $500,000 each. Nine 45 square-foot wine cellars and 15 storage units, with 30 to 111 square feet, will be in the basement. Prices for those units are $50,000 and $30,000, respectively.
Since sales started in September, five apartments, each occupying a full floor -- except the penthouse, which fills two floors -- have been sold and a sixth is under contract to be sold, said Bret S. Bobo, director of sales for 838 Associates L.L.C., the development group of the $79 million project. Principals in the development company are A. Alfred Taubman, chairman of both Sotheby's and the Taubman Group, a shopping center development and management company, and Louis M. Dubin and Metin Negrin, both of the Athena Group, a real-estate investment and development company in Manhattan.
Residential brokers say the sales at 838 Fifth Avenue reflect the demand for large luxury apartments at the highest rung of the market, which they describe as units priced at $3 million or more. "It is the smallest segment," said Kirk Henckels, a senior vice president at the Manhattan brokerage of Stribling & Associates, who specializes in the sale of such apartments. "But the demand is incredible, particularly for condos, which has been enhanced by the lack of prewar co-ops and buyer frustration with board approval for purchasing and renovating units."
Despite this demand, the number of condominium units being built has decreased. According to the Real Estate Board of New York, there were 113 plans for condominiums, with 3,696 units, filed last year with the New York State attorney general's office, down from 125 plans, with 4,105 units, in 1998. In 1986, at the peak of the last building boom, plans were filed for 6,463 units.
Mr. Henckels said the constraints were tighter on large luxury units in "top-tier locations" like Fifth and Park Avenues and Central Park West, pushing developers, and by extension buyers, into "emerging locations" like Third Avenue and parts of downtown.
In turn, prices are rising. Stribling's 1999 year-end report on the luxury market found that prices had risen at least 25 percent over the preceding year, with condos generally selling for $1,800 to $3,100 a square foot. Mr. Henckels said that while current prices for luxury condos as well as other housing types "seem high, in reality incomes have risen faster than real estate prices." He added that, assuming a stable economy and stock market, "prices have room to increase still further."
At 838 Fifth Avenue, the sale prices per square foot "are where they should be" at $1,660 to $3,369 for the apartments, most with direct views of Central Park, Mr. Bobo said, noting that the average price for the units already sold was $2,400 a square foot.
He said the developers were drawn to the building because "it was the only opportunity left in a prime location," on Fifth Avenue with Central Park frontage between East 60th Street and the upper 90's, "to convert to condominiums."
In October 1998, 838 Associates bought the building for $30 million from the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which moved to 633 Third Avenue at 40th Street. Though the union first sold the building through a sealed bid to Beit Yaakov, a Sephardic congregation, which had wanted to rebuild it as a synagogue, that sale never closed, and ultimately the building was sold to the development group.
To create the apartments the developers envisioned, they also purchased, for $7 million, the adjacent property at 2 East 65th Street, which has been razed, and combined it with the 20-foot-deep rear yard behind 838 Fifth Avenue to provide room for the 10-story addition. A 12th floor will be added to the original building to form the penthouse. The project was granted a certificate of appropriateness from the Landmarks Preservation Commission last August.
Most of the interior of the former office building has been demolished and is now being reshaped to apartments with mostly nine-foot-high ceilings. Layouts of the units, designed by Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron, a Manhattan architectural firm, also include three to five bedrooms, corner living rooms of up to 20 by 47 feet and libraries with wood-burning fireplaces. Buyers who choose to finish their own space are given credit off the purchase price, Mr. Bobo said.
Planned amenities include a rooftop terrace. Monthly common charges, including real-estate taxes, for the apartments are expected to be $9,676 to $13,879. The cost for one each of the staff apartments and wine and storage units adds $573 to $708 more to the monthly fee.
The project's architect, Beyer Blinder Belle of Manhattan, will clad the exterior of the 10-story addition with limestone from the same quarry in Indiana that provided the stone for the original building. New windows and limestone embellishments will be added to that building's facade to give it a more residential look.
But when residents start moving in next March, they will find that one of the most notable details of the old facade has been preserved: the inscription "Love Thy Neighbor as Thyself."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sends Rescue Team to Help Flood-Ravaged Mozambique

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The United States began sending search-and-rescue teams to Mozambique today and sent additional emergency supplies in response to weeks of severe flooding in southern Africa.
The American aid is expected to eventually involve about 500 people, five MH-53 cargo helicopters and five C-130 transport planes, according to Capt. Bob Pritchard, a spokesman for the United States European Command in Stuttgart, Germany. 
 Ten military specialists from Europe are en route to Mozambique to join a dozen others already there, Captain Pritchard said.
President Clinton said in a statement, "All Americans have been deeply moved by the tragic events in southern Africa."
The United States had already pledged $12.8 million for the flood relief effort, including money for a 14-member team from the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Department, to travel to Mozambique. The team will be taking three inflatable rescue boats and three small trucks.
"Our primary mission will be rescuing people from the high areas and taking them to the shelters," said Lt. Louie Fernandez, a rescue team spokesman in Miami.
The MH-53 helicopters, which can carry about 38 people and have infrared systems for operating at night, are suited for search and rescue, a Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth Bacon, said.
The C-130 aircraft will conduct in-flight refueling of the helicopters, enabling them to travel much greater distances, Mr. Bacon said. Most of the flood zone can be reached only by helicopter.
About 2,400 blankets, 6,000 water cans and 160 rolls of plastic sheeting to build emergency shelters have already been flown into Mozambique by an American C-17 aircraft.
Those supplies, which were provided by the United States Agency for International Development, were to be distributed by the United Nations, the government of Mozambique and South African military units.
The American aid package will also provide $7 million worth of food as well as sandbags, shovels and wheelbarrows.
The flooding is the result of several weeks of torrential rains that have killed more than 150 people in Mozambique, South Africa, Zimbabwe, Swaziland and Botswana.

HEADLINE: High U.N. Official Sees Loss of Rights in China

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 2

 BODY:
The United Nations' top human rights official expressed deep concern here today over what she called a deterioration in China's human rights practices.
"I am concerned about three areas, of expression, freedom of religion and freedom of association," Mary Robinson, high commissioner for human rights, said at a news conference after meeting senior Chinese officials. 
 She gave her assessment less than three weeks before the annual session of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, starting on March 20 in Geneva, where the United States plans to offer a resolution to censure China's rights record.
Ms. Robinson declined to comment on the resolution. Her remarks here may bolster the American case. But the resolution has little chance of passing, diplomats said, because China can muster a majority of countries to oppose it as unwarranted meddling in its internal affairs.
In meetings today with Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen and other officials, Ms. Robinson presented her concerns about developments over the last year and a half. Those included the arrests and lengthy prison sentences given to democracy advocates, what Ms. Robinson termed "a notable clampdown on religious expression," and the repression of labor organizers and the Falun Gong spiritual movement.
She gave the government a written report detailing violations of international rights standards and listing numerous individuals who had been imprisoned without fair legal procedures.
At the same time that Ms. Robinson spoke, the Foreign Ministry said in a regular press briefing that only the people of China had the right to judge whether their rights were worsening or improving.
"The Chinese people are satisfied" with the freedoms they enjoy, said a spokesman for the ministry, Zhu Bangzhao, who called on Ms. Robinson to cooperate with China "on the basis of mutual respect."
Ms. Robinson, a former president of Ireland, was clearly mindful of China's prickliness and offered praise for what she called the country's continued progress in "economic and social rights" and efforts to improve criminal procedures. But she was frank in her critique of the record in the core freedoms and legal safeguards enshrined in international declarations.
Ms. Robinson had hoped for agreement this week on a long-discussed program of technical cooperation with China, to study how its laws and criminal practices can be brought into compliance with the two international rights covenants that China has signed but not ratified.
No such agreement was announced today. But Ms. Robinson said she had been assured that the Chinese expected to sign on to the program this year.
Ms. Robinson said she was encouraged that the Chinese Parliament had begun discussing the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which China signed in 1997. But she said no such progress was evident in the case of the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, signed in 1998, and warned that China would have to make wide-ranging changes to bring its legal practices in line with international standards.
Among other changes, Ms. Robinson said, the notorious system of "reform through labor," in which accused criminals and opponents of the state are sent to labor camps for up to three years without trials or basic legal protections, would have to be phased out. As of 1997, according to government figures, 230,000 people were held in such labor camps, and the government has given no sign that it would seriously consider abolishing the system.
Ms. Robinson said she had been alarmed to hear of proposals for a new law to govern the reform-through-labor system, as though that would raise its legitimacy. "Bad law can be a tyranny," she said.
Ms. Robinson was here for a United Nations workshop on human rights in Asia. The Chinese press today featured the workshop as a sign of progress and carried President Jiang Zemin's congratulatory message to the forum in which he praised the global development of human rights, in keeping with the cultural traditions and needs of each country.
"China has made tremendous efforts on the human rights front, and it has achieved successes that have astonished the world," he said.
Last week, after the State Department had in its annual report on rights castigated China for regressing, China issued its own report on human rights violations in the United States like racism and prisoner mistreatment. China's newspapers have prominently covered the trial of four New York City police officers who fatally shot Amadou Diallo, a West African immigrant, and were acquitted of all charges.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Major U.S. Markets Tread Water Waiting for Jobs Report

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks moved higher yesterday while the Nasdaq market sagged as traders await a jobs report that the Federal Reserve will probably consider when mulling more interest-rate increases.
"It is certainly nice to see sponsorship of the old-economy stocks," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "Throwing 29 points off the Nasdaq is like throwing a deck chair off the Titanic. It doesn't really do much. We are going to be on pins and needles going into the employment numbers." 
 Before the market opens today, the Labor Department will release employment data for February, with analysts expecting the jobless rate to remain unchanged at 4 percent.
The estimates also call for 206,000 jobs to have been created outside the farm sector.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 26.99 points, or 0.27 percent, at 10,164.92, led by AT&T , which rose 6 5/16 , to 54 1/8, on investor interest in United States telecommunications.
SBC Communications, a Baby Bell, advanced 2 1/2, to 44 1/2. Telecommunications shares have been active recently on reports of strategic partnerships and other business initiatives.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 2.57 points, or 0.19 percent, to 1,381.76.
The Nasdaq composite index lost 29.57 points, or 0.62 percent, to 4,754.51. The technology-laden index lost ground after Palm Inc., one of this year's most-talked-about initial public offerings, made its Wall Street debut. Palm, which makes the line of hand-held organizers that can connect to the Internet, was offered to select investors at $38 and ended at 95 1/16 , after opening at 145.
But its parent company, 3Com, slid 22 5/16 , to 81 13/16 , with the stock the most actively traded on Nasdaq.
3Com has more than doubled from $40 a share to more than $100 a share since Dec. 13, when it announced the spinoff of the Palm division.
"The Palm I.P.O. may mark a near-term top for Nasdaq because there was so much anticipation building up," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. "People buy on the expectation and sell on the event, and there's an awful lot of room for profit taking in some sectors after the last two weeks of strong performance."
Wall Street brushed off positive news on the inflation front. The Commerce Department reported that Americans bought new homes at a slower-than-expected pace in January, a sign that higher borrowing costs may be starting to weigh on one of the most interest-rate-sensitive sectors of the economy.
Traders instead are awaiting the February payroll numbers.
The tight labor market has been one of the Federal Reserve's biggest concerns, with Wall Street still predicting that the central bank will raise interest rates this month to slow down the economy. A stronger-than-expected jobs report could fan fears of aggressive Fed action to stop inflation.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Treasuries Trade Narrowly

Treasury bonds prices traded in the narrowest range of the week yesterday, a day before an employment report that investors and analysts expect will point to faster growth and inflation.

The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32 , to 101 18/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.14 percent from 6.15 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Nothing Left to Buy?;
Pondering the Indiscreet Charm of the Superrich

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
Rex Golding, a partner at Softbank Technology Ventures, has made a lot more money than he had ever expected. But even among the circle he associates with, things are getting a little out of hand.
"My 6-year-old is starting to say things like, 'their house is bigger,' " Mr. Golding said, recalling a recent drive through his neighborhood in Menlo Park, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley. "She knows the different cars. It is troubling to me." 
 Peter Kiernan, a senior executive at the Goldman Sachs Group, attended an Ivy League party last fall where one recent graduate boasted he would own a fleet of personal airplanes by age 30. " 'I don't just want wealth,' " Mr. Kiernan said the young man told him. " 'I want plane wealth.' "
Keeping up with the Joneses used to mean buying a vacation home, a BMW perhaps, first-class airplane tickets. But your own fleet of planes? These days, though, even the superrich are finding that the rules of the game are being rewritten with each stock market move. In a world of instant windfalls where companies go public without ever earning a profit, a 10-figure fortune buys more freedom than nine, an eight-figure sum buys more than seven. So much so that at least two distinct classes among the rich have emerged -- the haves and the have s'mores.
Even the nearly newest of nouveau riche -- those who made their millions a decade ago in the Wall Street gold rush -- feel out of sorts with the fresh-faced generation filling its coffers today. And that angst pervades almost every conversation about their generally younger, often richer peers from the 90's.
Just ask Nelson Peltz who, in his heyday, was a confidant of Michael R. Milken, the former Drexel Burnham Lambert junk bond maven. Mr. Peltz made much of his wealth investing in troubled companies in the 1980's. No pauper, he caused a stir when he bought the singer Mariah Carey's $20 million estate in Westchester County, N.Y., and he has appeared on the Forbes list of richest executives for almost a decade, with a net worth estimated at $890 million.
"I'm like old money these days," Mr. Peltz complained one afternoon at his office on Park Avenue in Manhattan. "You see these young guys worth $3 billion to $4 billion, and you think to yourself, 'What have I done wrong?' I feel like the guy who has to say to his kids 'Go back to work because we can't make ends meet anymore.' "
O.K., he is joking -- at least a little. But an even bigger contrast between then and now is that people like Mr. Peltz were vilified a decade ago for flaunting their wealth in what was often called the Greed Decade. Not so today. The rich now, an overwhelming number of whom have profited from the technology boom, seem to be lauded as new-economy celebrities and have yet to experience the backlash of a disapproving public. And while some fear that is bound to happen, for now at least the benefits to the economy from new technology is helping to insulate the dot-com wunderkinds from attack.
Yet even this era's more restrained haves, it seems, have lost perspective in this time of fast, abundant riches. Consider Dave Welsh. As senior director for corporate development at Portal Software in Cupertino, Calif., he said, he has a stock option package worth tens of millions of dollars. But that is small change compared with the options given to John Little, Portal's chief executive and founder, who is now worth more than $1 billion.
"I don't have John's money," Mr. Welsh said, almost apologizing. "I'm normal."
True, being worth millions does not count for as much these days. Even the billionaires' club is getting a little crowded. Forbes magazine, in its annual effort to name the richest 400 Americans, counted 267 last year with a net worth of more than $1 billion, compared with just 13 in 1982. But it is not just the growing number that is causing the stir, but more importantly the very visible way in which those riches, mainly derived from stock ownership in newly public companies, can be monitored almost hourly by market watchers and journalists.
"It has created this mania to be rich," said Edward Wolff, a professor of economics at New York University. "The focus on other people's money has created a materialistic and self-serving milieu."
If anyone would know, Mr. Wolff would. For several years, he has been studying wealth and its impact on American society. The number of households with a net worth of more than $10 million, according to his research, has grown fourfold the last decade from about 67,700, to almost 350,000. And corporate executives are pocketing a lot of that money. In 1988, for instance, the average chief executive's salary was 40 times that of the average employee. A decade later, Mr. Wolff said, a chief executive made 400 times what the average employee did.
The wealthy are hitting the jackpot at younger ages, too. Today, 5 of every 100 people in the top 1 percent of the wealthiest Americans are 35 years or younger, compared with a fraction of a percent just 17 years ago. "Wealth today is more of a result of entrepreneurial activity than inheritance," he said. "It's not just the coupon clippers anymore."
If any executive has fast become the model of the new monied class it is Meg Whitman, chief executive of eBay, the online auction site. Two years ago, Ms. Whitman was a little-known marketer selling Teletubbies at the toymaker Hasbro. But today she is seen almost as often as that other most-talked-about female billionaire, Martha Stewart.
In the last year, Ms. Whitman has been on the cover of five magazines (she was anointed one of the most powerful women executives by Fortune); appeared almost 20 times on CNN and CNBC; sat through 15 photo shoots, including sessions for Vanity Fair and Glamour; and been mentioned hundreds of times in major newspapers and magazines. Her net worth (she had stock options worth close to $1 billion, according to recent government filings) is fodder for online chatter.
But that intrusion into her personal life is wearing a little thin. One evening, Ms. Whitman and her family were trapped at an ice cream shop in Palo Alto, Calif., delayed after several strangers grabbed her to chat. And at restaurants, diners whisper and point when she walks in the room.
"You know how you watch movies and you follow a star's career?" she recently mused. "You feel like you know them. But when you meet them, you have to hold yourself back. I think that is a little bit of what is going on now."
As the focus of where wealth is generated most quickly has shifted from Wall Street and Hollywood to Silicon Valley, the scale has escalated as well. Remember when Mr. Milken was chided for making $550 million in salary and bonuses in 1987? Pierre Omidyar, who founded eBay so that his wife would have a place to trade Pez dispensers and is now worth billions, owned stock options worth $661 million the day eBay went public in 1998.
At Harry Winston, the high-end jewelers at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street in Manhattan, a growing army of Internet millionaires barely out of college are splurging on diamond engagement rings at $125,000 to $1 million each.
And one young entrepreneur who could not be with his friends on New Year's Eve had his own affair last fall -- a black-tie dinner at Windows on the World at the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan, where 200 people danced until a wall-size clock brought in for the evening struck midnight. The cost? About $120,000, or $30,000 an hour.
Of course, many on Wall Street have been the beneficiaries of selling shares in Internet companies like eBay to an eager public. But some cannot help missing the spotlight they once enjoyed.
"All these cyberbillionaires, in a perverse way, have put Wall Street in its place," said Michael Biondi, chief executive of Wasserstein Perella & Company, the investment advisory boutique that helped mastermind many of the corporate takeovers of the 1980's.
Dinesh D'Souza, a research scholar at the American Enterprise Institute and author of a forthcoming book, "The Moral Conundrum of Success," said that among the monied class, wealth is less about a dollar figure than how secure a person feels about it. Much of the wealth created these days is tied up in stock option packages that are subject to the vagaries of a volatile stock market. So while a billionaire is assured the same grand life even if his stock price drops in half, someone who is worth, say, $50 million, may not feel so comfortable.
George Bell, chief executive of the Internet portal Excite@Home, acknowledges that he used to track his stock options several times a day after each market tick. But that exhilaration wore off as soon as his wealth became the talk of the party circuit.
"One of the first things people ask is: 'How much are you worth?' " he said. "You kind of laugh at first. But now it has gone out of my psyche. You've got to get over it."
That is not so easy to do. Unlike earlier generations, many of the new rich were raised in middle-class homes and seem awestruck by their good fortune. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon.com, for instance, likens his success to winning the lottery.
But there is a practical side to such humility, too. "The new money doesn't want to separate itself from the population at large," Mr. D'Souza said. "They are not sure they can defend their extravagances."
Mr. D'Souza said the most affluent Americans have an income of at least $10 million a year and assets of $100 million or more. The merely rich earn $1 million to $10 million a year, with assets of $10 million to $100 million. The difference between the two is scale. The rich own two homes, he said, while the superrich own homes around the world. And besides, the superrich get something the merely rich do not. "Great wealth, even if it is paper wealth," he said, "propels people into celebrity."
On a Sunday afternoon last December, a crush of cars filled the parking lot in front of Buck's restaurant in Woodside, Silicon Valley's equivalent of Morton's in West Hollywood. For years, entrepreneurs and wealthy venture capitalists gathered weekdays to discuss ideas over coffee and toast. But Saturdays and Sundays have lately been given over to camera-carrying tourists and television news crews eager to catch a glimpse of a Silicon Valley billionaire, who is now more likely to be holed up in his home miles away.
Such notoriety is producing some fear among many in the entrepreneurial class who are beginning to sense a rising tide of resentment toward those who became too rich, too fast. Most hope they will not be remembered as many of their predecessors of the 1980's were.
"In 20 years if all these people go out and make a difference, there will be no backlash," Mr. Little, the chief executive of Portal Software, said. "But if all they end up with is 14 cars, 3 houses, and the jet -- the symbols of wretched excess -- there will be."

HEADLINE: Accused Killer of 3 Is Linked to Racist Writing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WILKINSBURG, Pa., March 2

 BODY:
A black man accused of killing three people and wounding two in a shooting rampage had anti-white writings in his apartment and singled out whites during the attack, reassuring a black woman in his path, "Not you, sister," the authorities and witnesses said today.
A third victim of the rampage died tonight; two others remain in critical condition. 
 "The general tenor was that he wasn't shooting anybody but whites," Lt. John Brennan said today of the man, Ronald Taylor.
Tonight, the police charged Mr. Taylor with ethnic intimidation, Pennsylvania's term for a hate crime, accusing him of setting fire to his apartment and shooting the men with malicious intent "toward white males," court documents said. The Federal Bureau of Investigation also said it had initiated a civil rights investigation.
District Justice Alberta Thompson asked Mr. Taylor if he had any history of mental illness. He replied yes. No details were available.
Mr. Taylor was initially charged with two counts of criminal homicide, an umbrella charge covering murder and manslaughter in Pennsylvania. The police took him before Judge Thompson tonight and charged him with the hate crime, five counts of aggravated assault, one count of arson, a firearms violation and one count of causing a catastrophe. He is being held without bail on the homicide charges.
Mr. Taylor, a 39-year-old jobless man, is accused of shooting a maintenance worker at his apartment building and four other people at two fast-food restaurants on Wednesday in working-class Wilkinsburg, a town of 22,000 six miles east of Pittsburgh. All five victims were white men.
Mr. Brennan said that when the police searched Mr. Taylor's home on Wednesday night, they found anti-white writings.
Joyce Ambrose, who was briefly held hostage by Mr. Taylor said he told another black woman, "Not you, sister," as he threatened to shoot others.

HEADLINE: In Talks, Union Seeks Big Raise From City

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Leaders of a union representing New York City school safety officers and housing authority workers took a tough line yesterday when they met with city officials to kick off a new round of citywide labor negotiations.
Carl Haynes, president of Teamsters Local 237, demanded that the 18,000 city workers he represents receive a wage increase substantially above inflation and a cash bonus to compensate for the two-year wage freeze the workers accepted in their old contract. 
 Mr. Haynes's local was the first of 100 municipal unions to begin bargaining with city officials as part of a new wave of negotiations that will cover teachers, police officers, firefighters, sanitation workers and others -- close to 300,000 workers in all. Through coordination by the Municipal Labor Coalition, an alliance of municipal unions, each union has agreed to demand a raise substantially higher than inflation.
"For two years, we've witnessed and heard endless discussions about the economic prosperity the city, state and federal governments are enjoying," Mr. Haynes said, "but none of that prosperity has trickled down to city workers. We're saying, 'It is about time.' "
Mr. Haynes's local represents school safety officers, police officers at city-owned hospitals and more than a dozen categories of housing authority workers, including maintenance workers, superintendents and heating technicians. The contract for some of those employees expired on Dec. 31; for others, the contract will expire on March 31. The union's workers make from $20,000 to more than $40,000 a year.
A delegation of 100 representatives from the union met for 90 minutes yesterday with James F. Hanley, the city's labor commissioner. Mr. Haynes and Mr. Hanley said the meeting was devoted to the union's presenting its demands.
"We'll take a look at them, we'll analyze them and we'll get back to them with our own proposals," Mr. Hanley said. "It was an uneventful first session."
Mr. Hanley said that at the next session, which has not been scheduled, he would present the city's demands, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's demand that all wage increases be based on merit. Mr. Haynes denounced that idea, saying managers would award raises based on favoritism and patronage.
Mr. Giuliani announced yesterday that a newly named deputy mayor, Robert M. Harding, would oversee the city's collective bargaining.
One of Mr. Haynes's key demands was for no layoffs in any new contract. He also called for reducing employees' pension contributions, having a cost-of-living adjustment for pension benefits and having a 401(k) retirement plan with an employer match. He also demanded on-site child care and expanded vacations and sick leave.
The Giuliani administration has often said that it will not grant raises unless unions agree to productivity increases that finance the raises. But Mr. Haynes proposed that the city and union share any savings from past and future productivity increases.
"City workers have had no real wage increases in the last 20 years," Mr. Haynes said. "We have answered the city's call time and again for cooperation, taken benefit reductions, deferred funds owed to us, and now it's time for the pendulum to swing the other way. We want our fair share of the pie. We've earned it."

HEADLINE: NYC;
Who Needs Diplomacy In This Town?

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, apparently feeling that he could always use a few more enemies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went on a crusade against the United Nations and its many diplomats who sniffed at New York's parking laws with the disdain they might give an indifferent Burgundy. You may remember how the mutual nyah-nyah's flew.
The mayor was so exercised about unpaid parking fines that he allowed how he didn't care if the United Nations packed up and moved elsewhere. Never mind that his own administration put the diplomats' contribution to the city economy at more than $3 billion a year. 
 For their part, some General Assembly delegates threatened to take the parking dispute to the World Court in The Hague, where issues run more along the lines of NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia and the legal status of the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet. Talk about dumbing down diplomacy, some New Yorkers said.
Eventually, the dust settled. Outrage on Manhattan's East Side, the heart of diplo-land, has turned of late to Donald J. Trump's monster apartment tower on First Avenue, which will dwarf the United Nations complex and everything around it.
But the Great Ticket Tiff seemed worth revisiting, if only because the issue is a hardy perennial, like the circus coming to town or Darryl Strawberry's nose for trouble. If you want to get some New Yorkers' blood boiling, just whisper "diplomats" and "tickets" in the same sentence.
Well, an interesting thing has happened. Mr. Giuliani's browbeating, often an irritant to much of the populace, produced impressive results on this one. Since he made a big deal about foreign scofflaws, the number of parking summonses slapped on diplomats' cars has gone down -- way down.
Last year's total was 44,079, according to the mayor's Office of Operations. That is less than one-third the 1996 figure, 143,508. Naturally, the money owed also declined sharply. The 1996 total was $15.8 million. In 1999, that shrank to $4.8 million, a sum so small it would not keep the city government running for 70 minutes.
This is not a case of the police suddenly sitting on their ticket-writing hands, city officials and diplomats agree. Rather, they say, foreign missions and consulates got the message that the days of blithely tossing summonses into the trash or the paper shredder were over.
Some of the more notorious scofflaws of the past, like old Soviet-bloc countries and Israel, now rent spaces in garages instead of leaving cars wherever they feel like on the street. The results, in some instances, almost qualify for a Ripley's entry.
Russia, long the scofflaw king, received a staggering 32,350 parking summonses in 1996. Last year, it got a paltry 372. Ukraine in the same period dropped to 224 from 2,689; Belarus to 46 from 1,987; Israel to 311 from 4,739.
In the last two years, the city's figures also show, the scofflaw parade has been led by Egypt, followed by three countries whose oil wealth has not kept them from being deadbeats: Nigeria, Indonesia and Kuwait.
"We have spoken with our people and underlined that good relations with the city is one of our main goals," said Kirill Speransky, a spokesman for the Russian Mission. An Israeli official made a similar point. So did Ambassador Sotirios Zackheos of Cyprus, who is chairman of the United Nations Committee on Relations with the Host Country.
"We are more sensitive in respecting the traffic regulations," Mr. Zackheos said. "There is nothing like the crisis situation of three years ago." That goes for the police, too, he added. Officers have been known to single out cars with diplomatic plates, even when legally parked. That sort of harassment has faded, the ambassador said.
MIND you, many countries still refuse to pay the tickets they get. "Give me parking or give me death" remains the attitude at some consulates, a city official said. There is not much that the mayoral bully pulpit can do about it.
Enforcement lies with the State Department, which registers diplomats' cars in every American city. City officials complain that the department has not followed through on an agreement to yank the registration of any car with a year's worth of outstanding tickets.
Still, the improvement is there, enough for Barry Schneider, chairman of Community Board No. 8 on the East Side, to suggest that the police shift gears. "If they're not spending as much time writing tickets for diplomats," he said, "maybe they can go after other violators. There are plenty of them."

HEADLINE: Military Rumblings Over Taiwan

 BODY:
The triangular relationship between China, Taiwan and the United States seems to veer from one crisis to the next. The latest one was provoked last week by Beijing's threat to take over Taiwan by force if island leaders do not soon agree to reunification on the mainland's terms. Now Taiwan and its supporters in the Pentagon and Congress want Washington to provide the island government with four American destroyers equipped with sophisticated Aegis radar and antimissile technology. There must be a more constructive way to manage the sensitive issue of Taiwan's future status. 
 A showdown over Taiwan is in no one's interest. Any Chinese effort to take control of Taiwan by force would risk an armed confrontation with the United States. Taiwan on its own could not long resist a Chinese attack, even with advanced American weapons. An escalation of Chinese threats and American arms sales to Taiwan can only make the equation more explosive. Yet Washington will have little choice but to accept that escalation if China persists in trying to intimidate Taiwan. Fortunately, there is time to pursue other options.
China, which set off this crisis, needs to modify its course. Beijing's pressured approach to reunification is not productive. Someday it may be possible to work out a political arrangement that both mainlanders and Taiwanese find acceptable. But that is not feasible today. China should back off from its threats before they do lasting damage to its important relationship with the United States.
Taiwan has recently shown greater sensitivity in its own approach to the reunification issue. It has stepped away from provocative suggestions that its leaders were preparing for independence. But at this point it should not be clamoring for the Aegis destroyers, one of America's most technologically advanced weapons systems and one that has never been sold abroad completely equipped. Even with these destroyers, which would probably not be delivered for five years and not become operational for several more, Taiwan would not, on its own, be able to withstand a full-fledged Chinese attack.
Washington, for its part, should urge moderation on both sides, while not stepping back from its promise to treat any forcible attempt to reunite Taiwan with the mainland as a matter of grave concern to the United States.
It would be beneficial to America, China and Taiwan to see Beijing admitted to the World Trade Organization under the reasonable terms negotiated last year. But China is now pressing its luck in Washington. Its bullying attitude toward Taiwan will increase Congressional opposition to W.T.O. membership. The longer-term risk is that continued Chinese threats could lead to dangerous military tensions in the Taiwan Strait. That would be the least promising way to deal with Taiwan's future.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Directors Fail to Rally Around Any New Leader in Poll

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Directors of the International Monetary Fund failed today to rally around any of the people who want to lead the world financial institution, and expectations rose that Europe would search for a new candidate to keep its half-century lock on the job.
The European, American and Japanese contenders for the fund's top post all fell short of a majority of the votes in a straw poll. No further poll was scheduled, and people involved in the selection process said it could now take weeks to choose a replacement for Michel Camdessus, the Frenchman who recently retired as managing director. 
 The vote result, which was not a surprise, confirmed that Germany had misjudged its chances of rallying support for Caio Koch-Weser, a deputy finance minister whom Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany aggressively pushed for the job during a four-month campaign. Germany backed Mr. Koch-Weser despite public opposition from the United States and a lukewarm endorsement by European allies.
Mr. Koch-Weser got 43 percent of the votes in the straw poll, people involved in the process said. That was a modest margin over the nearly 37 percent of the votes that the European Union controls. Stanley Fischer, the American candidate nominated by a coalition of African and Arab countries, placed a distant second, with 12 percent. The Japanese favorite, Eisuke Sakakibara, a former finance ministry official, got 9 percent.
The United States abstained, as did many other countries, and 36 percent of the votes were not cast for any candidate.
European Union officials expressed hopes that Germany would admit defeat and allow the 15-nation European Union, which had formally endorsed Mr. Koch-Weser earlier this week, to search for a new candidate. Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, told European reporters today that Mr. Koch-Weser's candidacy was effectively dead and that Europe should find someone the United States could support.
German officials sent no clear signals about their next move. European and American participants in the process speculated that Germany, which has surprised people with the tenacity of its campaign so far, could try to force a second vote.
At the least, these people said, Germany could seek to extract diplomatic concessions from European partners before agreeing to clear the way for a new I.M.F. candidate. The fear was that such maneuvering could take weeks, leaving the I.M.F. leadership in limbo.
Even so, attention quickly turned to other possible European candidates. Clinton administrations officials have said that they intend to back a European for the job, a tradition that dates to the founding of the monetary fund just after World War II. Americans have historically run the I.M.F.'s sister institution, the World Bank.
President Clinton, speaking before the vote, reiterated that line today. "I am completely committed to having a European head of the I.M.F.," he said. In an apparent attempt to soothe wounded German pride after the United States rejected Mr. Koch-Weser, Mr. Clinton also said he would like see other German candidates.
"I'd like to see Germany play a bigger role in all these international institutions," the president said.
While there are no other publicly declared European candidates, speculation has focused on five people. Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, is considered a possibility if he is willing to put aside ambitions to succeed Tony Blair as prime minister. Andrew Crockett, a Briton who heads the Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland, has a solid reputation in financial circles. There is a question, however, whether Germany could accept him, because he is not viewed as having substantially greater political stature than Mr. Koch-Weser.
The French have a potential heavyweight candidate in Jean-Claude Trichet, the head of the Bank of France. But Mr. Trichet would have to sacrifice plans to head the European Central Bank to take the I.M.F. post. Two Italians, Treasury Minister Giuliano Amato, and Mario Draghi, a senior Italian Treasury official, are both seen as experienced in finance and likely to be interested in the I.M.F. job.
Aside from Germany, the big losers in the process were the 20 African and Arab countries that on their own decided to nominate Mr. Fischer, the popular deputy director of the fund, risking German contempt for failing to support its choice. Delegates of those countries had clearly hoped that their bid would sooner or later attract the support of the United States. Mr. Fischer, a former professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is highly regarded by the Treasury Department.
President Clinton appeared to rule out the Fischer possibility today. He said that he admired Mr. Fischer, but would not turn away from Europe. "I will not support an American candidate even though I have enormous respect for Mr. Fisher," he said.
Still, some people involved said there was a set of circumstances in which Mr. Fischer could get the job. In this case, Europe would decide that it needed more time to settle on a qualified candidate and would agree to throw its weight behind Mr. Fischer, perhaps for an interim term of two years.
