HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
From Old Buenos Aires to a Brave New World

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
BUENOS AIRES 1910: Memories of the World to Come" is the latest ripple in a wave that has been undulating through art, architecture and entertainment for almost a generation: the rise of the City as an icon for cultural globalization. In museum shows, scholarly books and MTV dance marathons, not to mention tourism promotions, individual cities are being recast as the neighborhoods of one vast cosmopolitan condition. Images of Moscow, New York, Prague, Brasilia, Berlin, Vienna, Lisbon, Chicago, Havana, Dublin, Lagos, Macao, Barcelona and others are converging like segments of an ever-expanding Baedeker map. The Buenos Aires show, on view at the World Financial Center, adds a few new folds.
First presented last year in Buenos Aires, the show was organized by Margarita Gutman, a professor of urban history at the University of Buenos Aires, in association with the Getty Research Institute for the History of Art and the Humanities. Incorporating more than 500 photographs, drawings, maps and miscellaneous ephemera, "Buenos Aires 1910" documents one of the 20th century's most dramatic stories of urban growth. In 1910, Argentina staged a massive nationwide celebration to honor the centenary of its independence from Spain. The modernization of the capital city was the main focus of the event. Architects and engineers drew up extensive plans -- some practical, others fantastic -- to guide Buenos Aires into the future. The remaining vestiges of colonialism were to be cast aside as the city remade itself in the image of a modern cosmopolis. 
 In 1895, 15 years after Buenos Aires became Argentina's capital, the city's population was 663,000. Today, the metropolitan region is home to 12 million souls. The pivot for this explosive growth was 1910, a moment when the city gave itself permission to face the future. Like the 19th-century industrial cities in Europe and the United States, Buenos Aires confronted the need for physical expansion beyond a dense historical core. Local opinion was divided over what form the expansion should take. One group favored a grid of straight streets. Another faction fought for diagonal avenues.
In 1909, the government adopted the Centennial Plan, devised by Joseph M. Bouvard, chief of public works in Paris. Incorporating a grid overlaid with diagonals, like Pierre L'Enfant's plan for Washington, Bouvard's plan was arranged in the form of a fan, with the Plata River port lying at the handle end of the design. The diagonal avenues radiated inland from the riverfront, which is in the southwest corner of the city. In effect, the plan was a microcosm of the entire country, with the port occupying the position of Buenos Aires on the map. Only portions of this plan were realized.
Drawings and photographs of public spaces and transportation infrastructure make up the core of the show. Massive new bridges, a subway system, parks, avenues and highways, along with industrial fairs dedicated to the cars that would use them: these feats of engineering, landscape and industry laid down the capital's connective tissue. Examples of iron fabrication, like the hulking black piers of the Nicolas Avellaneda transport bridge, were permanent versions of the scaffolding that covered much of Buenos Aires in 1910, when the city was an immense construction site.
In counterpoint to the city's mostly horizontal infrastructure, the show presents a series of images that point the way toward the development of Buenos Aires as a vertical city. Elevated highways, train viaducts, airplane and balloon corridors are layered above the streets to serve the city as its buildings increased in height. One particularly imaginative plan published in a leading newspaper depicts an elevated train in the form of a roller coaster ride that soars and dips precariously over the roofline.
Like the fantastic renderings of New York in the same era, these pictures lie halfway between architecture and advertising. They are posters in a campaign to promote an image of progress as yet unsullied by the social upheaval and environmental degradation that technology would bring in its wake. The new Buenos Aires was to be more than a symbol of national pride. It represented a bid for membership in the international community of advanced industrial production. In effect, the city became a permanent world's fair, dedicated to international trade. As one writer observes in the show's impressive catalog, the city was the country's calling card on the world stage.
Photographs of the centennial events are among the show's most captivating images. Anticipating the rise of the theme park metropolis, they depict the citizens surging through streets adorned with banners and festive lighting, as if they were a grand opera chorus. Other sections of the show document more ephemeral forms of the urban spectacle. Pop songs. Newspapers. Centennial souvenirs. Nightclubs. Cafes. An appearance by Halley's comet. And that rousingly theatrical vision of stylized sex, the tango, a dance that has done infinitely more than architecture to broadcast the idea of Buenos Aires abroad.
In 1910, it took two men to tango. The show is somewhat coy about this social arrangement. We are shown a provocative picture of male couples dancing, big bruisers dressed in butchers' aprons. But we are not told why a dance considered too racy for women to perform in public would be acceptable when danced by men. We can speculate about the reasons, but it would be useful to have the phenomenon explained. How a culture handles dualisms in one area of life can shed light on others. It took two to design Buenos Aires, too, as we see in the implicit dichotomies between architecture and engineering, vertical and horizontal, the grid and the diagonal plans.
Tucked away toward the rear of the show is a section on social conflict, featuring pictures of striking workers, brandished copies of left-wing newspapers and an anarchist bomb explosion at the grand Teatro Colon in 1910. The section illustrates the severity of political oppression during the centennial events. The creation of an industrial society was contingent on the fear provoked by censorship, mass arrests and other police operations. The classical order of Beaux-Arts architecture represented the unattainable ideal of a society torn apart by its progressive ambitions.
Craig Hodgetts and Ming Fung, two architects based in Los Angeles, designed the show's installation for its original presentation in Buenos Aires last year. Their design's handsome metal armature has been retained for New York, but the show's setting is otherwise disagreeable. The presentation has been split in two. One half is installed on the northern pedestrian bridge of the World Financial Center, the other on a balcony-level gallery adjacent to Cesar Pelli's Winter Garden. This arrangement creates problems with continuity and access. In addition, the bridge is in the midst of a remodeling. The gallery looks like an afterthought to the restaurant court below. It is disheartening that New York cannot provide a more receptive venue for such an intelligent exhibition.
There are, however, lessons to be gained from contrasting the show to its surroundings. The appeal of City shows like this one lies in their representation of cultural difference. The message at the World Financial Center, by contrast, is homogenization. With its corporate architecture, mall-like shops and airport-style eating spots, the Winter Garden is Manhattan's foremost example of the monoculture, the prefabricated environment brought into being by mass tourism, business travel and industrial standardization. The retro design of Battery Park City's apartment buildings adds to the theme park effect.
In this alien setting, visitors are unintentionally prompted to see the growth of Buenos Aires as symptomatic of the monoculture's industrial roots. Although the city tried to shed its colonial image, it packaged its future in a Beaux-Arts image. This was the image pursued by many European and American cities in the late 19th century. It was, by design, an international style. Difference mattered less than similarity. All the calling cards were printed in the same cursive script.
It is not that big a stretch from this way of thinking to the outlook embodied at the World Financial Center, which is essentially an airport without planes. In this complex of buildings designed by Mr. Pelli (a native of Argentina, coincidentally), the Beaux-Arts model has been run through an edge-city processor. The place offers the illusion of public space within a high-security environment patrolled by private guards.
This context puts a sinister spin on the use of urban history to enrich the promise of cultural globalization. The tendency today is to look at the emerging global culture in optimistic terms. Many of us look forward to a time that will respect cultural difference, a time when the West will surrender its colonial insistence on judging other civilizations according to our terms. Ideally, shows like "Buenos Aires 1910" should support global diversity.
It could be, however, that shows like this are just diversions from the homogenization of everything urban. At the World Financial Center (home of American Express), we stand on the brink of a time when older urban centers have themselves become edge cities, providing hotel rooms, work stations, duty-free shopping and "authentic" historical entertainment. Urban populations, meanwhile, are transformed into the Mickeys, Minnies, Snow Whites and Goofys of their hometowns. Airplanes may not fly through the streets, as envisioned by the architects of Buenos Aires, but entire cities may be reduced to picturesque service centers for air carrier hubs. In fact, the consortium Aeropuertos Argentina 2000 is credited as national benefactor for the New York presentation of this fine traveling show.
"Buenos Aires 1910: Memories of the World to Come" is at the World Financial Center, Courtyard Gallery and North Bridge, 225 Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, through March 26. In conjunction with the exhibition, there will be free performances celebrating Argentina's music, dance, literature and cultural heritage. Information: (212) 945-0505.
All around, hopeful entrepreneurs are treasuring new patents like geese ready to lay golden eggs. Stephen D. Messer, for example, is building an Internet business called LinkShare around a patent he got in November on managing referral fees for traffic between affiliated Web sites. His sister, Heidi Messer, a lawyer who is now LinkShare's president, encouraged him to apply for the patent on his idea. "When he told it to me, I thought it was profound," she says.
He's a believer in patents now. "Without the patent system, I never would have done what I did," he says. "Without the patent system you create a world where pirates have the advantage and pioneers are penalized."
As for one-click ordering, a final verdict could be years away, and in the meantime, online merchants will have to be careful. Mothernature .com already has one-click remedy packs. Safe Harbor has one-click ordering of digital video products. Are they patent infringers?
"I think the beauty of the patent law is, it encourages innovation, because it says, look, we challenge you to come up with a better way," says Heidi Messer.
"Somebody out there," says Stephen, "I guarantee you, probably sitting in a garage right now, has an idea that does zero-click."
Heidi laughs. "Telekinetic!"
Telekinesis would be worth patenting. Meanwhile, much of the value of the patent system lies in the disclosure of technologies that might otherwise be hoarded as trade secrets. But when Barnes & Noble decided to implement one-click ordering, its programmers did not need to see Amazon's patent. The software techniques are transparent. Any Internet company with a decent programmer at hand could imitate Amazon's system without breaking a sweat and without copying its actual code.
This isn't rocket science, in other words. I say as much to Commissioner Dickinson. He is unruffled; evidently he has heard it before. "We don't patent only rocket science," he says. "We patent football-helmet mailboxes." And indeed they do. Sportsbox Inc., a k a a couple of guys in Richmond, Ky., owns the patent for mailboxes built in the shape of football helmets; before you make one, you'd better get their permission.
Dickinson, who practiced as a corporate intellectual property lawyer for 25 years before taking over the patent office, says the law prohibits him from discussing any particular patent. (The patent office forbids its examiners to speak to the press at all, and the examiners who did talk about their work for this article insisted that their names be withheld.) Still, he can't resist revealing some pride in the progress of the Amazon case so far. "It's interesting because it's one of the first Internet patents to come to at least one conclusory stage of the litigation process," he says. "A federal judge found that the patent was sufficiently valid to issue a preliminary injunction, which is a rather extraordinary thing, right in the face of the Christmas holiday season. I thought that was kind of amazing, to be honest, and tends to suggest that the patent has validity."
In making her preliminary finding that Barnes & Noble infringed the Amazon patent, Judge Marsha J. Peckman in Seattle did not have to examine the underlying software code. Just how Barnes & Noble implemented one-click ordering doesn't matter. Any single-action ordering system violates Amazon's exclusive rights, she found. She also expressed a public-interest argument: "Innovation will be discouraged if competitors are permitted a free ride on each other's patented inventions," she declared.
The commissioner agrees. "The patent system has done its job for two centuries of protecting and nurturing and rewarding innovation. The system has worked."
But the digital revolution worked without patents. The great bursts of technological innovation of the past two decades, the rise of personal-computer software and the spread of the Internet, took place in a freewheeling and competitive climate, with ideas bouncing at light speed from one place to another. A little head start in this world goes a long way; in the digital economy, "first movers" gain a tremendous and possibly long-lasting advantage, without extra government fortification. The greatest successes, like Microsoft and America Online, had nothing to do with patent protection. Amazon did not need patents to grow from Jeff Bezos' garage to its current pre-eminence.
Only Congress can now return the patent system to its time-honored role as a catalyst for innovation, rather than a concentrator of economic power. "For limited times," the Constitution says -- and the generations of technology pass much more quickly now than they did in 1790. We want to reward inventors with a head start, not a lifetime entitlement. "Perhaps on the Internet, patents should last one 'Internet lifetime,' which is about two years," says Greg E. Blonder, a longtime researcher and vice president at Bell Labs and now "entrepreneur in residence" at AT&T Ventures.
This is a crowded and densely packed world; when a software engineer at I.B.M. comes up with a new idea, it's usually safe to bet that hundreds of software engineers in cubbyholes around the world are thinking along the same lines. Blonder himself has more than 60 patents to his name: toys, consumer electronics, software and business methods. He often gathers technologists for daylong brainstorming sessions; typically, these groups produce hundreds of useful "ideas," of which perhaps one in 10 turns out to be truly novel. "Problem is," Blonder says, "had I gathered together a different group of a dozen people, they'd come up with practically the same list. Arguably, any idea generated so easily and frequently is both obvious and a dubious candidate for a 20-year government-sanctioned monopoly."
Patents should be the exception, not the rule, he says. "As to my own business-process patents, well, as long as everyone in town is carrying a gun, I have to be armed as well. But I'd be glad to see the system change."
One thing is certain: the modern Internet entrepreneur is not a species in need of extra government incentives. If one-click ordering had not been patentable, surely Jeff Bezos would have invented it anyway in May 1997, put it to work in September 1998 and seen it copied in subsequent years by Barnes & Noble and thousands of other Internet merchants, all learning from his success, to the benefit of consumers. Surely he would have become a very rich man; and his future success would depend on his ability to continue outperforming his competitors, and to continue innovating.

 CORRECTION:
A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on March 3 about the exhibition "Buenos Aires 1910: Memories of the World to Come," at the World Financial Center in Lower Manhattan through March 26, misstated the location of the Plata River port in Buenos Aires. It is on the east side of the city, not in the southwest corner.
An article on Page 44 of The Times Magazine today about patents and Amazon.com's patented 1-Click method of online shopping makes several references to the 20-year duration of patents and the potential for stifling innovation in e-commerce. On Thursday, after the magazine went to press, Jeffrey Bezos, the chairman of Amazon.com, proposed that patents for software or business models expire after three to five years, and that the change be retroactive, covering his company's patents.

HEADLINE: Job Growth in February Way Off the RecentPace, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Job growth suddenly weakened in February, the Labor Department reported yesterday, but almost nothing in the unexpectedly sharp decline suggested a softening of the economy itself.
Employment grew by 43,000 jobs, way off the recent pace of 250,000 or more a month, and the unemployment rate edged up to 4.1 percent from 4 percent. But the February performance was mostly a result of abnormal weather, economists said. An unusually warm January had caused a surge in outdoor jobs, especially in construction, and those jobs disappeared in the colder February weather. 
 "This is one of the more remarkably irrelevant job reports that we have seen for some time," said William Dudley, chief United States economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company. "There are plenty of indicators that show the economy is still really quite strong."
Stock market investors, however, took a different tack. They seemed to see in the weak employment report a sign that the Federal Reserve would not have to raise interest rates that much after all because the economy was beginning to slow on its own. So they bought stocks with abandon, driving up the Dow Jones industrial average by 202.28 points, or 1.99 percent, to 10,367.20. Nasdaq, where most Internet stocks are traded, jumped even more, to another record.
That bullishness may turn out to be self-destructive. The Federal Reserve seeks to slow the booming economy to avert inflationary shortages of goods and services. But the Fed also seeks to slow the stock market, on the ground that the growing market wealth encourages people to spend freely, and thus contributes to the inflationary shortages.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, made these points in Congressional testimony last week. He warned, in effect, that the Fed will raise interest rates in coming months partly to cool the stock market. Stock prices plunged after his remarks, but they have been recovering all this week and the February employment report only fed the bounceback -- almost in defiance of Mr. Greenspan's warnings.
"The market could compel the Fed to raise interest rates even more than it had planned," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities.
The Clinton administration stressed the economy's strength. Alexis Herman, the Labor Secretary, noted that although job growth in February was the smallest number since last May, when only 28,000 new jobs were created, the performance is much better when viewed over a longer period. The surge in January created 384,000 new jobs, so the monthly average for January and February was 214,000, she said, and that was not much below the 1999 average of 226,000.
"I don't think there is anything in this report that shows the economy is weakening," Ms. Herman said.
The wage measure included in the employment report also showed no sign of rising. Average hourly earnings for production workers -- one measure of whether a tight labor market is forcing employers to raise wages -- went up only 6 cents, or 0.3 of a percent, leaving this measure of wage growth hovering, as it has for months, at a mild annual rate of 3.6 percent.
What stood out in this report were construction workers. In the unusual January weather, the construction industry added 116,000 jobs, but in February it lost 26,000 jobs -- a huge downward shift.
Much slower growth in service sector jobs, however, was harder for economists to explain. The overall rise in this category was only 62,000 jobs -- way below the monthly norm of 200,000 or so, and the smallest increase since August 1997. The biggest falloff was in the service category that includes office work, computer processing, ski resorts, amusement and recreation, health care and temporary-help agencies. Here the job growth was only 6,000, the smallest increase since April 1991, at the end of the last recession.
"This may suggest that we have had some softening in consumer spending on services in February relative to the very strong showing in January," said Kenneth J. Matheny, senior economist at Macroeconomic Advisers, a forecasting and data gathering firm in St. Louis.
Some of the falloff was also weather related: outdoor work in restaurants and amusement centers fell, for example. But so did jobs in transportation, particularly trucking, where rising fuel prices appear to be taking a toll. And rising mortgage rates appear to have reduced employment in the mortgage industry, said Thomas Nardone, chief of the division at the Bureau of Labor Statistics that prepares the employment reports.
Manufacturing jobs, on the other hand, are beginning to revive, rising by 5,000 last month and 31,000 since October after having fallen by 527,000 over the previous 18 months. Overtime in manufacturing also edged up. And with energy prices rising, a more profitable oil and gas industry added 9,000 jobs last month.
For the country as a whole, the small February gain in new jobs, while pushing total employment to 130.33 million, produced very little change in the unemployment rates for men, women, blacks and Hispanics. Teenage unemployment rose to 14.1 percent from 12.6 percent.
For the labor force as a whole, however, the pool of people who might be drawn into seeking and taking jobs seemed smaller than ever.
The work force as a percentage of the total population is now a record 64.8 percent, the level reached in January from 64.4 percent in December. The labor force participation rate -- that is, not only all those employed but also those who are unemployed but actively seeking jobs -- rose to a record 67.6 percent of the population from 67.5 percent in January.
For unemployed workers, the average time they remained without landing a job has fallen to 12.5 weeks from 13.8 over the last year, the lowest level since the last recession. And the unemployment rate among people with less than a high school education is now only 6 percent, the lowest level since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began tracking this group in 1992.

HEADLINE: New York's Economy, Through Another Lens

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Jobs Data for 1999 Paint a Rosier Picture for Upstate New York" (news article, March 2):
It may be a little premature for Gov. George E. Pataki to herald the turnaround of the upstate economy. At least 40 percent of the private job gain last year occurred in industries like retail and social services, where the average wages are 40 percent below the average for all workers in New York State (leaving aside Wall Street jobs where the pay is off the charts). 
 With many of these new jobs paying about $25,000 a year, the state has a long way to go before it can make up for the 400,000 middle-income jobs that it has lost over the last decade.
It is also puzzling that Mr. Pataki links job growth to his tax cuts, since more than one in five of all jobs added last year occurred in sectors (health and social services and education) heavily affected by government spending.
 
JAMES A. PARROTT
Deputy Director
Fiscal Policy Institute
New York, March 2, 2000

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Uncertainty in Thailand Over a Big Bankruptcy Case

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, March 3

 BODY:
A bitter bankruptcy court struggle between Thailand's largest corporate borrower and its creditors has generated considerable uncertainty over the fate of billions of dollars in unpaid loans in the country where the Asia financial crisis began.
For the last two years, Thai Petrochemical Industry has been talking with creditors about how to begin repaying $3.5 billion in debts it defaulted on when the crisis struck. In early February, the company balked at a deal that would leave its family owners in charge but declare it insolvent. It was not insolvent, Thai Petrochemical protested. Exasperated lenders, which include not only Thailand's largest bank but the World Bank's International Finance Corporation and the United States Export-Import Bank, petitioned Thailand's fledgling bankruptcy court to let them take over the company. 
 The court said Thursday that it would decide on March 15, but more than the company's fate appears to hang on the outcome. As the dispute escalated last month, foreign investors headed for the exits, sending Thailand's benchmark stock index tumbling almost 20 percent last month, to four-month lows.
"The big issue here is debt restructuring," said Therapong Vachirapong, a strategist at Merrill Lynch in Bangkok. "People now realize it's a bit more difficult than they thought."
The strength of investors' reaction is giving some economists a sense of repetition: only weeks ago, the International Monetary Fund declared Thailand's financial crisis over and said that the economy could expand by 5 percent this year.
Thailand's banks have already restructured about one trillion baht, or $26.4 billion, in loans, according to the central bank's corporate debt restructuring advisory committee.
But so far, the restructuring agreements have been largely consensual. Now comes the hard part, analysts say. The problems at Thai Petrochemical trouble investors not only because the company is Thailand's largest corporate debtor, but because of what it may mean for attempts to recover some of the two trillion baht in nonperforming loans that remain and the more than 400 lawsuits to recover them filed by creditors in Thailand's new bankruptcy court.
"People are worried about whether the court is going to work," said Donaldson Hartman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in Bangkok.
Thai Petrochemical was established in 1978 by an ethnic Chinese family of rice traders, the Leophairatanas. To this day Prachai Leophairatana remains the chief executive, overseeing a plastics and gasoline business that turned the family members into billionaires in the mid-1990's.
The devaluation of the baht in July 1997, however, nearly doubled Thai Petrochemical's debt as measured in local currency. Talks with creditors quickly degenerated into what has become a bitter soap opera, as Mr. Prachai and the company's nearly 150 lenders feud over how much ownership the family must surrender.
About a year ago, the two sides reached a tentative agreement that in exchange for $300 million to $400 million in accrued interest, the company would give creditors a 30 percent stake and reduce the family's stake to 40 percent from roughly 60 percent. Mr. Prachai would retain control, but if the company failed to meet interest payments, lenders could raise their stake to 75 percent.
In December, Mr. Prachai sought to change the terms. Creditors refused and set a January deadline for Mr. Prachai to agree to a court-supervised restructuring deal or be taken to court involuntarily. The company objected and a court hearing began Wednesday.
Legal experts say the case highlights remaining weaknesses in Thailand's bankruptcy and foreclosure laws. Though both laws were strengthened after the financial crisis struck, the bankruptcy law still has problems inherent in the original version that Thailand adopted decades ago from Britain, according to Sutee Supanit, a law professor at Thammasat University in Bangkok. Foremost among its shortcomings, experts say, is that the creditor must prove that a company is insolvent.
Thai Petrochemical's defense is that it is not insolvent: assets exceed liabilities. Creditors dispute that interpretation, saying the company has not paid debts in two years and is therefore insolvent.
In English, both conditions fit the definition of insolvent. The problem is that in the Thai legal lexicon, Mr. Sutee said, the word for insolvent means liabilities that exceed a debtor's assets. An inability to pay debts on time, on the other hand, is described by a different Thai word that translates roughly into "overindebtedness" and is not provided for under the law.
To decide in favor of Thai Petrochemical's lenders, Mr. Sutee said, the judge hearing the case will have to expand the interpretation of insolvency.
The dispute has helped accelerate an exodus of foreign money from Thailand's stock market.

HEADLINE: Clinton Calls for Stronger Measures to Protect the Privacy of Computer Users

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 3

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he considered cyberspace too insecure for him to correspond privately by e-mail with his daughter, Chelsea, who is away at college. In the same speech to high-tech executives here in the heart of Silicon Valley, Mr. Clinton also called on the industry to enhance computer privacy to reassure many people like himself who are still wary of the new technology.
And the president issued a memorandum to the heads of federal departments, urging them to increase the safeguards of federal computers against intrusions like the recent attacks that overloaded and shut down major Web sites. 
Privacy rights in cyberspace received renewed attention this week with the decision by DoubleClick Inc., the nation's largest online advertising company, to back off from a plan to combine information it collected about Internet users' Web surfing habits with data about their offline consumer behavior.
During a technology forum at the offices of Novell Inc., a software company, Mr. Clinton said the federal government ought to get involved in protecting the privacy of financial information and medical records on the Internet. But he called on the industry to police itself in other areas. Already, Mr. Clinton said, 66 percent of the commercial Web sites have privacy standards, up from 15 percent a year ago.
"We know we have to keep cyberspace open and free because it sparks creativity and innovation, because its infinite networks can do so much to bring us together," he said. "But we also know that cyberspace must be a community of shared responsibilities and common values."
Eric Schmidt, chairman and chief executive of Novell and one of Mr. Clinton's supporters in the industry, said, "What was new was the emphasis on privacy and security. It was the first time he had talked about that with that kind of coherence as an initiative."
Asked whether those were areas better left to self-regulation by his industry, Mr. Schmidt said: "There are certain things the government can do, and the president clearly stated what those are -- medical records, financial records, children. As long as the role of government is properly defined, I think most people would agree with that."
At the forum, organized by the Aspen Institute, Mr. Clinton told the high-tech executives that computer users deserved notice about what personal information was being collected and how it would be used, and should be able to choose whether the data would be shared with others.
"You know, ordinary folks, even people who aren't online yet, are very excited about the prospects of this age so many of you have done so much to create," Mr. Clinton told the executives, including the executives of such Silicon Valley powerhouses as Yahoo, Cisco Systems and Siebel Systems. "But they are really concerned about this. They are afraid they will have no place to hide."
After his speech, Mr. Clinton said in a brief interview that he was one of those people wary about sending information through cyberspace.
"I won't send e-mail to Chelsea because I don't think it's secure," he said.
The president added that once he left office next year he would probably not be as concerned about his electronic communications.
Mr. Clinton admits he is a novice when it comes to the Internet. Just last week, during a fund-raising visit to Florida, he marveled at something as mundane as a screen saver. Before Christmas last year, Mr. Clinton ordered some gifts over the Internet, an experience he still talks about in his speeches.
"Yesterday, we got a new benchmark for the new economy when the Department of Commerce released its first ever quarterly report on e-commerce," he said today, "telling us the Internet sales from the fourth quarter of last year, the holiday season, were $5.3 billion -- about $65 of those attributable to the president."
Mr. Clinton's anxiety over e-mail messaging will clearly not stop him from communicating with his daughter. He said they spoke on the phone, and in between a string of fund-raisers in San Francisco and Los Angeles tonight and Saturday that will raise $1.6 million for the Democrats, Mr. Clinton plans to spend time, face-to-face, with Chelsea in Palo Alto, Calif.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
The Menace Of A.T.M.'s: Convenience

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
THE New York City Council is about to consider banning a baffling new menace to consumers. What's baffling is the way it afflicts its victims. They succumb in a two-step process:
1. They go to an A.T.M. at a bank where they don't have an account, and must therefore pay a surcharge. Typically it's $1 or $1.50 -- an "unfair and unconscionable" amount, according to a report by the Council's staff. Because of this "price gouging," the report notes, "consumers may find themselves paying fees that are a large percentage of the money they are desperately attempting to save." 
 2. The next time they need cash, these gouged and desperate consumers cannot be bothered to go to a machine at their own bank.
How to explain such behavior? If you were not a member of the City Council, you might think it is similar to paying extra for orange juice at the corner store instead of walking to the supermarket. Perhaps $1.50 doesn't strike people as an unconscionable fee for convenience. Since the surcharges were introduced in 1996, the number of new A.T.M.'s has soared to meet consumer demand.
Are consumers being hoodwinked? Even though the machines explicitly warn them of the surcharge, do they remain unaware of it? No, according to the Council's own survey of 800 New Yorkers. It found that 90 percent of the people using machines not operated by their own banks knew they were paying a surcharge.
You might also think that banning the surcharges, as council members are promising to do, would leave consumers with fewer choices. It would presumably become unprofitable to operate the machines in some out-of-the-way places that didn't have them before the surcharges.
Some banks in New York might also stop allowing outsiders to use their machines, just as banks in California did after the surcharges were banned there. Chase Manhattan, which operates the largest network of A.T.M.'s, has already raised the obvious question: Why would it make its customers wait in line behind noncustomers who aren't paying the surcharge?
You don't have to be a banker to entertain these thoughts. Robert H. Frank, an economist at Cornell University, drew a blank when he was asked to suggest a colleague of any political persuasion who would defend the City Council's legislation.
"I can't think of a single reputable economist who would speak in favor of that kind of regulation," Dr. Frank said. "One thing that has made travel so much easier these days is that A.T.M.'s have eliminated the frantic stop at the bank on the way to the airport. But cash machines are costly, and if regulators succeed in protecting us from being charged for using them, banks won't continue to serve out-of-town travelers."
Those concerns were dismissed by Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, one of the chief sponsors of the legislation.
"I can't believe that the banks here will alienate the public by taking out A.T.M.'s or cutting off access," he said. He also dismissed the possibility that the legislation would discourage the installation of more machines.
"In the city of New York," he said, "I think we already have a maximum build-out for A.T.M.'s." He did not explain how he had divined that the current network is precisely the maximum size for a city of seven million, now and forever.
WHY does the City Council have any more right to set A.T.M. fees than it does to set the price of orange juice at the corner store, or the price of this newspaper?
Mr. McCaffrey said banking is different because the industry is already regulated. He also pointed to the public's desire to ban the surcharges, as evidenced by the passage of a referendum in San Francisco.
"People voted 2 to 1 in favor of it in San Francisco," he said. "What are you supposed to do? Ignore public opinion? Tell people that their votes don't matter?"
That's a good question. You could argue that this sort of populist uprising is not so much democracy as tyranny of the majority: a majority of voters willing to appropriate money from the small number of bankers and other people who invested in setting up the cash machines.
But you could also argue that the majority has a right to impose price controls, no matter how stupid and counterproductive they seem to economists. If the economists are right, the people will just have to make do with fewer cash machines and longer lines. They will have won the right to inconvenience.

LENGTH: 1524 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Race Challenges Loyalties, and Families

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: EASTCHESTER, N.Y., March 2

 BODY:
The Odyssey Diner here is one of those old-fashioned political hangouts, where establishment pols, mostly Republicans, gather at the counter or in a side room to hash things out over the famous cheesecake and coffee courtesy of the affable Doukases, who have run the place for 27 years.
But the stiff competition among the G.O.P. candidates and the approach of the New York primary on Tuesday have enlivened the discourse here, even among the Doukas family. They unwittingly served up an example of the split among Republican voters in this 336-year-old town of mansions and Cape Cod-style homes when it comes to George W. Bush and John McCain. 
 George Doukas, the proprietor, scoffed at the televised face of Senator McCain as he spoke during a television news report while Mr. Doukas played backgammon. Mr. Doukas firmly declared his commitment to Governor Bush, aligning himself with the county Republican establishment, including this Westchester County town's supervisor, James E. Cavanaugh, who is the newly anointed county party leader and a firm Bush man.
"I think Bush has the better chance of winning," said Mr. Doukas, 65, who owns the diner with his family. "He seems to have done a good job in Texas and has a good record there."
But just as the G.O.P. as a whole has not united behind Mr. Bush, neither have the Doukases. Standing a few feet away at the register, Angela, Mr. Doukas's wife, just as firmly declared her commitment to Mr. McCain, of Arizona.
"When he lost in South Carolina he made that speech and what he said stuck in my heart," said Mrs. Doukas, 61. "He said we will go forth, but he congratulated Bush even though they fought so much. It just showed what a strong gentleman he is.
"I think he will look out for the older people, for Medicare."
While far from being a scientific sounding, 28 interviews with registered Republicans over two days here and in the two self-governing villages this town encompasses -- Tuckahoe and Bronxville -- suggested an electorate tuned to the primary campaign but sometimes ambivalent about the choices a few days before the Tuesday primary.
There was hope for Mr. McCain in people like Mrs. Doukas, willing to buck the conventional wisdom and even to risk domestic bliss for their man.
But Mr. Bush can take comfort, too, in the likes of Mr. Doukas and William Carlson, a 69-year-old semi-retired sales representative who said he was turned off by reports of Mr. McCain's negative campaigning by telephone. Besides, Mr. Carlson said, Mr. Bush stands firm on conservative principles and served as governor of a large "tough state."
"He has done a lot of good things in Texas," Mr. Carlson said. "He has used the death penalty a lot and I think we need more of that."
Not many people could articulate policy positions of the candidate they favored. Lower taxes, keep the economy cruising, do something to improve access to health care -- these emerged as the more common requests, but few could explain what their candidate might do to achieve such goals.
The issues that have consumed the news media and the pundits -- like whether it was right for Mr. Bush to visit Bob Jones University or for Mr. McCain to lash out at the Christian right -- did not seem to make as firm an impression on voters.
And the often strident back and forth on display at debates has fed a sense of cynicism in this town of 19,000, a mix of the wealthy and the middle class where commerce centers on mom-and-pop stores as well as on shopping malls.
"Everyone gets up there and tries to prove you're a liar," said Frank Campamatio, a retiree shopping at the Vernon Hills mall.
But many more were like Rosemarie Princiotta, 59, a secretary who has paid faint attention to the campaign and finds it difficult to express why Mr. Bush appeals to her.
"He just gives the impression that he is warm like his mother and father," Ms. Princiotta said. "I liked his father. He was outgoing and truthful."
Ms. Princiotta was not alone in tying her support for Mr. Bush to former President George Bush.
"I liked Bush's father so this Bush is fairly credible," said Art Reid, 70, the retired fire chief of Eastchester, as he sat in a pub. "McCain is real honest but I don't think he is going to make it. Bush has more money than him and money is a key factor."
The Bush name may be an asset to some voters, but to others it is a liability. "He is relying on his father's name and record," said Constantine Despotakis, a 47-year-old lawyer leaning to Mr. McCain, who he said had "a sense of honesty and integrity. He comes across as untainted." Mr. Despotakis said he was dismayed that Mr. Bush did not seem to have a command of world affairs, noting that he had failed to name several world leaders when a television reporter presented him a pop quiz a few months ago.
"He needs a better grasp of these issues," said Mr. Despotakis, who like many McCain supporters said he would consider voting for a Democrat in the fall. "People will always vote their pocketbooks and the economy has been doing very well," he said.
Mr. McCain's post-New Hampshire primary surge entranced some who otherwise would have supported Mr. Bush because he was so far ahead.
"I think it is still an open race," said Kevin Scully, an Internet entrepreneur from Bronxville. "I didn't think of McCain before when Bush was the primary candidate, but now I'm starting to get serious about thinking of McCain. I'm still not able to clearly get his message, but I will be paying more attention now."
Marvin L. Cooperman, 53, a physiotherapist, said he thought Mr. Bush was "spending too much time attacking, and I don't like those tactics." This comment came a day before the Bush campaign began broadcasting radio advertisements and disseminating fliers questioning Mr. McCain's record on financing for breast cancer research.
While favoring Mr. McCain, he said both candidates had disappointed him by not fully explaining how they would improve the delivery of health insurance, particularly for the poor. Mr. Cooperman has a personal stake in that; he said he had seen too many patients unable to afford his services because they did not have insurance or were underinsured.
Now, Mr. Cooperman finds himself wondering about the fall. He predicts Mr. Bush will win the nomination and face Vice President Al Gore, for whom he is tempted to vote. He crossed over and voted for President Clinton in 1996.
"The way the economy has been going for the past eight years, I don't know if it's because of the Democrats or Alan Greenspan or whatever," he said. "But since there has been a Democratic president, I have been very happy."
How such sentiments will translate in the voting booth remains anybody's guess.
Mr. Cavanaugh, the party leader, acknowledged Mr. McCain's draw. "I am not the least bit dismissive of McCain's challenge," he said. "He is making a strong challenge and there are people who are enamored of him. I am not saying Bush has it in the bag. We all have to work for him."
Other veteran vote watchers were even less confident of Mr. Bush. Michael R. Edelman, a Republican consultant, predicted that Mr. McCain would prevail in the county.
"John McCain has become extremely appealing to the moderate Northeastern Republican voters," said Mr. Edelman, who once favored Mr. Bush but switched after what he called the governor's embrace of the right wing in South Carolina. "I think McCain will win Westchester by 10 points, assuming voters when they go into the voting booth can discern which delegates are McCain delegates."
That is no small point. Rather than selecting candidates directly, under New York's Republican ballot voters select delegates -- whose names are listed in larger type -- who are backing the candidates.
As is the case elsewhere in the state, Mr. Bush's delegates here in the 18th Congressional District, which includes Eastchester, are by and large recognizable officeholders, including State Senator Nicholas Spano of Yonkers, the former county Republican leader. Mr. McCain's delegates are all unknowns. That undoubtedly will have an impact on voters like Marissa Barile, a 23-year-old legal secretary who is admittedly not well versed on the issues and who said she traditionally followed the course of leading Republicans. "I haven't heard much but I think I will probably go with Bush," she said.
For the undecided and even those with a bent, the race could hardly be described as the same-old, same-old. "With all these choices, it's hard to keep up," said Robert Frederick, a 38-year-old computer scientist who said he planned to take the next few days reading about the candidates before deciding.
"I am a fiscal conservative but sort of moderate on social issues," Mr. Frederick said. "Bush and McCain both say they are fiscal conservatives, and it's hard to keep up on where they stand on things like abortion, which I think they both oppose, but then they may have said things like it's OK in certain cases, or something like that.
"I'm pro-choice and think the Democrats have done good with the economy," he said. "Where does that leave me?"

 BODY:

THE REPUBLICANS
 
HISPANIC VOTE INFLATION -- The share of the Hispanic vote that Gov. George W. Bush of Texas received in his 1998 re-election campaign seems to be creeping upward. In Thursday's debate with Senator John McCain, Mr. Bush said he had received "over 50 percent of the Hispanic vote." The William C. Velasquez Institute in San Antonio says the actual figure is 39 percent. "He's inflating it a little, but the important point is that he did very well for a Republican among Hispanic voters," said Antonio Gonzalez, president of the institute. Ross E. Molloy (NYT) 

THE DEMOCRATS
 
FOCUS ON BLACK VOTERS -- Worried about overconfidence, the Maryland Democratic establishment is putting a homestretch effort into the Super Tuesday primary race in the face of polls showingVice President Al Gore with a 2-to-1 lead over Bill Bradley. The party's state leadership, headed by Gov. Parris N. Glendening, is focusing on a weekend drive to get out the vote among blacks in Prince George's County, one of Washington's most politically active suburbs. Mr. Glendening intends to capitalize on a Gore lead measured among blacks in the latest Mason-Dixon poll as 69 percent to Mr. Bradley's 12 percent. Statewide, the Gore lead is 59 to 28. Francis X. Clines (NYT)
 
THE WEST
 
EDUCATION AND TAXES -- California voters will have to reconcile their desire for education reform with their longstanding antipathy to property taxes. While education has been ranked in some polls as the most important issue to voters this season, the Proposition 13 ballot measure that rolled back property taxes in 1978 has long been regarded as untouchable. But on Tuesday, voters will be asked to support Proposition 26, which would reduce the approval threshold to pass school bond measures to a simple majority of the vote from two-thirds. The chief backer is the California Teachers Association. (NYT)
 
THE SOUTH
 
DEATH WATCH -- With 453 inmates on death row in Texas, campaigns for three judgeships on the state's Court of Criminal Appeals might be expected to be among the hottest contests on March 14, in part because Texas has received increased scrutiny during Gov. George W. Bush's presidential bid. But political analysts predict that the judges will be elected by only 4 percent to 5 percent of the voters. One candidate, Sally L. Ray, is married to a judge on the court, and told The San Antonio Express News she hopes to win because she has "a short name and an inoffensive name, which we all know makes a big difference." Ross E. Molloy (NYT)
 
HOLIDAY HOPES DIM -- Chances that South Carolina would join the rest of the country in enacting a state holiday on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday dimmed this week. On Thursday, Republican legislators added a provision to the holiday bill that would require the state to declare the Confederate flag a symbol of heritage, not of racism. A bill to enact the holiday had passed the state Senate; Democrats accused Republicans in the House of adding the unrelated flag section to kill the holiday. The bill could be revived later in the session, but legislators say growing tensions over racial matters may prevent any consensus. David Firestone (NYT)
 
A PROMISE KEPT -- One of Gov. Jeb Bush's electoral promises has come about: the crime rate dropped in Florida last year, and by a record 10.8 percent. Mr. Bush attributed the decline state's falling crime rate, the lowest since 1973, to a toughening of Florida's crime laws, prison construction and an end to early release programs for violent criminals. The drop was the most drastic since the Florida Department of Law Enforcement began collecting crime data in 1971. Rick Bragg (NYT)

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Amtrak and Blacks Settle Discrimination Suit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Amtrak has settled a racial discrimination suit for the second time in nine months, the latest one alleging that white supervisors had created a hostile work environment for black engineering employees in the Northeast.
Amtrak admitted no wrongdoing in the settlement announced today, but the national railway did agree to change personnel policies. The settlement, which must be approved by a federal judge, sets up a $16 million fund to provide economic relief to 800 to 1,000 black employees who suffered discrimination since 1995 and as many as 4,000 black job applicants who were turned away by Amtrak. 
 The suit claimed that Amtrak had discriminated in hiring, disciplining, training and promoting blacks.
In July 1999, Amtrak settled a suit filed by black managers and employees seeking management positions. The railway agreed to change company policies and set up an $8 million fund to compensate those who sued.

HEADLINE: Cities Reduce Crime and Conflict Without New York-Style Hardball

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
With the city's stunning drop in crime in the 1990's, many New Yorkers have come to assume that aggressive police tactics and crime reductions are inextricably linked.
But a look at other cities around the nation suggests that large reductions in crime can be achieved in places that rely less on the confrontational law enforcement measures New York has used, like the stopping and searching of thousands of people for guns by the Street Crime Unit, four of whose officers were acquitted in the killing of Amadou Diallo. 
 In fact, some cities, notably San Diego and Boston, have recorded as big or even larger drops in violence while employing strategies that rely on close cooperation between the police and the community and have ended up improving race relations.
In the eyes of many police chiefs and criminologists, San Diego and Boston have become the national models of policing, and while New York's accomplishments are also studied and admired, there is a sense of sadness that a great opportunity has been squandered.
"To see crime rates down but people still fearful of the police is not a healthy situation," said Jeremy Travis, the director of the National Institute of Justice, the research arm of the Justice Department, and a former deputy police commissioner in New York. "The national challenge is to bring crime down while simultaneously enhancing public confidence in the agencies of justice, and that is what dropped out of the picture in New York."
Rana Sampson, a former police sergeant in New York who is director of public safety for the University of San Diego, said: "New York has paid a huge price. What the N.Y.P.D. did was throw people at the problem, putting cops on every corner, but who wants to live in a society like that?"
But New York City police officials dispute suggestions that the department is more confrontational than others, and they say that its outreach efforts do not receive enough attention. "The commissioner and the precinct commanders do community meetings all the time," said Maureen Casey, a deputy commissioner for policy and planning. "Not only is the feedback positive, but consistently the thing that the community asks for is more police officers."
Statistically, New York, Boston and San Diego have all achieved enormous declines since crime began dropping nationally in 1991. From 1991 to 1998, the murder rate fell 76.4 percent in San Diego, the largest decline of any major city, with New York second at 70.6 percent and Boston third at 69.3 percent, according to Alfred Blumstein, a professor of criminology at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. Their robbery rates showed a similar pattern. During those same years, the robbery rate dropped 62.6 percent in San Diego, also the steepest decline, and 60.1 percent in New York and 50.2 percent in Boston.
But the three cities employed very different strategies. New York stressed tough enforcement, San Diego pioneered community and problem-solving policing, and Boston developed an approach combining careful research, participation by local ministers and selective action against the worst criminals.
Several other large cities have also reported sharp decreases in crime -- the murder rate fell 62.8 percent in San Antonio from 1991 to 1998, 61.3 percent in Houston, 59.3 percent in Los Angeles and 52.4 percent in Dallas -- without as coherent a strategy as those in New York, San Diego or Boston.
Indeed, law enforcement experts acknowledge that they are baffled by the decline in Los Angeles, whose Police Department has been plagued by scandals and low morale and has seen a drop in arrests. This suggests some, or much, of the nationwide reduction in crime may well stem from factors beyond better policing, like longer prison sentences, the improved economy and changes in the attitude of young people toward drugs and crime.
One way to understand the variations in police tactics in different cities is to look at the cities themselves and their leaders, said Herman Goldstein, a professor emeritus at the University of Wisconsin Law School and perhaps the most widely respected authority on policing. "A community gets the policing it deserves, or demands," he said.
In New York, under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- a former federal prosecutor -- and his first police commissioner, William J. Bratton, there was a two-pronged approach. They began a new emphasis on the rigorous collection of crime statistics and holding precinct commanders accountable for addressing them.
At the same time, they created the Street Crime Unit to patrol for violent armed criminals and to stop large numbers of people in high-crime neighborhoods to check for guns, and they instructed all officers to crack down on petty crimes like graffiti. Community policing, which makes citizens the allies of the police, was scorned as social work by Mr. Giuliani and abandoned by his second commissioner, Howard Safir.
"They tried to do all this too quickly," Professor Goldstein said, "without the investment of years of groundwork in refined training and supervision and discipline. Historically, this is a prescription for runaway police organizations."
San Diego took almost the opposite approach, he said. By the 1990's, it had already invested heavily in careful training and was already using the kind of statistical crime mapping that Mr. Bratton brought later to New York.
"Our basic premise was, we didn't have enough police officers to do it all, so we needed participation by the community," said Jerry Sanders, who retired as San Diego's police chief last year. San Diego has 1.7 officers per 1,000 residents, compared with 5 per 1,000 in New York.
So San Diego adopted community policing. After a series of meetings with citizens, the police divided the city into 99 neighborhoods, with a police team assigned to each, so that residents could get to know their police officers and feel comfortable giving them information. The city also recruited l,200 volunteers, many of them retired, to watch over neighborhoods. They receive police training, wear policelike uniforms and drive official vehicles.
In addition to using crime figures, Mr. Sanders decided to measure his department's success with an annual survey of public satisfaction. The most recent one showed approval at 89 percent, he said.
Boston's approach began with an effort to figure out the real source of crime in the city and how to reduce it with the least racial confrontation. David Kennedy, a senior researcher at Harvard, was hired to help, and he advised focusing on gun violence, not on gangs or drugs, a seemingly small distinction, but a crucial one for enforcement.
Mr. Kennedy, along with a team of Boston police officers and representatives of the district attorney's office, the United States attorney's office, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, began tracing how guns got into the hands of criminals and discovering who the most serious offenders were. They then began consulting black ministers to win their cooperation in going after the ringleaders.
The team, including the ministers, began inviting known criminals, drug dealers and young gang members to what they termed "call-ins," meetings at which they were warned the violence had to stop or there would be federal prosecutions. The few who did not heed the warnings have been arrested and are now facing long federal sentences. The number of arrests and confrontations on the street with the police were minimal, Mr. Kennedy said.
The program has been so successful that in the past two-and-a-half years, only one juvenile has been killed by gunfire in Boston.
Mr. Bratton, who was appointed by Mr. Giuiliani in December 1993 after serving as Boston's police commissioner, said that given New York's high crime rate, an aggressive approach was needed at first. But then as crime dropped, he said, "the mayor made a conscious decision not to put in place the other half of the strategy, reaching out to the black religious and political leaders."
The former commissioner, a frequent critic of Mr. Giuliani since his ouster, added, "If we had reached out in New York the way we reached out in Boston, we could have not only solved the crime problem, but we could have begun to resolve the race problem too."
The Boston model, which evolved over time, has succeeded in several other cities, including High Point, N.C., Indianapolis, New Haven, Memphis and Portland, Ore. In High Point, where it has been directed by Walter Holton Jr., a United States attorney, a team like Boston's has called in 150 known criminals and given them warnings. Since it started in December 1998, Mr. Holton said, there has not been a single drug- or gang-related murder, after nine murders each in 1997 and 1998. The number of citizen complaints against the police has been cut in half.
"It's a very nontraditional approach to law enforcement," Mr. Holton said, and it benefits from the cooperation of the black ministers, who have told criminals that if they do not stop breaking the law, "don't expect to come hide in my church."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: March 7, 2000, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about several cities that have reduced crimewithout the aggressive police tactics used in New York misstated the origin of the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit. It was created in the 1970's by Police Commissioner Patrick Murphy and greatly enlarged in the late 1990's under Howard Safir, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's second police commissioner. It was not created during the tenure of Mayor Giuliani's first commissioner, William J. Bratton.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: NEW ENGLAND;
McCAIN IS STRONG IN NEW ENGLAND

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 3

 BODY:
On paper, New England ought to be George W. Bush country. Not only does he have roots here -- his father was raised in Greenwich, Conn., and his family has a home in Maine -- but he also enjoys broad support from New England's Republican machines.
The governors of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island are supporting Mr. Bush. In stark contrast, his chief rival for the Republican presidential nomination, Senator John McCain, has no state-level official supporting him in Connecticut, and only a scattering of relatively obscure state legislators, former congressmen and retired military veterans working for him in all of New England. 
 In Maine, for instance, Mr. McCain's state campaign chairman is a retired marine from Dresden who coaches college softball.
And yet, polls show that Mr. McCain has a chance of winning all five New England primaries on Tuesday and their 102 collective delegates, one more than are at stake in New York on the same day.
"I think McCain will sweep New England," said Darrell West, a political science professor at Brown University in Providence, R.I. "This is a segment that has a tradition of going for mavericks."
But even if that tradition works in Mr. McCain's favor -- polls indicate Mr. Bush has a good shot only in Connecticut and Maine -- there are 613 delegates at stake on Tuesday and some formidable obstacles.
No wonder that before today, neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. McCain had set foot in New England since Feb. 1, the day of Mr. McCain won the New Hampshire primary by 19 points.
There are bigger prizes elsewhere on Tuesday. Mr. Bush is strong in California and Georgia, with 216 delegates, and the races in Ohio and New York, with a total of 168 delegates are tight.
Jay Malcynsky, Mr. Bush's Connecticut campaign manager, said of the New England states, "They don't have the number of delegates to deliver to one candidate or another."
"If McCain is able to win most or all of New England, the rest of the races, particularly California, New York and Ohio, will pull him through," Mr. Malcynsky said of Mr. Bush.
But, he conceded, "it's been a battle for Bush in New England since New Hampshire."
Perhaps more than any other region, the five New England states of Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Vermont offer Mr. McCain tailor-made, fiercely independent, moderate voters whose counterparts delivered Mr. McCain primary victories in New Hampshire and Michigan. In every New England state except New Hampshire, independents outnumber Republicans and Democrats, and only in Connecticut are non-Republican voters banned from voting in the Republican primary. Such voters have been among Mr. McCain's main supporters in earlier primaries.
More than 30,000 voters in Massachusetts have switched registration in time for Tuesday's primary, mostly Democrats changing to independents, state officials said.
Such momentum does not seem to have waned after Mr. McCain's triple primary defeat last week in Virginia, Washington and North Dakota, said Scott McLean, a political science professor at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn.
"Those elections were in different parts of the country, and I don't see them slowing him down in Connecticut," Mr. McLean said in an interview this week. "I'm not sure anyone even paid attention in Connecticut."
In Massachusetts, where Mr. McCain was trailing Mr. Bush last September by 30 points, he now leads by more than 20. In Rhode Island, where the Republican Party is weak and more than half of all voters are independents, he is leading by more than 20 points. In Vermont, Mr. McCain's campaign chairman bragged this week that victory was a foregone conclusion.
A poll in Connecticut by Quinnipiac College after Mr. McCain's resounding win in New Hampshire but before Mr. Bush's win in South Carolina, showed Mr. McCain ahead, 52 percent to 39 percent. But a Zogby poll of 361 likely voters released today showed Mr. Bush ahead, 45 percent to 42 percent, with a five point margin of error.
In Cheshire, Conn., an affluent town southwest of Hartford, several Republicans interviewed today said that they would vote for Mr. McCain Tuesday, mostly because of their perceptions about his character and willingness to shake up Washington's political establishment.
"I don't want George Bush's son in office; I've had enough of Bush," said Sue Paulik, 59, who works in a Cheshire drug store. "I think his policies would follow Reagan and what happened under his father. The economy really suffered under his father."
Even Gov. John G. Rowland, Mr. Bush's foremost Connecticut booster, has a less zealous outlook on winning Connecticut, whose 25 delegates are second in New England to the 37 of Massachusetts.
The cooling became notable 10 days ago, after Mr. Rowland criticized as "stupid" Mr. Bush's visit to Bob Jones University, a South Carolina college that espouses anti-Catholic views.
Asked about Mr. Bush's chances yesterday, Mr. Rowland, who is Roman Catholic, said, "Governor Bush as a candidate is back on the offensive, back on message," and he criticized Mr. McCain as taking "inappropriate advantage" of Mr. Bush's Bob Jones debacle.
Whichever way New England voters go on Tuesday, they will do so largely without the benefit of having a chance to see either Mr. Bush or Mr. McCain in person. Both are far more obsessed by their battle for New York's 101 delegates, and until today, neither had set foot in New England since flying out of New Hampshire on the night of its primary.
This afternoon, Mr. McCain diverted his New York campaign briefly to deliver a speech at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn. Mr. Bush's wife, Laura Bush, has stumped for her husband in the state. On Saturday, Mr. Bush is expected to speak at a rally at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks.
Regardless of what each man wins in New England, experts and even devout McCain supporters say they believe Mr. McCain's candidacy may decline rapidly after Tuesday.
"I just think he's cool, fresh," said Denny Maisano, 47, a banking consultant from Cheshire who plans to vote for Mr. McCain, but "I don't think he has a broad enough appeal or enough money."
Mr. West, the political science professor at Brown, went further, predicting that after a loss in California on Tuesday, "the media begins to turn against him, McCain's money dries up and he's forced out the race."

HEADLINE: Agency Rejects High Duties on Imported Steel

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
In a stinging and unusual disappointment for United States steel producers and workers, a federal trade agency refused today to levy punitive import duties on a variety of steel products from Japan and five other countries.
The ruling, by the United States International Trade Commission, cancels plans by the Commerce Department to impose duties on hundreds of millions of dollars worth of imported cold-rolled steel, which is used in a wide spectrum of products from cars to household appliances. 
 The commission decided, on a vote of 5 to 1, that imports from Japan, Argentina, Brazil, Russia, South Africa and Thailand were not a threat to the United States steel industry. The ruling broke a string of recent cases in which the trade agency had sided with domestic companies and workers in roughly similar circumstances.
Reactions to the ruling, which can be appealed in federal court, ranged from elation to bitter disappointment.
"This is a great victory for open trade," said Hidenori Tazawa, chairman of the Japan Steel Information Center, a New York-based advocacy association for Japanese steel exporters. "Ultimately, this is good for both the American and the global economy."
But Roger Shagrin, a Washington lawyer who represented several United States steel companies and an independent union in the proceeding, called the decision "difficult to understand" and said it would cost some Americans their jobs -- "no question."
The United Steelworkers of America, which had also sought the duties on imports, expressed disappointment. "It demonstrates the continual failure of our trade policies," said Gary Hubbard, a union spokesman in Washington.
Companies and workers have often complained in recent years about what they call the flooding of United States markets with steel that is priced below fair-market value to lure away customers, a practice known in trade law as dumping. Thirty United States producers employing nearly 22,000 workers in a dozen states make goods comparable to the imports that are affected by the decision today, the trade commission said.
But the agency noted that by law, it is not supposed to assume that any problems felt by a United States industry are a result of imports. Rather, it must find firm evidence to reach that conclusion, and the agency said today that after a nine-month investigation it could not. Indeed, the agency said, domestic steel makers' output of products like the ones under consideration has actually gone up slightly in recent months.
Foreign competition is a highly charged issue this election year, and steel companies and their workers have heavily lobbied the White House and Congress to protect American interests. Last month, after the trade commission could not reach a decision, President Clinton imposed punitive tariffs on wire rod, pipe and other imported steel products from South Korea, Brazil, Germany, Japan and other countries.
The trade commission's members serve nine-year terms. They are nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate. No more than three can be of one political party. The agency has broad investigative powers and is supposed to advise Congress and the president on trade policy.
Lynn M. Bragg, the chairwoman of the agency, was the only member to vote today for imposing higher duties. She is a Republican who has been on the commission since 1994.
The commission's rulings can be appealed to the Court of International Trade in New York, and then to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. A commission spokesman said no case from the commission had gone to the Supreme Court.
A former senior official for the trade commission said the agency might have decided as it did today because several recent rulings the other way gave it more cover to do so. Moreover, he noted, in a global economy in which Americans invest in overseas companies and foreigners invest in the United States, it is not so easy anymore to say exactly which companies are "American" and which are "foreign."
Investigations are under way to determine whether high duties should be imposed on steel from Indonesia, China, Slovakia and Taiwan. "These issues don't go away," the former official said.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about duties on imported steel referred incorrectly to actions taken last month by the United States International Trade Commission. The commission split, 3 to 3, on whether relief should be provided to makers of wire rod and voted 5 to 1 in favor of relief for pipe makers. Both recommendations were sent to President Clinton, as required by law, and he decided to impose duties. The commission was not unable to reach a decision.
