HEADLINE: Warning: This Is a Rights-Free Workplace

BYLINE: By Barbara Ehrenreich; Barbara Ehrenreich is author of the coming "Nickel and Dimed: Surviving in Low-Wage America."

 BODY:
If the laws of economics were enforced as strictly as the laws of physics, America would be a workers' paradise. The supply of most kinds of labor is low, relative to the demand, so each worker should be treated as a cherished asset, right? But there have been only grudging gains in wages over the last few years, and in the realm of dignity and autonomy, a palpable decline.
In the latest phase of America's one-sided class war, employers have taken to monitoring employees' workplace behavior right down to a single computer keystroke or bathroom break, even probing into their personal concerns and leisure activities. Sure, there's a job out there for anyone who can get to an interview sober and standing upright. The price, though, may be one's basic civil rights and -- what boils down to the same thing -- self-respect. 
 Not that the Bill of Rights ever extended to the American workplace. In 1996, I was surprised to read about a grocery store worker in Dallas who was fired for wearing a Green Bay Packers T-shirt to work on the day before a Cowboys-Packers game. All right, this was insensitive of him, but it certainly couldn't have influenced his ability to keep the shelves stocked with Doritos. A few phone calls though, revealed that his firing was entirely legal. Employees have the right to express their religious preferences at work, by wearing a cross or a Star of David, for example. But most other forms of "self-expression" are not protected, and strangely enough, Green Bay Packer fandom has not yet been recognized as a legitimate religion.
Freedom of assembly is another right that never found its way into the workplace. On a recent journalistic foray into a series of low-wage jobs, I was surprised to discover that management often regarded the most innocent conversation between employees as potentially seditious. A poster in the break room at one restaurant where I worked as a waitress prohibited "gossip," and a manager would hastily disperse any gathering of two or more employees. At the same time, management everywhere enjoys the right to assemble employees for lengthy anti-union harangues.
Then there is the more elemental and biological right -- and surely it should be one -- to respond to nature's calls. Federal regulations forbid employers to "impose unreasonable restrictions on employee use of the facilities." But according to Marc Linder and Ingrid Nygaard, co-authors of "Void Where Prohibited: Rest Breaks and the Right to Urinate on Company Time," this regulation is only halfheartedly enforced. Professionals and, of course, waitresses can usually dart away and relieve themselves as they please. Not so for many cashiers and assembly-line workers, some of whom, Linder says, have taken to wearing adult diapers to work.
In the area of privacy rights, workers have actually lost ground in recent years. Here, too, the base line is not impressive -- no comprehensive right to personal privacy on the job has ever been established. I learned this on my first day as a waitress, when my fellow workers warned me that my purse could be searched by management at any time. I wasn't carrying stolen salt shakers or anything else of a compromising nature, but there's something about the prospect of a purse search that makes a woman feel a few buttons short of fully dressed. After work, I called around and found that this, too, is generally legal, at least if the boss has reasonable cause and has given prior notification of the company's search policies.
Purse searches, though, are relatively innocuous compared with the sophisticated chemical and electronic forms of snooping adopted by many companies in the 90's. The American Management Association reports that in 1999 a record two-thirds of major American companies monitored their employees electronically: videotaping them; reviewing their e-mail and voice-mail messages; and, most recently, according to Lewis Maltby, president of the Princeton-based National Workrights Institute, monitoring any Web sites they may visit on their lunch breaks. Nor can you count on keeping anything hidden in your genes; a growing number of employers now use genetic testing to screen out job applicants who carry genes for expensive ailments like Huntington's disease.
But the most ubiquitous invasion of privacy is drug testing, usually of urine, more rarely of hair or blood. With 81 percent of large companies now requiring some form of drug testing -- up from 21 percent in 1987 -- job applicants take it for granted that they'll have to provide a urine sample as well as a resume. This is not restricted to "for cause" testing -- of people who, say, nod or space out on the job. Nor is it restricted to employees in "safety-sensitive occupations," like airline pilots and school-bus drivers. Workers who stack boxes of Cheerios in my local supermarkets get tested, as do the editorial employees of this magazine, although there is no evidence that a weekend joint has any more effect on Monday-morning performance than a Saturday-night beer.
Civil libertarians see drug testing as a violation of our Fourth Amendment protection from "unreasonable search," while most jobholders and applicants find it simply embarrassing. In some testing protocols, the employee has to strip to her underwear and urinate into a cup in the presence of an aide or technician, who will also want to know what prescription drugs she takes, since these can influence the test results.
According to a recent report from the American Civil Liberties Union, drug testing has not been proven to achieve its advertised effects, like reducing absenteeism and improving productivity. But it does reveal who's on antidepressants or suffering with an ailment that's expensive to treat, and it is undeniably effective at weeding out those potential "troublemakers" who are too independent-minded to strip and empty their bladders on command.
Maybe the prevailing trade-off between jobs and freedom would make sense, in the narrowest cost-benefit terms, if it contributed to a more vibrant economy. But this is hardly the case. In fact, a 1998 study of 63 computer-equipment and data-processing firms found that companies that performed both pre-employment and random drug testing actually "reduced rather than enhanced productivity" -- by an eye-popping 29 percent, presumably because of its dampening effect on morale.
Why, then, do so many employers insist on treating their workers as a kind of fifth column within the firm? Certainly the government has played a role with its misguided antidrug crusade, as has the sheer availability of new technologies of snooping. But workplace repression signals a deeper shift away from the postwar social contract in which a job meant a straightforward exchange of work for wages.
Economists trace the change to the 1970's, when, faced with falling profits and rising foreign competition, America's capitalists launched an offensive to squeeze more out of their workers. Supervision tightened, management expanded and union-busting became a growth industry. And once in motion, the dynamic of distrust is hard to stop. Workers who are routinely treated like criminals and slackers may well bear close watching.
The mystery is why American workers, the political descendants of proud revolutionaries, have so meekly surrendered their rights. Sure, individual workers find ways to cheat on their drug tests, outwit the electronic surveillance and sneak in a bit of "gossip" here and there. But these petty acts of defiance seldom add up to concerted resistance, in part because of the weakness of American unions. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is currently conducting a nationwide drive to ensure the right to organize, and the downtrodden workers of the world can only wish the union well. But what about all the other rights missing in so many American workplaces? It's not easy to organize your fellow workers if you can't communicate freely with them on the job and don't dare carry union literature in your pocketbook.
In a tight labor market, workers have another option, of course. They can walk. The alarming levels of turnover in low-wage jobs attest to the popularity of this tactic, and if unemployment remains low, employers may eventually decide to cut their workers some slack. Already, companies in particularly labor-starved industries like ski resorts and software are dropping drug testing rather than lose or repel employees. But in the short run, the mobility of workers, combined with the weakness of unions, means that there is little or no sustained on-site challenge to overbearing authority.
What we need is nothing less than a new civil rights movement -- this time, for American workers. Who will provide the leadership remains to be seen, but clearly the stakes go way beyond "labor issues," as these are conventionally defined. We can hardly call ourselves the world's pre-eminent democracy if large numbers of citizens spend half of their waking hours in what amounts, in plain terms, to a dictatorship.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 84; Column 2; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Capitalist Cell

BYLINE: By Tom Vanderbilt; Tom Vanderbilt last wrote for the magazine about reality-based television.

 BODY:
Driving through downtown Rochester on a January evening, the barren streets caked with exhaust-tinged snow, Heath Row, 27, is talking about anarchism and assessing the strength of a local cell.
"Tonight will be interesting," says Row, clad in green suede Pumas, Trotskyesque glasses and a tangle of self-cut hair. "The cell is relatively small and it hasn't been particularly active. I'm hoping a couple of people will step up as emergent leaders." 
 Row is sort of a scholar of the way anarchist groups form, or, as he puts it, of "emergent leadership in connection with antihierarchical self-definition." Yet he has not come to Rochester to advance a strain of anarcho-syndicalism. While members of the cell he is meeting no doubt consider themselves revolutionaries, their call to arms is Fast Company, the rapidly growing magazine that began in April of 1995 with a bold series of declarations blending Situationist sloganeering with Madison Avenue exhortations. "Work Is Personal." "Computing Is Social." "Knowledge Is Power." "Break the Rules."
The job of Heath Row is to journey to cities like Rochester and meet the local "cells" of what the magazine calls its Company of Friends. The brainchild of Row, the company began as a way of linking Fast Company readers. There are now more than 25,000 members in 120 cities worldwide; 1,000 members a month are added.
But the cells promise more than the chance to get together with strangers and hash out the subtle distinctions of Tom Peters. Most immediately, the cells are a living embodiment of Fast Company, an incubator of the magazine's revolutionary fervor. Members, like readers, tend to view themselves as like-minded people disenchanted with mainstream corporate life. They talk of "reinventing the workplace," bringing "passion" and "values" to their companies. They share the vision that the New Economy has "soul," i.e., that it is about more than pecuniary gain, because "this generation would not sell out for money." They share an equally utopian vision that top-down managerialism will not work in an economy where real power resides with the "brand called you."
Of course, the rapid-fire growth of the groups, as well as the magazine's own rise in circulation (this year's projection: 500,000, up from 100,000 just a few years ago), says much about the appeal of Fast Company's vision of "democratic capitalism." The cells would seem the vanguard of that revolution, a spontaneous cult of Fast Company ideologues. "The Company of Friends is the Grateful Dead of the New Economy," says Daniel Pink, a Fast Company contributing editor. "I'm expecting local cells to start selling bootleg tapes of their meetings to one another." But is all the excitement of the cells really about social change? Or are they merely the New Economy's version of the old-boy network, threatening at any moment to sink into self-parody?
From the beginning, Fast Company billed itself as more movement than magazine, which probably helps explain why it -- and not Wired, Business 2.0 or The Industry Standard -- has been able to mobilize such a sizable off-page community of readers with comparatively little effort or money in such a short time.
While most business magazines were busy charting the convulsions of the New Economy in terms of mergers, pinstriped protagonists and economic indicators, the founders of Fast Company, Alan Weber and William Taylor, understood that new technologies would create a new business culture, which would in turn require a new magazine. Fast Company billed itself as a "workstyle" magazine, tying the rising obsession with work to the aspirational nature of lifestyle magazines, and indeed the pages of Fast Company are populated with people whose lives are meant to seem fantastic but faintly attainable. The magazine also addresses the commonplace concerns of "knowledge" workers the way Good Housekeeping circa 1954 spoke to the housewife: "But what if you arrive at a meeting with a laptop full of killer slides -- only to find that your host doesn't have a projector for you?" Stories like "Do You Hate Your Boss?" at times read like "Can This Marriage Be Saved?"
Not surprisingly, many Fast Company readers describe the magazine as a revelation. Row, who joined the magazine in 1997 as an associate editor, began to notice this discovery moment speaking to readers at the magazine's "RealTime" conferences. "They were saying things like, 'I didn't know I could have a job like that,' or 'I didn't know I could run a company like that.' They were talking about the magazine almost as if they were talking about meeting somebody."
Row recognized in this sense of connection an incipient community. One of Row's models was the salons organized by Utne Reader in the early 1990's after the magazine ran a cover article on the dying art of conversation. The salons, focused on topics ranging from spirituality to ethical business, seemed as much a product of their time as Fast Company does now. Like the Utne salons, the cells initially revolved around magazine articles. But they soon evolved. "Some of them were turning into business support groups," says Griff Wigley, the creator of Utne's salons, who later organized the first Twin Cities cell of the Company of Friends. "People would bring particularly thorny problems at their companies and the group would try to brainstorm solutions."
Carla Stroud, a project manager at the Seattle office of the law firm Perkins Coie, describes a survey taken several years ago in which her department scored near the bottom in morale and similar factors. In response, the firm embarked on a number of management initiatives, one of which was an enthusiastic embrace of Fast Company. After a manager passed around copies of the magazine, an in-house cell was formed; it meets monthly in the firm's offices. "We take ideas out of the magazine and say, O.K., maybe this is the culture in an Internet start-up but it doesn't mean we can't tweak it for our organization," says Stroud. Like many readers, she is convinced that the magazine is heralding an inexorable change in managerial culture, driven by presumably unbounded opportunity of an ever-vibrant entrepreneurial economy. "I work in the 'Silicon Forest' -- there are stock options everywhere," Stroud says. "For those companies that don't offer stock options, how are you going to attract talent? People want to have exciting work, and they want to have a voice too."
The cells' popularity also points, however, to the questions Richard Sennett raised in his book "The Corrosion of Character: The Personal Consequences of Work in the New Capitalism." What happens to the individual in an economy where attachment and loyalty are replaced by flexibility and perpetual reinvention? Where does connection come from in a post-secure world where one is loyal to oneself or a project rather than a company, and social bonding extends only as far as contingent "teams"?
In one sense, the growth of the cells challenges Sennett. People can resiliently adapt themselves to the social and economic formations of the New Economy -- the cells are meeting people's desire for connection. Yet are they truly a vehicle to foment real workplace change, or merely a way for the brand called you to move up the career ladder? Moreover, the magazine, like most manifestoes, often offers a skewed view of reality. Fast Company projects no downside to the New Economy; rather, it paints a persistently upbeat world of "e-lancers" and "change agents," a world where individuals morph into nonhierarchical teams, which are then whisked together to work on "wow projects" before disbanding to spend meaningful time with their families or at Canyon Ranch. It is a concordantly boosterish, quasi-mythical universe in which managers are enlightened, labor unions are unnecessary and any ill social or economic consequences the New Economy might augur are safely ameliorated with gently prim reminders on the order of: "Those who have the talent to succeed in the New Economy have a responsibility to address its harsh side effects." Phrases like "work is personal" are not seen as Orwellian declarations that imply there is little time left for anything personal outside of work; they are bold affirmations.
In Rochester, the Company of Friends meets at the Empire Brewing Company, a cozy brew pub within view of Kodak's headquarters -- in Fast Company's world, the very symbol of hierarchical control.
The shadow of Kodak, the city's largest employer, hangs over tonight's meeting for another reason. Today Kodak released a healthier-than-expected earnings report, attributed in part to a recent series of layoffs -- it is a faster company. Clustered at the bar, the cell -- a group of about 20 who have come from Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse -- gossips about Kodak ("the dinosaur," they call it ) with the mixture of awe and scorn a revolutionary group might use to discuss the governing power. No Kodak employees are in attendance.
Indeed, the table at which Row and I sit is New Economy Central Casting: there's the C.E.O. of an Internet services company who happens to be the youngest person in the room; there's an ebullient public-relations consultant and self-professed Fast Company evangelist whose card reads Czarina of Buzz. And there is Claire Crittenden, a 52-year-old consultant profiled in Fast Company who picks up on the ostensibly revolutionary theme of the evening. "I'm really the classic hippie that never lost that," she says. While Crittenden says she could have "made a fortune" in the personal-growth movement of the early 1970's, she instead turned to business, "the very vehicle that shapes this country."
This is classic Fast Company stuff -- the revolutionary zeal of the 1960's and the therapeutic language of the early 1970's have been seamlessly assimilated by the business world. Revolution and change now involve making alterations to flow charts, building "extreme teams" and dropping words like "zoomwidth." Against the Fortune 500, Fast Company has the same aura of cool the yippies exuded against mainstream America. The question of how a business magazine -- or business itself -- could acquire revolutionary trappings or an aura of cool speaks to the social transformation that made Fast Company possible. As numerous pundits have argued by now, this is based on a larger realignment of business and society in which business is replacing politics as a force for social change.
The Rochester meeting seems less a revolutionary enclave than a standard, if casual, business luncheon. Neither insurrectionist rhetoric nor socially conscious agitating is promoted. From this meeting, at least, the Company of Friends would appear to be not all that far from the Kiwanis or Elks Club. In the world of the New Economy as chronicled by Fast Company, these service clubs of the past are anachronistic, with their rigid bylaws and entrance requirements, their costly brick-and-mortar lodges and male-dominated aura. And to be sure, in Fast Company cells, membership is fluid and available simply by showing up; participants cross gender, age and profession; and the initial organizing takes place on the Internet. Yet as with all revolutionaries, the test for Fast Company and its cells is how quickly it begins acting like the status quo.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 45; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2906 words

HEADLINE: The Artist in the Gray Flannel Pajamas

BYLINE: By Michael Lewis; Michael Lewis is a contributing writer for The Times Magazine and the author of "The New New Thing."

 BODY:
If you pick up one of the many books written about American business in the 1950's, you will find a typical corporate employee who is unrecognizable today. The Organization Man, the Man in the Gray Flannel Suit -- whatever you call him, he seems as freakish today as a bearded lady or a six-toed foot. The worker who is willing to subordinate his identity to some giant corporation is so deeply unfashionable that, for cultural purposes, he might as well not exist. Where did he go? One answer is that he was set free.
A few years ago I began to notice that people I was introduced to were suddenly describing their work, not saying who they did it for. The senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank had somehow vanished. In his place had arisen any number of people with baffling new job descriptions: migrant Web master, kernel hacker, creative director. For about six months it seemed as if half the people I met called themselves software consultants. What the hell was that? As best as I could tell it meant piercing some highly unlikely body part and cultivating an air of total independence. 
 Actually, what these people all were, or appeared to be, were artists. They kept artists' hours. They wore artists' clothes. They had preserved the sort of odd habits that membership in any group -- other than the group "artists" -- tends to drum out of people. Maybe the most interesting thing about them was their lack of obvious corporate attachments. Corporations usually paid for their existence, but otherwise seemed to have no effect on their lives. If forced to discuss the companies that paid the bills, these people tended to be dismissive or, at the very least, ironic.
Here were the prosperous children of the great American economic boom, an amorphous, un-pin-down-able labor force. They were not full-time employees of big companies, just temps. But there was now sufficient glory in being a temp -- rather than a full-time employee with hours and a boss -- that a temp was no longer a temp. He was, in new-economy parlance, a free agent.
Of course, most of the 131 million or so workers in the United States civilian labor force are not free agents. Only about 12 million people fit the description of "workers with alternative arrangements," according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Moreover, the fastest growing job title is not "independent contractor" but "cashier" -- a fact that anyone who sets out to make sweeping generalizations about the changing nature of work in America must come to grips with. I mention the more conspicuous free agents not because they are exactly typical but because they point to something that is: a general drift away from old-fashioned corporate order and a tendency toward individualism in work life, especially among those who tend to invent new lifestyles for everyone else -- Wall Street, Hollywood and now Silicon Valley.
Back in 1984, an M.I.T. economist named Martin Weitzman published a short, powerful book called "The Share Economy," in which he suggested that the solution to unemployment was to change the way people were paid for their work. Most unemployment, he argued, was caused by inflexible wages; if workers would only accept pay cuts in bad times, they could keep their jobs. Because they tended not to do this, the only way for companies to reduce costs in bad times was to lay off or fire workers.
Why not get around this dilemma by mov-ing away from a wage-based pay structure? Weitzman asked. Why not make some large portion of a worker's pay dependent on the fortunes of the company, so that in good times workers would be paid more and in bad times workers would be paid less? In other words, Why not pay them with stock?
In 1984 this sounded like one of those theoretical fantasies economists were forever dreaming up for other people to ignore. Still, in Weitzman's tract lay the intellectual origins of the single most powerful trend in American work: employee ownership. Oddly, the trend had its practical start on Wall Street in the 1980's. Remember leveraged buyouts? One result of these buyouts was that companies ended up (via stock) in the hands of the people who worked for them -- mostly the people who worked at the very top, true enough, but they were, after all, employees, too. The general idea was that people worked harder and smarter when they had a stake in their businesses, and that is an idea widely held today.
Whether or not the investment bankers and corporate managers who did the deals actually believed what they were saying -- their actions often suggested they did not -- their argument had a couple of consequences. The first was to undermine the moral authority of the corporate executive class. The willingness of top executives to put their companies at great financial risk for personal gain raised an obvious question in workers' minds: why should I devote my career to a company that my boss treats like a private lotto?
But the other consequence of the leveraged-buyout bonanza was to cause lesser executives to demand their own stock packages. By the mid-1990's, the idea that employees should also be owners had trickled down to the rank and file. In 1974, 200,000 workers had equity in their companies. In 1999, 10 million held company stock. For the most part, employees have been purchasing modest numbers of shares through employee stock-ownership plans; in New Economy firms, though, even the secretaries tend to have options. One way or the other, Martin Weitzman's fantasy has become the new reality, and its consequences are all around us. But they aren't, at least so far, what anyone expected them to be. Here are a few of them:
The decline of corporate loyalty. Oddly, equity stakes have not created what you might think they would create: stable, loyal work forces. True, a company whose share price rises inexorably has a greater ability than most to keep its workers. There are currently employees at Microsoft who are the equivalent of the 1950's Organization Men, known as Rest and Vesters. They hang around dutifully and wait for the stock options they have been promised to be awarded to them, simply because it would cost too much for them to quit. But Microsoft is more the exception than the rule in the current boom. More typical is the stale old company whose stock price lags the Nasdaq, or the manic-depressive start-up whose stock price gyrates wildly.
For these sorts of companies the ubiquity of stock options has actually made employees jumpier. Many corporate employees behave less like old-fashioned workers than they do like investors. Rather than think, I need to stay here and do my best because I have an investment in this company, they think, I am going to keep a close eye on this ship, in case it starts to sink and my options become worthless. It is no accident that the world's capital of stock options, Silicon Valley, is also the world's capital of job-hopping. Silicon Valley employees perpetually scrutinize their companies for dark signs. When things go slightly wrong employees race out to find jobs that offer stock options that might be worth more. With so much at stake they cannot afford to be loyal. They cannot afford to succumb to old-fashioned tricks used by companies to promote worker loyalty. Which brings us to a second change in worker attitudes:
A new skepticism toward the company's argument that it serves some purpose higher than itself. Fantastic booms like ours create new forces of selfishness. The higher the price of working for something greater than yourself, the less easily people will be persuaded that they must do so.
Actually, there's a model for corporate employees in the 1990's boom: Wall Street employees in the 1980's boom. Until the early 1980's most Wall Street firms had been partnerships, and the most ambitious people who worked for them were roped to the business by the dreams of becoming a partner. The implicit goal of every Wall Street person circa 1979 was to spend his career with a single firm, which he believed to have some mythical superiority to other firms. To reach the goal required years of slogging, and at least the pretense that you were willing to subordinate your selfish interests to those of the group.
Then, in the early 1980's, the great old partnerships (Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley, Salomon Brothers) sold stock in themselves and became public corporations. At the same time that the Wall Street executives were preaching the virtues of employee ownership they were selling their own companies to the public, and turning themselves and their employees into hired guns without much stake in their own businesses. The incentive to devote oneself to the long-term glory of the employer was suddenly gone.
It is instructive to see how quickly moral codes change when the conditions that gave rise to them vanish. Just a few years earlier faith that one's Wall Street employer was engaged in some higher activity had seemed like principle; now it was just another one of those archaic customs, along with the edict against borrowing money you couldn't clearly repay and the belief that the customer was always right. At all levels of the company the quest for partnerships was replaced by the quest for huge year-end bonuses. The question that the newly tightly strung Wall Street worker asked himself at the start of each year was no longer "What do I do this year to further my career at my company?" It was "How do I maximize my take for the year?" One of the stranger psychological hazards of work on a trading floor was the new and widespread sense that one was doing his company a favor by working for it. There was a great whooshing sound in the heart of capitalism as all sorts of attitudes and unwritten rules were blown away.
In retrospect, it's clear what happened on Wall Street: the labor market opened up. The status of the ordinary worker was transformed, as it was no longer dictated by his company but by the market. Professional athletes and Hollywood movie stars -- to take the two most obvious examples -- had broken free of restraints on their trade. But the collapse of the old order had not yet affected serious businesspeople -- perhaps because they were closer to the center of that order.
Since then, the markets for lots of other sorts of jobs have also opened up. The rise of market forces in the outside world has been mirrored inside the corporation. Chicken-and-egg changes in social attitudes and technology have left a lot of workers better informed of a) their market value; b) their corporation's relative prospects; and c) the nature of life inside other rival companies. The Internet boom has been the great promoter of free-labor markets, not only in the enticements it offers to employees to quit their jobs in companies with slow-moving stock prices but also in the information it arms them with to do so.
The most obvious beneficiaries are the highly skilled workers who already have it best -- life has never been so good for computer programmers. But there is no reason why the new freedoms cannot also be a boon to certain kinds of low skilled workers -- like cashiers. In a booming economy a good cashier is hard to find; a good cashier will benefit from knowing his options; perhaps he will even figure out a way to get some. Interestingly, two giant slow-moving companies, Ford Motor and Delta Air Lines, have announced plans to give their employees computers and printers and Internet access (for nominal fees). In handing their workers the tools they need to do their jobs they are also handing them weapons to advance their self-interest at the expense of the corporation. How long will it be before Ford and Delta employees create notice boards on the Internet to exchange helpful tidbits about jobs at General Motors and American Airlines and damning information about their bosses? Which brings me to a third curious feature of modern work life:
The boss is no longer the boss. Countless American comedies have depended on the need of some wage slave to please his boss. Companies, it was rightly assumed, were tiny fascist states in which the workers were meant to feel lucky to have citizenship. Today no decent scriptwriter looking for character motivation would dare to use fear of the boss. It hardly exists.
Authority has not exactly vanished from corporate America, but it isn't what it once was. The boom has turned employers into buyers in a seller's market, and it is tough to sell discipline and order to a newly empowered population imbued with the free-agent spirit. Anyone who doubts just how vulnerable the boss now is need only visit the Web site of Vault.com, where employees of such places as United Parcel Service and Boeing exchange information about superiors. It's hard to think of a form of authority that has gone unchallenged in this boom, other than the faceless authority of huge piles of money. Which brings me to:
Collapse of the guild mentality. The rise of free agency, and of employee ownership, has caused a crisis in the highest tier of wage slavery, the professions. The mystical grip of the old-fashioned guild on the middle-class American imagination must be at an all-time low. This trend, too, began on Wall Street in the 1980's; six fancy-pants lawyers and an actual brain surgeon sold bonds on the trading floor at Salomon Brothers because it paid them so much more to do so. Similarly, Silicon Valley now teems with exquisitely trained lawyers and doctors who have chucked in medicine or the law to work for a venture capital firm, or to start an e-health or biotechnology company.
The gist of the problem here is what might be called "the business model" of the professions. All a lawyer or a doctor or an accountant has to sell is his time. This might have sufficed when there was great prestige attached to working at Ernst & Young or Sherman & Sterling. But that prestige has collapsed, under the weight of the money made by people who are not professionals.
Indeed, one casualty of the boom has been all forms of work-related prestige other than sheer moneymaking. A good example is the university president. Once a plausible stepping stone to perhaps even the White House, the job was coveted for all sorts of nonmonetary reasons. Now it is widely regarded as something of a dumping ground for the bureaucratically minded. Benno Schmidt's 1992 decision to quit as president of Yale to enter the private sector would have been unthinkable a decade earlier. When, last month, the president of Brown quit to take a job for a lot more money, as chancellor of Vanderbilt, he reinforced the idea that Ivy League prestige no longer trumped pay.
The decay of a lot of old-fashioned status means that a lot of very important people are doing things that not very long ago they would have thought beneath them. When President Clinton leaves office few will be shocked if he takes a job with Lazard Fr<heart>res or DreamWorks. That in itself is shocking. Which brings me to a final, and perhaps defining, trait of work today:
The new spirit of nonconformity. In the free-agent economy anything that smells of conformity is out of fashion. Even in giant companies there is a trend to nonconformity. Corporate cultures have changed a great deal in the current boom, at least on the surface. Across America staid corporate executives are busily devouring such unsettling (to them) books as Clayton Christensen's "Innovator's Dilemma." Every corporate boss now understands that he's supposed to turn the wage slaves who report to him into whirling dervishes of innovation.
A new corporate language has been invented to support people's need to believe that their work is actually an endless quest for originality. "Outside the box," for instance. These days you cannot spend two hours inside any big American company without some poor sucker telling you how he believes in "thinking outside the box." "Outside the box" is to our age what "plastics" was to the 1960's. The one thing that is certain is that anyone who uses the phrase "outside the box" is as deeply inside the box as a person can be.
Of course, the current fashion for nonconformity is itself a kind of conformity. There are now many jobs to which it takes more nerve to wear a blue suit than a nose ring. Working from home in the nude is no longer evidence that you are an interesting person, or even a happy one. The next step comes when people figure that out. There are limits to the pleasure of individualism.
A lot of what workers find appealing about the new openness in markets for their labor is actually just a byproduct of our magical boom. It's always a joy to be a seller in a seller's market. The joy is only enhanced when your counterpart is a faceless corporation, to which you owe nothing. But this pleasure comes with a price tag: the risk that you may one day find yourself a seller in a buyer's market, where the buyer is a faceless corporation that owes you nothing. The corporate socialism that constrained the old-fashioned worker had its benefits. (One of them was "benefits.") When things went bad there was at least a pretense that the company bore some responsibility for the worker's fate. In some cases this assurance wasn't worth all that much but in many others it was worth quite a lot. Now that pretense has nearly vanished. Guess what that means? You're on your own.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 82; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Come Back, Company Man!

BYLINE: By Adrian Wooldridge; Adrian Wooldridge is a Washington-based correspondent for The Economist.

 BODY:
A decade ago, corporate America tore up the social contract that bound employees to their companies. Downsizing and re-engineering made it clear that employees were expendable commodities, not valued resources. Today, many bright workers are getting their revenge by fleeing their fickle employers for better-paying rivals -- or dot-com start-ups. Indeed, quitting has become so fashionable in Silicon Valley that the turnover rate for companies there has reached an estimated 25 percent a year. The average American 32-year-old has already worked for nine different companies. Workers today fantasize not about landing a "dream job" but about having a "portfolio career" -- one dream job after the other. 
 Is the death of the Company Man something that should be lamented or celebrated? We asked three leading management experts to offer their thoughts on loyalty in a virtual age.
 
Jeffrey Pfeffer
Stanford graduate School of Business
If loyalty is dead in some companies, it's mostly because it has been murdered by business practices like downsizing at the first sign of trouble and subcontracting out all "nonessential" positions. The message of "employability" -- that a company's only responsibility to its people is to get them qualified for their next job -- has clearly registered with the work force. Who can blame them for acting accordingly?
Today's rapid-turnover arrangements may seem good for the corporate bottom line, but in fact they make it difficult to build long-term, sustained success. In an economic environment in which capital and the latest technology are widely available, the only hope for building sustained competitive advantage resides in companies' management of their people. Thankfully, a few companies like Southwest Airlines, Toyota and Cisco Systems have retained the wisdom of building profits by taking care of their people.
Consider SAS Institute, the largest privately held software company in the world (with annual sales of more than $1 billion). It has a turnover rate of less than 4 percent. SAS does not contract out very much of anything, use many part-timers or tell people they need to think about their next job -- in fact, the company says that people will have three or four careers during their working lives and it hopes all will be at SAS. Nor does it offer stock options, dole out big bonuses or do any of the other things that companies with toxic workplaces have to do in order to bribe people into staying.
What SAS does instead is provide generous benefits like on-site day care, a full-indemnity health insurance plan (bet you thought this didn't exist any more), a 35-hour business week, recreational facilities -- as well as something much more important. While lots of companies say that "people are our most important asset," SAS actually believes it. People are trusted rather than monitored and controlled, given great equipment to work with, permitted to try new things, allowed to have a life as well as a job and, in short, treated with a respect all too rare in today's high-stress workplaces.
For SAS, being nice is good business. What happens when you work while exhausted?
You make errors. SAS actually prefers to ship software that isn't full of bugs -- what a unique idea! It needs fewer checkers than other software companies because its employees are awake on the job. The organization's low turnover saves it an estimated $70 million annually.
Too many companies think that laying people off or reducing wages is the best way to turn a profit. But loyalty is central to achieving success.
 
Rosabeth Moss Kanter
Harvard Business School
We are currently experiencing nostalgia for a golden age of company loyalty. Yet in too many organizations people were "loyal" not because they really cared but because they had no choice. Seniority reigned. Status, influence and big pay increases were tied to promotion. People didn't have stock options -- they had pension plans that handcuffed them to the company. The "loyalty" workers seemed to demonstrate by sticking around was illusory; many of them secretly dreamed of escape and retired on the job.
Old-fashioned corporate loyalty in which all status and rewards accrued to seniority stopped being good for the economy when global competition heated up; productivity and wages stagnated under the old corporate bureaucracy. Now that the economy is characterized by high work-force mobility, productivity is up and wages are rising. With a tight labor market, the shoe's on the other foot, and in many industries, it is employees who have numerous opportunities and companies that are desperate to retain them.
Companies today must offer great jobs in a great environment with great amenities -- and constantly improve on them. They must earn loyalty. Razorfish, a digital design firm, holds people who could go anywhere by offering exciting work for top clients, a hip corporate ambiance and larger-than-life amenities, like a Las Vegas trip for everyone in December. "I'd never leave such a cool company," a 30-something Web site producer told me. That is, not until a cooler company comes along. Razorfish has to think every day about how to stay the coolest.
I think it's a good thing that companies today have to work harder to keep the best people. The benefits they add make work more rewarding. Stock options make more people act like owners of their companies, and that can only benefit performance. And it's wonderful that companies now recognize that people have lives outside their work. Discovering high rates of turnover among female professionals, Deloitte & Touche, an accounting firm, took steps to add flexible schedules and control travel. These changes, useful for men as well, landed Deloitte in Fortune magazine's Top 10 list of best companies to work for in America -- helping the firm attract still more talent.
Some companies earn employee affection by making people proud to work there. I.B.M. gets high marks from employees because of its major financial commitment to public education innovations. Timberland offers its employees 40 hours of paid company time per year to work on community service projects.
You can't buy loyalty with just a paycheck. Building long-term commitment depends on four things: the nature of the work itself, the opportunity to grow, the chance to speak up and be listened to and the feeling of making a difference. Members of the new generation in the work force don't want to be subordinates; they want to control their own fate. They want to do meaningful work that has redeeming social value without sacrificing the chance to get a life. Give them that and they'll give you loyalty in return.
 
Tom Peters
Author of "The Brand You 50"
Loyalty is the glue that holds society together -- including commercial society. That said, corporate loyalty is rubbish. If you apply for a job at the Tom Peters Company and imply that you'd like to make a life of it, I'll unceremoniously throw you out of the office. Suppose you are a would-be Michael Jordan of my trade, consulting? I'll still toss you out.
Here's my New Social Contract. I want my company to be so attractive, so laden with talent, so energetic it makes your head swim. I want to give you an exciting work environment, peerless teammates and a string of challenging projects with top clients you could not match anywhere else. In turn, I demand that you give your all to these hot projects. And I demand that you be loyal -- to your teammates, to the client, to yourself. You must perform and grow as you've never performed and grown before.
However, I also demand that you not be "loyal" to me or my company. If you do turn out to be a Michael Jordan-type superstar, don't I want you to stick around? No! (And yes.) That is, I do not want you to stick around out of misguided allegiance. If I can provide you with exciting new challenges, and if you respond accordingly, well, then I hope we do indeed grow old together -- one project at a time.
Mindless corporate loyalty -- the essence of 50's Babbittry -- was always a rotten idea.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 6; Page 56; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2065 words

HEADLINE: 0%* Unemployment

BYLINE: By David Brooks; David Brooks is a senior editor at The Weekly Standard and author of the forthcoming "Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There."

 BODY:
Karl Marx spent all those years dreaming about the worker's paradise. Yet he never got to sit in the conference room at Berbee Information Networks Corporation and listen to Jim Berbee rattle off all the luscious perks he offers his employees. They get stock options, of course, but also Palm Pilots, cell phones and a $1,000 bonus to help with the down payment on their first homes. If they want to work in their pajamas, the company pays to install and maintain high-speed I.S.D.N. lines in their bedrooms. Two years ago Berbee took everybody in the company and their families to Disney World. Bagels and muffins are free on Fridays, the sodas in the office machine are free all the time (consumption went up 400 percent after that change), and if employees want to use the office copiers for personal use, no problem. An auto-repair service comes to the employee parking lot every other Wednesday to do oil changes and tire rotations. There's dry-cleaning delivery four days a week and pizza at least once a month (which for some reason employees still have to pay for).
Marx would have looked at all the cushy benefits and figured that the dictatorship of the proletariat had finally come to pass. But there's a simpler explanation. Full employment. Berbee is located in Madison, Wis., which has a microscopic 1.2 percent unemployment rate, second lowest in the country after another university town, Columbia, Mo. Jim Berbee is desperate to attract and retain workers. He has 220 employees and an amazing 94 percent retention rate, but his company is growing so fast he also has 110 job openings. "We're losing ground every week," he cries. 
 And it's not only the tech geeks who are in short supply. The employment classifieds in the Madison paper land on porches each Sunday with Richter-scale thuds. One company offered free maid service for new employees. No-skill, entry-level jobs carry wages of $8 or $9 an hour, blowing away the federal minimum wage of $5.15. Burger chains are beginning to offer health benefits to grill workers, and still some franchises have closed for lack of staff. Wisconsin Dells, a nearby resort area, has been forced to fly in summer help from Lithuania, Zimbabwe, Russia and New Zealand. Lands' End in nearby Dodgeville has given Green Bay Packers tickets to employees who recruit friends. Figi's, a mail-order company, offers free bus service and free breakfast at Burger King. (Talk about killing off your work force.) Carlson Company, which makes cosmetic counters, built a $750,000 day care center so staff members can visit their kids at story time.
Hubert Humphrey used to go to bed dreaming of conditions like this. But they're not celebrating in Madison. I bounced around talking to businesspeople, politicians and workers, and I kept trying to introduce the phrase "full employment" into the conversation, because it sounds so happy and satisfying. But they'd come back with the phrase "labor shortage," and then their brows would furrow with that expression of grave concern people used to wear when talking about exploding federal deficits. "Employers are have a very tough time finding workers," laments Madison's mayor, Susan J. M. Bauman. We sit in her office, looking gravely concerned.
The other thing you notice is that the locals aren't behaving like rational economic actors. With all these openings, workers should be hopping from job to job, taking advantage of all the perks and lures, boosting their income to the max. Yet a survey done by the QTI Group, the largest local staffing agency, found that the job-turnover rate has been dropping even as the unemployment rate has plunged. QTI has 48 people in Madison trying to find mostly lower-skill workers for clerical and industrial jobs. Every so often, the company offers $10 to anyone who comes in and completes a job application. In Madison, in other words, they're paying people just to look for work.
But no one's jumping at the opportunities. Nor are wages skyrocketing. Salaries are rising, especially among low-end workers and up top among the techies. But salaries are rising nowhere near as fast as you'd expect in such tight labor conditions. You get the impression that even in flush times most people are still pretty conservative when it comes to work and job hunting.
I keep hearing the same things. People don't like to jump around. People like to work at places that are familiar, or where some member of their family already works. Nepotism reigns. Melster Candies Inc., the country's leading manufacturer of circus peanuts -- those orange puffy things made from sugar -- solved their staffing problems when they sent job applications home with some of their workers, asking if they had any underemployed relatives. Jim Berbee boasts that he has had daughters recruit fathers and husbands recruit wives.
This isn't the free-agent nation that our futurologists are always predicting. This isn't the land of rampant, loyalty-is-dead individualists. There's a little more caution and communitarianism in the air here. One is reminded that Wisconsin is said to outstrip most of the rest of the nation in Tupperware use per capita. This is the kind of state where people save their leftovers. And that basic sense of ballast colors the local reaction to prosperity. There aren't many people riding around in Lexus or Mercedes S.U.V.'s.
The job center in Madison, which coordinates state and county jobless, housing and other benefits, is just in the shadow, and definitely within the aroma range, of the Oscar Mayer meat-processing plant. Inside, it looks like a high school library, with rows and rows of computers, where people can page through the online job listings. I plugged in my profile and came back with 442 executive openings, 403 clerical openings, 292 sales openings and so on, including some career options I'd never really considered, like boar-semen collector, TV weatherman and wooden-pole inspector. The people at the keyboards around me were diverse, a couple of young Asian and Hispanic men (there has been an influx over the past two years as word of the hot job market has spread), a middle-aged white guy in a hunting hat, a few seniors and miscellaneous young people. There was some sarcastic chatter among terminals: "Work on Saturdays? Are you kidding me?"
Mary Witt, the director of Dane County Job Service, says that most of the people already have jobs, but would like to find some place where they can advance. A basic problem for employed and unemployed alike is that people are too cautious when looking for work. "Most people select the line of work they've done before," Mary Witt says. "People think small."
In contrast to greater Madison's relentless optimism, the mood in the employment office is sober, if not gloomy. And why not? This is about the only place anyone hears any bad economic news. "I can get anyone a job," says Tom Swoboda, a counselor, "but will it pay the bills?" Madison's real estate prices have risen with the economy, so about a third of the people in the homeless shelters have full-time or more than full-time work. The saddest cases, the counselors tell me, involve extraordinarily well-educated people -- men and women with Ph.D.'s and law degrees -- who have propelled themselves into an elite stratum where job competition is still fierce. Job experts are urging employers to begin looking for workers among formerly marginalized groups, like criminals and liberal arts majors, but apparently it hasn't helped these folks.
I've driven a few miles from the job center, and it is as if I am standing at the source of the Nile. I am here at the midway point of the assembly line for the Sub-Zero Freezer Company. From this very spot, high-end refrigerators flow out to overendowed kitchens around the globe -- to Santa Monica, Fifth Avenue, Bethesda, Boca, Winnetka and across the whole fertile crescent of upscale squash-court-size kitchentopia. It is humbling to be here, at the source, knowing that the shelves being installed in front of me will one day hold organic chutneys, frozen free-range prawns, Florentine pestos and all the other delicacies so pleasing to the nation's bull-market gourmets.
If there is any place in Madison where people have a right to feel puffed up by their economic success, it is here at Sub-Zero, the makers of the quintessential chichi 90's product. Yet I'm not sure I've ever been in a more unpretentious and tradition-conscious corporate culture. I've just had a meeting with three executives, genial conservative white men in their 50's in blue or gray suits, white shirts and muted ties. These guys are proud to be making a top-of-the-line product, but it could be top-of-the-line turbines or diesels, to judge by their complete lack of fabulousness.
Sub-Zero tried to use robotics to put together its machines. But the robots made too many mistakes. So they went back to making the machines by hand. The workers look like classic assembly-line labor, former high school football stars now wearing Packers shirts over slightly bulging waistlines. They have old-fashioned Harley-Davidson tattoos, not newfangled Nirvana-inspired tattoos, and high school degrees or an equivalent. Sub-Zero, though it is growing quickly, doesn't have much trouble finding workers. Fathers bring in sons and daughters; some are third-generation Sub-Zero families. Once in place, workers tend to stay. And newcomers are drawn by the company's reputation at the rate of about 10 to 15 applications a week.
That's the final striking feature of the Madison job market. If the average worker were strictly Homo economicus, he'd choose an employer on the basis of salary and benefits, and jump when he's offered something better. But time and again, people mention the importance of reputation. They want to be able to give a satisfying answer to the cocktail-party question "Where do you work?" Status companies seem to have a big advantage finding workers, and that is true in the manufacturing sector as well as among the biotech and high-tech start-ups.
In the heart of downtown Madison there is a tech company that has a corporate culture several galaxies removed from Sub-Zero. Sonic Foundry is a software firm that makes it possible to convert audio and video for the Web. It is located in a string of renovated warehouses. There's an iron rule of office design: the more beaten and industrial the look, the more likely the firm is a high-tech start-up looking for a patina of gritty industrial authenticity. (If the headquarters are clean, quiet and sedate, with tranquil carpets and serene watercolors, then you know the company is in manufacturing.) Sonic Foundry, with its factorylike office design, is at the cutting edge of the information age.
I should confess straight out that I'm probably not cool enough to even write about Sonic Foundry. There are 20-somethings with bleached-blond surfer haircuts, pierced noses, Smash Mouth goatees, baggy pants and office nameplates with tags like Dirtforker on them. The hipness rolls off them in waves. "Our business is one of the sexiest industries you can be in," says Rimas Buinevicius, the company's C.E.O., lounging back in his black turtleneck on the couch next to a retro steel coffee table. "It's the nexus of new media and music."
The hiring process sounds like the velvet-rope scrutiny you might get at a downtown club. Each potential employee is interviewed seven or eight times, to make sure the person is "going to fit in culturally," Buinevicius says. Sonic Foundry has a growth rate of about 100 percent a year. But once you're in, there's no cooler place to be. There are about 60 computer engineers on staff, and over the past five years only one has left.
So there's even stability among the stock-option rebels at Sonic Foundry. In fact, the affluence feels a lot more stable here than in the Silicon Valleys or Alleys or the rest of the Fast Company corridors. Economists have been puzzling about how the recovery has been able to surge for so long without inflation. Many have been wondering when the nation is going to have to pay for all the gilded-age excess. But maybe Wisconsin is more typical of America than Palo Alto or SoHo or any of the other Next New Thing zones. Maybe even where the economy is hot, most Americans have remained cautious, conservative and cool.

PUB-DATE: March 5, 2000

SECTION: Section 5; Page 11; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2289 words

HEADLINE: Feel the Burn? It's More of a Glow

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO writes frequently for the Travel section.

 BODY:
SPA is one of those curious words that is redefined every generation or so. A century ago, spas in the United States were mineral springs, where visitors suffering from ailments such as arthritis, rheumatism or jangled nerves soaked in steamy, sulfurous waters. A 1950's spa was a fat farm, with a lettuce-leaf diet and a battery of beauty treatments. Fitness spas, where chirpy instructors screamed "Feel the burn," typified the 1980's; everyone jumped and sweated for hours in big, mirror-lined rooms and almost never went outdoors.
Now comes a new definition: the holistic spa. True to its New Age name, the holistic spa aims to treat the whole person -- mind, body and spirit -- and gently instill good habits meant to last long after the visit. The prototype calls for a diet of organically grown food that's healthy but ample (no more lettuce-leaf entrees), generous exercise with an emphasis on strength training, hiking and yoga (goodbye step aerobics) and exotic pampering treatments using techniques and natural ingredients from the Far East, ancient India or even the region around the spa. Health services, such as bone density tests, acupuncture and consultations with a nutritionist, are often included in the holistic approach. And to keep you in touch with nature, a waterfall or cactus forest should grace the grounds. 
 "A spa today is not about a massage," declared Horst Rechelbacher, founder of the Aveda Corporation, speaking last fall to the annual convention of the International Spa Association, an industry organization of spas, their owners, wellness instructors and service providers such as massage therapists, which has grown from 91 members in 1990 to more than 1,200. "It's about everything -- healing, learning, relaxing, well-being -- and how it all integrates."
Not every spa in the country is equipped, or even inclined, to provide an all-out holistic retreat. But the theme is pervasive as spas try to offer visitors a complete experience instead of a haphazard series of workouts, massages and meals. The model is the classic mind/body spa, which has been around, in various incarnations, for 60 years. The philosophy is that physical fitness isn't enough: you need to nourish and refresh your mind to be completely relaxed. And relaxation is the elusive but desirable commodity spas want to offer. In a recent survey, commissioned by the spa association, 61 percent of 351 people who had visited a destination, resort or cruise spa within the past year said they went to a spa to relax, followed by 13 percent who said pampering was their priority.
Dramatic growth in the number and variety of spas is the other significant trend. In 1980 there were fewer than three dozen spas in the United States. Today there are more than 1,600, according to Bernard Burt, an industry consultant and a founding director of the spa association, ranging from day spas to resorts and cruise ships with spa amenities to full-blown destination spas. You'll even find a handful of old-fashioned mineral spring spas. Burnished by the strong economy, most of the growth is at the high end. Lower-priced spas still thrive, though it's unusual to find a full-service spa with overnight accommodations for under $135 a night a person, without treatments.
Industry observers expect the growth to continue, particularly as the health-conscious baby boom generation ages. In the spa association survey, just 5 percent of nearly 28,000 respondents said they had been to a resort spa in the past year, but 25 percent said they were interested in staying at one. Spas are attracting younger visitors, as well, "particularly day spas, where increasingly guests are 35 and under," said Peter C. Yesawich, whose marketing firm, Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown, conducted the survey. In addition, 35 percent of visitors to the resort, cruise and destination spas are now men, the survey found.
Not surprisingly, the growth is shaking up what was once a sleepy, if iconoclastic, cottage industry. In the past, the American trailblazers were destination spas that reflected the vision of a single individual, such as Deborah Szekely's sybaritic Golden Door in Escondido, Calif., or Sheila Cluff's sportyspa the Oaks in Ojai, Calif. But operating a spa has become so expensive, real estate concerns and large corporations are behind much of the recent expansion. Indeed, in 1998, the Golden Door was purchased by a Dallas real estate investment trust, which has since opened branches at resorts in Telluride, Colo., and Las Croabas, P.R.
To aficionados, the destination spa, where clients immerse themselves in healthy living day and night, is the genuine spa experience. "We make you stay for a week because that allows you the time to get into your mind and visualize peace," said Ms. Szekely, who also founded the Rancho La Puerta spa in Tecate, Mexico. "It also builds a sense of community. If you know the woman next door will be your neighbor all week, you'll say 'hi.' "
But such spas are labor-intensive and costly to run. Though Mr. Burt estimates there are around 30 in North America (and just under 60 worldwide), no new ones are being built. To raise the destination spa profile, 25 of the best known, including the Greenhouse in Arlington, Tex., and Cal-a-Vie in Vista, Calif., recently banded together, producing a magazine and launching a Web site, www.destinationspas.com.
Most of the growth is in day and resort spas. If a destination spa is a nutritious five-course meal, a day spa is a glass of fresh-squeezed orange juice -- a quick gulp of health and indulgence. In tune with the holistic philosophy, the best day spas go beyond conventional massage and fete you with herbal tea and eye candy, such as waterfalls and greenery, as they dispense such services as Chinese herbology facials, hot stone massage, ear candling and acupuncture.
Resort spas blend elements of the two, although depending on the resort, they vary enormously in scope. Generally, a resort spa provides many amenities of the destination spa with a more permissive diet and stays of almost any duration, even one night. As at a day spa, you can usually drop by for a scalp massage or an aromatherapy bath, even if you are not staying at the resort. Resorts allow you to graft a spa experience onto a conventional golf, beach, skiing or even theme-park vacation and provide the perfect holiday compromise when only one member of a couple wants to visit a spa. And because you can pick and choose spa activities, you determine how much wellness and herbal tea you can stand. In addition, children are often welcome.
Spas outside the United States are evolving, too. As Europe's state-run health systems cut back financing for classic hydrotherapy treatments, many old-style hotel spas in France and Germany have closed. The survivors are spas in better quality hotels, particularly those with American-style treatments. Day spas are flourishing worldwide, as are spas fashioned as retreats that immerse visitors in a country's culture. And big international hotels in Asia are building American-style resort spas.
"ALL resorts and hotels, if they want to survive, will eventually have spas," said Raoul Andrews Sudre, president of Aspen Spa Management, a consulting firm in Fort Lauderdale. He predicts that big hotel chains will start their own schools, training spa staff to a uniform standard of service. "It shouldn't be acceptable that four different estheticians do four different versions of the same treatment," he said. "If you visit a Ritz-Carlton or a Holiday Inn, you know what to expect. But people don't always know what to expect at spas."
So what can you expect from the spa of the future -- or the one you plan to visit next month? More than before, as spas new and old scramble to set themselves apart from the pack. An attractive building and adventurous pampering treatments are two obvious allures.
Think of the classic old-style spa, a clinical, Mitteleuropean structure out of a black-and-white movie, more hospital than haven with boxy, windowless treatment rooms. It's history. The new and refurbished spas are integrating historical or geographical details into their architecture, creating light-filled buildings with high ceilings and windows galore. The Spa Ojai, part of the Ojai Valley Inn and Spa, resembles a California mission, while the Westglow Spa in Blowing Rock, N.C., looks like Tara. Mr. Sudre describes the newly renovated spa at La Mamounia hotel in Marrakech, Morocco, as a facility with touches of the Arabian Nights. "A spa should give people the opportunity to live a dream, or be transported to another world," he said.
Many spas choose to transport visitors to the natural world, with the creative use of woods, rocks, waterfalls, plants and windows. "Losing touch with what's outside is what causes people to get so out of balance," said Jane Segerberg, president of the International Spa Association and former director of the Sea Island Spa at the Cloister in Sea Island, Ga. "Your mind doesn't quiet unless it's with nature."
Treatment rooms are friendlier, too. Treatment suites, where couples can indulge in simultaneous pampering, have become popular at spas like the Canyon Ranch Health Resort in Tucson, Ariz., and the lovely spa, in its own freestanding building across the Chao Phaya River, of the Oriental Hotel in Bangkok. Alfresco treatments are growing in appeal, too, at places like the Aquae Sulis spa at the Regent Las Vegas, which has a massage cabana.
Like spa architecture, the newest pampering treatments are elaborate, individualistic and laced with fantasy. Prevailing influences are Asian; instead of Swedish massage, you'll see Shiatsu massage, Reiki and Thai yoga massage on trendier treatment menus. Watsu, a style of massage based on the principles of Shiatsu and performed as you float in a pool, was the talk of the spa association's convention and is offered by a growing number of spas, including Canyon Ranch.
"When you're in warm water, the massage has more effect on your body and spirit than when it's performed on land," said Michele Chelenza, whose company, Waterdanse Consulting, in Middletown, Calif., trains Watsu practitioners.
High on the exotica charts is Aquae Sulis's Ela Kizhi rejuvenation treatment, based on the 7,000-year-old Siddha Vaidya system of herbal medicine, which purports to make skin look younger with the use of fresh herbs harvested from Hawaii and India during the monsoon season. "We do about two dozen a week," said Patricia Schneider, the spa director, of the 80-minute treatment, which costs $225.
For that holistic touch, spas are designing treatments that use local plants or traditional therapies. During the Adobe Clay Purification at the Spa at Marriott's Camelback Inn in Scottsdale, Ariz., adobe is applied to the skin, then washed off with a soap made from Southwestern plants and a cactus cloth, made from cactus ribs. Following a rubdown with juniper and sage oils, guests relax in the sauna ($110 for 60 minutes).
Spa experts expect these treatments to become more personalized. "Spas need to listen to what a client wants," said Mr. Rechelbacher. "I hate lavender, and I remember a massage therapist saying, 'You'll like it because I do.' Well, I didn't, and she shouldn't have used it."
To further distinguish themselves, spas are cultivating specialties. In the future, look for spas that provide child care, particularly for new mothers who want to get back in shape after having a baby. Or spas specializing in treating alcohol and drug abusers. And more spas will provide healing and recovery centers for patients who have undergone plastic surgery.
Medical-service spas are already a fast-growing niche. As health insurance companies cut back on preventive care, spas have stepped in with services such as cholesterol tests, bone density scans, cardiac stress tests, nutritional analysis, fitness assessments, even physician consultations. Spas provide a controlled environment in which to foster healthy eating, exercise and lifestyle habits. "People used to ask how to lose weight and look 10 years younger, but now they're coming with health questions," said Kristine Huffman, health and healing director at Canyon Ranch in the Berkshires in Lenox, Mass.
SPAS that don't have a health team on staff may look to outside sources. Last year, Dr. Florence Comite, an associate clinical professor at Yale University School of Medicine, initiated Destinations Health, a customized preventative care program for 35-to-55-year-old women that is available at the Noelle Spa for Beauty and Wellness, a day facility in Stamford, Conn., and the Spa Ojai. Before visiting the spa, participants fill out a questionnaire that is evaluated by a team in Connecticut. During the spa visit, a health and longevity portfolio is created that makes recommendations in areas such as diet, exercise and stress reduction.
"It's a health road map, with information on how to prevent disorders of aging and make the most of your health assets," said Dr. Comite, who plans to implement the program at additional spas. It costs $1,800 at Ojai and $1,500 at Noelle.
Escape -- from stress, worries and screaming kids -- is, of course, a classic spa specialty that will continue to flourish. Consider the town of Hershey, yes, that's Hershey, Pa. With a theme park, chocolate museum and candy factory tours, Hershey is a children's fantasy, but what about their parents? This fall the Hotel Hershey will open a spa, and is planning luxurious grown-up treatments like rose petal baths and milk and honey body wraps. Can cocoa-powder exfoliants and crushed-almond body scrubs be far off?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1069 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Work Now: 3-5-00: Word & Image;
Free Agents Unite!

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
By their media shall ye know them.
That has always been my test for whole societies. Never mind whether they call themselves Democracy or Republic: free press means free country; controlled press, miserable tyranny. The same goes for individuals. My media test also works for sorting out people, especially office workers. Never mind the title on the door or the workplace habitat, media power is what denotes true rank, clout and worth. 
 It was in Washington that I first realized that medium is not just message but also identity. Obviously, not every civil servant of rank could command a corner window or private toilet. So the telltale sign of superiority became a pen -- a government-issue tapered pen that stood erect in a holder originally designed for quills. A mere stenographer might also accidentally qualify for a window or coat closet instead of rack. But only a boss had one of those pens beside the blotter and water pitcher. Federal regulations required that token of status, no less rigorous than the Pentagon's dress code.
Ever since, I have come to expect workers' media of communication to define their hierarchical worth. After elegant desk sets became commonplace, corporate and government strivers acquired intercoms to summon subordinates. Next appeared dictation machines, and then portable recorders whose content could be tossed to underlings for typing and brought back for signing with those executive pens. Later down the chain of command came multibuttoned telephones with one-touch connection to different layers of the bureaucracy. And later still managers got silent buzzers to alert a secretary to overhear and transcribe a conversation. Eventually, inspired by the White House, the highest ranks achieved voice-activated recorders.
Inevitably, these functional media spread to hoi polloi, forcing the invention of supplementary definitions by decor, notably rugs on the floor, art on the walls and keys to private toilets, elevators and dining rooms. But ranking by media remains the most reliable status index. Indeed, it seems to be surviving even the centrifugal force of the Modem Rebellion.
In the post-modem world, the passkey to privilege is the PC password. In communal offices, whosoever is enabled by secret code to read into another's files -- without being read in return -- is well on the way to sizable bonuses and stock options. And even the least powerful password leads to a corporate support system of benefits, counselors and technological expertise. Walls, windows, carpets, paintings -- all the old physical attributes of rank and power have been supplanted by a virtual, and portable, medium. Institutional passwords unlock undeniable privilege. Few individuals cruising alone on the Web can long compete.
There are young techies who persist in believing that the Information Revolution is destroying all hierarchy and rapidly democratizing the means of creation and expression. They sound much like the last century's revolutionaries who thought they could democratize (i.e. communize) the means of production. Wired magazine, the liberationists' bible, would have us believe that every wired person on the planet will soon have an equal voice in things -- except, of course, that Wired itself is empowered by the lush advertising of corporate behemoths.
The modem explosion has indeed produced a great dispersion of the work force. And many of America's more than 20 million new home-office laborers proudly proclaim themselves "independent" contractors, "free agents" and "self-owned" businesses. Many delight in their flexible work schedules, with time for the kids and for errands, and their escape from supervision. But the truth is that a great many of today's independents, temps and self-employed are the downsized of yesterday, cast adrift without community, benefits or unemployment insurance. Never mind what they call themselves; by their media shall ye know them.
Look past the deceptively egalitarian cell phones, faxes and PC keyboards: truly secure, insured and tax-code favored Americans are wired into networks and propelled by corporate engines. And their speech is amplified by a collective. They get group health and pension plans that are subsidized by taxpayers as well as employers, plus numerous workplace amenities, sometimes even including child care. Equally well served are some "outsourced" workers who may labor at home or on the road but are authorized by higher authority to use SecurID cards and passwords to scale institutional fire walls and tap into networks of privilege.
The majority of home workers who cruise alone in the Internet without these corporate keys or community are discovering that their vaunted autonomy comes with a large dose of ignominy. They labor in fear of illness or recession, or both, and they lack protection against discrimination, most notably in taxation. They must pay an employer's share of Social Security as well as their own. They do not qualify for group insurance or benefits. They must fight the government to deduct office expenses. Only a few professionals among them enjoy the power to bargain collectively.
Show me a worker who hacks at home without a corporate password and I'll show you an underprivileged citizen. To be sure, communal office workers (is there no better term for the old office-office?) are bound to routines and schedules that interfere with domestic bliss and duties. And they are intensely scrutinized, most gallingly by WatchDog, a software that lets the boss track your every movement on the Web. But the home-office worker must watch the dog -- and greet the repairman, pay bills, chase accountants and lawyers and cry out constantly for technical help. That's multitasking with a vengeance.
Sooner or later, most unincorporated individualists will be corralled into unions that bargain for benefits and provide shared services. The MacArthur genius finders have already embraced the farsighted Sara Horwitz, the founder and leader of Working Today, a nonprofit lobby for nearly 100,000 free-agent members. Effective representation, of course, will require taxation and incorporation, then elections, politics and varied ranges of influence -- in other words, hierarchy. The reward will be benefits collectively achieved and individually coded, duly accessed by some password, the key to social worth, your place in the crowd.
