SECTION: Section 2; Page 39; Column 3; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1653 words

HEADLINE: SPRING MUSIC/ORCHESTRAS;
With a Texas-Size Ambition

BYLINE: By ANNE MIDGETTE; Anne Midgette writes frequently about art, music and theater.

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
TELL a New Yorker that the symphony orchestra in Dallas is 100 years old, and the reaction will probably be surprise. The Dallas Symphony Orchestra would like to change that.
True, being 100 in Dallas is a little different from being 100 in, say, Philadelphia (where the orchestra is celebrating its centennial this year as well). The Dallas Symphony's history has followed a roller-coaster track of highs and lows. The group that started in May 1900 as the Dallas Symphony Club rose to see Antal Dorati and, briefly, Georg Solti as music directors in the years after World War II. But it also had to suspend operations during both world wars. It almost folded in the 1938-39 season, and in 1974-75, when Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphians were celebrating that orchestra's 75th anniversary, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra was shut down for most of the season because of a bankruptcy that nearly snuffed it out. 
 But you get to reinvent yourself in America, and the Dallas Symphony has forged a new identity as a healthy American orchestra. In 1989, it opened the striking Meyerson Symphony Center, designed by I. M. Pei. In 1994, it hired a young American music director, Andrew Litton. In recent seasons the orchestra has visited Carnegie Hall regularly, and this year it will make its second European tour. It releases two to three CD's a year. Its composer's chair, established in 1999, is filled by one of America's most successful young composers, Lowell Liebermann. And the orchestra is aiming even higher.
"The board has a mandate to get Dallas within America's top-tier orchestras," Mr. Litton said. "It's a long-term project. I think it will take 10 years. And another five before the world notices."
The $100 million question (that being the size of the endowment the orchestra's president, Eugene Bonelli, hopes to raise in his quest for international renown) is whether it is possible to buy a tradition as something more than a good, solid, middle-of-the-road American orchestra.
In the last two decades, Dallas has devoted considerable resources to putting its cultural life on the national, even international, map. The downtown Arts District, where the Meyerson Center is located, did not exist 20 years ago. The symphony and the Dallas Museum of Art had been housed in outdated buildings in a complex known as Fair Park, a 15-minute drive from downtown.
The vision and backing of a few community leaders helped create the culture district out of whole cloth. The Dallas Museum of Art opened its new Arts District premises in 1984; the Meyerson followed in 1989. The Nasher Sculpture Park is to open in 2001, a gift of the Dallas real estate magnate and sculpture collector Ray Nasher. Next, Mr. Nasher and others dream of a new performing arts center for the opera company, the last Fair Park holdout. All of this, they hope, will gain the city a new cultural standing.
Certainly, the $82.5 million Meyerson Center -- which, if it had been named for its lead backer, would be known as the Ross Perot Center -- proves that with enough vision and money, you can indeed elevate your status. Justly famous for its architecture, the hall is also known for its sound. Its acoustical designer, Russell Johnson, equipped the wood-lined auditorium with huge resonance chambers, curtains that retract at the touch of a button and a 42-ton acoustic and lighting panel that looks like something out of a science fiction fantasy as it rises and falls on wire cables over the stage.
From the audience's standpoint, the sound is impressive. But not all the musicians agree. "It can be a tricky hall to play in," the principal clarinetist, Gregory Raden, said. "Onstage, you can have trouble hearing each other." Orchestra players were quoted as saying the same thing to Donal Henahan of The New York Times when the hall opened.
An important figure on the Meyerson's building committee was Mr. Bonelli, a symphony board member for 15 years. In 1993 he switched over to take charge of the orchestra's administration. As president of the Dallas Symphony Association, Mr. Bonelli has gone out of his way to stress his commitment to making the orchestra one of the best in the country. Formerly a dean of the School of the Arts at Southern Methodist University, Mr. Bonelli brings plenty of musical knowledge, if not practical experience, to his task.
But what will be most crucial to the endowment campaign is his ability to raise money. Still profiting from the groundswell that the Meyerson's opening created in the community, the Dallas Symphony has a lot more backing than it did in, say, 1974, when it went bankrupt during a period of local economic prosperity. Then, businesses chipped in a mere $28,000, a pittance even in 1974 dollars. Now Texas Instruments alone has pledged to help underwrite the orchestra's regular classical series for the next three years, to the tune of $1.3 million.
Local businesses have also contributed to the recent redesign of the Web site dallassymphony.com. Four of them have worked with the orchestra to create a technologically up-to-date site equipped with such bells and whistles as live 32-bit Webcasts of concerts, e-commerce and, come June, fully automated ticketing capabilities. The price tag over three years: more than $10 million. Even taking into account that this figure includes in-kind services from the companies involved, it's a whopping sum that occasions envious glances from other American orchestras.
Another place the Dallas Symphony spends money is on recording. Its label, Delos, stresses the importance of a two-way relationship. What this means in practice is that the orchestra itself covers the musicians' fees for recordings. Delos pays the costs of preproduction, bringing in equipment, and marketing and distribution. In these tight times for classical recording, there is a feeling in the industry that orchestras will, more and more, be going Dallas's route and assuming part of their own recording costs.
The Dallas Symphony will also need to spend money to attract the top-flight players necessary to achieve its high-flown goals, and to add at least 10 to its current roster of 92. But however much it spends, it may not be able to compete with all the cultural advantages of the Northeast or the tradition of an orchestra like Philadelphia's, which has lured away both the concertmaster, David Kim (who spent the 1998-99 season in Dallas), and the principal trumpeter, David Bilger.
"I want to have an impact on the history of music," Mr. Kim said. "I don't think I can do that in a Dallas or a Houston."
It is going to take a lot more money to change that. It also means that an improvement in musical standards that began in 1977 under the previous music director, Eduardo Mata, and that has continued since 1994 under Mr. Litton will have to be pushed further.
"The orchestra's level of technical expertise wouldn't need apology in any city in the world," said Scott Cantrell, the new music critic of The Dallas Morning News, which sponsors the orchestra's main concert series. "Whether Litton is one of the profound and compelling interpreters of today is another question."
Mr. Litton said he felt a "closed" quality about the orchestra under his predecessor. Opening it up and helping it move toward a more individual, freer playing style is a big part of his self-assigned task. The repertory Mr. Litton favors tends toward big, splashy works like Walton's "Belshazzar's Feast" or the Mahler symphonies. Not much Haydn or Mozart appears on the schedule.
Among the players, there is a consensus that Mr. Litton's energy and drive have led to more touring, more recordings, more exposure. But he has proved an uneven interpreter. His energy, expressed in Bernsteinian flourishes onstage, can be compelling, but it can also spill over into coarseness. His tempos are audibly idiosyncratic. He also has a predilection for the loud.
"The brass pushed to the very edge of vulgarity, and then, just, drew back," a critic from The Times of London wrote of a 1997 performance of Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony at the Royal Albert Hall. "It seemed an emblem of the entire performance. Litton would dare extremes of tempo and dynamics which, in other hands, could well curdle into sentiment or flash into mere histrionics. Yet he pulled it off."
This description of a kind of tightrope act, of snatching a decent performance from the jaws of something far less classy, could apply to a number of Mr. Litton's live and recorded performances.
To judge from reviews, the orchestra can make a good first impression, which it may not sustain on longer acquaintance.
"Artistically, we're in a holding pattern," said Gregory Hustis, the principal horn player. Audiences may feel the same way. The last five or six seasons under Mata, and the first seasons under Mr. Litton, were completely sold out. But attendance has declined slightly over the last two seasons.
Mr. Litton seems unconcerned. His contract runs until 2003, and he is clearly content with his position. "You can tell when things are right," he said. "Why leave when we're on the up curve?"
However harrowing the history, there can be little question from the present perspective that the Dallas Symphony is a success story. "When I first came, we played background music while people stood in line to get swine-flu shots at the North Park Mall," said Mr. Hustis, a 24-year veteran. "The musician's lot in the Dallas Symphony is incomparable, it's so much better."
And some players see nothing wrong with embracing this new status as an eminently respectable second-tier American orchestra and leaving it at that.
"For who we are and what we are, we do a pretty good job," said the flutist Harvey Boatright, who has played with the Dallas Symphony for 40 years. "If it makes some people happy to think that we're shooting for the top, well, fine."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 50; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Price of Freedom

BYLINE: By Nina Munk; Nina Munk last wrote for the magazine about the architect Thierry Despont.

 BODY:
It's early winter. Cold. We've ordered in breaded-chicken sandwiches, Ari Horowitz and I, and are sitting in his cheerless office in Midtown Manhattan. "This whole concept of having to be in the office from 9 to 5, or whatever it is, that's gone, that's just not the world," muses Horowitz, founder of FreeAgent.com, a Web site for independent contractors, freelancers, part-timers and moonlighters. "There's no corporate loyalty or any of that stuff anymore."
Above Horowitz's desk is a badly framed reproduction of a Jackson Pollock. Near the door, tacked to the wall, is a blown-up cover of Snowboard Life magazine that Horowitz rescued from someone's trash. ("Learn to Snowboard the Easy Way!") Not that Horowitz, 31, has much time for snowboarding or art collecting. Himself, he's not a free agent. "I'm an entrepreneur, so I've got to come here every day. I can't disappear. I can't even take vacations. The free agent has a much better lifestyle. They're not necessarily going to make as much money as I might, but they can go snowboarding; they can decide when they want to work and when they don't want to work. It's an incredible lifestyle. I can't really think of a better way to spend your life." 
 Along with Horowitz, a small but vocal group of academics, evangelists and entrepreneurs are promoting this way of life: they're convinced we're on the cusp of a free-agent revolution. From their point of view, big centralized companies with thousands of permanent employees are relics. Back in the days of manual typewriters, before the electronic age, megacompanies made sense. How else could a team of engineers, designers and marketers work together? But in the digital age, the reasoning goes, megacorporations will be displaced by something called virtual corporations -- teams of "free agents" who work together for the duration of a project, and no longer. Ari Horowitz compares the virtual corporation to a movie set: "In Hollywood, when you produce a movie, it's not about a corporation, it's about all these individuals who have complementary skill sets: they come together, they work on a team, they produce something and they disperse," he explains. "This is what I envision the future of work being."
According to the gospel, free agency isn't just a business model; it's a workers'-liberation movement, promising emancipation from the shackles of corporate America. Perhaps you've heard this radio ad for FreeAgent.com, whose slogan is "For a Brave New Work Force": "If people often call you the hired gun, you just may be a free agent. If people call you 'that guy on 15 who's been here forever,' you are not a free agent. If you've ever sent an urgent e-mail pitching yourself for a primo project half a world away, you're a free agent. If you've ever sent an urgent e-mail asking, 'Who left the burrito in the office microwave?' you are not a free agent."
Fussing over burritos left in the microwave is hopelessly conventional. As are dental plans, expense accounts, life insurance, 401(k) plans and sick leave. Today's heroes take risks -- they're entrepreneurs and I.P.O. millionaires, and if you haven't achieved that status, becoming a free agent may be the next best thing. The term free agent conjures the seven-figure salaries of professional ballplayers. It also hints at self-reliance: free agents, like mercenary soldiers, can join one army after another. They don't need the company, they claim; the company needs them. "Be your own boss!" exhorts an advertisement for Guru.com, another Web site for free agents. "Work where you want, when you want. No supervisors. No commuting hassles. Earn $$$ thousands. Freedom to balance your priorities and work in your pajamas."
The cult of the free agent took off in January 1998, when Fast Company, organ of new-age management, heralded on its cover, "Free Agent Nation." As if reporting the demise of corporate America (with its layoffs, office politics, demotions, harassment, hierarchies and general incompetence), the cover lines continued: "25 Million Americans Declare Independence. Are You Ready to Join Them?" It was the Boston Tea Party all over again.
The author of that story, Daniel Pink, a former speechwriter for Al Gore, has since become a one-man advocacy group for free agency, quoted as an authority in publications like Newsweek and The Wall Street Journal. A contributing editor at Fast Company, Pink is currently writing a book about free agents. He also operates a Web site called FreeAgentNation.com, and he gives (paid) speeches promoting free agency. In exchange for stock options, he serves on the advisory board of FreeAgent.com's parent company, Opus360, and writes an advice column for Guru.com. Pink claims he's enriching the lives of workers (many of whom do not have stock options). "I happen to think it's a human way to work, so I advocate it for people," he tells me.
Pink believes that something bigger and higher than technology is driving the free-agent revolution: a search for spirituality. "I thought this was an economic story," he says. "Then I realized it was much gooier than that. It's about emotions, feelings, lifestyle, family. . . . After I wrote the Fast Company article, my mailbox started flooding with letters from people saying, 'Oh, my God, this is me!' Work has become almost a secular religion; people are trying to self-actualize through work. But it's hard to find yourself in a cubicle. It's easier when you're on your own." In other words, earning $$$ thousands in your pajamas may well be the path to self-fulfillment.
Pink's greatest contribution to free agency involves statistics: when he wrote the Fast Company article, he counted 25 million free agents in America; now he says there are 33 million. Just how did Pink arrive at those huge numbers? He won't let on. "I'm pretty sure the government agencies don't know how to count this," he says confidently, explaining how his estimate is nearly three times larger than numbers compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (which says there are 12 million nontraditional workers in America). "I have in my book a separate chapter on numbers," Pink continues. "But I'd like to hold off on giving out that information until the book comes out. It's very difficult," he admits, "to be definitive."
Definitive or not, by this time Pink's hopeful and opportunistic numbers have been repeated so often they've become a cliche, repeated in stock-offering prospectuses, publicity material and other channels of hype. "Between you and me," a founder of a temp agency said, "Dan had no clue. But his numbers became gospel and, hey, it worked. Now everyone bases the market on those numbers."
Promoting their business models with Pink's buoyant stats, dozens of companies targeting free agents have been popping up. Among them: icPlanet.com, Ants.com, IMCOR.com, eLance.com, MBAFreeAgents.com, iNiku.com and Aquent.com.
Like FreeAgent.com, these Web sites match employers with employees, listing short-term and part-time jobs and encouraging "free agents" to post resumes online. They also offer advice and give pep talks promoting free agency to those who cling to their 401(k)'s as if to life rafts. ("Sure working for yourself is scary," warns Aquent's Web site. "Life is an adventure and then you die. Live now!") MBAFreeAgents' focus is business-school graduates; Aquent's is technology; IMCOR's is "portable executives," including chief executive officers, chief financial officers and chief technology officers.
Other companies riding the free-agent wave include the Ebays of human capital: online talent auctions like Bid4Geeks.com and Talent Market, part of Monster.com, where free agents offer their services to the highest bidder. Recently, a freelance pastry chef in Astoria, Queens, with a talent for making croissants and brioches, put himself up for sale on Talent Market. (He had attracted no bidders when I last checked.) At Ants.com and icPlanet.com, free agents compete in a process known as a reverse auction, in which an employer offers a job and entertains bids. One posting at Ants.com, for example, urges multilingual free agents to bid on this job: translating a mammoth high-tech manual from French into Turkish and English. As of late February, 12 translators had placed bids ranging from $50,000 to $750,000.
Whether they specialize in technology or Turkish, dot-coms dedicated to free agents have yet to prove they can make money. According to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, FreeAgent.com, for example, lost $30 million last year on revenues of just $400,000. Access to the site's basic services is free to anyone who registers with FreeAgent.com; at last count (Feb. 9), roughly 64,000 people had done so.
But in order for FreeAgent.com to be profitable, it must get its registered users to upgrade to membership status, which costs $199 upfront, plus $119 to $274 a month (higher rates offer more benefits). Members -- there were only 286 as of Feb. 9 -- get to buy group-rate insurance, join a retirement plan and have their paperwork looked after (invoices, bills, taxes and so on). Each member also receives between 250 and 500 stock options in FreeAgent.com's parent company, which is about to go public. In addition to fees from members, FreeAgent.com intends to charge companies for posting jobs. It also plans to sell banner ads and earn commissions on products sold through FreeAgent.com. An optimist, Horowitz anticipates that throngs of free agents, lured by "the perfect lifestyle," will eventually be drawn to his Web site.
For all the hype, there's nothing glamorous about most of the jobs posted on the free-agent Web sites. On FreeAgent.com, someone's looking for a bookkeeper to work 4 hours a week, there's a 15-hour-a-week job editing marketing material, an opening for a receptionist ("able to professionally answer 4+ incoming lines!") and so on through the range of skills.
I contacted a few dozen people whose resumes were posted on FreeAgent.com. Almost everyone admitted this much: if the right full-time, permanent job came along, they'd embrace it, eagerly. Last year Ralph Armenta lost his job as a managing director of a big hedge fund. When I spoke to him in January, he identified himself as "an involuntary free agent," working from his home in New Jersey on short-term assignments. "I'm 40 years old," he explained. "I have a couple of kids, age 6 and 2. I'd like stability. Maybe if I were 5 or 10 years younger and had less responsibility, I would take a run at it. But I want to be back in the work force." He doesn't want to earn $$$ thousands in his pajamas; like most people, he'd like a regular paycheck.
The profile that Paulette M. Glassman posted on FreeAgent.com highlights her 10 years of experience producing advertisements and films. But like Armenta, Glassman is not a free agent by choice. She is forced to make do with part-time work. "I keep hearing about how good the job situation is, but for me, for people who are grown women -- I'd rather not give my age, but I'm not 21 -- it's been tough to find work. I'm struggling to stay solvent." Most of the responses Glassman gets to her posting on FreeAgent.com and other job-recruitment Web sites are unwelcome: offers from multilevel marketing outfits, many of which appear to be Ponzi schemes. Sometimes, when the phone does ring in her cramped studio apartment, it's a debt-collection agency calling.
More than 60 percent of free agents earn less than regular full-time workers in comparable jobs, according to a study by the Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning Washington research group. They have no benefits, they don't get stock options or paid vacations, and free agents may not be protected by employment laws. "It's certainly true that there's a growth in the number of workers who are contract workers," remarks Stephen Barley, co-director of the Center for Work Technology and Organization at Stanford University. Barley spent two years studying free agents in Silicon Valley. (The results of that study will be published later this year.) "To call them free agents, however, is, well, interesting. The vast majority of them work through a staffing firm." Which is to say that the vast majority of them are temps. Outside Hollywood and Silicon Valley, the "virtual corporation" is virtually unknown.
For people whose skills are in high demand -- Java programmers, corporate turnaround experts, Internet consultants -- being a free agent may have the potential to be liberating. Last summer, Samantha Saturn (her real name) quit her job as director of marketing for CDNow, an online music store, in order to do her very own thing. She called her firm Saturn Network, whose promising slogan is "Expert Marketing Solutions for Digital Brands." So far, working out of a one-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village, Saturn, 28, has had four short-term assignments. Her latest: a five-month marketing project for PlanetOut, a gay-and-lesbian Web site that's getting ready for an initial public offering.
Saturn sets her own hours. She telecommutes. She doesn't have to play office politics anymore. Sometime she works from Les Deux Gamins, an of-the-moment cafe right around the corner from her apartment. Installing herself at a corner table with her I.B.M. laptop, cell phone and a pot of coffee, as if Les Deux Gamins were her office, Saturn holds meetings, she brainstorms, she writes long memos. "It makes me feel like I'm in Paris," she says. Like Hemingway at Les Deux Magots.
But New York in the 2000's is a lot more expensive than Paris in the 1920's. Being a free agent is costly. There are bills to pay: office supplies, long-distance phone calls, Internet service, photocopying, FedEx deliveries, travel, business lunches, lawyers and accountants. There's health insurance and Social Security and Medicare taxes, which, at 15.3 percent of income, is double what old-fashioned permanent employees pay. To balance the burden, Saturn has been given a bit of equity from some of the dot-coms she has counseled. "I'm getting little pieces of a lot of companies at a very critical time," she explains sotto voce. "There's no way I could do this unless I were a venture capitalist."
About her past life as an ordinary full-time employee, she remembers that she "was a slave to my job, a total workaholic." Is she following the 12 steps? Not exactly. "Actually," she confesses, "I work more now."
Back in 1988, long before the term "free agent" signified the emancipated worker, Randy Nelson, now 50, made a business decision: never ever again would he be tied to one company. For eight years, Nelson had been a rising executive in the oil-and-gas division of CSX Railroad in Houston. When CSX decided to get out of oil and gas, Nelson was out of a job, just like that. "That was a wake-up call for me, a watershed event, an epiphany," he recalls. "I thought, I never again want my personal identity to be wrapped up in a corporation. From now on I want to think of my employer as a customer, a client, a revenue generator."
Now Nelson identifies himself as a free agent, a portable executive. His last project was overseeing the introduction of software at a chemicals firm in New Jersey. It lasted 18 months. "I'm an entrepreneur, a make-things-happen guy, a mover-shaker," he says excitedly, explaining why the free-agent life suits him to a T. "I'm not a nurturer; I'm not a long-term guy."
But as Nelson admits, there's a downside to being your own boss and doing your own thing. "It's a very hard, grueling lifestyle," he says. On his last project, he was away from home for a year and a half. "I only came home on alternate weekends. And you don't have control over the downtime between assignments. You may want two months off but get five, or want five months off an'd get only six weeks. You can't do it if you're not a self-driven person who's happy being lonely. You'll always be an outsider; you'll never be accepted as a full member of the team. You're kind of like the gunslinger who comes into town. People will say you're a coldblooded mercenary and look down on you for that."
The longer Nelson and I talked, the more his enthusiasm seemed to wane. "Sooner or later," he said, "I'm going to tire of this interim-executive thing."
Who has the most to gain from the free-agent revolution? Certainly those who advocate it. Ari Horowitz must surely be grateful that he is not a free agent but an Internet entrepreneur instead. He'll probably be worth about $35 million, on paper, when Opus360, FreeAgent.com's parent company, completes its coming initial public offering. As for Dan Pink, unofficial census taker of the free-agent nation, he'll soon be able to cash in his options in FreeAgent.com. And when his book is published early next year, he'll no doubt take his free-agent publicity machine on the road.
The other big winners are companies in the market for what economists call a flexible work force, which is to say, workers who can be hired and fired overnight, in the blink of an eye. Workers who answer 4-plus incoming lines and to whom you have no obligation whatsoever. Workers who are here today, gone tomorrow.
FreeAgent.com knows the score. Its Web site includes a page that encourages employers to hire its eager temps. "Top 10 Reasons Why Managers Love Free Agents" is how it begins. And then FreeAgent.com shows its hand:
10. They don't need pep talks.
9. They don't gripe about their salary.
8. They won't stab you in the back.
7. They tell you when your ideas expletive .
6. When they're sick, they work from home.
5. They don't ask for health insurance, paid vacations, personal days . . .
4. . . . 401(k) plans, stock options, quarterly bonuses. . . .
3. no performance reviews.
2. If they're stupid, lazy or incompetent, you can fire them pretty easily.
1. They do all the work, you take all the credit.

HEADLINE: From the Classroom to the Ballroom

BYLINE: By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
WHEN the sixth-grade students begin arriving for the 6:30 p.m. Social Dance Class at Eastern Middle School in Greenwich, each girl picks up a pair of white gloves from a basket and puts them on. They are all wearing dresses, or dressy blouses and skirts and party shoes, their hair neatly styled.
An equal number of boys enter the room, all wearing jackets, ties and leather shoes, their hair combed, with not a pair of jeans or sneakers in sight. 
 Youth dance classes like this are blossoming in Connecticut schools, social clubs, dance halls and restaurants. Ballroom dancing has shed its stuffy image and become the in thing to do.
Hip hop and rap, and the oversized clothes associated with them, may not be ready for the oldies heap, but they are facing competition from ballroom dancing and maybe even a return to good grooming among Connecticut youth.
Laura DiNatale arrived to the dance class at Eastern Middle School with her mother, Jean DiNatale, a Parent Teacher Association volunteer who helped set up the evening's refreshments with a fellow P.T.A. volunteer, Maria Dubaz. Mrs. DiNatale is also in charge of the gloves for the entire group. She collects and washes them after each session and brings them back to the next class.
"I'd rather be in the gloves than touch some of the boys," said Laura. "Their hands get all clammy. Plus the gloves are elegant," she adds, looking at her hands.
The trend toward ballroom dancing, which is a generic term for dances such as the cha-cha, fox trot, tango, mamba, waltz and swing, is attributable in part to the popularity of big band music, like "Zoot Suit Riot," performed by Cherry Poppin' Daddies. Santana's "Smooth," which recently won Grammy Awards for record of the year and song of the year, is also very popular with midddle-school dancers.
Robin Poska of Ballroom Magic Inc. of Darien teaches dance classes with her husband, Edward. The Poskas had 250 students in their ballroom classes five years ago. They now have 1,000 students and have added more programs in other communities.
Arthur Murray Dance Studios in Danbury has had a 10 percent increase in programs for young adults and Sophia Almeida, the Danbury franchise owner, said the company reports the same increase worldwide.
Ms. Poska said parents sometimes need to give a gentle push to get their children to try ballroom dancing, but by the time they have been doing it awhile, as the Eastern Middle School youngsters have, they look forward to it.
Besides teaching at Greenwich's Eastern and Central Middle Schools, the Poskas teach social dancing and etiquette to young people in Darien, Rowayton, Westport and New Canaan. They have waiting lists in many communities.
A return to civility is prompting a renewed interest in ballroom dancing and good manners, according to Tammis Lazarus, director of the Junior Assembly of Rowayton, where the Poskas teach social dancing and etiquette, including table and telephone manners, and thank-you note writing to children in Grades 4 through 6.
"I think it's something all kids need to be exposed to," Mrs. Lazarus said. "Learning these things from people other than their parents helps kids to listen and take it in."
It took a while to catch on when she first started the program, five years ago, she said. Some parents were reluctant to sign up because they thought their children wouldn't like it.
"But they don't know how fun and beneficial it is until they try it," she said.
Movies and the media have also revitalized ballroom dancing. A Gap commercial, featuring swing dancing, that aired last year was a huge catalyst, as were movies like "The Mask" and "Swingers," according to Peter von Oy, a college senior from Newtown, who recently started a swing dance group, "Swing in' Time" with his younger sister and brother, Alyssa and Tyler.
Peter von Oy, a soccer player and martial artist, had never taken a dance lesson before his new-found passion. His interest began after a visit from his best friend who goes to college in Colorado and introduced the von Oys to swing last year. They were hooked after the first session. They hold regular weekend dance parties in their basement recreation room and give demonstrations at fund-raisers and special events.
"People who do ballroom dance are in as good shape as runners," Peter said. "
Although Tyler, a seventh grader involved in the school drama club, admitted to preferring computer games to swing, he agreed, "It's a lot of fun and gets your heart going. It's good to impress people at school dances."
Alyssa, a senior in high school and all-around athlete, is involved with a program called physical education leadership at Newtown High School and has taught swing to younger students during gym classes.
The von Oys' goal is to compete in swing dancing and teach it to other young people. They have a Web site for their dance group at www. geocities.com/swing_in_time/.
Virginia King, the assistant principal at Newtown Middle School, introduced ballroom dancing three years ago at the school. Ms. King had been attending the Wednesday dance nights at Newtown's Fireside Inn and became involved with ballroom dancing, so much so that she added a large dance studio to her home.
"My dance partner and I would attend our middle school dances, and we always attracted a crowd of students," Ms. King said. Ms. King surveyed the parents, determined a high interest level and hired Stephen Karpovich, director of the Arthur Murray studio in Danbury.
The Newtown students have their classes right after school and wear their regular school clothes, but Karpovich still manages to incorporate dance etiquette into the sessions.
"We all learn etiquette without the white gloves," he said. "I was a big-time jock in school. Dancing takes endurance and technique. It's made me a better athlete. I like to call it 'dance sport,' rather than ballroom dancing."
John Grocki, director of athletics at Irving Robbins Middle School in Farmington, has arranged to have a ballroom dance artist teach swing to the eighth grade in preparation for their promotion dance at the end of the year, where they will be accompanied by the school's jazz band.
Michelle Evans, a winner with her dance partner of numerous ballroom dance awards in the United and England, will teach the in-school sessions, paid for by the Parent Teacher Association. Last year Ms. Evans taught after-school classes at Irving Robbins, but her schedule does not permit it this year, Mr. Grocki said.
"The kids really enjoyed it," he said. "Every kid that started out with it finished it. They're coming to me this year and asking if we're going to do it again. My feeling is the kids need more dance. Their coordination is not where it should be."
Ms. Evans, who lives in Collinsville, started a nonprofit organization called Hartford Youth Dance Initiative five years ago. She teaches social dance to children from all different socio-economic groups at Moylan Elementary School and the Breakthrough Charter School in Hartford.
"I decided to devote myself to teaching the lifelong fun of ballroom dancing to children," she said. "It's something you can do your whole life, like riding a bike. Once you learn it, you never forget it."
Ms. Poska agrees with the notion of starting dance training at a young age. Some parents think fourth grade is too young, but Ms. Poska finds it's ideal because children are so receptive at that age.
"We make an effort to make the program enjoyable and child-friendly," she said. "Parents remember the girl who didn't get picked, or the boy no one wanted to dance with. Now everyone dances with everyone. The hardest job for parents is to get their child there the first night."

HEADLINE: From Tree to Table, It's Time to Taste Syrup

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
MUD season is maple syrup season. Now is the best time to visit one of Connecticut's 200 maple syrup producers to watch tree sap boiled down into syrup.
Even though the state produces its own maple syrup, the odds are that syrup bought here will come from somewhere else, most likely Vermont. 
 Last year, Connecticut generated 1.9 percent of the New England maple production compared to Vermont's hefty 54.8 percent.
Stephen H. Broderick, extension forester for the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension system, said Connecticut wasn't thought of as a maple products state, but it should be. "According to a survey of the U.S. Forest Service there are at least 100,000 acres that could be managed for maple production," Mr. Broderick said. But they are not, he added, because "homeowners don't understand that they could rent their property to maple producers."
Small wooded areas could be tapped but the trees must have a diameter of about 10 inches. Maples must generally be about 40 years old before they can be safely tapped without harming the tree.
Maple syrup sells at a premium price because maple sugaring, the process of converting maple sap to maple syrup, is labor intensive and requires about 40 gallons of sap to produce just one gallon of syrup.
The sap, esentially sugar water, is gathered in buckets or by flexible plastic tubing, then collected in a tank and fed into an evaporator, which dissipates the water, leaving only the concentrated sap. High-quality syrup requires fast boiling at 218 to 220 degrees.
Jason Mancini, a staff archeologist for the Mashantucket Pequot tribe, said the Connecticut Indians probably learned the skill of tapping for sap from tribes in more northern parts of New England. He explained that sugaring, which includes making both syrup and granular maple sugar, was a relatively new activity.
"About 300 to 400 years ago there were hardly any maples," he said. The native people, he said, burned the forests "to prepare to plant crops, build homes, encourage browsing of game and to spur growth of nut trees which they believed occurred after burning."
The Connecticut landscape at that time resembled "a big field," according to Stephen Cook, the curator of the Mashantucket Pequot Museum. Connecticut was a significant grain-producing state until the 1920's, he said. Maple trees began to reappear in the mid-18th century when the burning had subsided.
Several different varieties of maples grew but only two types of maple trees yield sap for syrup. One is the classic sugar maple (acer saccharum) which turns golden yellow in fall and produces a sap that is 2 percent sugar. The other, soft or swamp maple, (acer rubrum) turns brilliant red in fall and yields sap that is half as sweet and requires much more to yield a gallon of syrup, according to Mr. Broderick.
Homeowners can forget tapping that spreading Norway maple in the front yard. It cannot be used. For the adventurous, black birch trees can be tapped for a birch syrup with a minty flavor that Mr. Broderick said was the original source of wintergreen flavoring.
Maple production is not a large industry; in fact, in the words of Ron Olsen, a marketing representative from the Connecticut Department of Agriculture, it is "a little niche." In 1999 that niche was 13,000 gallons of syrup, earning producers $500,000, which Mr. Olsen called a good year.
Maple products have an additional impact on Connecticut's economy. When families visit the sap houses found throughout the state, they are part of the emerging business of "ag-tourism," combining a family outing with an opportunity to learn about agricultural. "It's not necessary to drive up to Vermont to see the sugar process," he said.
Visiting farms is growing in popularity in Connecticut. The tree tapping begins when the ground is frozen and ends when trees begin to bud.
"This time of year, folks are looking forward to spring and a visit to a Connecticut sugarhouse is a bridge into the new season," said Shirley Ferris, agriculture commissioner.
Homeowners can make their own maple syrup but Mr. Broderick suggests it be done outdoors. Mr. Broderick warns that the process produces so much steam it can peel off kitchen wallpaper and coat walls and ceiling with light brown sticky stuff.
"I have seen homemade rigs designed through Yankee ingenuity including 55 gallon drums, brick walls for the firebox and big lasagna pans to cook the sap," he said.
Several Connecticut dealers sell modern equipment to make maple syrup. (Mr. Broderick said it could be dangerous to use the old sap collection buckets and boiling pans because of the lead.) The Flanders Nature Center in Woodbury, has a booklet, "Making Maple Syrup at Home" that provides how-to directions and recipes that include maple-flavored popcorn and ice cream.
The nature center has been demonstrating the art of making maple syrup since the mid-1960's. On weekends, up to 50 people inspect the taps and buckets and crowd into the sugarhouse to watch the sap boil into syrup. Visitors leave smelling sweetly of maple.
Jolynn Rostowsky, director of education at the center, said demonstrations will conclude on March 19.
Another traditional New England treat consumers can easily make is called "sugar-on-snow." It involves pouring boiling hot thickened syrup over fresh snow packed into a pie pan or cone. The result is a confection with a taffy-like texture. In Vermont the traditional accompaniment to sugar on snow is the dill pickle. The Northwest Park Sugarhouse in Windsor serves this treat without the pickle.
Richard Norman, of Woodstock, the president of the Maple Syrup Producers Association of Connecticut, expressed concern about this year's crop because of last year's drought.
"Summer is when the trees put away their starch," said Mr. Norman, who has tapped trees for 25 years. "The drought might make a difference. We'll know in a few weeks."
Warm sunny days followed by cold nights below freezing cause the pressure in the maple trees that starts the sap flowing. The season is over when the tree buds appear, generally mid to the end of March unless it is an unusually cold spring when the sap flows into April.
Several Connecticut nature centers have maple syrup demonstrations. For a complete list of maple producers, call the Connecticut Department of Agriculture at (860) 713-2503 and ask for the "Guide to Maple Sugarhouses."

HEADLINE: Convention Center Shapes Boston Harbor Area

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
WITH a 2.3-million-square-foot convention center as its vanguard, a new commercial neighborhood with luxury housing is emerging on Boston Harbor, which for almost four centuries has been the heart of this compact city perennially in search of expansion space. Nine projects valued at $3 billion are being developed in a district once dominated by wharves, ship terminals, fish processors and warehouses.
On April 2, after almost a year of site preparation, construction will start on the $700 million South Boston Convention and Exhibition Center, the linchpin of this new downtown district. 
 "It's a big gorilla that's about to sit down on the waterfront," said Dean F. Stratouly, a Cambridge developer who is directing the convention center project for the Massachusetts Convention Center Authority.
Once completed in 2003, "It will legitimize the whole area." Mr. Stratouly said, creating "a demand for 4,800 hotel rooms and support services that will drive up real estate values."
The modernistic 120-foot-long, 6-story convention center will be large enough to attract the major meetings that have been bypassing Boston. The eight other projects being developed nearby include luxury hotels, offices and 1,200 residential units to be built within the next five years.
They will complement the convention center as well as the 1990's projects -- a new federal courthouse and hotel -- that sprouted on this section of the waterfront, which is a 10-minute walk from Boston's financial district and a six-minute drive to Logan International Airport.
"It's a gold rush already," said Mr. Stratouly, president of Congress Group Ventures, referring to the new projects being planned and the rising real estate values. The increased real estate costs are raising housing prices in the surrounding residential areas of South Boston. "The waterfront," Mr. Stratouly said, "is going from lunchboxes to briefcases."
But some wonder whether this boon for developers and businesses will hamper the operations of New England's premier commercial port, which in 1999, according to port officials, transported $10 billion in goods through its newly dredged waterways. "When you have incompatible uses, something has to give," said Vivian Li, president of the Boston Harbor Association, a private maritime advocacy group. "The conventioneers and firms moving in from the financial district will displace the small businesses that work the commercial port."
Indeed, 92 mostly maritime-related businesses were relocated to assemble the 62-acre convention center site. But the Port of Boston, which since 1996 increased the value of the cargo it handles by 30 percent, hopes to acquire more waterfront space for support operations like warehouses. "We're bursting at the seams," said Georgeanne Tacelli, a spokeswoman for the port.
Signaling the competition under way for space at the harbor, the Gillette Company, one of New England's largest manufacturers, with a sprawling plant on the South Boston waterfront, also intends to continue growing in the area.
Ultimately, the factor that has made all this development possible and will determine which players can efficiently use the waterfront is access to a modern intermodal transportation system, a network that integrates travel by land, sea and air. "What makes this area work for any particular user is transportation," said Ms. Li, the maritime advocate.
Throughout the 1990's, about $20 billion in federal, state and municipal funds have been earmarked to rebuild the land transport network that runs through downtown Boston, linking the waterfront and with the airport via a new tunnel under the harbor. During the road construction, new sewer, water, electric and telecommunications lines are being installed underground. Some of the funds have also been invested to upgrade facilities at Logan Airport, as well as to clean and dredge the harbor waters.
The convention center site is at a crossroads where all forms of the upgraded transportation network will intersect. It is within a few blocks of what will be a rebuilt downtown highway, Interstate 93; a new extension of the Massachusetts Turnpike; a truck haul road; a rapid transit line; and the Ted Williams Tunnel to the airport. However, while about $320 million in federal and state funds have been allocated at the 500-acre commercial port for new terminals, cranes and computerized truck-cargo processing, its transport system is still missing a vital link.
MODERN ports need double-stack freight rail facilities so cargo containers can be lifted off ships and loaded two high on freight trains. In 1995, the State Legislature allocated $86 million to modernize tracks and raise a few bridges to enable the double-stack trains to pass underneath, but the funds have never been appropriated.
"There's no more movement on double-stack rail," said David Panagore, who is directing the convention center project for the city planning agency. But a recent planning agency agreement with CSX railroad will enable steel for the convention center to be shipped to the site by rail, to lower construction costs. Given these developments, shippers and truckers worry that they may lose access to the area in a few years if roads are closed to commercial traffic to make way for pedestrians, Ms. Li added. Nevertheless, each year the port is generating $10 billion in revenues and $3 billion in related economic activity.
Meanwhile the convention center, financed by $700 million in state and municipal bonds and taxes, is likely to lose $15 million annually in its early years while generating $500 million a year in direct economic activity, according to Alan D. Reid, chief financial officer of the convention center authority. "The convention center is a loss leader to fill the hotels and restaurants," he explained.
The convention center has gone from concept to construction quickly for a project of its size and complexity. In only three years, a group of business leaders and politicians shepherded enabling legislation through the Statehouse and agreed on a site and a design; the city took the 62 acres by eminent domain; and the South Boston community settled on a benefits package of about $10 million in housing, training and jobs.
The glass, steel and precast concrete convention center, designed by Rafael Vinoly Architects of New York and HNTB Architecture of Boston, will have a 600,000-square-foot exhibition hall, 200,000 square feet of meeting rooms and parking for 1,000 cars in its first phase of 1.9 million square feet. Attached will be a $265 million, 1,120-room Sheraton Hotel to be developed by Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc. of White Plains.
While many hotel projects here and across the country have been stymied by a dearth of financing, Starwood expects that banks will extend loans and that pension funds will invest.
"Boston is a hot hotel market, we're attached to a state-of-the-art convention center, our site is a mile from the airport and so much new development is planned for the area," said Andrew E. Zobler, a vice president at Starwood.
Development prospects are bright, Mr. Stratouly stressed. After he completes his unpaid tour of duty for the convention center authority, even he may invest there. "At some point, this is going to be prime property," he said. "I can't develop anything now, but I hope to in the future."

HEADLINE: Foxwoods-Glen Cove Ferry Rules the Sound

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WHEN a Glen Cove councilwoman, MaryAnn Holzkamp, showed up on Wednesday to greet the Tatobam as it arrived in Hempstead Harbor to inaugurate high-speed ferry service from New London, Conn., there was no fanfare. In fact, she barely had time to get on board before an aide was whispering that the crew was ready to pull up the gangplanks for the return trip to Connecticut and they had to get off.
So after a rushed tour of the two decks, she was ushered out to the newly rebuilt pier as the Tatobam's twin 7,000-horsepower gas turbines began to whine and the ship moved away from the dock. She said she hopes that in time, the Tatobam will be seen as more than just a connection to the Foxwoods Resort Casino. 
 "I think eventually it will become an alternative means for Long Islanders to get over to New London, and hopefully it'll bring people from the other side to our community," Ms. Holzkamp said.
But not this week: all 28 riders who boarded in Glen Cove for the first regularly scheduled trip to Connecticut immediately boarded a bus in New London headed for the gambling halls.
"I've been waiting for this since they first started talking about it almost two years ago," said Nicholas F. Distasio of Oceanside. "I go to Foxwoods once in a while, and now I can see myself making more trips."
Inez S. Mirra of Old Westbury called in sick to her office to make the trip to Foxwoods, her first to the casino; one reason she has not visited is her refusal to face the traffic on Interstate 95, she said.
"This way, you can leave your car at home and the captain will do the driving," Mrs. Mirra said. At the Connecticut end, a Foxwoods bus picks travelers up at the dock and deposits them at the casino, then brings them back for the 6:30 p.m. trip back to Long Island.
"You really can't have a better way to travel," said Mark Doherty of Locust Valley, also a first-timer to Foxwoods. "The only problem is, you're kind of stuck to their schedule."
The only paying passenger who did not take the Foxwoods bus was Rudy S. Mackin of Jewett City, Conn., who boarded in New London for a round trip. He said that while he is a regular casino-goer, he was traveling last week to check out connections from Glen Cove to Manhattan for a trip he plans with his wife, Rose Marie.
"We usually drive, so I'm doing some reconnoitering," he said. "On a good day the drive is two hours and 45 minutes, maybe three hours. I would say 25 to 30 percent of the time, though, there's a delay, and that's only going to get worse."
Fox Navigation will run the 249-foot, 318-ton ferry the length of Long Island Sound and back twice each day, departing from the Cross Sound Ferry Terminal in New London at 6:30 a.m. and 6:30 p.m., and from Glen Cove at 9 a.m. and 9 p.m.
On three Fridays in February the ferry made test runs to and from Glen Cove, but Wednesday was the first day with paying passengers, and it went off within minutes of its published schedule, and with no evident glitches. Four stewards served coffee, soft drinks and snacks in the passenger areas. Three deck hands made sure all the mechanical systems were operating smoothly.
A light breeze out of the south and glass-calm water did not even put the advanced stabilizing technology to a test. A set of "wings" can be extended eight feet under the ferry to prevent it from rolling too much in the worst weather.
"Obviously, we're always looking for ways to improve our service, but this is an excellent start," said J. Grant Parker, director of operations for Fox Navigation. Among the improvements planned this month: satellite television that will beam sporting events and other special broadcasts to keep passengers entertained on the 2-hour, 15-minute run. "We want to turn this into an experience, not just a ferry ride," Mr. Parker said.
Up on the bridge, Capt. John F. Falvey Jr. stood with his hand on the joystick that has replaced the ship's wheel, his eyes scanning the computer screens that monitor every system on the ship. Underneath the ship powerful water jets pushed the boat through the Sound at more than 50 miles an hour, so fast the Coast Guard will not allow passengers outside during operation for fear they may be blown overboard.
"This boat is more manageable than just about anything else you're going to see," Mr. Falvey said. "I can stop this boat right now in less than 700 feet, an emergency stop, if we had to. You wouldn't want to do that with passengers on board, but we have done it in sea trials."
There had been some opposition in Glen Cove to the lease that the city gave Fox Navigation, reflecting concerns about the environmental impact, the deterioration of tidal wetlands because of runoff from the parking area, traffic and the impact on marine traffic.
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi responded that revenues from the lease will go toward cleaning up polluted sites along Glen Cove Creek, and that ferry service is one way of returning the area to productivity.
Mr. Parker said the ferry had environmental advantages as well. Its water jets will pump oxygen into the waters of the Sound; because of pollution the water suffers from low levels of oxygen every summer. And its gas turbines put out about one-fourth the pollution of a comparable diesel engine, and a small fraction of what would be generated if everyone aboard drove their cars back and forth to Foxwoods.
But the North Shore Environmental Alliance has not been appeased: it vowed to pursue a lawsuit against Glen Cove for failure to require an environmental impact statement before allowing the ferry to operate. Dan Maddock, co-president of the alliance, said that under State Supreme Court rules, a judge must decide within 30 days whether to hold a hearing on the case.
Kenneth L. Robinson, an attorney representing the alliance, noted that Fox Navigation had originally proposed landing the ferry elsewhere in Hempstead Harbor, at a site under the jurisdiction of Oyster Bay, but moved to Glen Cove because Oyster Bay was going to require a full-scale environmental study.
"The project should be suspended until the affected communities have an opportunity to review and evaluate the total impact of the operation on area traffic, air and water quality," Mr. Robinson said.
First-day passengers shrugged off those concerns, and said they expected the arrangement would eventually work to the environmental and economic benefit of Glen Cove.
"The property was a dump," said Kathy Lagatta, whose house overlooks the harbor. "They cleaned it all up. The community should be thankful for all they've done here."
Her husband, Neil Lagatta, said the new ferry dock could prove to be a turning point for Glen Cove's waterfront. Foxwoods and its rival casino, the Mohegan Sun, have already paid more than $1 billion to Connecticut under an agreement that allows them to operate slot machines, "and now, you can bet they're going to spread some of that money around here."
The new dock definitely means a shorter trip for Island gamblers. "If traffic is good it takes about three hours," said Carl Vita of Lynbrook. "But the day it snowed, it took me six hours. This ferry landing is only 18 miles from my house. It's a blessing."

HEADLINE: From Far-Off Shores to Long Island

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER 

DATELINE: STONY BROOK

 BODY:
IN the beginning, there were the Native Americans: the Algonquin tribes like the Matinecocks, the Shinnecocks and the Montauks. Then in the 17th century came the English and the Dutch, with their African slaves, in the first of what was to become succeeding waves of immigrants to Long Island.
When, how and why they came, where they settled and what they added to the melting pot is the subject of "New Neighbors: Migrations and the Changing Face of Long Island," an exhibition at the Museums at Stony Brook. Two years in the making, with art, photographs, oral histories, maps and personal artifacts, the show explores the cultural, economic and political effect each group of newcomers has had on the existing populations. 
 By "going back historically to look at the changes on Long Island," said Joshua Ruff, the exhibition's curator, "we can help contemporary Long Islanders understand the roots and the results of that diversity."
This understanding could eliminate some misconceptions, he said. "Most people tend to think that suburbanization dates back to Levittown," Mr. Ruff said, admitting he had believed that when he started the project. "But the growth of new suburban enclaves and villages really started in the mid to late 19th century when the population actually did start to rise, growing very quickly in the World War II period and then after the war and following the Hart-Celler Immigration Act of 1965."
This law, which liberalized the nation's immigration policy, Mr. Ruff said, had a major impact, both in numbers and in the nature of the immigration. It brought people directly to the Island, just as the Italian railroad and sand-mine workers, the Polish, German and Irish farmers and Jewish watchmakers had come in the 19th century, instead of by way of New York City.
The story is told both chronologically, divided into periods before 1880, 1880 to 1940 and more recently, and thematically, dealing with such subjects as "Fears, Stereotypes and Discrimination" and "Searching for the American Dream."
More than 100 items are featured, drawn from the Museums at Stony Brook's vaults or on loan from historical societies and libraries, museums like the museum on Ellis Island and private sources.
For the more contemporary aspects of the story, Mr. Ruff had to rely heavily on families that had kept photos and papers documenting their ancestors' arrival on the Island.
"I suddenly realized that the historical societies and museums, including ours, had very few, if any, modern items," he said. "And we should be collecting things that detail and document new populations arriving. But we've stopped roughly around 1940 and if we don't begin again there will be little around about the 20th and 21st centuries."
There are Native American clay pots from Montauk; a cane dating to 1639 that belonged to Edward Howell of Southampton; an 1824 sampler made by a member of the Elliott family of Sag Harbor; photos, circa 1890, of Italian-Americans at work on the Long Island Rail Road and sandmines in Roslyn; a Ukrainian wedding headpiece used at the turn-of-the-century in Riverhead, and broadsides put out in 1890 by the Long Island Rail Road inviting people to "Buy Homes on Long Island" with the "most healthful . . . climate on the coast."
There are also the medical license, circa 1950, of the Island's first Hispanic physician; deeds excluding blacks, Asians and Jews from buying property; a World War I poster in Yiddish urging Jewish immigrants to save food; photos and news accounts of the first black police sergeant in Babylon who settled in Amityville in 1950 after unsuccessfully trying to buy a house in Levittown; an ornate Indian baby cradle belonging to a family in Kings Park, and an oral history account of a political refugee's escape from El Salvador to Brentwood in 1981.
Among the more unusual items is a late 17th-century Dutch print labeled "Nieu Amsterdam," said Mr. Ruff, 27, who lives in Kings Park. "I found it at the New York Public Library, but I also found the same exact print labeled 'the West Indies.' I guess, the Dutch looked at both colonies the same way."
One of the more fascinating stories he came across, Mr. Ruff said, dealt with a village in Suffolk that a developer, Thomas Wellwood, founded in the 1870's. "He called it 'Breslau' in an attempt to attract the Germans who like the Irish farmers of the day were beginning to settle in the area. The name was changed to Lindenhurst in 1892, not, as legend has it, because the residents wanted to escape their German heritage, but because they had become disenchanted with the developer and wanted to break away from him completely."
Mr. Ruff had only one regret: "that I couldn't include more in the show, but I'm very limited in terms of space."
"Although," he said, "I guess I would have liked to have gotten A. L. Henry's painting, 'The Last of the Montauks' from an upstate museum. With others moving in, the Island's Native Americans became more and more invisible."
The exhibition features an interactive world map. "We're asking visitors to sign the book to tell us where their ancestors came from," Mr. Ruff said. "And then every week we'll update the map, adding pins for new places and new totals."
Eventually, Mr. Ruff said, he hopes the exhibition will help "start a dialogue as people, looking more historically at the phenomenon of migration, realize that it's a continuous process with ongoing phases. There are similarities in the way people respond to newcomers throughout these migrations. Furthermore, these changes taking place on the Island are clearly happening in other places as well."
"New Neighbors: Migrations and the Changing Face of Long Island" runs through July 4 at the History Museum of the Museums of Stony Brook on Route 25A. It can be seen from 10 a.m. to 5 Wednesdays through Saturdays and noon to 5 p.m. Sundays, and will be accompanied by special programming like "Merengue!," a concert by Luis Cordero and Los Amigos de la Amarque of dance music with roots in African and Spanish music, at 2 p.m. next Sunday. (631) 751-0066.

HEADLINE: Foxwoods Reaches Out to Long Island

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WHEN a Glen Cove, N.Y., councilwoman, MaryAnn Holzkamp, showed up on Wednesday to greet the Tatobam as it arrived in Hempstead Harbor to inaugurate high-speed ferry service from New London, there was no fanfare. In fact, she barely had time to get on board before an aide was whispering that the crew was ready to pull up the gangplanks for the return trip to Connecticut and they had to get off.
So after a rushed tour of the two decks, she was ushered out to the newly rebuilt pier as the Tatobam's twin 7,000-horsepower gas turbines began to whine and the ship moved away from the dock. She said she hopes that in time, the Tatobam will be seen as more than just a connection to the Foxwoods Resort Casino. 
 "I think eventually it will become an alternative means for Long Islanders to get over to New London, and hopefully it'll bring people from the other side to our community," Ms. Holzkamp said.
But not this week: all 28 riders who boarded in Glen Cove for the first regularly scheduled trip to Connecticut immediately boarded a bus in New London headed for the casino.
"I've been waiting for this since they first started talking about it almost two years ago," said Nicholas F. Distasio of Oceanside. "I go to Foxwoods once in a while, and now I can see myself making more trips."
The Mashantucket Pequot tribe built two high-speed ferries, the Tatobam and the Sassacus, before it shut down its New London shipyard. It envisions a network of ferry routes that would serve much of the Northeast. Some of the lines bring patrons to its casino -- besides the Glen Cove trips, it operates a route from New London to Martha's Vineyard during the summer. It has also operated a route between New Jersey and Martha's Vineyard, and the tribe has said it is interested in eventually linking Boston, Cape Cod, and possibly Newport, R.I.
Inez S. Mirra of Old Westbury called in sick to her office to make the Wednesday's trip to Foxwoods, her first to the casino; one reason she has not visited is her refusal to face traffic on Interstate 95, she said.
"This way, you can leave your car at home and the captain will do the driving," Mrs. Mirra said. At the Connecticut end, a Foxwoods bus picks travelers up at the dock and deposits them at the casino, then brings them back for the 6:30 p.m. trip back to Long Island.
"You really can't have a better way to travel," said Mark Doherty of Locust Valley, also a first-timer to Foxwoods. "The only problem is, you're kind of stuck to their schedule."
The only paying passenger who did not take the Foxwoods bus was Rudy S. Mackin of Jewett City, Conn., who boarded in New London for a round trip. He said that while he is a regular casino-goer, he was traveling last week to check out connections from Glen Cove to Manhattan for a trip he plans with his wife, Rose Marie.
"We usually drive, so I'm doing some reconnoitering," he said. "On a good day the drive is two hours and 45 minutes, maybe three hours. I would say 25 to 30 percent of the time, though, there's a delay."
Fox Navigation will run the 249-foot, 318-ton ferry the length of Long Island Sound and back twice each day, departing from the Cross Sound Ferry Terminal in New London at 6:30 a.m. and 6:30 p.m., and from Glen Cove at 9 a.m. and 9 p.m.
On three Fridays in February the ferry made test runs to and from Glen Cove, but Wednesday was the first day with paying passengers, and it went off with no evident glitches. Four stewards served coffee, soft drinks and snacks in the passenger areas. Three deck hands made sure all the mechanical systems were operating smoothly.
A light breeze out of the south and glass-calm water did not even put the advanced stabilizing technology to a test. A set of "wings" can be extended eight feet under the ferry to prevent it from rolling too much in bad weather.
"Obviously, we're always looking for ways to improve our service, but this is an excellent start," said J. Grant Parker, director of operations for Fox Navigation. Among the improvements planned this month: satellite television that will beam sporting events and other special broadcasts to keep passengers entertained on the 2-hour, 15-minute run. "We want to turn this into an experience, not just a ferry ride," Mr. Parker said.
Up on the bridge, Capt. John F. Falvey Jr. stood with his hand on the joystick that has replaced the ship's wheel, his eyes scanning the computer screens that monitor every system on the ship. Underneath the ship water jets pushed the boat through the Sound at more than 50 miles an hour, so fast the Coast Guard will not allow passengers outside during operation for fear they may be blown overboard.
"This boat is more manageable than just about anything else you're going to see," Mr. Falvey said.
"I can stop this boat right now in less than 700 feet, an emergency stop, if we had to. You wouldn't want to do that with passengers on board, but we have done it in sea trials."
There had been some opposition in Glen Cove to the lease that the city gave Fox Navigation, reflecting concerns about the environmental impact, the deterioration of tidal wetlands because of runoff from the parking area, traffic and the impact on marine traffic.
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi responded that revenues from the lease will go toward cleaning up polluted sites along Glen Cove Creek, and that ferry service is one way of returning the area to productivity.
Mr. Parker said the ferry had environmental advantages as well. Its water jets will pump oxygen into the waters of the Sound; because of pollution the water suffers from low levels of oxygen every summer. And its gas turbines put out about one-fourth the pollution of a comparable diesel engine, and a small fraction of what would be generated if everyone aboard drove their cars back and forth to Foxwoods.
But the North Shore Environmental Alliance has not been appeased: It vowed to pursue a lawsuit against Glen Cove for failure to require an environmental impact statement before allowing the ferry to operate. Dan Maddock, co-president of the alliance, said that under New York State Supreme Court rules, a judge must decide within 30 days whether to hold a hearing on the case.
Kenneth L. Robinson, an attorney representing the alliance, noted that Fox Navigation had originally proposed landing the ferry elsewhere in Hempstead Harbor, at a site under the jurisdiction of Oyster Bay, but moved to Glen Cove because Oyster Bay was going to require a full-scale environmental study.
"The project should be suspended until the affected communities have an opportunity to review and evaluate the total impact of the operation on area traffic, air and water quality," Mr. Robinson said.
In Connecticut, the ferry is operating out of an area where boats already serve Block Island, R.I., as well as Orient Point and Fishers Island in New York, so there has been no outcry about the environment. First-day passengers shrugged off those concerns and said they expected the arrangement would eventually work to the environmental and economic benefit of Glen Cove.
"The property was a dump," said Kathy Lagatta, whose house overlooks the harbor. "They cleaned it all up. The community should be thankful for all they've done here."
Her husband, Neil, said the new dock could prove to be a turning point for Glen Cove's waterfront. Foxwoods and its rival casino, the Mohegan Sun, have already paid more than $1 billion to Connecticut under an agreement that allows them to operate slot machines, "and now, you can bet they're going to spread some of that money around here."
The new dock definitely means a shorter trip for gamblers from Long Island. "If traffic is good it takes about three hours," said Carl Vita of Lynbrook. "But the day it snowed, it took me six hours. This ferry landing is only 18 miles from my house. It's a blessing."

HEADLINE: In the World of Starter Mansions, More Is More

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
WHAT are high-tech, high-intensity home buyers looking for in their new haciendas?
They are looking for houses that are bigger than ever; bigger than their parents' homes, bigger than their classmates', bigger than their colleagues', bigger than their friends' -- and more impressive, too, architects and real estate agents agree. According to the National Association of Homebuilders, the average American house is growing in size: to 2,225 square feet last year from 1,710 square feet in the early 80's. 
 But that is just the national average. In the new subdivisions of Westchester and Fairfield Counties -- along with the Hamptons and Aspen and other spots populated by the Nasdaq nouveau riche -- a house is not a house unless it is at least a minimansion, with 3,000 square feet as only the first notch on the architect's ruler.
"I've done them 3,000, 4,000, 8,000 square feet," said Joesph R. Crocco, a prolific architect based in Tuckahoe. Most recently, Mr. Crocco finished Whippoorwill Ridge in Armonk -- where houses start around $650,000, he said -- and he is working on more megahouses in Bedford, Pound Ridge and Armonk.
Judging from a selection of some of the newly constructed houses in Armonk subdivisions, the developers are also looking for variety: there is the chateau-esque, the baronial, the Abode of the Sea Captain, the shingle style gone post-modern and the House of the Seven Gables, among others.
"It's hard to make fun of these houses, seeing that my wife would kill to live in any one of them," said Alex Herrera, an architect who works at the New York Landmarks Conservancy and, among other things, advises developers on new construction appropriate to historic areas. Nevertheless, Mr. Herrera said the problem with the designs of many of these monster houses often stems from the proportions.
"In the old days, builders tended to be guided by pattern books," he said. "Now they're guided by product catalog: they pick out the fanciest windows by Pella, the fanciest doors from Marvin, the fanciest columns from that fancy column place and the fanciest garage doors from the fancy garage door place, so the parts go together in no particular order."
He pointed to a photograph of a house with seven gables ("And that's only on one side!" he said) in the Whippoorwill Hills subdivision, where houses sell for more than $500,000.
"Look at the tiny windows at the top of the garage door," he said. "They are out of proportion to the windows. And where's the front door? It's lost among the gables."
Inside, critics say, some of the houses have another problem: their layouts.
"These bigger houses are easier to design, because bigger houses are better armatures for the features the buyers know they want," said Duo Dickinson, the Connecticut architect who is the author of "Small Houses for the Next Century" (McGraw-Hill) and four other books.
If the outside of the house is suitably impressive, prospective buyers then seek to check off an ever-expanding laundry list of amenities (including, of course, a laundry.)
"It's gotta have a three-car garage with an eight-foot door for the S.U.V.," said Mr. Dickinson, who sheepishly admitted to having designed a handful of these pricy behemoths.
"It's gotta have his and her closets and his and her bathrooms, and a fireplace in the master suite and a separate study off the master suite and a den and his and her offices and a reading room and a media room and . . . " He paused to catch his breath. "I went through a spec house in Greenwich last week and it was mind numbing, all these rooms."
And the rooms do not always work the way they do in the older houses. Like Mr. Herrera's description of the exteriors as an amalgam of different parts, so, too, Mr. Dickinson said, is the inside.
"The house isn't designed," he said. "It's just rooms combined."
Mr. Crocco, the architect who has designed several projects for Michael Fareri, the prosperous Armonk developer, almost echoed Mr. Dickinson's list of rooms -- for people and automobiles.
"The developers have a lot of requirements," he said. "I get a lot of requests for three-car garages, large family rooms, elaborate kitchens, master bedroom suites with his and her bathrooms and media rooms."
In Mount Kisco, Russ Davidson, last year's president of the the county's American Institute of Architects chapter and this year's spokesman, said the architectural merit of new houses in Westchester County varies dramatically.
"Some," he said, "are very low-quality, cookie-cutter plans that have just been scaled up, and they show it. Others have been carefully worked out."
But in the end, he said he "can't understand why people pay $750,000 and more for a house that isn't as well designed as their Jaguar or their Armani suit."
Mr. Davidson admits he is prejudiced: he is an advocate of the individually custom-designed, client-commissioned dwelling, which he argues often costs less than the builder's spec model, no matter how magnificent.
Nevertheless, he conceded that people might actually like these off-the-rack, amenity-laden minimansions on a grass-coated suburban plot.
"There are a lot of people who don't take risks," he said, carefully, "people who don't want to wait a year to see how it turns out."
But there is a delicate balance between designing a house to make the house as impressive as possible and keeping it from looking, uh, eccentric.
In fact, some say the less stylish, the better.
Michael Carliner, an economist for the National Association of Homebuilders, said that his research shows that the more nondescript a new house is, the better it sells.
"Like Realtors tell you: paint the walls white," he said, "and keep it unoffensive -- and definitely stay away from the unique. These houses may be less imaginative, but they're certainly more marketable."
For Mr. Crocco, the architect for Whippoorwill Ridge in Armonk, it all depends on what the developer asks for in the design of his speculative mansionettes.
"Different developers have different ideas and different expectations," he said. "Some want top quality -- and some want it down and dirty.
"I've done it all," the architect said.
