LENGTH: 2321 words

HEADLINE: Well-Kept Secret? Armonk Becomes Builder's Paradise

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: ARMONK

 BODY:
MICHAEL E. FARERI pilots his silver Mercedes, with his name on the license plate, along the winding, wooded roads of this Westchester hamlet, pointing to swaths of property he used to own, currently owns or plans to own any day now.
Mr. Fareri is the developer du jour in this booming community, part of the town of North Castle, where hillsides and wetlands have given way to vast tracts of starter castles, home to Wall Street's bonus babies, who can pay cash for multimillion-dollar houses. 
 Mr. Fareri waves to everyone he passes, friends and foes alike, knowing that for every person here dazzled by his accomplishments there are many more who consider him the enemy, the defiler of what used to be. But he could not care less.
"Most people think I'm trying to rape this place," he said. "But if you want to be in the wilderness, go to Vermont. How can anybody say it's too much? As fast as I build them, they get snapped up. The world should run by the law of supply and demand."
The real estate explosion in Armonk, 30 miles from midtown Manhattan, has produced a typical small town tableau, comedy or tragedy depending on one's point of view. It offers plenty of conflict between old-timers and newcomers, developers and preservationsists, citizens and their leaders and neighbors fighting for their views. It has several stock characters, larger than life and full of bombast; a predictable subtext about history versus progress and a chorus of "Not In My Backyard" coming from all sides.
Let's start with the antagonists:
The nouveau riche builder with a midwinter tan, cufflinks like Krugerrands and a fleet of cars, lawyers and servants to fill his every need. The blue-blood former chairman of the Town Planning Board, who relished the power of a big fish in a small pond.
The new homeowners, some with more money than they know what to do with and others so real-estate-poor that their mansions have indoor swimming pools but no furniture. And the old-timers, who fear that the water wheels, grist mills and Revolutionary-era barns where they played as children will be destroyed and forgotten.
Mr. Fareri, the flashiest of the bunch, stands at center stage.
On a whirlwind tour of his real estate holdings, the 53-year-old builder points to grand houses, one after another, that he built for himself and later sold at 250 percent profit. He points to residential developments, from $200,000 condominiums in a renovated schoolhouse to small clusters of half-million-dollar town houses in a gated community, to tracts of nearly identical million-dollar McMansions, each an arm's length apart.
He drives by a Victorian-style office and retail complex on Main Street that he recently developed. Then the shell of a brick garage on Old Route 22 that he plans to turn into a diner, with a gas station theme. Next a desolate tract he has owned for years, home to an abandoned bowling alley, where he dreams of a sprawling supermarket, the kind with a coffee bar, sushi chef and gourmet takeout. And then there is a nursery, currently for sale, where he would like to set up a business for his daughter, a 25-year-old landscape architect.
"If I see a "For Sale" sign, I buy it," Mr. Fareri said. "Armonk was a well-kept secret. Now it has taken off. And it's only going to get better."
Besides Mr. Fareri, the man most responsible for Armonk's remarkable residential growth is Piers L. Curry, the recently retired head of the Planning Board. When he took up his appointed post a dozen years ago, Armonk was already blessed with the strong tax base that comes from commercial and industrial giants like International Business Machines, Swiss Re and Travelers. So, low property taxes were a draw in the subdivisions that have been built under Mr. Curry's watch, which some say have turned Armonk into a rich man's Levittown.
"Nobody was paying any attention" to Armonk for decades, Mr. Curry said. It was bypassed by the Metro-North, which has its nearest station in North White Plains 10 miles away, and had no highway access until Interstate 684 was built in the late 1960's, said to be a concession to I.B.M. Then the developers took notice, buying up estates and farms, only to be stymied by a stalled economy, high interest rates and widespread unemployment.
All that changed in the flush 1990's, when Wall Street money and pent-up demand turned Armonk into a builder's paradise. The first to capitalize on the change was Mr. Fareri, once an electrician in Yonkers, who had been buying land here for 25 years.
Since Mr. Fareri started building, others have joined him. Five major estate developments are in the works on Route 128, between here and Mount Kisco. Plus two on the hillside overlooking the Kensico Reservoir and other small subdivisions tucked here and there on older residential properties where excess land, fetching $300,000 an acre, has been sold.
Combined, Mr. Curry said, this recent building surge will add 391 new homes practically overnight to a community that had 957 houses in 1990 and a mere 257 20 years before. That growth rate -- to 1,348 from 257 units in 1970 -- is huge, said John Nolon, director of the Land Use Law Center at Pace University, attributable to open land in a neglected pocket and nearly a decade of unbroken prosperity.
This pace of development, needless to say, has spurred furious controversy. There is conflict between newcomers, who ride limousines to their jobs in the city and have no time to serve on town boards or as volunteer firefighters, and old-timers, who yearn for the secret wooded places where they played as children, now paved and off limits behind electric gates or deer netting.
"In a perfect world, three of us would own the whole place and nobody else would live here," said Mr. Curry, who recently sold his old farmhouse here and now divides his time between a vacation home in Rhode Island and an apartment, meant for a caretaker, in historic Smith's Tavern. "We'd all have 10-square-mile estates. But we don't and we can't. We have to play the hand we're dealt. I'd love to see gracious homes, less density. But it wasn't my call. The zoning existed. I saw it as my job to make the best of it."
Mr. Curry, who concedes he is no diplomat, has nearly as many detractors here as Mr. Fareri. Many residents say he conducted too much of the town's business in private, and he admits that many meetings about development took place "off line," without his fellow commissioners or the public present, in the interest of efficiency.
Mr. Curry argues that he had no leverage to stop development or influence its aesthetics, so long as builders were not asking for property to be re-zoned. Other communities slow the approval process to a crawl, he said, in the hope that a builder will give up and go elsewhere. But instead, Mr. Curry said, the builder often sues, or loses so much money during the delay that he puts up a shoddy product.
John A. Lombardi, town supervisor for 40 years, said efforts were made to slow the residential development by upzoning, so that many houses must now sit on two- to four-acre lots, and also by encouraging builders to put up fewer units than the law allows, say 25 homes on 80 acres when 40 would be legal. The culprit in the development boom, as Mr. Lombardi sees it, is neither the aggressive developers nor the lenient planning board, but the descendants of the original landowners.
"The people who sold the property caused the problem," he said. "The kids, the first thing they do when the old folks die is go to a lawyer" and put the land on the market.
The growth, Mr. Lombardi said, has strained Armonk's infrastructure -- its stores, roads and parking areas. The downtown, a mere block and a half, is choked with traffic and double-parked sport utility vehicles; the modest Food Emporium is no longer sufficient.
"We'd like to catch up," Mr. Lombardi said. "It's going to take some bold moves, but it has to happen. The only questions are how much, where and when."
One of the quaint local landmarks, Schultz's Cider Mill, is on the market, with a prospective developer who wants to use the land for a supermarket, which would require rezoning. Another promising site, owned by Mr. Ferari, is far enough from downtown to disperse traffic, but it also requires rezoning. It is here that Mr. Fareri will build a supermarket if he can, with a health club as his fallback since it is permitted under current zoning.
As Mr. Fareri has grown in influence, some townspeople have concluded that the government bends over backward to advance his projects, a charge town officials reject. Mr. Lombardi tiptoes around a question about which supermarket proposal he favors. To answer, he said, is to risk offending the people who have elected him to 20 terms or to invite litigation against both the town and himself. He only observed that Mr. Ferari's parcel is much larger -- 16 acres compared with 6 at the cider mill -- with room for a bigger store and more parking.
Future town meetings, regarding the requests for rezoning, are sure to be a cacaphony of opposing interests.
Environmentalists fear that improved roads or new stores in the buffer zone around the Kensico Reservoir will endanger the water supply. Urban planners and town officials, citing the goals of a 1996 comprehensive plan, are determined to provide additional parking and more places to shop.
Newcomers in the hillside developments, who have already blocked one attempt to build a supermarket or shopping center on the Fareri site, are adamant that they do not want commerce so close to their homes. But long-standing residents are just as dug in. Their vistas of rushing streams and blue herons have already been marred by the sight of backhoes and newly framed condos. How dare the very people who bought those houses say no to stores and parking lots that the hamlet needs?
"The town let them just cover the hillsides with matching houses, throw up gates and then keep everybody else from having a decent grocery store," said the Rev. Jack Miller, a Presbyterian minister. Mr. Miller lives here in a tiny Frank Lloyd Wright house that abuts a gated community built by Mr. Fareri and another subdivision, under construction, which Mr. Fareri sold to Toll Brothers, one of the nation's leading home builders.
Bernard Magdelain, a banker at Chaseand president of the Homeowners' Association at Whipporwill Ridge, a Fareri subdivision visible from Mr. Miller's home, commiserates with those who find houses like his own eyesores and even shares their feeling that the Town Board has let developers run amok.
But Mr. Magdelain and the homeowners he represents are four-square against a new supermarket on either of the sites visible from Whipporwill Ridge. They do not want the daytime traffic, the nighttime noise of trucks unloading or the Dumpsters and other mess and are quite content to travel beyond their borders to shop, some of them going to Greenwich, Conn.
"The town is being . . . I'm not going to use the word manipulated, but reactive to developers who come in with ideas," Mr. Magdelain said.
"Why don't they do site surveys and determine where is the best place and how big should it be? Why don't they show us the traffic studies, the environmental studies? There should be a long-term game plan here. Why do we only hear about things in whispers at cocktail parties?"
Mr. Magdelain sounds much like Mr. Miller, who asked the same questions about the planning process in regard to the new subdivisions. And there is a further ironic echo when he disdains the aesthetics of the subdivision that abuts his own, called Whipporwill Hills.
Mr. Magdelain said he sought a bucolic setting when he moved here and thus chose a site at the edge of a nature preserve -- and as far as he could get from Whipporwill Hills, which lacks some of the architectural details of Whipporwill Ridge.
His subdivision, Mr. Magdelain observed, is landscaped with good-size hardwood trees and fast-growing white pines that will eventually curtain each house from the others. Next door, he said, the developer must have "used Agent Orange" to clear the land. "I call it Jurassic Park," Mr. Magdelain said.
The land around both Whipporwill subdivisions is in the buffer zone near the watershed or wetlands protected by Federal environmental law. But these lands are under no legal protection, said Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council who has written a report on the risks to the Kensico Reservoir, the strategic choke point for 90 percent of the drinking water headed to New York City and lower Westchester. The situation "illustrates the weakness and short-sightedness of the existing laws," he said, adding that Armonk is Exhibit A for preservationists, since it has some of the last remaining parcels of open land in Westchester County and plans to develop retail projects and improve roads near sensitive sites.
"This is the most controversial development activity in the region," he said. "You can expect a raging battle there in the next six months."
Walt Bell will be watching it unfold.
Mr. Bell, a retired laborer in the warehouse at Reader's Digest, has lived in Armonk since 1928. He remembers when the I.B.M. campus was Wenga Farm, where he picked apples, milked cows and baled hay. He is trying to persuade the developers along Route 128 to preserve the ponds, grist mills and rock formations that once defined the landscape.
Mr. Bell admires the architectural detail and landscaping of Mr. Fareri's properties, compared with other subdivisions. But that does not blunt the loss he feels each time a childhood haunt is paved over. This he pours into poetry, including one poem that ends with this verse:
"The greed of man is what it be.
He sold our land of liberty.
And now our land is not so free.
So fear what is ahead of thee."

HEADLINE: EDWARD J. LOGUE;
Shared Leadership

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Herbert Muschamp's appreciation of Edward J. Logue "From an Era When Equality Mattered," Feb. 20 fails to get at some fundamental differences between the way urban reinvestment policy was conducted in Mr. Logue's heyday and the approach that cities have to pursue now in order to "reconfigure themselves in the era of mass suburban exodus." 
 The key issue is not the "collapse" of planning but the need for cities to manage a transition from traditional master planning to contemporary strategic planning in order to make inner-city revitalization efforts succeed in today's environment.
Urban renewal-era master planning in New York and other big cities was managed by the local development "czar," who was widely recognized as the center of policymaking and implementation. The photo accompanying Mr. Muschamp's essay, a shirt-sleeved Mr. Logue standing in the rubble of a soon-to-be-redeveloped site, is the perfect image of this traditional centralized leadership. In contrast, strategic planning for present-day reinvestment depends on a sharing of leadership responsibilities by government and community interests.
The most visible master-planned projects of Mr. Logue's era relied on large-scale demolition -- often accompanied by the displacement of families and businesses -- followed by new construction on cleared sites. Today's best strategic planning minimizes displacement and generates well-designed new construction combined with the rehabilitation of valued existing structures to preserve the traditional community fabric. Government-subsidized housing financed through the federal Low Income Housing Tax Credit and HOPE VI programs within the past decade in New York and elsewhere provide great present-day illustrations of the positive qualities Mr. Muschamp praises in Roosevelt Island's Southtown.
Mr. Logue and other city-rebuilders had access to lots of government money to support the realization of their plans. Like Philadelphia's Edmund Bacon, Mr. Logue showed that good design and a substantial investment of public funds could produce lasting benefits for targeted downtown and neighborhood development sites. Today's strategic planners confront a much more difficult problem: how to succeed in an environment of greatly reduced public fund-ing, through smaller, incremental implementation approaches which, though more limited in scale, produce tangible benefits for urban communities.
Planning for urban reinvestment in an era of constrained authority and limited resources is a challenge which, though formidable, can be mastered. When leaders in government, community organizations, and the planning-design professions collaborate effectively in the service of today's inner-city communities, they do far more to advance the ideals of equality and democracy cited by Mr. Muschamp than Ed Logue and other master planners were capable of achieving in their day.
 
JOHN KROMER
Philadelphia
 
The writer is Philadelphia's Director of Housing and the author of "Neighborhood Recovery: Reinvestment Policy for the New Hometown."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Habitats/West 110th Street;
After Agency's Reversal, A Tenant Faces Eviction

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
ANNE GILMAN, an artist and teacher whose works on paper are quietly riveting, moved into her two-bedroom apartment on West 110th Street 10 years ago with her husband at the time and their daughter, who was then 7 years old. It is in a well-maintained building with polished marble floors and friendly doormen, in a neighborhood more homey than chic.
Shortly thereafter, she became convinced that her landlord, Marsid Realty, was overcharging for the rent-stabilized apartment, so in 1990 she filed a rent appeal with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, an agency that oversees rent regulation. For four years, she heard nothing, but the silence didn't really matter, because she and her husband, who had met as teenagers in Queens, could afford the $2,095-a-month rent. 
 However, when they decided to break up after 20 years of marriage, and she still hadn't received an answer, she filed a request for a resolution of the case, called an Article 78. If the rent was going to remain, neither she nor her husband could afford it alone. She began looking for a smaller, cheaper place, and found one across the street and down the block.
"It had no doorman, and the fire escape led right into the apartment, which scared my daughter," she said. Still, it seemed she had to move, and it had two bedrooms. But just as she was about to sign the lease, she got a letter from the state agency telling her that her rent had been too high and that it would be essentially cut in half. So she decided to stay. The landlord was also assessed treble damages of $50,000.
Since then, she has paid the amount established as her new legal rent and specified in her lease, $1,011.12 at the time, and later, adjusted upward by the legally allowable increases. So when she received a letter two months ago saying that the rent decision had been reversed on appeal six years after the first ruling, and that she would now have to pay $2,223 a month, she was in shock.
But that was hardly the worst of it. The state told her that she also had to pay her landlord back rent, estimated at more than $47,000. And it nullified the treble damages, which the landlord had not been required to pay while the case was on appeal.
AND so, instead of planning the surprise party she had hoped to give for her father's 80th birthday in April, maybe making the salmon with cilantro and tomatoes she had prepared for her parents' 50th wedding anniversary, she is now wondering whether she will be evicted before that, and if she is, where she can go.
Her family now includes not only her daughter, Lisa Gilman-Rosen, a junior at Stuyvesant High School, but also her husband of 11 months, a writer and translator, and his two daughters, one at Hunter College High School and one living away from home at college. She declined to give her husband's name, saying she did not want potential landlords to know they were married.
The case, she said, has tainted her, making her appear as a bad tenant, when in fact she has lived as a careful person, never taking the big risks or rash steps that put people in debt.
"You could call the credit bureaus today," she said. "I pay off my credit cards. I always have a zero balance. I find this humiliating."
She and her new husband spend a lot of time at home; they cook, they play Scrabble on their bed -- which is in the dining room so their daughters can have the bedrooms. They live carefully and quietly, and yet, she said: "I feel inept. I feel like I've done something wrong to get us in this position, and I've never lived that way. I've never lived on the edge."
Under the agency's ruling, she was supposed to begin paying the new rent of $2,223 in January, plus $1,900 a month toward her back-rent debt. She said she cannot pay that much and continues to pay her old rent. The landlord has gone to court to evict her, and to collect the back rent.
Hoping to get help, she has applied to an arts organization for an emergency grant. "They say they help with catastrophic events," said Ms. Gilman, who teaches at Pratt Institute and at Purchase College, State University of New York. She exhibits her work four or five times a year, and she recently had a piece bought by the Brooklyn Museum of Art.
The possibility of being evicted, and of having to declare personal bankruptcy, has left her distraught. Sitting at her dining room table, serving but not eating mandel bread and herb tea, she said she finds the situation unbearable and mystifying. "I had no evidence at that time that the ruling was something I should doubt," she said. "I have leases. Nowhere does it say this is a provisional rent."
After receiving the latest ruling, she filed appeals of the state decision and the eviction action through her newly hired lawyer, Robert Levy, who has handled many tenant-landlord cases. "I've been doing this for 30 years, and I've never seen anything like this," Mr. Levy said.
When Ms. Gilman filed her fair market rent appeal, she was challenging the rent under provisions that guide landlords in setting new rents when apartments move from rent control to rent stabilization.
Generally speaking, the rent-control laws apply to apartments that have been occupied by the same tenant since July 1, 1971, and are in buildings of three or more units built before Feb. 1, 1947. When such tenants vacate an apartment, its rent is generally regulated by the rent stabilization laws.
The previous tenant in Ms. Gilman's apartment had paid $605 a month; the landlord then raised the rent to $2,000. Under the law, the landlord can show rents for comparable apartments to justify the establishment of the initial rent under stabilization laws.
In the four years before the first ruling, Mr. Levy said, the landlord presented no comparables. The decision was reversed last year, Mr. Levy said, because the agency decided that a legislative change in 1997 allowed the landlord to submit comparables that would buttress his case, even though new evidence is typically not allowed in an appeal unless it was unavailable the first time around.
Because the landlord in his appeal submitted evidence that pertained to rental leases signed around 1990, it should have been previously available to him, Mr. Levy said.
"The feature that's so upsetting is that they changed the rules in midstream," he said. "They bent them beyond recognition." Ms. Gilman, he said, was right to assume that even if her landlord prevailed in an appeal, any rent change would be minor.
THERE was no reason, he said, for her to believe that the agency could fully reverse itself. "It's really a Kafkaesque situation," he said. "You wake up one morning and you owe your landlord nearly $50,000."
Bill Harra, a vice president of ABC Realty and the managing agent for the building on West 110th Street, said the landlord had at one point voluntarily lowered Ms. Gilman's rent somewhat when she and her first husband were having financial difficulties. The landlord did not even get notice of the first challenge to the rent, Mr. Harra said, until several years after it was filed.
"The D.H.C.R. apparently lost the papers for two years," he said. Because of that, he said, the landlord did not have time to gather the comparables that his case required. When the landlord was told that the rent was being rolled back -- and that he was being assessed the $50,000 in treble damages -- he appealed, and during that process, the overcharge he owed Ms. Gilman was frozen.
He has now taken her to court to get the back rent and to evict her, Mr. Harra said, because she is still paying the old rent. "She chose not to pay the new legal rent," he said, "and the landlord said, 'I gotta take you to court.' "
Debbie Del Pino, a spokeswoman for the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said it would not comment on its procedures in the case, or the time it took to issue rulings, because it cannot talk about cases that are pending or on appeal.
Meanwhile, Ms. Gilman is wondering where she will go if her appeal is unsuccessful, or even worse, if she is evicted before a ruling on the appeal is issued. Most important to her is a safe place, in part because she still remembers the terror of being assaulted at knifepoint as a teenager in Queens. To her, a good neighborhood is not fancy, but "lively, well lit and well trafficked."
But she has talked to some real estate agents and says she is gloomy about her prospects. "There's no place to move to that is comparable," she said. "We're not lawyers. We're not doctors. How do normal people pay the rent?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Along Rt. 1 Near Princeton, the Market Is Booming

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE office market along the Princeton Route 1 corridor is on a roll: over the last year 800,000 square feet of space in six mostly speculative buildings became available, and all but 100,000 square feet has been leased.
Now the market is entering a second round of building. Work is under way or will soon begin on projects totaling 507,000 square feet. And thousands more square feet are planned, including research and development space, along the 20-mile corridor between New Brunswick and Trenton. 
 Developers say they are trying to capitalize on the state's strong economy and job growth, which continue to stoke tenants' need for space and their desire to be in this central location close to Princeton University.
Commercial brokers said they were initially concerned about overbuilding when so much space came onto the market in 1999. The Princeton corridor's 800,000 square feet of new office space was the second-highest production level last year -- after the Jersey City waterfront, with 1.1 million square feet -- in New Jersey's 11 central and northern counties. But that situation did not materialize, and "demand remains strong" said J. Douglas Petrozzini, a senior vice president in the Edison office of Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage company. The market should be able to handle the additional space, he added.
Most of the demand is from present tenants who are expanding along with a few companies relocating from North Jersey and Manhattan, said Jonathan Miesel, anassociate director of the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield. "If businesses continue to grow at a rate of 5 percent a year, that will generate a demand for 500,000 square feet of space," he said.
At the end of 1999, Mr. Miesel's firm reported that the Princeton market had a vacancy rate for prime space of 12.4 percent, up from 9.8 percent the year before. But Mr. Miesel said that the rate was skewed by the availability of a 400,000-square-foot building in South Brunswick. It was built about two years ago for a Dow Jones subsidiary that was later sold. If that building is omitted, the vacancy rate for prime space "hovers around 4 percent," he said.
Meanwhile, the average asking prices for prime space rose to $29.13 from $28.85 per square foot. For all other space, they remained stable at $22.87 per square foot, according to Cushman & Wakefield.
These factors, developers said, gave them the confidence to move ahead. "There is a dearth of new product in the pipeline, and there are still plenty of tenants in the market," said Walter F. Thomas, Northeast regional manager for the Patrinely Group, a Houston development company with offices in Princeton. Patrinely is making its initial foray into New Jersey and the Princeton corridor in particular.
LAST March, Patrinely contracted to buy, in pieces, 98 acres from Princeton University to build a large office complex, up to 1.2 million square feet, as part of the larger 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center, which straddles South Brunswick and Plainsboro Townships. The first building there was started on speculation last September, and 108,000 of its 154,000 square feet has been leased, Mr. Thomas said.
A second building with 70,000 square feet is planned. Both will occupy 24 acres on the west side of Route 1. The remaining 1 million square feet of space planned for the complex will rise on 74 acres on the east side of the highway.
Explaining the deal, David Knights, the director of marketing for Princeton Forrestal Center, noted a continuing demand for space: 6.1 million square feet of office, retail and hotel space has been completed or is under way there, and the occupancy rate is 98 percent. Eventually, the center's site is zoned for a total of 9.2 million square feet.
Mr. Knights said a 168,000-square-foot building at 650 College Road East that was started last August is now 94 percent leased. That building is being developed by a partnership of the Aegis Property Group and the Berwind Property Group, both of Philadelphia, on 12 acres bought from the university. The partnership is planning another building with 100,000 square feet on 13 adjacent acres, he said.
The office complex the Patrinely Group is developing, Mr. Knights said, "opens up a new section of Forrestal Center on the east side of Route 1."
The complex, Princeton Corporate Campus @ Forrestal is, as its name implies, being designed to attract the growing number of technology companies, but not to the exclusion of mainstay companies in the pharmaceutical and financial-services sectors, said Mr. Thomas of the Patrinely Group.
The leases signed at Patrinely's three-story, 154,000-square-foot building are to two growing companies already renting space in Princeton corridor. Nova Nordisk, a Danish company that manufactures insulin and related devices, took 80,000 square feet for its North American headquarters, and ZS Associates, a global pharmaceutical consulting firm, leased 28,000 square feet for its regional office. Rents are $30 to $31 a square foot, with the tenants paying for their own electricity.
Since that building is 70 percent leased, Mr. Thomas said Patrinely would begin construction on the second 70,000-square-foot building by July. Then, he said, his company will follow the same formula to develop speculative buildings on the east side of Route 1, where there are also opportunities for build-to-suit projects for specific tenants. Up to seven buildings, each with at least 150,000 square feet, could be built on that side of the highway, he said, adding, "There is enough of a critical mass in the corridor now to feed on itself."
AT Carnegie Center, the 450-acre office campus in West Windsor, a 65,000-square-foot building is also rising. There, about half of an eventual four million square feet has been built. "With our existing tenant base, we're building to meet their growth needs," said John Brandbergh, the director of marketing and leasing for Boston Properties, a real estate investment trust that acquired the center in 1998. Once the new building is leased, "we'll take a wait-and-see attitude," he said, on whether to start a speculative building that could contain as much as 140,000 square feet.
And with leasing winding down at 600 Alexander Park, a 140,000-square-foot building, also in West Windsor, the Trammell Crow Company will start construction in the next few months on a second speculative building of 70,000 square feet, said Aubrey Haines, a vice president of Trammel Crow. It is developing both buildings for the Multi-Employer Property Trust, a pension fund. Rents are $29.50 a square foot, with tenants paying electricity. "In a tight labor market companies are using quality office space to attract employees," Mr. Haines said.
One developer also sees this as the right time to add research and development space to the market, along with offices. "The demand for quality one-story R & D buildings is the highest it has been in years, and the supply doesn't even come close to filling it," said Vincent Marano, the chief operating officer of National Business Parks, the managing arm of the partnership that owns College Park. That 11-building campus in Plainsboro, part of Forrestal Center, has 814,000 square feet of fully leased space, half of it for research and development.
A partnership of Pocantico Associates and Zirinsky Associates, both of Manhattan, is under contract to buy 31 adjacent acres straddling South Brunswick and Plainsboro Townships, but outside of Forrestal Center, to build a 320,000-square-foot office and R & D complex called Princeton Business Park. The project, which must gain approvals from both townships, will have a maximum of five buildings constructed on a build-to-suit basis.
"It's a natural progression of College Park," Mr. Marano said. "We're striving to meet the needs of high-tech and biotech companies. It's a niche we see as the future" He said the partners would start on the 17.4 acres in South Brunswick, which are zoned for the 200,000 square feet of office and research space his firm wants to build. Approvals could be secured by July, he said, adding that negotiations are under way with a tenant, whom he would not name, for a 92,500-square-foot building. Rents are to be in the range of $25 -to $27 a square foot, he said.
Once that site is completed, Mr. Marano said the partners would turn to the 13.6 acres in Plainsboro. In the interim, the partners would seek the rezoning and approvals needed for the site, which could accommodate buildings totaling 120,000 square feet. The entire project is projected to take three to five years to build.

PUB-DATE: March 5, 2000

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2513 words

HEADLINE: Warm-Weather Retreats;
Summer Rentals Are Going, Going . . .

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
I WISH you had called me two weeks ago, because the rentals are just zapping up," Kelly Lee, an agent with B & K Real Estate in Bay Head, N.J., said regretfully to a caller one day in early February.
"But I thought we were too early to call," the astonished woman responded. In fact, though the snow was still on the ground and the breeze off the ocean was chilly, the woman was anything but early in her quest to rent a house in the picturesque Jersey shore village. 
 "For the right house in the right areas, we probably have six or seven people waiting," Benia Grygent, an agent with B & K, said as she drove around town showing houses. "We start in the fall, so that by now 80 percent of the available properties are gone."
Indeed, if the number of leases already signed and the swarms of prospective tenants looking over houses, mansions, cottages or condos everywhere from Nantucket to Connecticut to the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania are indicative, it will be a banner season for the rental market -- and a profitable one for owners. Prices in these areas have risen from 5 to 25 percent in the last year, brokers say; in the Hamptons they have escalated by at least 20 percent.
In Fire Island Pines, a community with some of Fire Island's more lavish homes and many swimming pools, "99 percent of the seasonal rentals for this summer were spoken for by Columbus Day, and now we are getting inquiries about shorter rentals," said Carole Weissman, an owner of Island Properties Real Estate and Management Corporation.
In the Poconos, Rob Baxter, a broker and owner of C. R. Baxter Rentals Unlimited, said: "People who know the community often started looking last summer. It seems like the market is up over last year, and we have run out of homes in certain categories."
Rentals for the properties that Mr. Baxter represents generally run from $500 to $3,000 a week, depending on size, amenities and their proximity to a lake. Most of his rental houses are in two lakeside communities, Arrowhead Lakes and Lake Naomi, and he also has town houses, two-story homes attached in groups of three or four, bordering a lake in Pinecrest.
In Nantucket, Mass., "the market is out of control," said Joyce Montalbano, a sales associate with Congdon and Coleman Real Estate. Rentals listed by her agency range from $1,000 a week for a one-bedroom cottage in town to $17,500 a week for a six-bedroom house in Brant Point that is coveted for its easy access to both beach and town.
And in Martha's Vineyard, Ann Floyd, the owner and principal broker of Sandcastle Realty, said: "The demand is still extraordinary despite the fact that some people say we have priced ourselves out of consideration. We got inquiries starting last summer and now we are wondering what are we going to do about the inquiries for the year 2001."
This year, rents go from $1,000 a week for a rustic workshop on a farm to $15,000 for a house that is on a saltwater lagoon, sleeps 10 and has a private beach and dock.
But nowhere is panic over renting more palpable than in the Hamptons. "You show people a rental for $50,000 and they say, "Bring my check to the landlord immediately so I am sure will have a house,' " said Judi Desiderio, the vice president of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate. The number of houses rented through her agency, which has seven offices from Westhampton Beach to Amagansett, is up by 18 percent over last year at the same time, she said, and the average rental price has increased by 20 percent.
"One couple walked into our Bridgehampton office last weekend and were distraught because there were no brokers available to help them," she said recently. "They pleaded with the manager, 'We must get a rental right now.' They would have taken anything we would have shown them."
Given their experience, such desperation was not totally irrational: they had lost bidding wars to other renters with fatter checks. "They made an offer on one house and the offer got topped," Ms. Desiderio said. "On the second one, they signed a lease and mailed it to the landlord, but by the time the landlord received it, an aggressive broker from another office had hand-delivered a check for more money."
"People are frantic," she continued. "We tell them: 'Pick one of the houses you saw. It won't be here next week.' "
Though it is possible to find a small house in the Hamptons for as little as $12,000 for the season, oceanfront mansions command at least $250,000. The highest rental that Ms. Desiderio has heard so far is $410,000 for the season, and that was snapped up in January. "It is a complete estate," she said, "with everything known to man but a helicopter pad."
According to George C. Ballantyne, senior vice president and New England regional manager of Sotheby's International Realty, responses to what only a few years ago would have been considered astronomic rents are largely dependent on where people come from.
"New Yorkers are more used to spending and are more prepared to do so," he said. "Residential prices are still substantially less expensive in Boston and New England, even in Back Bay and Beacon Hill, than they are in Manhattan. For example, in the past month I sold a town house in Boston for a new record: $5.9 million. Many town houses in New York sell for more than $10 million."
Still, does it make sense, no matter how unlimited the budget, to plow hundreds of thousands of dollars into rent?
For people who want grand mansions with breathtaking views, tennis courts, swimming pools and other luxuries, that may be the only choice, in the view of Timothy G. Davis, principal managing director for Allan M. Schneider Associates, which has seven offices in the Hamptons and Montauk. "If you want to live in that kind of a house, you can only rent it," he said. "It is not available."
For example, he said: "There is a house we rent in East Hampton that has several guest houses and a pool on 30 acres and is $400,000 for July 1 to Labor Day. If it were for sale it would be $25 million, but it's not. There is no way to build it or buy it."
And though the economy has been soaring, there is no certainty that it will continue its upward flight. That has bred a live-for-the-moment attitude toward putting what would certainly be the down payment on a house, and in some cases could buy a sizable house, into rent.
WITH all the bonuses on Wall Street, people find they have a certain amount of disposable income," said Anne Orton, manager and associate broker in the Southampton office of Cook Pony Farm. "But they don't know if they will have it next year, so they don't want the responsibility of owning or maintaining the property, and they don't want the continued overhead that kind of house would command."
Thanks to stock market profits and hefty bonuses, second-home sales have been unusually brisk, depleting the supply of houses available for rent and driving up rental prices, brokers say. "People who want to be in the Pines will pay whatever is necessary, and there is no balking because they have the discretionary funds," said Ms. Weissman, the Fire Island broker. An oceanfront house there would go for $75,000 for the period between May 1 and mid-September, she said; a simple three-bedroom inland cottage for $18,500 for mid-May to mid-September.
In Nantucket, "we're probably getting up to 50 new inquiries a day," said Douglas Foregger, chairman of Country Village Rentals and Real Estate, which conducts business there as well as in Stowe, Vt., Aspen, Colo., St. Bart's in the French West Indies, and Lyford Cay and Harbour Island in the Bahamas. "We have doubled the number of houses rented over the same time last year, and the phones are ringing nonstop." In fact, he added: "The market in Nantucket is now very strong for October and November, because prices go way down then. You can figure that a rental that would be $10,000 for a week in August can be as low as $5,000 a week in late October and November."
At Lake Wallenpaupack in the Poconos, prices exceed those of last year by about 10 percent, said Peter Helms, president of Davis R. Chant Realtors.
The rental season in Lake Wallenpaupack does not go into full gear until the beginning of March, "but we are getting probably twice as many calls already as last year," Mr. Helms said. "A rustic cottage with three bedrooms and a loft starts at $800 a week and can go to $1,100. A four- to five-bedroom house can bring as much as $1,600 a week. The $800 house would have been $750 last year, and there has been no resistance."
Some househunters have found they have to spend much more than planned. Others have made compromises, and still others have found themselves shut out, so far.
Frederick D. Hoff of Hackensack, N.J., who retired as director of national accounts for the former Celanese Corporation five years ago, was fully prepared to pay $22,000 a month for a long season rental in Bay Head or Mantoloking, N.J. But when he went to look last month, he found what he considered all the nicely appointed places taken.
"Instead I saw a lot of yuck, smelly older places," said Mr. Hoff, who was widowed and is now in the process of getting a divorce from his second wife. "Sure I could easily spend $100,000 and like what I am in, but that is crazy. It is a down payment on something. I want value for my money."
Jennifer Millington of Manhattan, a 28-year-old financial software account executive, has been renting group houses with friends almost every summer in towns on the New Jersey shore like Belmar, South Belmar, Sea Girt and Spring Lake since graduating from college in 1993. She began looking in those locales in November but didn't take anything then.
"Everything was $20,000 to $24,000 for Memorial Day to Labor Day, and we thought we would have a bigger group," she said. "We didn't have enough people who wanted to spend that kind of money or make that kind of commitment."
In January she resumed her search and found a house for $9,000, but it was only for five weeks between Memorial Day and the end of July. Finances were a major consideration. "The price worked out better for the partial summer, and we figure we will be more likely to come down every weekend this way," she said.
Last year Susan Kirshenbaum of Manhattan, a partner at Greenberg Kirshenbaum, a recruiting firm for advertising agencies, and two friends paid $24,000 for the Memorial Day to Labor Day season for a three-bedroom, two-bath house on a cul-de-sac in Amagansett, L.I., that she found barely adequate. "It had a Murphy bed version of a kitchen where if you opened the refrigerator door, it hit the wall," she said. "The broker told the owner he could get $40,000 for it this year."
Instead she and her friends will pay an amount she would only describe as "significantly more than $30,000" for a small three-bedroom house perched on a dune in Amagansett. "Two years ago we rented that same house for June and July because we thought the rental for the whole summer was absurd, and now we are paying it," she said. "But how much is happiness worth?"
That depends on the locale, on the size of the house, on the amenities and the length of the rental -- but more than anything else on its proximity to the water, preferably the ocean.
IN Osterville on the south shore of Cape Cod, for example, Paul Grover, senior vice president of Kinlin Grover GMAC Real Estate, which has 14 offices on the Cape, said: "A nice oceanfront rental on a sandy beach could be $30,000 to $50,000 a month for July and August. Across the street, you would pay $15,000 to $20,000 per month, and if you are in the village, walking distance to the beach, you can get a nice house for $10,000 a month, but then you wouldn't have a private beach. If you have to drive to the beach, then the rental could be $5,000 a month."
In Lake Naomi in the Poconos, prices range from $500 to $3,000 a week. "It's the lake that makes the difference in price," Mr. Baxter said. "Off the lake they don't bring in more than $1,100. Those on the lake have their own private beach and maybe a boat docked, and most of those are already booked."
Rents for houses in Litchfield County, where many artists, writers and theatrical and political luminaries have homes, are significantly less than on Long Island. "If the Hamptons is upward of $70,000 for the season," said Seymour Surnow, owner of the Surnow Group at William Raveis Real Estate, "then our top rent is $50,000."
And there would be no roughing it at that price. "That would get you a four-bedroom, centrally air-conditioned house with a heated pool on 10 acres with ponds and English gardens, if you're lucky," he said. "It is up 10 percent over last year, and several years ago it went for $10,000. '
The range of rents in the area goes from $8,000 or $10,000 for the season up to $50,000, he said. Mr. Surnow said last week that he had just got a listing for a four-bedroom saltbox in Bridgewater for $13,000. Another listing he described as modest is for a three-bedroom house in Roxbury on 46 acres that is available for $21,000 for the season.
Besides the bargain -- relatively speaking -- prices, he said, the area offers a more subdued lifestyle despite its high quotient of celebrities. "There is no scene here at all," he said. "You could see Mia Farrow, Stephen Sondheim, Dustin Hoffman and Arthur Miller in the grocery store, and no one gives them a never mind." (You won't see Whoopi Goldberg anymore; Mr. Surnow just sold her farmhouse in Cornwall.)
"And you don't have to make restaurant reservations two weeks ahead," he said. "In fact there are not that many restaurants. The big excitement on Saturday evening is having friends come over."
As far as ambience is concerned, modernity seems to prevail over charm, no matter what the locale. "In the past a lot of people who would go to Martha's Vineyard or Nantucket would want a great old farmhouse with a lot of character," Mr. Foregger said. "Now they want new and shiny and not as much rustic."
Although Nantucket has exceptionally strict rules on architecture, style, color and trim -- the rules dictate, for example, that in most circumstances houses must be gray -- "you can still make an old house new inside," he said.
On Martha's Vineyard, "people may want a quaint New England shingled cape with a rose-covered fence," Ms. Floyd said, "but they also want it to be well equipped. They ask for fax machines, a second plug and phone for Internet access, Jacuzzis and nicely equipped kitchens. We hardly ever get requests for swimming pools or tennis courts."
By contrast, in the Hamptons, "most people won't even look unless something has a pool and is centrally air-conditioned," said Tina S. Fredericks, a broker who has been in business in the Southampton to Montauk area for 35 years.
"We used to think people came here for the beach and the air quality," she said. "If they could go swimming in the bay they were very happy. Now everyone wants air-conditioning, not air quality."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
A Ready Constituency Awaiting Recognition

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month.
E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AMID all the fighting over Confederate flags and Christianity, none of the presidential candidates have tried very hard to connect with an important constituency: older Americans.
That is not to say that the contenders have ignored issues that affect seniors, like Social Security and Medicare. And Vice President Al Gore's recent trips to Florida have hardly been to visit college students. 
 But no candidate has tried to go beyond a handful of trigger issues and to forge an empathetic bond with older people, to become their champion, as President Clinton has with blacks over the last seven years, as Senator John McCain has with fellow veterans or as Mr. Gore has with organized labor.
Older Americans, of course, are a very diverse lot, making them more difficult to appeal to than, say, an ethnic minority group with a shared history.
But Bill Zinke, a consultant for corporations on hiring and retaining older workers, thinks the time is ripe for a leader to tap into this important voter pool.
"A candidate who can show that he really understands the needs of older Americans could certainly swing important votes in his direction," Mr. Zinke said. "And I don't mean just in terms of entitlement programs or more laws."
In other words, he is not asking candidates to pander to seniors' pocketbooks. Rather, he wants to hear them talking about what older Americans have to contribute.
The comments from House members in the wake of last week's unanimous vote to lift earnings restrictions on Social Security beneficiaries aged 65 to 69 indicate that, at least on the Congressional level, some politicians are catching on.
Although Mr. Zinke has no formal expertise in politics, he argues from the numbers. Some 58 million Americans are 55 or older, a figure that will bulge as the baby boomers enter retirement. And older people go to the polls. In the 1996 presidential election, 77 percent of Americans over 65 voted, compared with just 49 percent of the overall voting-age population.
Henry J. Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington and an expert on aging and demographics, is among those who argue that older people are too diverse to be captured as a core constituency. He agrees, however, that their growing numbers and high voting rate -- combined with "ennui among younger voters" -- could make them fertile ground for a candidate able to forge an "emotional connection."
Mr. Zinke wants to see political leadership that will change what he calls the "national mind-set" about older Americans. "Jawboning is as good a term as any to describe what I think is needed," he said.
"The general attitude is that when you reach a certain age, you're over the hill. You should go somewhere and enjoy the 'golden years.' "
He cited a 1999 Harris Poll showing that there were 3.7 million people over 55 who were out of the work force but who would like to keep working. "Because of ageism and the national mind-set about older people, they think there are no jobs for them or they are not wanted," he said. "In a tight job market, this is a valuable resource pool."
SO why doesn't one of the candidates start beating this drum? "I think they and their advisers are just plain missing the boat," Mr. Zinke said.
Steve Murphy, a Democratic political consultant in Washington, thinks there may well be an opening for a candidate with such a message. But he said national office seekers had to be careful of too many segmented appeals. "You need an overarching appeal to build a majority," he said.
Still, a focus on seniors, he added, could have traction as a subtext of a campaign, because values are important in this year's elections. "Equal opportunity and respect for elders are important values," he said. "Also, building credibility with older voters is important, because traditional means of reaching them are becoming less effective. They don't respond well to pandering."
Mr. Zinke, a former corporate and criminal lawyer in New York, runs his own consulting company, Human Resource Services in Boulder, Colo. He is organizing a conference in Washington in June on the importance of older workers in meeting employment needs. Sponsors include AARP, Chase Manhattan, GTE, Nortel Networks, Pitney-Bowes, Young & Rubicam and AXA Equitable.
Mr. Zinke is an example of what he preaches. He will be 73 this month, and he has no plans to retire.
"We should not see aging and our increased longevity in a negative light," he said. "Instead of worrying about the graying of America, we should be looking forward to the benefits and opportunities of this demographic change." After all, he said, "an older population is also a wiser and more skilled population."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 16; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 688 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
As Gasoline Prices Rise, the Cost of New Cars and Trucks May Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
RISING gasoline prices and wavering consumer confidence might mean better deals on new cars and trucks this spring.
Consumers might not get the bargain of a lifetime from auto dealers, but they could save enough to help offset their higher fuel costs, particularly with gas-demanding sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks. 
 "As strange as it may seem, the consumer's purchasing power will actually be enhanced" this spring when it comes to buying a popular S.U.V. or pickup truck, said David Littman, chief economist with Comerica Bank in Detroit.
Mr. Littman said the fact that automakers have changed their production schedules to turn out more S.U.V.'s and pickups means that they have bigger inventories of these vehicles. And because light trucks like these have relatively high profit margins, automakers and dealers have more leeway to bargain. Although car and truck sales have been very strong so far in 2000, Mr. Littman said he had anecdotal evidence that it was taking more incentives to sell the bigger vehicles.
"Gas prices are having an impact," he said.
Until recently, those prices were not a big issue. But the national average cost of a gallon of gasoline, including all grades and taxes, reached a record $1.4713 in late February, according to the Lundberg Survey of 10,000 gas stations across the country. A year earlier, the average was 99.8 cents a gallon.
As a result, an owner of an S.U.V. or a pickup truck can find himself pouring plenty of money into a fuel tank. Using the Lundberg figures, it would cost about $640 a year more than it did a year ago to gas up a Chevy Tahoe -- with a 26-gallon tank -- once a week. It would take $960 more to fuel a Chevy Suburban with a 39-gallon tank, and about $1,083 more for a Ford Excursion's 44-gallon tank.
Of course, the future of gasoline prices is hard to figure. Representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are expected to approve an increase in crude oil production when they meet later this month, but any increase is unlikely to bring gas prices down to the levels of early last year.
Aside from gasoline prices, there are other reasons that automakers and dealers may be inclined to bargain.
With very strong auto sales during the last few years, including a record 16.9 million in 1999, "there's no pent-up demand left" for new cars and light trucks, said Susan Jacobs, head of Jacobs & Associates, an automotive marketing and research firm in Rutherford, N.J.
Manufacturers will need to persuade consumers "to come in and replace their cars even though they're not falling apart or in need of major repairs," she said. That may be a difficult task, she added, because the stock market, a big source of wealth for many consumers, is not turning in the gains this year that it did in 1999.
Rising interest rates may also prompt car sellers to negotiate more. Americans were slightly less confident about the economy during February, largely because of higher interest rates and gasoline prices, according to the Confidence Board, the business research group.
Although consumer confidence is still very high, it could ebb if the Federal Reserve continues to raise interest rates, as it is widely expected to do. And consumers who check Internet sites about the availability of good used cars could migrate toward the used-car market to save money, Ms. Jacobs said.
Consumer groups advise auto buyers to go into a showroom only after doing a lot of research into new car prices. Consumer Reports and Consumers Digest suggest that buyers learn the invoice price of a model, or the price the dealer pays the automaker for the car or truck.
Consumers Digest notes on its Web site (www.consumersdigest.com) that the invoice price generally includes a small profit for the dealer. The magazine suggests that customers "negotiate upward from that baseline."
The Internet has many sites for researching the invoice price, including the Kelley Blue Book (www.kbb.com). Consumer Reports also sells reports on car prices through www.consumerreports.org or through its toll-free phone number (800) 888-8275.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS WORLD;
Modestly, India Goes In for a Swim

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: BOMBAY

 BODY:
WITH its acres of artificial rivers and cement oceans painted swimming-pool blue, Water Kingdom could almost pass for a theme park in Florida, if it weren't for the men in turbans who are bobbing in the wave pools and the women sailing down the water slide in pants and long-sleeved shirts.
But Bombay is a long way from Orlando. The water park here was built for people who don't know how to swim; it rents swimsuits to women who have never worn one before. Sarabjit Kaur, dressed in a bathing costume of long black stretch pants and a loose T-shirt, shuddered at the thought of a one-piece, never mind a bikini. 
 "Our culture doesn't allow us," she said shyly. Her husband, Tanjendar Singh Sodhi, a well-traveled banker, explained: "Things are changing. She wouldn't have even worn this five years back. Now she is."
Water amusement parks are springing up all over India, in New Delhi and Bombay, in Madras and Hyderabad, in Ahmedabad and Indore -- signs of change in a country where tens of millions of people have benefited from an increasingly open, market-driven economy over the past decade. They have money to spend on luxuries that their parents could never have afforded, or even imagined.
India may still conjure up exotic images of snake charmers, leprous beggars and bejeweled maharajas, but there is a new middle class rising here, and its members are busily doing the consumerist things that the middle classes do everywhere: shopping for refrigerators, chatting on the phone, watching cable television -- and looking for fun.
"Leisure is on the boom here," said Rajen Shah, general secretary of the Indian Association of Amusement Parks and Industries. "One Sunday, people will go to a bowling alley or a pool parlor. The next Sunday, they'll go to a water park."
Gautam and Madhauri Varik are just such a couple. He owns a small workshop that assembles electronic gadgets using circuits from Singapore. She sells chemicals to biotechnology laboratories. Each has a master's degree, and together they earn roughly $4,000 a year, about five times the national average, putting them in the upper middle class.
They have a far higher standard of living than their parents did. Mr. Varik, 27, grew up in a one-room house with three other family members. He and his wife, who have no children, live in a two-room apartment with a kitchen and a host of appliances, including a refrigerator, washing machine, television, VCR, CD player and telephone.
They enjoy their prosperity, but their lives are more hectic than those of their parents. Neither of their mothers had jobs, but Mrs. Varik, 30, works and travels almost as intensively as her husband. "They had more free time than us," she said, a bit wistfully, of her parents' generation. "We are working too hard."
So the Variks look for convenient places to relax. They enjoy going out to play billiards, and on a recent Sunday they tried Water Kingdom for the first time. "One of my friends took his wife here," Mr. Varik said, as he sat next to a wading pool. "He insisted this was the best place to spend a weekend. And it is fantastic."
Economists caution that being in the middle of the Indian income range doesn't yield anything like the buying power of a middle-class income in western Europe or North America. Iswar Natarajan, chief economist at the National Council of Applied Economic Research in New Delhi, thinks a better term for this group might be the consuming class. Using survey data, he estimates that the number of households in this class, with incomes of $1,200 to $6,000 a year, has almost doubled in the past decade, to about 39 million. That translates to 220 million of India's one billion people. Most still cannot afford a big-ticket item like a car, but they still find themselves with growing amounts of disposable income.
Ashok Goel's family owns the 22-acre Water Kingdom park, which had more than half a million customers last year. Mr. Goel said a typical visitor to the park spent about $5 over all, including admission, suit and locker rentals and snacks; at a water park in the United States, $5 might not even cover parking. Prices are kept affordable at Indian parks by low labor costs and the fact that there is no off season -- the weather is warm all year round in most of the country.
Parks like Water Kingdom adapt to the needs of local customers in ways besides price. Almost all the pools are shallow, because few Indians can swim, Mr. Goel said. Women, most of whom rent their bathing gear, can choose among styles that reveal as much or as little skin as they want.
"The swimming gear has been tailor-made for the Indian psyche," Mr. Goel said. "You can cover from wrist to ankle. We have all the kinds. But the two-piece does not exist."
There are now about 80 water parks, large and small, in India, most of them opened in the last few years, said Mr. Shah, who besides heading the trade association is also managing director of the Arihant Industrial Corporation, which manufactured the water slides and wave pools used at about 60 of the parks.
On a recent Sunday, Water Kingdom was full of playful scenes. There were young lovebirds floating in inner tubes down Drifting River; lumpy, out-of-shape people lined up to buy french fries and a Coke at an on-site McDonald's, and families riding the waves in Wetlantic.
Meenaxi Patel, a homemaker, sat astride a large inflatable crocodile in the wading pool at Goofers Lagoon with a group of other women from her apartment building.
"We have come, all the ladies and kids, no gents," she said. "My husband is very sporting. If I go out with the kids, he feels good. He's at home relaxing. My mother-in-law is also there, resting."
Like others in the park, Mrs. Patel spoke of freedom and fun as the parks' big draws. Wearing her own colorful swimming costume, a style that covered her thighs and upper arms but that was gaily splashed with fuchsia flowers, she said she and her friends had left all their worries behind.
"It used to be that women stayed at home," she said. "They wouldn't wear these costumes and come out. But times have changed. We want to enjoy."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
The Real Bottom Line For All This Free Stuff

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE best things in life may not be free, but lately a lot of pretty good things can be had for practically nothing.
The Village Voice, for instance, is one of many newspapers that are now distributed gratis. There are also no-fee credit cards, free income tax software and even free computers. In the investing world, of course, there are no-load mutual funds, not to mention stock-trading commissions that seem to be fast approaching zero. 
 The Internet, of course, is truly the land of the free -- from free e-mail, voice mail and fax services to access to Encyclopedia Britannica and major newspapers and magazines of every stripe. Linux, the upstart operating system that some people see as a challenge to the hegemony of Microsoft, is free, too. And until Microsoft scotched the idea recently, there was even talk of making Windows free.
With news of $30-a-barrel oil and $2.85 million for a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan, Alan Greenspan is hardly the only one worried about inflation. In such a climate, it is deceptively easy to overlook the opposite trend: all the cheap stuff bubbling up to the surface of our economy. And the cheapest of these goods and services -- the ones that cost nothing -- are notable as harbingers of long-term social and economic changes.
For one thing, this free stuff is aimed at affluent people, who in effect are trading on their status as sales leads. That suggests that the trend offers yet another way, besides marrying each other and investing in Internet stocks, that the rich will keep getting richer.
A further implication is that the recipients will be obliged to surrender more of their already depleted store of privacy. But despite considerable hand-wringing, they probably won't mind very much, because even though their lives have become a more open book to strangers, they already enjoy unprecedented physical privacy from the people they really care about -- their neighbors. These days, the affluent do not perambulate in watchful villages. They cruise sprawling suburbs behind tinted windshields. For most people, this supposedly horrifying arrangement has proven remarkably congenial, and it doesn't appear likely to change.
Of course, nothing in life is really free. Providers of free information may hope that the recipients will pay by listening to advertisers' messages; providers of free computers make the recipients sign long-term Internet access agreements. Yet many of us find that the costs of our new free services are borne mainly by other consumers, suggesting that we are at the threshold of a golden age of free riders.
I'm not referring here to turnstile jumping, but to arrangements like no-fee credit cards with grace periods. People who pay in full, and on time, get free use of a bank's money for a month, underwritten by customers who maintain outstanding balances. Similarly, investors in index funds get to ride free on the coattails of the costly research and investment decisions made by others, decisions in the absence of which the stocks in the index would cease to rise. If you read this column on a Web site instead of buying the paper, you would be free-riding, too.
Can all this continue? Some of it surely can, because the rising tide of free services reflects two long-term trends that show no sign of abating. The first is global competition, which has a way of making even things that aren't free amazingly cheap. Consider the labor, materials and capital investment that went into what you are picking up for a song at Wal-Mart or Costco.
The second trend is a technology-inspired acceleration in the commodification of goods. Is there really any material difference between brands of vodka or cola or comparably equipped personal computers? Stock-trading systems, mutual funds, Internet access and other goods and services are becoming ever more alike. Even cars, within a given model class, are more difficult than ever to tell apart.
GIVEN a decently managed money supply, how do you raise prices in this environment, or stand out in the crowd? I predict ever-higher premiums attached to marketing, which already occupies a hallowed place in American business culture.
There will also be innovation, naturally. Building a better mousetrap always holds out the possibility that people will be willing to pay more for rodent control. That won't be inflationary, if the mousetrap really is better.
Nonetheless, the possibility reminds us that the best mousetrap is always likely to cost something, and that even in Freebie Nation, you get what you pay for, one way or another.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
A Season To Consider Very Real Earnings

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
BELIEVE it or not, spring is just around the corner. And while most stocks slogged through January and February, the companies behind the ticker symbols have been out there in the real world, doing real business, many of them making real money.
In about a month, when first-quarter profit numbers start to roll in, people who have been worried sick about rising interest rates may start to remember that there is a lot of life out there. Of course, there is a very real chance that outside of technology, those investors may spend the intervening period merrily selling shares of very good companies that are making very good money. 
 Leah Modigliani, a United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, took some time last week to talk about profits, interest rates and the stock market. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. The economy barreled ahead at nearly a 7 percent annual clip in the fourth quarter, and so far this quarter hasn't shown many signs of slowing. Does that bode well for corporate profits?
 
A. Earnings were very strong in the fourth quarter and we think that trend is continuing.
For the Standard & Poor's 500 companies, we think earnings will rise about 15.7 percent on a year-over-year basis in the first quarter, and 12 percent for the year.
There will be some aberrations within the group, particularly in the energy sector, where in some cases earnings will go from negative to very positive. And we will continue to see good earnings growth out of technology, even though some of these stocks are ahead of themselves on fundamentals.
 
Q. Are there other sectors that will do particularly well?
 
A. We should see very strong earnings growth in basic materials companies, the paper, chemical and aluminum stocks.
According to our calculations, the consensus projected earnings growth rates for energy companies will go from negative in 1999 to 45 percent this year. The projected growth rate for basic materials is 36 percent, which is a little higher than the 33 percent earnings growth projected for technology companies.
 
Q. For the most part, investors seem to have ignored these signs, especially in the groups you just mentioned. Why?
 
A. Even though we are seeing very strong earnings growth in energy and basic materials, the market doesn't seem to care.
We have liked energy stocks for some time, and still do. But people seem to be concerned that oil prices will come down from these peaks. That may happen, but they will still be way up from where they were a year ago. And that will be reflected in earnings.
Most of the so-called Old Economy stocks are undervalued. Even some of the companies that are migrating to the New Economy are not getting much credit for it right now, like the auto stocks. They have good sales and are really jumping on more efficient Internet-based purchasing methods. But for the most part, the stocks are in the dumps.
 
Q. Isn't there also some concern that if rising interest rates choke off growth, these kinds of cyclical stocks will get badly hurt?
 
A. If the economy gets into trouble, that would be the case. But because of healthy growth overseas, energy companies would be a little bit of an exception to that.
 
Q. What about interest rates? The worry seems to be that the Fed will tip the economy into recession. Is that likely?
 
A. If the economy goes from 7 percent growth to 4 percent, it is a slowing that on the margin is a negative. But 4 percent growth is still very strong.
 
Q. Technology stocks seem impervious to the prospect of higher interest rates. Are they really that bulletproof?
 
A. The cost of capital for these companies is extremely low, so higher rates will not impact that. You would think stocks with a high price-to-earnings multiple would be impacted. But people are looking at the wonderful opportunity for technology in the future and are not worrying about a one-year rise in interest rates.
That said, valuations are ahead of themselves.
 
Q. With the Nasdaq composite index being the notable exception, most major measures are down so far this year. Are you expecting more selling?
 
A. In the beginning of the year, we were calling for a 20 percent to 25 percent correction for the Dow Jones industrial average and the S. & P. 500. We are probably part of the way through that, but there may be more to go. I am not talking about the Nasdaq, which is an index I don't have a focus on.
 
Q. What stocks do you like right now?
 
A. In a general sense, we like the oil service stocks. Schlumberger and Halliburton are two that I like. And I like integrated oil company stocks like Conoco, and some of the bigger companies, like Exxon Mobil.
