HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Cutthroat Capitalism, Only 99 cents

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
IT is retail red in tooth and claw.
So say the owners of several 99-cent stores strung like a discount archipelago along shop-crammed Myrtle Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens. They say the competition is cutthroat in this heavily trafficked half-mile strip between Forest and Wyckoff Avenues. And it has only got worse as new stores have opened in the area, at the rate of about one a year. 
 When Muhammad Choudry, a Pakistani immigrant who opened Power 99 last April, is asked to compare his store to the others, he picks up a cardboard box and rips it open. "The other stores don't have this," he says, pulling out a hand-held electronic game called Einstein. "The other stores," he says, "they have no variety!"
Mr. Choudry is mistaken. Variety -- overwhelming, cornucopial, floor-to-ceiling and baroque -- is a defining characteristic of the 99-cent stores. Every store has row upon row of the same steel wire bins, like gaping pelican mouths brimming with snacks and toys and videos, octopus in hot sauce and powdered amaretto cappuccino. (And antacid.)
But after a while, as you move from store to store, you begin to see the same core group of items, the 10-packs of hair clips and boxes of off-brand baking soda. And the stores themselves begin to blend in an endless stream of shuffle-worn floors and bouquets of plastic carnations blooming in hues unknown to nature.
So, clearly, one of the ways to survive in the business is to offer something different. Hence, the fresh meat at Mario Bortz's store, Supermarket 99. Mr. Bortz's son, Fabian, said that late last year his father was searching for a way to distinguish his inventory from his competitors. He had already lowered prices to 88 cents -- where they remain, with the odd 79-cent sale thrown in -- though the name of the store hasn't changed.
"We started getting shipments of meat two times a week," said Fabian, 19, a student who works part time for his father. "We get hot dogs, ham, turkey, American cheese and sausages," he said. "It's very popular."
Martha Gillings agreed. She recently bought two packs of Perdue chicken thighs, three two-liter bottles of soda and a 16-pack of Star Farm American cheese slices at Supermarket 99, all for $5.65. "Eighty-eight cents for Perdue chicken," she said. "You can't get that at Waldbaum's or Pathmark."
Price competition is a lot keener than customers might expect from places where nothing goes for more than 99 cents; $1.07 with tax. Mr. Choudry says he occasionally slashes the price on a popular item, like a Bounty Big Roll of paper towels, and announces it on a sign in the window. He said the attention-getting price draws shoppers into his store. Once inside, he says, their urge to browse becomes almost irresistible.
"The customers come in for one thing," he said, "but they leave with five things." (On Thursday, in an extreme form of this tactic, the corporate owner of a 99 Cents Only Store in Woodland Hills, Calif., part of a chain, offered microwave ovens and television sets for 99 cents to the first nine customers at the store's grand opening.)
Mr. Bortz said his father, who went to a trade fair in Las Vegas two weeks ago, hunting for fresh items, also sells at a loss sometimes, but for a different reason. Thefather owns seven 99-cent stores throughout the city, and one, on Westchester Avenue in the Bronx, is engaged in fierce competition with local stores.
"They kill themselves for a dime in that neighborhood," Fabian Bortz said. He recalled that last year a competitor posted a sign for a popular item at 76 cents. Mr. Bortz lowered his price to 75 cents. The other store owner went to 74 cents. Mr. Bortz won when he dropped the price to 73 cents. He summed up the confrontation: "Sometimes you have to buy something for 75 cents and sell it for 73 cents just to kill they guy across the street."
Shoppers in Ridgewood seem fond of the 99-cent stores, as do New Yorkers on Broadway in Harlem, on Westchester Avenue in the Soundview section of the Bronx, on Church Avenue in Kensington, Brooklyn, and in the many other areas where such outlets are found. And why shouldn't they be? It doesn't take an economic Einstein to figure out that with price wars breaking out at even the low-margin end of the retail food chain, it is the bargain hunter who benefits. Randy Kuntz, a house painter from Glendale, Queens, said he strolled down Myrtle Avenue once a week in search of sundries. At 99 USA, he fingered some tape for repairing leather and said simply, "You cannot beat the prices here."
Three doors down from 99 USA is a Duane Reade drugstore. The manager, Joshua Pierre-Louis, said the bulk of his business comes from filling prescriptions and selling items that cost much more than a dollar. When asked if he worried about being undercut by the 99-cent stores, he replied: "I don't pay them no mind. Our competition is Rite Aid and Genovese. I never go into those other stores." Yet, propped up in the corner of the store's large display window is a Bounty Big Roll. The price? 99 cents.
Beyond the prices, some shoppers enjoy 99-cent stores for the chance to go on a treasure hunt. Carmen Gil said she took her two children to Supermarket 99 five or six times a week. "This is like a treat for them after school," she said, as well as a way of showing them how to shop sensibly. Last week, her daughter, Bethsaida, bought a notepad for school, while her son, Gabriel, purchased a Disney coloring book.
Ms. Gil admitted she did not stand idly by while her children rummaged for goodies. "I love to shop here, too," she said. "Sometimes they have to kick me out of the store."
There is a pleasure to getting and spending that goes deeper than even the treasure hunt. That something else, you might say, is the magic of the deal.
Even Isidro Tejada, a worker at 99 USA, succumbed to it recently when he picked up a wine glass and said, "I heard this is genuine crystal." It was a nicely fluted glass, etched with a wispy flower pattern. But it was one of dozens of similar glasses stacked haphazardly on a shelf piled high with batteries and plastic vases.
Mr. Tejada continued, "They say if you put water on the rim and run your finger on it, like this, it makes a ringing sound." He glided his finger in a reverent circle over the mouth of the glass, without touching it.
There was no sound, but he seemed to hear one anyway. "That's crystal," he concluded.
Of course, real crystal is expensive, and it is unlikely a crystal wine glass would sell for 99 cents, even on Myrtle Avenue. But pointing this out might break the spell of a place where it can seem at times that the iron laws of commerce are suspended, a place where the great American promise of discriminating acquisition among shelves groaning with product is available to all.
As Mr. Choudry said: "Where else can you spend $20 and leave with a bag of 20 things? You may be poor, but you feel rich."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 3; Column 6; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 779 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The RisksIn the Fed's Assault On Stocks

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN can be clear as a bell when he wants to be. Testifying before Congress last month, he left no doubt that he intends to keep raising interest rates for as long as the wealth being created by the stock market generates more demand than the economy can satisfy.
Yet even as he put investors on notice that monetary policy will get tighter, he was unwilling or unable to address head-on the quandary he faces: how to put a speed bump in front of Wall Street without sending the entire economy into a skid, hurting workers who own little if any stock while he hunts an enemy, inflation, that is nowhere in sight. 
 Mr. Greenspan, who has been all but deified over the last few years, rarely finds himself on the defensive. But his approach is puzzling even some of his biggest fans, and if he miscalculates in raising rates this year, his reputation, not to mention the nation's prosperity, could take a beating.
It is one thing for the Fed chairman to lay the blame for inflationary pressures on Wall Street. Whatever the economic merits of his position, making the stock market his bogeyman is less politically incendiary in an election year than the traditional central banker's warning that too many people are working and earning good money.
But having made the stock market the villain, he could have trouble justifying interest rate increases that also skewer the innocent. Is there any practical difference between raising rates to curb the wealth effect and raising them to push up the unemployment rate and subdue wage increases?
When Mr. Greenspan appeared before the Senate Banking Committee, Senator Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky, told Mr. Greenspan not to lose sight of the fact that wage and price increases have remained remarkably restrained, given the robust pace of growth. "Don't become so frightened by success that you throw wet blankets on a fire that isn't burning," he said.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, suggested that Mr. Greenspan consider raising margin requirements on investors who buy stocks with borrowed money, as a way of reining in the stock market without putting jobs and improved standards of living at risk. "Isn't raising interest rates too blunt an instrument, a meat cleaver rather than a scalpel?" Mr. Schumer asked.
IMPLICIT in these pleas is that ownership of equities, although far more common than in the past, remains relatively concentrated among the wealthy. The Fed's most recent Survey of Consumer Finances found that in 1998, 48.8 percent of households owned stocks, either directly or through mutual funds and retirement accounts -- a remarkable jump from 31.6 percent in 1989.
Among households earning $25,000 to $50,000 in 1998, those stock holdings had a median value of $11,500. Among households earning $100,000 or more, the median value of stock holdings was $150,000.
Senator Paul Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, cited the example of a high school dropout he met recently who had finished a training program and found work for the first time. "This young fellow is far removed from the wealth effect," Mr. Sarbanes said. "If the activity and the volatility is in the stock market, we may need to think of some way to address that without slowing down the whole economy and affecting the opportunities for these young people."
Mr. Greenspan is far more attuned to the benefits of strong growth than his critics acknowledge. He makes a solid case that the best thing for Mr. Sarbanes' young dropout and others like him is to ensure that the long expansion is not poisoned by an outbreak of inflation. And there is no question that the economy's 6.9 percent annual growth rate in the fourth quarter is far above anyone's speed limit.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan is candid in saying that there are many things about the fast-changing economy that even he does not fully understand.
The charitable view is that Mr. Greenspan is still puzzling over how to deal with the ways that lofty stock prices ripple through the economy. The more skeptical view is that Mr. Greenspan, for all his protestations that he is not aiming directly at stock prices, is really doing just that.
Newly released transcripts of policy meetings of the Fed during 1994, when it was raising rates repeatedly, show that Mr. Greenspan was concerned even then that the equity market was in dangerously speculative territory -- and that he quite consciously used rate increases to send a chill through investors.
He is no doubt equally eager now to take the froth out of the markets. His challenge is to do it without draining the life out of the best economy most of us will ever see.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Mr. Fix-It Rewires a Company

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
EVER since he was a child, Dick Syron has been a tinkerer. As a teenager, he fixed TV sets and cars for spare cash. As an adult, he rewired a 134-year-old house. And he loves working on his 28-foot Bertram motorboat almost as much as he loves powering it through the waves.
And now, at 56, Richard F. Syron is facing what may be his biggest tinkering job yet. As the chief executive of the Thermo Electron Corporation -- a post he has held for just nine months -- he is revamping the diverse manufacturing company top to bottom. 
 Once he is done, Thermo Electron will no longer be a multitentacled company with dozens of publicly traded subsidiaries. It will be a mainstream manufacturer with one set of shares.
"People's willingness to buy small, thin-float stocks that don't have dot-com on them is pretty low," Mr. Syron said. "We're better off as a conventional company."
The revamping is well under way. The company, based in Waltham, Mass., announced on Jan. 31 that it would sell businesses that had provided one-third of its $4.2 billion in revenues. It is spinning off to shareholders two other businesses: biomedical devices and paper manufacturing equipment. And it plans to buy back the public shares of those companies that will form a business making analytical instruments.
Such a transformation is a tall task for someone who had never before run a public company. Sure, Mr. Syron had been on Thermo Electron's board for nearly two years, and yes, he had known George Hatsopoulos, the company's founder and former chairman, for decades.
He has done some big-time quasicorporate tinkering, as well: as president of the Boston Federal Reserve in the early 1990's, he helped keep many New England banks solvent as others across the country went under. In his most recent job, as president of the American Stock Exchange, he was an architect of its merger with Nasdaq's parent, the National Association of Securities Dealers.
But analysts wondered about Mr. Syron's qualifications to run Thermo Electron. "When he was first named, I did have to scratch my head a bit," said Deane Dray of Goldman Sachs, who nonetheless has high hopes for Mr. Syron's reign.
Mr. Syron acknowledges Wall Street's doubts, but says they are misplaced. "Organizational restructuring is not rocket science," he said. "It's common sense."
To hear Mr. Syron's friends and former colleagues tell it, he has that in abundance. "Dick is extremely bright, pragmatic and energetic -- emphasis on that middle word," said E. Gerald Corrigan, a Goldman Sachs partner who worked with Mr. Syron at the Federal Reserve. "He isn't caught up in theology; he's a doer."
Thomas F. Ryan, Mr. Syron's predecessor at the stock exchange, cited a case in point. "He knew enough not to involve the members in the merger decision until it was time to vote," Mr. Ryan said, "and then he knew how to persuade everyone that this merger was right."
Still, why would Dick Syron take on Thermo Electron? He took a 50 percent pay cut when he left the Amex, he says. And for now, his million stock options, priced at $19.10, do not represent any bonanza. Thermo's stock closed at $21.9375 on Friday -- well above its low of $12.50 on April 9, 1999, but nowhere near its high of $44.50 on Dec. 31, 1997.
"The stock has to go up substantially for this to be a good financial move," Mr. Syron said. "Anyone who says it is cheaper to live in Boston than New York hasn't lived in Boston lately."
So again, why? "I like to fix things," he said.
Mr. Syron grew up in Watertown, Mass., the child of Irish immigrants -- his father was a blacksmith, his mother a domestic worker. They lived in a three-family house, with relatives in the other apartments and other relatives a few blocks away.
Many of them loved to work with their hands, and Mr. Syron picked up the knack. "In our environment you didn't call a plumber; you borrowed your uncle's wrench," he said. Uncles and cousins taught him how to fix automobiles, and he learned to repair televisions at an after-school job.
He seemed destined to be an electrical engineer. But in college in the late 60's, he discovered he had a learning disability that made mechanical drawing impossible. He also met his future wife, Peggy. They have been married for 28 years, and have a daughter, Erin, 20, and a son, Brendan, 15.
As an economics major at Boston College (he has advanced degrees in economics from Tufts), Mr. Syron worked summers painting houses in poor sections of Boston. At the Boston Fed, he tried to ensure that people in poor neighborhoods were not unfairly denied mortgages.
Donald L. Isaacs, a retired banker and his best friend, recalls that Mr. Syron, an avid boater, has eschewed fancy sailing clubs, instead joining the more blue-collar South Boston Yacht Club. "Dick judges people by characteristics and qualities, not titles," Mr. Isaacs said.
Apparently, that is how Thermo Electron's board chose him, too. Investors had soured on the company's strategy of constantly spinning out public companies. In September, Mr. Hatsopoulos's brother John, his intended successor, announced that he would resign. The board, wanting someone familiar with the company, chose Mr. Syron. George Hatsopoulos resigned as chairman in January, giving Mr. Syron that title as well.
Mr. Syron expects that it will be more than a year before the sales are completed, the spinoffs done and the company operating as a manufacturer. When everything is fixed, will he leave?
Probably -- but then again, maybe not. "There are many other things I want to do," he said. "But you can't make decisions about what you'll do three years down the road."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
The Higher Stakes of Business-to-Business Trade

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
NO one doubts that there is tremendous money to be made helping companies do business with one another over the Internet. And judging by the enormous multiples that investors are paying, they seem pretty sure which kinds of companies are going to make that money. But are they right?
Business-to-business electronic commerce, known as B2B, covers a lot of ground. For some years, companies have been developing digital links with customers, distributors and suppliers to improve supply-chain management and demand forecasting and to squeeze out inventory costs. But lately the concept has taken a quantum leap in scale, to encompass whole industries buying, selling and trading with one another online. 
 Now growing numbers of software companies and dot-com start-ups are pouring in, enticed by the prospect of billions of dollars of transactions in, say, auto parts, freight-hauling services or specialty chemicals passing through a Web-based "exchange" or "marketplace," akin to an eBay for big business, that they could build and control.
And investors have followed, sending stock prices soaring for B2B companies like i2 Technologies, based here in Dallas, whose market capitalization of around $26 billion is about 1,000 times last year's earnings; i2 began life 12 years ago as an enterprise software concern. Ariba and Commerce One, two of i2's competitors, have also seen their stocks shoot up 20- and 30-fold from their offering prices, standing out even in the highflying technology sector.
But the announcement by General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler that they would combine forces to create a single Internet marketplace through which to do their buying has called into question whether the keys to the gold mine will ultimately be claimed by the B2B players or the Old Economy companies they want to serve.
Not that the automakers' announcement froze out the technology companies: Oracle, the Redwood City, Calif., database and e-commerce concern, was chosen to be a key technology provider to the new venture along with Commerce One, and both stocks have jumped since the announcement. But it is not certain that playing the limited role of technology supplier will ever yield enough revenue to justify today's sky-high stock valuations.
Analysts say most B2B exchange revenue will come three ways: from recurring subscription and maintenance fees from participants, from a small commission on each transaction and from equity stakes in the new exchanges. Together, the amounts should be huge.
Consider a few hypotheticals. Total B2B transactions are expected to rise from $145 billion last year to $7.3 trillion in 2004, according to the Gartner Group, a consulting firm. A cut of, say, 0.25 percent of that in transaction fees would yield nearly $20 billion in annual revenue, with much more growth to come. As for equity, some Wall Street analysts are already estimating that the Big Three's exchange could, as a publicly traded company, have a market capitalization of more than $30 billion.
"There is probably at least a trillion dollars in market cap up for grabs in the B2B industry," said Andrew Roskill, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read. "At the end of the day, there are probably only going to be a very few winners in each vertical industry sector, but those guys are going to command a very high premium."
For some others, it won't be pretty, as the aftermath of the carmakers' Feb. 25 announcement suggested. As it became clear during the day that i2, which had been helping G.M. with its own Internet site, had been left out of the new venture, its stock fell by more than one-quarter from its high that day. The stock recovered some of the lost ground last week, thanks to happier news about new Internet exchanges in the apparel and ground transportation industries and a successful meeting here with analysts; i2's shares closed Friday at $170.75.
Still, the episode shows that for all the talk of the New Economy triumphing over the old, some e-business highfliers cannot count on being masters of their own fate. Many traditional companies are rapidly deciphering the B2B world and demanding better terms for their participation, sometimes leaving smaller slivers of equity and lower fees for the technology companies than they had hoped. Some analysts expect Oracle's cut of the new auto venture to be smaller relative to Ford's than the two had initially discussed for Ford's own Web site project, although terms have not been announced.
With so much at stake, competitive tensions run high. The chief executive of i2, Sanjiv Sidhu, said in an interview last week that his staff was still negotiating for a role in the automakers' exchange. Mr. Sidhu argues that Oracle is not in his company's league technologically. "It's tough to really understand what they have to offer if you measure it based on what they have up and running," Mr. Sidhu said.
In response, an Oracle spokesman said new products due in the next few months would make the company "the best of the breed for supply-chain software" and that i2's exclusion, so far, from the Big Three's venture meant that "i2 is now irrelevant in the auto industry."
George Gilbert, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, agreed with Mr. Sidhu that Oracle lagged behind i2 in some crucial areas of technology. He said i2, struggling to cope with a huge flow of new proposals, was searching for a more standardized and efficient way to strike deals.
Historically, Mr. Gilbert said, i2's "biggest challenge has been marketing, because they've seen farther down the road than most, and they've had to bring people along." But lately, he said, "the market has caught up with them. It's like everything is coming together."
Speaking about B2B in general, Mr. Sidhu said fears that fees and equity stakes for companies like his would be squeezed were overblown. Demand for new Internet exchanges and associated software is so great, he said, that everyone is focused simply on getting sites up and running, not on the financial fine points. "There are many patients needing attention," Mr. Sidhu said, "and there's a shortage of doctors."
Technology companies may have an easier time in fields where both buyers and sellers are fragmented, like agriculture, than in concentrated industries where a handful of companies hold all the cards. Leah Knight, a principal analyst at the Gartner Group, said the automakers must have realized that they could dictate terms, and "if they want to take a larger percentage of the transaction, that comes with the turf."
Mr. Roskill said the same dynamic was developing elsewhere. "The last six months or so, we've seen a bit of a wake-up call from traditional industry players trying to shift the balance of power away from the technology providers to the actual people who provide the order flow," he said. But, he added, there is a limit to how far the pendulum should swing: "It makes sense to give the technology provider a stake that's meaningful, so their interests are tied together" with the users'.
In such an environment, Ms. Knight sees a shakeout ahead. While some B2B players "have the potential to become companies in the upper end" of the Fortune 500, she said, "maybe not even half" of those now in the field will be winners. The current stock market valuations of the remainder leave them a lot of room to fall.

As business-to-business e-commerce takes hold, the question of who will exert the most control over online marketplaces and exchanges -- and the rewards to be reaped from them -- will be answered differently from industry to industry, analysts say.
 
Concentrated buyers
One or a few main companies that buy from a host of suppliers.
Buyers are likely to dominate, with B2B companies in lesser roles as technology suppliers.
EXAMPLES: Big Three automakers; Sears and Carrefour
 
Concentrated sellers
One or a few major suppliers that sell to a host of customers.
Sellers are likely to dominate, with B2B companies in lesser roles as technology suppliers.
EXAMPLES: Metalsite (steel), ChemConnect and CheMatch (chemicals)
 
Fragmented
Many buyers and sellers trading, collaborating and competing.
Opportunities for B2B companies to dominate as intermediaries.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
A Credibility Gap In the Digital Divide

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
THE latest buzzphrase circulating among politicians and computer industry executives these days is the digital divide, the gulf between those who have access to computers and the Internet and those who do not. Poor people and minorities, or so the thinking goes, are in danger of being shut out of what promises to be the most important mode of gathering and exchanging information, and what is emerging as a common way of making and spending lots of money.
In fact, though, there is a growing recognition among those dealing most closely with the issue that the term digital divide, while clever and provocative, has become a catchall phrase for politicians with conspicuous agendas and that the divide is a complex phenomenon that no amount of measurement can fully explain. 
 Increasingly, it seems that the nation is actually facing a multitude of digital divides, not one limited to race or income or education. While it is true that millions of people are still without access to computers or the Internet, those who are counted as connected fall along a spectrum: Some are dialing into the Internet through antiquated rural phone lines that cannot handle high data speeds, while others use ultra high-speed connections from both work and home. Millions of others are getting their connection only occasionally from public libraries, classrooms or community centers.
Last week was a busy time for those in the digital bridge-building business. First, Vice President Al Gore visited a San Francisco nonprofit group to deliver a speech on the divide.
Later in the week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson opened a branch of his Rainbow/PUSH Coalition in Silicon Valley, with the goal of closing the divide among the poor. The same day, the Rev. Jackson delivered a speech at the University of California at Berkeley in which he pronounced access to technology "the newest stage of the civil rights struggle."
Also last week, results of a survey conducted by National Public Radio, the Kaiser Family Foundation and Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government corroborated earlier studies that found that at higher income levels there is virtually no racial gap. More good news: of those who bought computers in the last two years, about one-third are from low-income or minority groups.
And yet the survey found a persistent racial divide among low-income households when it comes to computer ownership and Internet access at home.
Such findings may not spell out the problem as much as help reveal its thorniness. It helps to start by looking at the ways in which people connect to the Internet. Plenty of people have connections at work, but some of them are not wired at home. In addition, connecting to the Internet from work, a library or school is quite different from connecting from the privacy of one's living room. Experts say that the only way to fully appreciate the Web is to experience it and that the most useful experience, unfettered by the constraints of an institutional setting, comes with using the Internet from home.
At the same time, a high-speed cable modem connection gives a Web surfer a far different view of cyberspace -- one that's lightning quick and rich with sound and motion -- than that seen via a slower link from a traditional modem.
Thus far, much of the digital bridge-building has focused on schools. At first blush, the gap there doesn't seem especially alarming. According to Market Data Retrieval, a company that has surveyed the nation's public schools, 94 percent of schools in wealthy districts have access to the Internet, compared with 84 percent of schools that serve poor populations.
But the figures are deceptive. "Those numbers fail to address the nature of those connections," David Gollaher, chief executive of the California Healthcare Institute, a nonprofit group in La Jolla, Calif., told a group of health care experts who gathered last week at Berkeley to discuss the digital divide and e-health (industry shorthand for the delivery of health information and services on the Internet).
Most of the poorer schools, Mr. Gollaher said, connect to the Internet using a relatively slow 56 kilobit-per-second connection, which may be fine for sending e-mail but prevents a large population of potential users from experiencing the full scope and power of the Internet.
Mr. Gollaher later said it was not until he got a high-speed connection at his home that his own children grew interested in the Web. "They download a lot of music, and they listen to radio stations online," he said. "Many of the uses they prefer are uses that depend on high-speed connections."
SOME experts have claimed in recent weeks that the digital divide is actually a myth, that income at all levels might play a greater role than race in disparities between the digital haves and have-nots, though the two are often connected.
The N.P.R. survey disproved that claim with a finding that among households of all income levels, 57 percent of whites under the age of 60 have Internet or e-mail access from home, compared with 38 percent of blacks. In households where income is less than $30,000 a year, the study found, 34 percent of whites have access from home, compared with 19 percent of blacks.
That divide narrows drastically when on-line access takes place outside the home, especially in the workplace. "The gap largely disappears everywhere except at home," said Molly Brodie, a vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, who oversaw the N.P.R. survey.
"As soon as you start to look a little deeper, you see that the biggest problem is at home," said Donna L. Hoffman, a professor of management at Vanderbilt University and the co-author of a 1998 study with results similar to those in the N.P.R. survey.
"There's no way you can understand what it can do for you unless you use it," she said of the Internet. "You have to try it, then you can see the meaning it can have in your own life."
Connecting to the Internet from outside the home makes having such an experience more difficult, she said. "I just think it's very hard to do that when you have a 30-minute limit, or when you have to wait in line, or with others around."
David Greenbaum, a researcher at Berkeley who works with community groups in Oakland to address the digital divide, suspects that the problem of access from home might be one of cause and effect.
"One premise that underlies all of this is that if someone had the right kind of access at home, they'd be much more involved in the whole wired and on-line world," Mr. Greenbaum said. "But if they already had the impulse and interest to be part of that world, then they'd have the kind of motivation to have a machine at home."
INTERESTINGLY, the N.P.R. survey found no significant difference between whites and blacks at low-income levels when it came to owning other home electronics, like cable television and V.C.R.'s.
Mr. Greenbaum said that at a recent digital divide conference in Oakland, a number of people asked: "Why is it people are willing to spend $500 on a big wide-screen TV? How can we instill that same kind of economic pull to a desire to being online?"

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 153 words

HEADLINE: A Dependence on Oil

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Effort for Lowering Oil Prices Gains at U.S.-Saudi Meeting" (news article, Feb. 27):
Sending Energy Secretary Bill Richardson to secure lower oil prices may provide consumer relief in the short term, but does nothing to address the long-term problem of our oil addiction. In addition to spewing 20 percent of our global warming pollution, automobiles guzzle 40 percent of the oil we use, keeping us dependent on foreign oil. 
 In fact, with the proliferation of S.U.V.'s, the average fuel economy of new vehicles sold has fallen to its lowest point since 1980. Since 1996, Congress has blocked President Clinton's ability to raise fuel economy standards. The president must stand up to Congress and the auto industry now to raise these standards.
 
ANN MESNIKOFF
Washington, Feb. 29, 2000
 
The writer is a representative of the Sierra Club's Global Warming and Energy Program.

HEADLINE: So Big That Politics Gets Lost

BYLINE: By Michael Yaki; Michael Yaki, a lawyer, is a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Moving the California primary to March 7 from its old date in June would ensure one thing, the politicos and party hacks said: it would give the state, the seventh-largest economic power in the world, some importance in the process of electing the president.
Never mind that with 54 electoral votes, California could be sure that once the primaries were over, the nominees would spend an inordinate amount of time here. Never mind that the well-heeled of Hollywood and Silicon Valley (and the occasional Buddhist monk) could already talk shop with any politicians they wanted. 
 If we Californians were really important, the thinking went, we should be part of determining which candidates were there in the general election to woo us. You can imagine party bosses muttering as the world focused on clumps of 45 frozen voters apiece in Iowa and New Hampshire. We are California! We incarcerate more people than live in Des Moines!
But California's sheer size keeps it from being a New Hampshire or an Iowa, even with the primary duly moved. Staged media events attended by thousands -- Chinatown walks, barrio strolls and anti-crime speeches -- replace the hourlong stop at the coffee shop.
Instead of the folksy meetings down at the courthouse, we've had an almost yearlong barrage of radio and television ads, glitzy mailers and annoying phone calls from "grass-roots" bullpens in Florida and Arizona. Yes, we may have a decisive impact early. But that doesn't necessarily translate into greater citizen involvement.
If we really want to make the voters of California connect with the early stages of the presidential marathon, we need a different approach. Why not be creative? We are a big, diverse state. Split California up into "affinity" primaries.
Each California group would vote on the same date as an affinity partner elsewhere in the country, with our delegates divided accordingly. By being lumped together with other, earlier primaries, we might have even more impact.
Take, for example, Iowa. The issue there seems to be farms, farms, farms. We have farms in California, big farms. The Central Valley. The Imperial Valley. We could link up with Iowa in a "farmers' caucus." We might even invite the very small farmers in Humboldt County (if we conveniently forget the illegal crop that several of our candidates swear they haven't touched in decades). Then Bill Bradley, George W. Bush, Al Gore and John McCain could wax philosophical in front of real corn and rutabagas. After all, what grows in Iowa in January?
Or consider San Francisco, which has the largest (surprise!) proportion of voters in the state who decline to state their political preferences when they register. San Franciscans pride ourselves on our independent (liberal) streak. New Hampshire prides itself on its independent (conservative) streak. The "live free or die" state and the "free love" city together on one primary day -- just imagine the synergy.
New York City and Los Angeles could end their foolish competition by beaming Palm Pilots at one another and recognizing that they're really only a cell phone's throw apart. The megacities with megadiversity and megaproblems could have a megaprimary in March (the ides would be most appropriate).
Communities like Palm Springs could be linked with their golf-saturated, water-table-draining brethren in Nevada and Arizona to form a "fairways and greens" primary. And so on. And then, for the general election, we could return to our usual winner-take-all vote to unite our great state behind one candidate.
Yes, I'm kidding. But the problem is real. And Iowa and New Hampshire are about more than just being the first hurdles of the presidential race. They also represent a model of politician-citizen interaction that is the envy of the nation.
In a California statewide contest, whether a primary or a general election, candidates tend to focus on their bases of voters, extracting the highest turnout possible among those most likely to support them.
Mr. Bradley, who has staked a position to the left of Mr. Gore, is focusing heavily on the San Francisco Bay area, a treasure trove of liberal voters. Mr. McCain, who is trolling for patriotic, heartland conservatives, has been seen hopping from meeting to meeting in Fresno and Stockton.
This approach means entire communities are ignored or given token attention. It may seem cynical, but it is dictated by California's size and the cost of campaigning. Affinity primaries might give everyone an opportunity to feel as courted as the waitress in the coffee shop in Concord or the office manager in Oskaloosa. They could be the way to bite-size California's vastness to connect the individual voters to the greater political good.
As a locally elected official, I know the power of the handshake, the conversation in the grocery store, the chat on the street corner. The willingness and ability to engage one-on-one is still one of our most precious grasps on the democratic process, but it is increasingly scarce.
We are the mighty California, with the coastline that stretches nearly 1,000 miles and the population of more than 30 million. But we are also many Californias, and we need to find some way to give more of our people the sense of an individual stake in the electoral process.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS: About Face;
Guess Who's Embracing Immigrants Now

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
IN 1994, Gov. Pete Wilson rode to re-election on his successful support of Proposition 187, which barred the children of illegal immigrants from attending public school in California.
Two years later, the Republican-led Congress pointed to the huge budget deficit when it enacted legislation that barred hundreds of thousands of legal immigrants from receiving food stamps and Federal disability assistance. 
 Immigrant bashing then swept into the presidential campaign as a wedge issue. Bob Dole, the Republican presidential nominee, called for barring the children of illegal immigrants from attending schools. Pete Wilson seized on anti-immigrant proposals to spur his faltering presidential bid. And Pat Buchanan's motto may well have been "Don't give me your tired, your poor."
What a difference four years make. George W. Bush has denounced the Republicans' past anti-immigrant initiatives and boasts that he can speak Spanish, while Al Gore has even assayed a few stumbling words of Espanol. Not only that, Republican Party strategists have declared that Hispanics will be the soccer moms of this year's campaign. It's as if immigrants have been transformed Cinderella-like into the belles of the political ball. "There's been a remarkable turnaround," said Frank Sharry, executive director of the National Immigration Forum, an advocacy group for immigrants.
It is easy to see why. Democratic and Republican strategists agree that Hispanics may provide the swing votes in the four states -- California, New York, Texas and Florida -- which have large Hispanic populations and which, taken together, account for half the electoral votes needed to win the presidency.
While immigrants tend to vote in smaller percentages than other demographic groups, the number of Hispanic-American and Asian-American voters is growing fast, and so are their campaign contributions.
Immigrants are also increasingly valued by corporate America; were the nation's six million illegal immigrants expelled tomorrow, thousands of restaurants, hotels, farms, poultry plants and garment factories and gardening companies would be forced to close for want of workers. Some economists also believe that the nation's record economic boom may have already sputtered without immigrants to fill millions of jobs.
"There's no question that without the flow of immigrants, we would have hit much earlier the level at which we started to have wage inflation and that would have meant higher interest rates and that would have reduced the spectacular growth that we see," said Daniel Bachman, chief economist at Transatlantic Futures, a Washington-based research institute. His opinion is shared by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
This is not a low-wage, service economy phenomenon. The high-tech sector has asked that the annual quota for high-skilled immigrants be nearly doubled.
Unions, like many Republicans, viewed immigrants with suspicion. The A.F.L-C.I.O., for example, saw them as an economic fifth column that took away union jobs and depressed wages. Recently, however, it has called for a general amnesty for illegal workers. In economic boom times, with unemployment at 4 percent, these are potential union members.
"We no longer have a knee-jerk reaction that immigrants drag down the standard of living," said John Wilhelm, president of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union. "We, the labor movement, want to show we're on their side."
Surveys by the Public Policy Institute of California found that in 1994, 20 percent of Californians said immigration was the topic they most wanted politicians to talk about, while this year only 2 percent of Californians feel that way. "Whenever we're in boom periods, as we are today, people are more generous in their attitudes toward immigrants," sSaid Mark Baldassare, survey director at the California institute. "Immigration is not a very good wedge issue in the current economic climate," said Mark Baldassare, survey director at the California institute.
Republicans switched tacks after sifting through recent election returns. In 1996, 72 percent of Hispanic voters backed Bill Clinton, while 21 percent supported Bob Dole. And exit polls showed that in California's 1998 race for governor, 78 percent of Hispanic voters backed Gray Davis, the Democratic victor. Republican strategists were also startled that in California alone, 250,000 Mexican and Salvadoran immigrants became naturalized Americans and registered to vote in 1996 and 1997.
The record number of immigrants who have sought citizenship, registered to vote and then voted Democratic around the country in recent years is widely viewed as a backlash against Republican-backed, anti-immigrant policies. "The politics of immigrant bashing has backfired," said Harry Pachon, president of the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute, a research group in Claremont, Calif. This has made a small group of Republicans, led by Jack Kemp and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who spoke out against their party's nativist policies, look prophetic.
Democratic politicians risk being torn between Hispanic voters and the traditionally Democratic African-Americans, who often see them as competitors for jobs and political power. Nonetheless, with demographers projecting that Hispanics will replace African-Americans as the largest minority group in five years, the role of Hispanics in politics will undoubtedly grow.
"The Ellis Island immigrants of the early 1900's became a key part of the New Deal coalition that led to decades of dominance by the Democratic Party," said Mr. Sharry of the National Immigration Forum. "The new wave of immigrants is clearly up for grabs, and with the tight races for Congress and the White House, this fast-growing population can determine who dominates over the next few decades."

HEADLINE: PRIMARY ENDORSEMENTS;
John McCain and Al Gore

 BODY:
On Tuesday, New Yorkers, Californians and voters in nine other states have the unusual opportunity of participating in presidential primary elections that could be decisive in their parties' nominating contests. By the end of the day, it could be clear whether Gov. George W. Bush faces a prolonged battle from Senator John McCain on the Republican side and whether Vice President Al Gore has put an end to former Senator Bill Bradley's campaign for the Democratic nomination.
This page does not always endorse in the presidential primaries. We last did so in 1992. We believe dual pre-nomination endorsements are in order this year because of the competitiveness of the contests and because of the importance of the choices before our readers. These endorsements are also, in some sense, a tribute to the vigor and seriousness that the four candidates have brought to this campaign season. So with a bow of respect to all four for reviving public interest in the election process, we endorse Mr. McCain as the preferable candidate for the Republicans and Mr. Gore as our choice for the Democratic nomination.
 
The Leadership Test
 
 In their very different ways, each of these two men communicates a greater capacity for overarching presidential leadership than his opponent. Mr. McCain's potential proceeds from deeper knowledge about government and a commitment to reform as a guiding idea rather than a hastily adopted slogan. Mr. Gore, for his part, knows more about domestic and foreign issues than any candidate in either party, and his aura of confidence and readiness for command have intensified while Mr. Bradley's appetite for the job seems to have mysteriously diminished during the campaign.
We have clear disagreements with Mr. McCain on issues like abortion and gun control, as well as profound reservations about Mr. Gore's record on the Clinton-Gore campaign's fund-raising abuses in 1996. But real campaigns seldom present perfect choices. Therefore a nomination endorsement has to take into consideration the broad agenda of challenges that will face the next president and to reflect a reasoned judgment -- and sometimes even a leap of faith -- as to a candidate's ability to rise above ideology and past mistakes. The list of tests confronting the next president is a daunting one. It includes preserving peace and prosperity, improving education, health care and the environment, and healing the religious and racial divisions in American society. In their respective races, Mr. McCain and Mr. Gore are unequivocally the best choices to lead in these areas.
 
The Republican Race
Clearly, this point in the political calendar finds the Republicans with the more competitive race. While trailing in the important California contest, Mr. McCain is strong in New York and has the potential to prolong a healthy battle for the soul of the G.O.P. The party's leaders first looked to Mr. Bush as a modernizer who would end the damaging "culture wars" that led to President George Bush's defeat in 1992. The governor was presented initially as an inclusive moderate with a short but impressive record in Texas. He improved his state's schools and challenged the G.O.P. status quo by opposing Congressional attempts to balance the budget by punishing the poor.
But in fighting off his opponent, Mr. Bush has embraced a punitive hard-right agenda. After first challenging his party's Congressional leaders, he has made himself an instrument of their opposition to campaign finance reform. His ill-advised tax-cut proposal, miscues on foreign policy, opposition to gun control and vows to appoint anti-abortion Supreme Court justices have further dimmed his appeal.
If he does win the nomination, perhaps he could reclaim his original political persona as a more spacious kind of Republican who would be a uniter, not a divider. But the smarter course for Republicans would be to choose Mr. McCain, who would not have to be repackaged and repositioned when it comes to outreach and reform. He has a proven ability to get votes from the vital center of the American spectrum. He began with a vow to destroy the "iron triangle" of donations, lobbyists and legislation. He broke further with the Republican leadership to oppose Mr. Bush's outsized tax-cut scheme as too weighted toward the wealthy. Bravely, and perhaps foolishly, he became the first important Republican figure to challenge leaders of the religious right for intimidating the party with religious-based litmus tests.
This has led Beltway Republicans to launch a nonsensical effort to depict Mr. McCain as a false conservative. The charge is wrong on the facts. Mr. McCain has opposed gun control and abortion. In the foreign policy area, he has been one of the Clinton administration's toughest critics. Although we do not agree with many of these positions, we think Republican voters should judge him on his real record, not the falsified version being pushed by Mr. Bush's right-wing enforcers.
As a zestful insurgent battling to open his party, Mr. McCain has brought gusts of fresh air, excitement and common sense to American politics. Despite our differences with him on abortion and other important policies, we respect his politics of principle and his opposition to Congressional influence-peddling, and we recommend him to voters in the Republican primaries.
 
 The Democrats
The reality of the Democrats' battle is that Mr. Bradley is on the ropes. Only weeks ago, he seemed the likely beneficiary of primary voters' conflicted attitudes toward President Clinton. The leader who presided over the longest economic boom in American history and accomplished many progressive goals had also brought dishonor to the Oval Office. Mr. Gore could not be blamed for the singular lunacy of the Monica Lewinsky scandal. But he was tarnished by fund-raising fiascoes invoked by the very words "Buddhist temple" and "no controlling legal authority."
At first, Mr. Bradley seemed ready to capitalize on a general public impulse to turn the page. But after a promising start, he stumbled badly in regard to policy and performance. His ambitious health care proposal, the initial centerpiece of his campaign, was attractive, especially because of its goal of universal coverage. Yet he never effectively answered Mr. Gore's charge that he had underestimated the cost of his proposals and jeopardized Medicaid and Medicare. Even more striking, Mr. Gore's swarming debate style did not bring out the warrior in Mr. Bradley. Instead, the challenges made him seem petulant and remote.
Perhaps it was simply that the thoughtfulness and independence that marked Mr. Bradley's Senate service did not translate to the stump. Certainly his eloquence on race and his demands for higher ethical standards elevated the campaign. But the voters picked up on Mr. Bradley's lack of energy and on a certain emotional austerity in his connection with them. If overeagerness to please is a defect in Mr. Gore, Mr. Bradley possesses an even more disturbing inability to convey a real hunger for the opportunity to serve.
 
Al Gore's Potential
There is plenty to criticize in the style and substance of Mr. Gore's record. The Republicans are already planning to run videos of the Buddhist temple event, where Mr. Gore still insists he was shocked to find that money was being raised. In this campaign, he has exaggerated flaws in Mr. Bradley's record and been evasive about the evolution in his own position on abortion, guns and tobacco.
But Mr. Gore brings tremendous gifts to his quest for the White House. Most impressive to us, he communicates a passion to lead, a determination to leave a positive mark on history and a burning desire to step out of his mentor's shadow and prove that he possesses the self-control and presidential high-mindedness so lacking in Mr. Clinton. The Al Gore of today has a deep commitment to social justice, abortion rights and gun control. To make up for his fund-raising lapse in 1996, he promises that if elected he will make campaign finance reform one of the top half-dozen legislative priorities for his first year.
On foreign policy, the vice president is clearly the best-prepared candidate in this race. He is also his party's strongest leader on environmental protection and scientific progress. On issues ranging from preserving the Everglades to pushing for a global treaty on carbon dioxide emissions, he is the primary architect of Mr. Clinton's environmental legacy.
Widely ridiculed for asserting that he invented the Internet, Mr. Gore can actually take credit for seeing the digital world before most other political leaders. He promises to bring a grasp of science and technological advances to the White House at a time when a host of tough problems on everything from Internet privacy to genetic engineering will confront the nation. Finally, Mr. Gore's experience as a successful partner in making the right decisions on budget and fiscal issues, and in fighting a reactionary Congress to protect and even expand domestic programs, holds great promise for the future. Like Mr. Clinton, the vice president can be a maddening compromiser. But he has a strong internal compass and is more prepared for presidential responsibility than Mr. Clinton was in 1992 and than Mr. Bradley is today.
Our endorsements of Mr. McCain and Mr. Gore apply only to the nomination competitions of their parties. As always, we will wait until late in the general election campaign to make a final endorsement for the presidency. The fall campaign, of course, will provide another set of tests for the final two contestants. But every citizen should hope that the last months of this political year will be marked by the earnest effort that Al Gore, Bill Bradley, John McCain and George W. Bush brought to the primary season.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Cross Purposes;
Mixing God and Politics And Getting Burned

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FORTY years and 10 presidential elections ago, John F. Kennedy felt compelled to journey to a hostile conference of Protestant church leaders in Houston to plead that he would never serve as a vassal of the papacy if he were elected the nation's first Catholic president.
It was an ignominious moment for many of Mr. Kennedy's fellow American Catholics as the candidate, a decorated war veteran, had to pass Protestant muster and deal with the dregs of anti-immigrant, anti-Catholic bigotry rooted in the nativist prejudices of the 19th century Know-Nothing movement, when native born Protestants demanded voting, citizenship and education curbs on the alarming waves of Catholic immigrants. 
 In weathering the fire and winning the election, Mr. Kennedy gently cautioned the nation to oppose any attempt to distort the presidency by "making it an instrument of one religious group." His words survive as a prescription for all the nimble campaigners who have followed him through the risky, often treacherous field where politics and religion overlap.
This year, spurred by an unexpectedly contentious Republican primary, the nation is witnessing a 180-degree turn on the historic Kennedy confrontation. This time, it is a worried Protestant candidate from Texas, Gov. George W. Bush, who is now daily seeking out Catholic forums and photo ops, replete with church banners and Roman-collared clerics, to assure one and all his presidency would not be an instrument of a dominant religious group -- evangelical Protestantism.
"Isn't that a neat little parallel -- a nervous George Bush trying to reassure Catholics?" observed Kate O'Beirne, the Washington editor for The National Review. She is less amused by Senator John McCain's wielding of the religion issue in his tooth-and-claw nomination struggle with Governor Bush.
"It's a rare Catholic who even cares about Bob Jones University," Ms. O'Beirne said of the South Carolina evangelical college Senator McCain has strategically lambasted as an anti-Catholic bastion happily visited by Governor Bush. "It's shameless Catholic baiting," said Ms. O'Beirne, predicting a backlash of sorts against Mr. McCain among the significant blocs of Catholic voters expected to turn out this week in the mammoth Super Tuesday primary showdown.
Whether Mr. McCain wins or loses, it is clear he has let a red-white-and-blue genie out of the bottle and its recorking seems unlikely during the general election campaign this fall.
Democrats, fairly leering in delight, are recording every sling and arrow exchanged in the Republican primary. And for good reason. It was only six years ago that the Newt Gingrich revolution in the House alarmed Democrats with the fact that a Catholic majority of voters had shifted for the first time in decades from Democrats to Republicans on the House ballot. Before that, Catholics had split their ticket, voting, say, for President Ronald Reagan but then returning to their lunch-pail party roots.
But the Republicans' painful disarray over the role of the religious right -- a bloc that Mr. Reagan first tucked masterfully into the G.O.P. fold -- is giving Capitol Hill Democrats new hope. In the House, the McCain attack has caused Democrats to revive an earlier, largely overlooked flap in which charges of anti-Catholicism marred a bipartisan attempt to choose a new chaplain.
In the Senate, Democrats, hoping to sting Republicans in open floor debate, quickly offered broadside resolutions condemning Bob Jones University as segregationist and -- 40 years after candidate Kennedy -- even anti-pope.
"This is the one question of value that will outlast the primaries," promised Senator Robert Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who runs his party's Senate politcal campaign. "People are going to want to be heard on this, the possible alienation of Catholics just when many thought they were part of the Establishment," the senator added, contending that Governor Bush would be tarred with the issue into the general election.
OTHERS, however, think that Senator McCain "went one day too far" with his attack, in the words of Scott Appleby, a history professor at Notre Dame University. He noted that Mr. McCain used the word "evil" in a follow-up attack on the Rev. Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson, two politico-evangelical stalwarts, but then quickly had to retract it.
Mr. Appleby, the director of the Cushwa Center for the Study of American Catholicism, feels the senator "is failing to tap into a deeper level" of Catholic fear that is more a relic of history than descriptive of modern Catholics, who are not monolithic voters unless faced by an appalling instance of anti-Catholic bigotry. Mr. Bush just does not fill the bill, Mr. Appleby thinks.
It should be noted, too, that it was only after Mr. McCain was defeated in South Carolina and headed for states with broader, more diverse voter blocs, that he threw down the religious glove and singled out Mr. Robertson and Mr. Falwell as "agents of intolerance," betting that the muscle of the religious right has withered since President Reagan blended it into a coalition with post-Kennedy, blue-collar Catholics.
In Michigan, Mr. McCain first denied, then confirmed that his campaign phone-blitzed Catholic voters with reminders of Mr. Bush's Bob Jones appearance and of the school's policy against interracial dating, which it reversed Friday, and its history of anti-Catholic polemics, including descriptions of the Vatican as running a "Satanic system."
MR. McCAIN was, in some sense, merely stealing from the religious attack playbook of the Bush campaign in South Carolina.
"It was some of the worst of American politics I've seen," the political columnist Mark Shields said of attacks by pro-Bush organizations on Mr. McCain, in which some observers sensed wisps of anti-Semitism and other insults to pluralism.
The key question is how the McCain initiative will play out Tuesday in states like Ohio and New York, where there are significant numbers of voters who consider themselves Catholic. Will the bloc fears of the old post-immigration generation revive?
In Ohio, as other states, Catholics may be increasingly uneasy about the Bob Jones reports, says John C. Green, director of the Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron. But he emphasizes that Protestant evangelicals also see the issue as an attack on them and not, as Mr. McCain insists, solely on two performers on the nation's politico-religion circuit.
Indeed, exit polls in Virginia and interviews with many voters who identify themselves as religious conservatives suggest that Mr. McCain's remarks are mobilizing support for Governor Bush.
In any case, the issue of religion, as ever in American history, is putting as much fresh life into primary day as into the Bush campaign. "The running joke here," Mr. Green said, "is whether Governor Bush will join the Knights of Columbus by primary day."
Peter Quinn, a veteran New York political speechwriter and historical novelist, said: "McCain is blowing on some old embers and causing some smoke, but no real fire. I don't think George Bush is seen as anti-Catholic." Still, Mr. Quinn admitted he was intrigued by how much the Catholic vote might resonate Tuesday with candidate Kennedy's trial by dogma before the Protestant prelates.
The net effect of Senator McCain's attacks on the religious right were "politically disastrous," in the view of Mr. Shields. "He failed to distinguish the followers from the leadership, implying they'd been bamboozled," he said. "And in politics you never blame the customers."
Beyond questions of strategic advantage in the electoral wars, there lies the large gray area where voters' impressions of personal and civic morality overlap. There, the rancorous butting of politics and religion itself can become an issue as much as a spectacle for the voters.
John C. Green, director of the Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron, sounds decidedly unalarmed about this instance of boundary crossing. Whether in the year 2000 or 1900, "this is what campaigns do: they look for appeals that will work and look for groups that will move," he said.
But he noted that this election cycle "has an unusual amount of explicit references to religion." He pointed to the early and emphatic statements of Christian faith from Mr. Bush, Vice President Al Gore and many of their rivals. He thinks this may be due to voters, who are looking beyond the booming economy to wonder whether a rapidly changing culture, regularly troubled by news of its own lack of control, as seen in a lurid ongoing melange of shootings and scandal-ridden leaders, demands more avowedly moral politics and politicians.
They certainly are out there now on the stump. They are talking beliefs and charging hypocrisy, looking for advantage while promising the high road to voters already sensing the risk, amid the spectacle of once more mixing politics and religion.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: FEBRUARY 28 -- MARCH 3;
New Interest in the Smokestacks

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Smoke was once again visible from the stacks on Friday as Old Economy companies retook a leadership role that they had relinquished to New Economy technology companies of late.
 What prompted the rally of shares in companies like Dow Chemical, DuPont and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing was a Labor Department report showing that 43,000 jobs were created in February, merely a fifth of what Wall Street economists had expected and the slowest pace in nine months. 
 The report eased concerns about a possible series of interest rate increases.
 What I'm seeing is a lot of old names coming back from the dead, and that's good, Charles Payne, head analyst at Wall Street Strategies, told Reuters.
 The Dow Jones industrials ended higher for five consecutive days for the first time since August, up 5 percent for the week, to 10,367.20. Those basic industry stocks had gotten totally whacked, Michelle Clayman of New Amsterdam Partners, told Reuters.
 But technology shares were not completely overlooked by investors. The Nasdaq composite continued its tear toward 5,000, ending the week up 7 percent, at 4,914.79. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Black History Awards

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
In honor of Black History Month, the county and its Millennium Commission have honored eight African- Americans for outstanding accomplishments.
M. Paul Redd, publisher of the Westchester County Press, the county's only black-owned newspaper, received the Alger Adams Award for outstanding work in the field of publishing, in honor of the founder of the newspaper. 
 Ainsley Adams, a teacher at the R. J. Bailey School in Greenburgh for 30 years, received the Cecil H. Parker Education Award, named for Westchester's first African-American elementary school teacher.
Warren Jackson, founder and chairman of Circulation Experti, a 32-year-old black-owned public relations and advertising firm, received the Madame C. J. Walker Award for economic development, for a black woman who was the nation's first female millionaire.
The actor Ossie Davis and his wife, the actress and writer Ruby Dee, received the Betty Shabazz Award for civic contributions, named for the late civil rights activist and wife of Malcolm X.
The acting coach Tina Sattin, founder of the Open Cage Theater in Mount Vernon, received the Cab Calloway award for culture and arts, named for the jazz pianist and musician.
Harry Jefferson, White Plains High School football and track star and basketball coach, received the Fritz Pollard Award for Sports, named for the first black head coach in the National Football League.
The Rev. Richard H. Dixon, retired pastor of the Macedonia Baptist Church in Mount Vernon, received the Amanda and Henry Foster Religion Award, named for the founders of the Foster Memorial A.M.E. Zion Church in Tarrytown.
Dr. Larry Spruill, a historian, museum curator and social studies director for the Mount Vernon Public Schools, received the John Henry Harmon History Award, named for an African-American historian and economist.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY;
A Psychiatric Theory On Irrational Exuberance

BYLINE: By RICHARD TEITELBAUM 

 BODY:
It is a truism that the stock market is a pendulum swinging between fear and greed. But what if there is no fear because investors are chock full of Prozac or other psychoactive drugs?
Perhaps stock prices and indexes like the Nasdaq composite, up 20.8 percent so far this year, could race to unprecedented valuations as investors' usual reactions to things like high price-earnings multiples and rising interesting rates are suppressed. 
 That is the hypothesis being floated by Randolph M. Nesse, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Michigan, in a recent essay posted on a Web site called Edge, (www.edge.org).
Dr. Nesse points out that prescriptions for psychoactive drugs rose to 233 million in 1998 from 131 million in 1988, with nearly 10 million filled last year for Prozac alone. Next, he considers the likelihood that a disproportionately high part of the population connected to the markets -- brokers and wealthy individuals, in particular -- are likely to be taking antidepressants.
And he says he has noted that certain of his patients who take such drugs seem to worry too little about real dangers. "This is exactly the mind-set of many current investors," he said.
Dr. Nesse said he did not want to belittle the positive effects that antidepressants may be having on the economy.
"They are productive employees," he said of workers taking such drugs.
"But if investor caution is being inhibited by psychotropic drugs, bubbles could grow larger than usual before they pop, with potentially catastrophic economic and political consequences," he said. "If chemicals are inhibiting normal caution in any substantial fraction of investors, we need to know about it."
On the other hand, if a "Prozac effect" on the markets is confirmed through further research, it might not necessarily be bad news for stocks. Only one-third of the population that could benefit from antidepressants is currently taking them, according to Dr. Nesse. So, presumably, the market has room to go higher.
(Full disclosure: Dr. Nesse said he was not currently invested in the market, having recently sold a position in a biotechnology stock, Affymetrix.)
In any case, Dr. Nesse is adamant that government-sponsored research into the topic is necessary. But he is not sure whether it should be carried out by the Securities and Exchange Commission or the National Institutes of Mental Health. RICHARD TEITELBAUM

HEADLINE: In Mexico, Nature Lovers Merit a Kiss From a Whale

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 4

 BODY:
Mexico learned this week that it cannot be half global.
After five years of pressure from an environmental movement that is every day more transnational, the government on Thursday canceled plans with the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan to build a gigantic salt plant on the shores of a lagoon where gray whales give birth. 
It was a decision Mexico never expected to make when the battle began, back in the early stages of the country's broad opening to foreign commerce under the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement. Up to that time, Mexican leaders had been able to dismiss the complaints of foreign environmentalists as an intrusion into their national affairs.
But in the war for Laguna San Ignacio, a tranquil inlet in an unblemished Baja California desert, the nationalist arguments no longer packed any punch. And as Mexico received $11.6 billion last year in long-term investments from abroad, it also discovered that it cannot ignore the other forces, like the environmental movement, that are crisscrossing borders and making politics into a global game.
"It took a million people to do it," said Jacob Scherr, a director of the Natural Resources Defense Council, an American group that led the campaign, "but we showed that we can work together worldwide to compel even the largest corporations to respect nature."
Mexican and foreign conservationists united behind the campaign, organizing support from the humble Mexican fishing communities on the shores of the lagoon to the offices of several United States mutual funds that agreed to shun Mitsubishi stock. The crusade was waged over the Internet and in the press across North America.
Mitsubishi received at least 750,000 letters calling for it to scrap the project, and a boycott of its products was getting under way in California. Bus stops in Mexico City carry posters showing a regal fin rising above the lagoon's serene waters and asking riders if they want the whales to belong to "a corporation" or to humanity.
The Mexican government owns 51 percent of the salt company that proposed the salt plant and Mitsubishi owns 49 percent. The company already runs a big 50-year-old salt evaporation plant in another lagoon frequented by whales up the coast from San Ignacio.
If Mexico and Mitsubishi had gone forward with the new plant, they would have been permanently stuck with the image of profit-happy predators that the environmental movement had spun around them.
Environmentalists were aware that their victory did more than guarantee peaceful swimming for the whales at Laguna San Ignacio. It proved that they can be lead players on what has become an international stage.
President Ernesto Zedillo lashed out with uncharacteristic spleen this week when he announced the decision to dump the project. "Frankly, it infuriates me that some groups used this project to gain fame and even, I have to say it, to reap economic and political profits," he said.
Mexico's embrace of the global economy has forced it to be flexible on trade issues with the United States, on whose economic fortunes Mexico now depends more than ever. It has begun to observe international standards in human rights, another area that was once considered off-limits to foreign pressure.
But no issue has been as open to direct influence by international groups as environmental protection.
In this case, of course, the environmentalists had one ally whose charisma was irresistible: gray whales are among the most amiable of nature's creatures. Although they are more than 40 feet long, they oblige whale-watchers by raising their snouts very gently to be kissed.
Environmentalists quietly conceded that the threat to the whales might not be as great as the protest propaganda suggested. But Mr. Zedillo and Mitsubishi finally acknowledged that the enormous industrial plant could alter and befoul the pristine ecosystem of the lagoon and its desert surroundings in ways that no amount of human science could foretell or repair.
Mexico's success in international trade probably contributed to its willingness to step back from the $100 million investment and 200 jobs the salt plant promised. Mexican officials long contended that scrapping the project might discourage other investors, but it became clear that not even Mitsubishi would change its view of Mexico as a promising market.
No one was as surprised at the reversal as Homero Aridjis, the Mexican writer and conservationist who began the drive to stop the salt plant five years ago from the living room of his Mexico City home. Today he is at the center of a powerful international network. "It was a victory of nature over commerce," Mr. Aridjis said simply.

HEADLINE: Kuwait Hints At an Increase In Oil Output

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: KUWAIT, March 4

 BODY:
Kuwait gave its first official hint today that it might accept a formula to raise the oil supply after its oil minister welcomed the outcome of talks among three major exporters.
The oil minister, Sheik Saud Nasser al-Sabah, said in a statement that talks among Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico this week were a step in the right direction "to safeguard oil market stability, guarantee supplies to consuming nations and avoid price fluctuations which harm all countries and global economic growth." 
 Saudi Arabia and Venezuela are members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Mexico is not.
The three oil ministers said after talks in London on Thursday that additional supplies were needed, but they did not say when producers would raise output or by how much.
Oil prices rose to a nine-year high on Friday after the assurances of extra production failed to calm worries over an increasingly tight gasoline market in the United States.
Sheik Saud, who had strongly supported extending an agreement to cut global oil output beyond its expiration when OPEC meets later this month, said Kuwait "seeks and supports any inclinations that lead to stabilizing prices in a fashion which serves the common interests of oil producing and consuming states."
Kuwait, which sits on 10 percent of the world's oil, is producing 1.837 million barrels of crude oil a day under the current agreement.
Bill Richardson, the United States energy secretary, said on Friday that he planned to meet Sheik Saud next week.
Mr. Richardson visited Kuwait last month to lobby for higher oil output to ease the rise in prices in the United States, the world's biggest oil consuming nation, before the summer driving season, when gasoline demand peaks.
Sheik Saud said in his statement today that oil prices had fallen over the last two years to below $10 a barrel and that this had had a grave impact on the economies of oil exporters. Kuwaiti crudes are currently selling for over $27 a barrel.
