HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Dips on Caution as Officials Talk of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices moved lower yesterday after three of the nation's financial leaders said higher interest rates were needed to cool the economy.
In addition to the cautionary comments, which were made by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; Lawrence H. Summers, secretary of the Treasury; and Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, last week's big run-up in stock prices provided additional incentive to take some profits out of equities. 
 "It's as if Greenspan wrote the speech for all of them," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "As the day wore on and the headlines of what they were saying hit the tape, the market went down." The three officials addressed a conference held at Boston College.
By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 196.70, or 1.9 percent, to 10,170.50. I.B.M., Microsoft, American Express and Wal-Mart led the decline.
On Friday, the Dow gained more than 200 points after the February employment data suggested that the economy might be starting to cool.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 17.89, or 1.3 percent, to 1,391.28, pushed lower by large declines in Exxon Mobil, Bristol-Myers Squibb and 3Com.
Technology stocks bucked the trend for much of the session, but late in the day the Nasdaq composite index began to sag and closed lower. The Nasdaq finished at 4,904.85, down 9.94, or 0.2 percent. At one point during the day it was up by as much as 65 points. Trading was brisk.
On the New York Stock Exchange, volume was 1.03 billion shares. On the Nasdaq stock market, 1.9 billion shares changed hands.
Stock investors have been worried that instead of cooling the economy, a further series of interest rate increases by the Fed will cause the economy to lapse into a recession.
"That is the big question," said David L. Mead, the chief investment officer at Harris Bank in Chicago. "I think they will be able to avoid a hard landing, simply because they have done it before."
Mr. Mead said the prospect of further increases in interest rates had not caused him to change his investment strategy.
"If we were to make a change, we would shift money out of large-cap sectors and into small and midcap stocks," he said.
A number of bellwether technology companies had a tough day.
Microsoft was one of them. The stock fell 5 1/2, to 90 5/8. Intel dropped 1 7/16, to 117 3/8. And Cisco Systems shed 1 5/16, to 136 1/8.
Hewlett-Packard was one of only three Dow stocks to gain ground. The stock rose 7 1/8, to 145 3/4, after Agilent Technologies, which is 85 percent owned by Hewlett-Packard, announced a switching technology breakthrough. Agilent closed at 161, up 53.
Telephone equipment manufacturers had a good day.
Nortel gained 8 1/2, to 129. Lucent Technologies was up 2 1/16, to 73 3/8. And Motorola gained 5 5/16, to 180 5/8.
Biotechnology stocks, which have been among the market's leaders so far this year, turned in a mixed performance.
Amgen fell 1 3/4, to 64 9/16. Genentech was off 19, to 215 1/2. But Immunex rose 3 11/16, to 248 1/8.
Williams-Sonoma fell 11 15/16, to 18 15/16, after the seller of kitchen equipment said it expected earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 30 might be below Wall Street estimates.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Drop
 By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell on speculation that the Federal Reserve would stay its course of raising interest rates, with few signs the economy is slowing to a pace that would not foster faster inflation.
"A rate increase later this month is in the bag, and we're expecting at least two more after that because another 25 basis points is not going to slow this wonderful economy," said Mark Macqueen, who invests $750 million at Sage Advisory Services Ltd. in Austin, Tex. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 101 16/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.14 percent from 6.13 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Ikea Wants to Move In, but Neighbors Fight Moving Out

BYLINE: By DEBRA WEST 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 6

 BODY:
When Albert L. Jones lost half his backyard to the New England Thruway, he was not happy, but he understood that his sacrifice was for the public good. He took the money the state gave him, put a new roof on his house, paid down his mortgage and learned to live with the noise.
Forty-odd years later, there is another threat to Mr. Jones's home and neighborhood here. Only this time, Mr. Jones is not quite so accommodating. 
 Nor is he alone. Instead, he finds himself in the midst of a battle raising questions far behind his endangered City Park neighborhood.
The fight to save his neighborhood from a proposed Ikea furniture megastore has become a drawn-out battle royal even by the standards of Westchester County, where antidevelopment jousting seems like part of the fabric of daily life.
But it is also raising two questions that go beyond the immediate dispute.
The first is: at a time of increasing development pressures, how aggressive should cities be in using eminent domain to push through developments?
The second is: as land and housing costs continue to soar, can uprooted people expect to find any place in the county they can afford?
Ikea, the Swedish assemble-it-yourself furniture store, wants 16 acres of this neighborhood off Interstate 95 to build a 280,000-square-foot store with a 1,300-space parking lot. Forget that City Park is a neighborhood with 34 homes and 160 residents, 29 businesses employing more than 400 workers, and two churches; Ikea wants the land, and the city has already taken steps to help the company get it.
Officially, city leaders say they are reserving judgment on the project until environmental studies are completed in May. But the lure of Ikea is strong: the store estimates that it will bring this city of 70,000 people $2.5 million a year in sales tax revenue.
The City Council has already declared the City Park neighborhood blighted, the first legal action necessary to condemn it. Now property owners unwilling to sell to Ikea face the threat that the city can take their land as part of urban renewal.
"Why do I have to move for a furniture company coming in?" asked Mr. Jones, 79, a retired school custodian who has lived in City Park since he was 10. "I ask you, is that fair? This is my home. I don't think none of us old people down here could afford to go."
Ikea is trying to negotiate with the property owners. In fact, Michael McDonald, property manager for Ikea North America, says half the owners have indicated that they are willing to sell. If so, they are the silent half of the neighborhood, because the opposition to Ikea here is loud, and getting louder.
"We have used urban renewal many times in the past, and I don't remember there ever being an outcry like this one," said New Rochelle's mayor, Timothy C. Idoni. "It's not as if we are doing what they did in White Plains, going in and knocking out the whole downtown. We try to be very, very careful."
The opposition started when David P. Newmark, president of Vernon Devices, a tool manufacturer, founded the City Park Association to fight the proposed development. He recruited his neighbors, a collection of old-timers and business owners, to join him.
Then, neighbors from surrounding communities joined in, spurred by the prospect of Ikea traffic drawn from as far as 90 miles away clogging local streets.
"Some people first come to the issue because of traffic and pollution," said Scott Stefan, a Larchmont resident and an advertising art director, who founded Wrain, Westchester Residents Against Ikea Now, a group that claims to have 2,100 members. "But then when they find out that they are taking people's homes and businesses to make way for a store, they are incredulous. If you talk to 100 people, 99 of them will say, 'You can't do that in America.' "
Every Saturday and Sunday, members of Wrain knock on doors in New Rochelle to gather signatures against Ikea. Mr. Stefan said each of the seven City Council members would be given a petition against Ikea signed by hundreds or thousands of constituents.
If the petitions do not stop the project, a group of lawsuits will surely delay it. Already, officials of the neighboring Village of Larchmont and Town of Mamaroneck have suggested that they will sue New Rochelle over the threat of increased traffic if the project is approved. And Mamaroneck recently proposed a law to give the town veto power over development on its border.
In addition, Randolph Scott-McLaughlin, the director of the Social Justice Center at Pace University School of Law in White Plains, has his law students researching a new twist in civil rights law. Forcing the 160 residents to move from City Park, where the racial split is about 40 percent black and 60 percent white, would deprive them of their civil right to live in an integrated community, Mr. Scott-McLaughlin said.
"Given the fact that these people are elderly, on a fixed income and their homes are not worth all that much, where else can they go in Westchester that will replicate an integrated community?" Mr. Scott-McLaughlin asked. "I would suggest nowhere."
Ikea first came to New Rochelle in 1997 looking for a place with good highway access to build a store that would complement its highly successful stores in Elizabeth, N.J., and Hicksville on Long Island.
After turning down a few sites that were too small, the city suggested that Ikea consider City Park, Mayor Idoni said. He said the site had been considered for redevelopment since the 1960's.
At the center of the debate over City Park is the blight study that the city commissioned. The study was conducted by Ferrandino & Associates, a planning firm in Elmsford, and Ikea reimbursed the city for its $35,000 cost.
The study found that of the 66 buildings, 84.9 percent were in good or fair condition and only 15.1 percent were in poor or deteriorated condition. Of the 79 tax lots, 51.3 percent were poor or deteriorated, and 49.7 percent were good or fair.
Despite those numbers, the neighborhood was found to be blighted and thus appropriate for bulldozing.
Elliot D. Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University who lives in Larchmont, said that the neighborhood was deemed blighted not because of the conditions of the houses and businesses there, but because it is such a hodgepodge of homes, factories, parking lots and vacant space.
"The study said that mixed use is evidence of blight," Dr. Sclar said. "But that is a very old-fashioned concept. The hottest neighborhoods in Manhattan are the ones that have businesses and residences together."
And Mr. Newmark said the city helped cause the decline, by never repairing its streets, putting in sidewalks or lobbying to have sound barriers installed along I-95.
Mayor Idoni said that eminent domain laws, which allow government to seize private property to benefit the greater public good, have helped New Rochelle, and many older cities, reshape their downtowns.
In the 1960's, a significant chunk of downtown New Rochelle was declared an urban renewal district to make way for the New Rochelle Mall, which closed in 1992 and sat empty until New Roc City, an entertainment and retail complex, opened on the site last fall.
In 1988, the city declared 24 acres around its train station blighted and dispersed hundreds of people who lived and worked there to make way for a condominium project that later fell through, leaving the area empty for a decade.
Mr. McDonald of Ikea said the store was being attentive to the financial needs of residents. "We are trying to put together a plan to address their financial concerns," he said.
Not everyone in the neighborhood opposes Ikea.
"Things have been pretty tough for me," said Minnie R. Burrell, 55, a widow who has had a hard time making payments on her house since her sister-in-law moved out some months ago. "I would like to get out as soon as I can. I hope Ikea will give me what I would like."
But many others say that their lives have been impeded.
Gregory Sands owns Ortho-Rite, a factory that makes orthotic shoe inserts and employs about 25 people. He has rented a building on Plain Avenue for seven years and is waiting to buy a neighboring building, if the neighborhood survives.
Dominick Gataletto, 77, has lived in his eight-room house on Pleasant Street since he was 2. He has thought about moving several times, first when I-95 was being built and again after zoning changes allowed businesses to move in next to homes. But he does not want to leave now.
"So I've got factories around me and I've got industry around me, but I'm comfortable here," said Mr. Gataletto, a retired postman. "I've got the house fixed just the way I want it. It would be very difficult for me to find what I've got here."
And that is the problem.
If someone wanted to buy Mr. Jones a $500,000 house and pay its taxes, he would move. But he does not expect his little house on the highway to fetch that much.
"I say let us stay here and retire," Mr. Jones said. "How can they walk by and look at the house and say it's blight? I have my roses. I keep my grass short. How could they come in and take this land when we were practically born here? I'm sure they could find something else."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Warns Again On Rates, and Stocks Fall
Just in case investors had chosen not to heed his previous warnings, Alan Greenspan gave them a reminder that the Federal Reserve intended to raise interest rates until it was sure it had squeezed any inflationary imbalances out of the economy.
In a speech at Boston College, Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, repeated his message that the wealth being created in the stock market is creating more demand than the economy can satisfy. Page C2. 

Investors took notice. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 196.70 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,170.50; the Nasdaq composite index declined 9.94 points, to 4,904.85; and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 17.89 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,391.28. C14.
 
Lawmakers Seek Tax Shelter Inquiry
Members of Congress from both parties called for an investigation into a tax shelter that makes it possible for American insurance companies to stop paying income taxes by moving their headquarters to Bermuda. C4.
 
Qwest Is Daunted by Its Own Deal
If Qwest Communications International had not agreed to acquire U S West, Qwest probably would have announced a deal to be acquired by Deutsche Telekom of Germany by now, and at a healthy premium to its stock price of $57.25 a share. For Qwest's top executives, that has to hurt. Not only have they failed so far to grasp a highly lucrative opportunity, but more important, the hurdles standing in their way are strictly of their own making. Market Place. C16.
 
Rubin Making $15 Million a Year
Former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will be paid more than $15 million -- not including options for 1.5 million shares of stock -- this year as an executive at Citigroup, according to a filing with the S.E.C. C2.
 
Music Industry Sees a New Threat
The music industry was already disturbed about how easy it is to copy music online without paying for it. But in recent months an online service called Napster has greatly magnified the threat by making it easier to find and copy music. Last month, the Recording Industry Association of America sued Napster, seeking damages and an injunction that would effectively end the service. A1.
 
Labor Faces a Test in Boeing Strike
The strike against Boeing by the union that represents engineers and technical workers has mushroomed into one of the largest strikes by white-collar workers against a private company in years. For national labor leaders, the walkout is clearly seen as a major test of their ability to organize a potentially large segment of the work force: professional workers. A1.
 
Hip Forefather Backs Dollar Coin
A wry, sly version of George Washington -- portrayed in contemporary pursuits from dining on Chinese takeout to surfing to riding the subway -- is the focus of an atypically offbeat campaign from the federal government, promoting use of the new dollar coin. The goal is to help prevent the new coin from suffering the same fate as its predecessor, the Susan B. Anthony dollar. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C13.

HEADLINE: Boeing's Brains Develop Brawn On Picket Line

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: TUKWILA, Wash., March 6

 BODY:
The chants and placards along the picket lines outside the Boeing Company's jet plants are a bit unusual. "No nerds, no birds," proclaims one sign. And many Boeing engineers, most on strike for the first time in their lives, say they are stunned at how unified their group has become in the face of its dispute with the giant aircraft manufacturer.
"Normally, if you get six engineers in a room, you'll get 12 different opinions," explained Steve Love, a 45-year-old flight test engineer who was warming his hands over a burning barrel on the picket line here the other day. "Well, Boeing has somehow managed to get 19,000 of us together with one thought and one goal, and that's a better contract." 
 Now nearing its fifth week, the increasingly bitter protest here by the Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace has mushroomed into one of the largest strikes by white-collar workers against a private company in years. It is an unexpectedly fierce action by a group long considered a union in name only, whose sole act of defiance in its 56-year history was a one-day walkout in 1992.
For the company, which has clearly stirred up deep resentment among the engineers by failing to offer 10 percent cash signing bonuses and other terms of a contract it reached last summer with its larger machinists' union, the strike is posing growing problems. Boeing recently announced, for instance, that the strike had already delayed 15 of 42 commercial jet deliveries planned for February, and such delays are likely to worsen if a settlement is not reached soon, since many of the striking engineers are needed under federal law to certify new airplanes as flightworthy.
But for national labor leaders, who have rushed in to help the strikers, the walkout is seen as a major test of their ability to organize a potentially large segment of the work force: professional workers, like many of the engineers here, who complain of both relentless pressure in the workplace and salaries that they feel do not reflect their contributions to the booming national economy.
Labor has already scored once-unthinkable successes in organizing doctors, especially in California and Florida, who are especially angry at the intrusions of insurance companies on their salaries and relationships with patients. It is making determined efforts, with somewhat less success so far, to organize the high-tech workers who are a huge part of the economy here in the Seattle area and in Silicon Valley. And because the high-profile battle the engineers are waging here is likely to resonate far beyond the corridors of Boeing, organized labor is manning the ramparts in a bid to help them win.
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., with which the engineers' union voted to affiliate a few months ago, visited the picket lines last week, and the federation's secretary-treasurer, Richard Trumka, the former head of the United Mine Workers, is due in town Tuesday. Both have promised money and help to the striking union, and Mr. Sweeney said the Boeing strike was an excellent example of how disgruntled white-collar workers could rally to press for better contracts and health benefits.
"This is a whole area of the new economy that organized labor would very much like to be involved in," said Harley Shaiken, a labor specialist at the University of California at Berkeley. "For many white-collar workers, there's just a volatile combination of feelings that they are underappreciated and not sharing fully in the benefits of this supposedly booming economy. This strike underscores what we've seen with doctors, teachers, now engineers -- there are many professionals who are feeling that they are the proletariat of the information age."
Even if the engineers prevail here and get a better contract, it remains to be seen, of course, whether organized labor can ever forge a broad-based coalition between professionals and the lower-wage workers it also continues to try to organize with major campaigns like the Justice for Janitors movement.
"These are different pressures and issues we're talking about," said Harry Katz, a professor in the school of industrial relations at Cornell University. "There are bound to be tensions between these kinds of workers and lower-wage earners. It's not at all clear that they have a lot of interests in common."
For now, though, here in the Seattle area, there is no question that the "brains behind the planes," as the engineers are sometimes called, are marching in the picket lines, and that truckers and other union workers who drive by here constantly blow their horns in support. (Some drivers making deliveries have declined to cross the picket lines; the machinists and other Boeing unions are contractually prohibited from stopping work in support of another union's strike at the company.)
Indeed, many Boeing engineers, who typically hold advanced degrees and whose salaries range from $37,000 to $128,000, express frustration at having to haggle over contract terms in a region where it seems like so many other smart, ambitious people are becoming dot-com millionaires. Many also expressed bitterness over the huge bonuses received by top corporate executives, including those at Boeing.
But an even more immediate factor in this strike seems to be the engineers' perception that the company is trying to play hardball with them while, the engineers say, it basically gave in with its settlement with the machinists' union. The company reached a deal with the machinists last summer as it was eager to achieve labor peace in the face of a huge backlog of orders; many analysts described the pact as extremely generous, and labor leaders described it as a major victory.
That pact, which headed off what would have been the third walkout by the machinists in the last 10 years, was approved overwhelmingly by the 44,000-member union. It raised hourly wages by nearly 16 percent over three years, and contained a one-time bonus averaging $4,400 per worker.
Details of the contract are labyrinthine, but the company essentially describes its offer as equally generous compared with what machinists received, and the engineers describe it as a step backward that nearly wipes out salary gains with new health-care fees.
In any event, it is undeniable that the engineers are incensed. Charles Bofferding, the union's executive director, likened Boeing's management to the schoolyard bully who declined to pick a fight with the class jock -- in this case, the machinists, the largest union at Boeing -- "and instead they see the little kid in the corner with the glasses and they say, 'Here, let's slap him around a little bit."'
"Well, guess what?" said Mr. Bofferding in an interview. "But what they don't realize is, the kid with the glasses has been taking kung fu. So watch out."
The union represents a broad array of engineers and technical workers with varying levels of training, though these workers are not required to join the union. The engineers' salaries average about $63,000; technical workers pay ranges from $21,000 a year to $81,000, with an average of $45,000.
Since contract negotiations began in October, more than 3,000 eligible workers have joined the union; while less than half of those eligible to join had done so last year, the figure now is nearly two-thirds -- 13,329 out of 20,683 workers in the "bargaining unit" are represented by the union. And even some of those who do not belong to the union are out on the picket lines. The union says 19,000 of the workers in the bargaining unit are out on strike; Boeing estimates that the number is about 17,000.
A Boeing spokesman, Peter Conte, said the company had made several generous offers to the union. Over the weekend, the company announced that it would try to impose the terms of its last contract offer on the engineers, a bid to force them back to work that the union insisted would not shake its resolve.
Many of the engineers say they have never even supported unions, and as one put it: "All that brotherhood and sisterhood propaganda kind of made me sick."
But that is changing. Jim Davis, a 64-year-old maintenance programs engineer who spent 27 years in the Navy and then the last 15 at Boeing, decided earlier this year to join the engineers' union.
"I've really been pretty much an anti-union person," said Mr. Davis, who has advanced degrees in aeroengineering and systems management. "I never, ever thought I'd see the day that I went out on strike. I still can't quite believe I'm out here on a picket line. But Boeing pushed me over the edge. I think they've been unreasonable and unresponsive to some truly unhappy engineers and technical workers."
Bill Sandell, a 34-year-old liaison engineer on the picket line, said he thought unions were for other kinds of workers, not engineers.
"I recognize their place for other people," he said. "But philosophically, I didn't want to be represented by a labor union. I wanted to be represented by my training, my experience and my abilities. I really thought that was my bargaining chip. But now, I feel like joining a union was really the only effective way to make my voice heard at this company."
Tom Claps, 37, a flight test engineer, said he was amazed to watch his fellow engineers, holding signs, chanting and throwing more wood in the blazing barrel to keep themselves warm.
"It takes a lot for a bunch of engineers to get up and walk out the door," he said. "The rocket scientists are literally out on the streets here. It's kind of incredible."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Don't Punish Africa

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
There is a travesty brewing in Congress that, if allowed to continue, will be a source of shame for all Americans. It will certainly be an ugly stain on the U.S. labor movement, particularly the apparel union and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- a stain that will highlight all the unions' phony-baloney assertions in Seattle that they just want to improve worker rights around the world and help the poor.
This controversy has to do with a stalled trade bill called The African Growth and Opportunity Act. And the bottom line is this: At a time when Africa is ravaged by AIDS, at a time when 290 million Africans -- more than the entire population of the U.S. -- are living on a dollar a day, the main U.S. textile union, UNITE!; the main textile manufacturers' lobby, ATMI; and the lawmakers who bow to both of them are blocking a bill that would allow Africans to export clothing to America duty free -- instead of with the current 17 percent import tax. 
 Why the opposition? Because Africa might increase its share of U.S. textile and apparel imports from its current level of 0.8 percent! Shame on the people blocking this bill. Shame on them.
Some 85 percent of the garments sold in the U.S. today are already sewn abroad. Honduras, little Honduras, already exports seven times more textiles and apparel to the U.S. than all 48 nations of sub-Saharan Africa combined. With our minimum wages, we can't produce jeans that retail for $16 and we don't want to. North Carolina's textile industry has already become highly automated and has moved away from low-value goods to high-value, high-tech fabrics. Much of the unionized labor force sewing clothes in the U.S. is in large cities and comprises new immigrants, many not citizens, since most Americans don't want these jobs.
If Africa were given duty-free access to our market, sophisticated textile plants in North Carolina wouldn't move to Madagascar. China would be the big loser, because Africans have the same skills to knit cashmere sweaters cheaply as people in China, and if Africa were given a 17 percent import tax advantage in shipping to the U.S., manufacturers would move their production from low-wage China to low-wage Africa. Which is why a study by the U.S. International Trade Commission concluded that "the impact of quota removal for African imports on U.S. producers and U.S. workers would be negligible."
So why do the unions still oppose it? Sheer knee-jerk protectionism -- even though the bill has tough measures to protect against any surge in imports from Africa, and restricts free-trade status to African countries moving toward democracy, economic reform and real worker protection.
No matter. Right now the only version of the bill the textile makers would permit is one that says Africa can only import duty-free into the U.S. if it first buys all the fabric, thread and yarn from U.S. factories, then ships it to Africa to be sewn, and then ships it back to the U.S. to be sold -- a costly obstacle course that would prevent any new investment in African factories. The real motto of U.S. trade unions is: We're for more worker standards in Africa, not more work.
This is really bad. This bill isn't a panacea for Africa, but it's important. Throughout the history of industrialization, poor countries have started down the road of development by sewing clothes. It's the one thing that poor people can do right away. It's critical that this bill go through now because by 2005 all the quotas on textile imports into the U.S. will expire. It will be a free-for-all. Right now investors are deciding where to locate plants for 2005 -- whether to stick with China or branch out to Africa, Vietnam or Mexico. If Africa is shut out from these investment decisions, it will fall even further behind.
The Clintonites talk the talk of Africa and AIDS, but, sadly, they have been afraid to get tough with the unions on this textile issue. Why is AIDS spreading so quickly among young women in Africa? One reason is that women have so few jobs they have to sell themselves to men with AIDS. Apparel jobs largely employ women. They make a difference.
But this is of no interest to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. crowd. All they care about is that Africa not sell more than 0.8 percent of garments here. Shame on them for what they are doing, and shame on us if we let them. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ELECTORATE;
As a Region's Economy Booms, So Does Interest in the Race

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: COVINGTON, Ga., March 1

 BODY:
In the old orange cotton fields of Newton County's past, bright automated factories now turn out an unending stream of Honey Nut Cheerios and flawless polyester sheeting. And with each truck that heads out from here on Interstate 20, the transformed local economy also produces what might be called the opposite of complacency, an engagement with the world of prosperity and politics that has surprised even those who planned for this growth.
Here in north central Georgia, Newton County and its neighbors are practically reverberating with the economic success that has enveloped the once rural region. With the unemployment rate below 3 percent, good jobs are piling up in the classified ads. There are no longer any vacant stores facing the historic town square, which served for years as the backdrop to the television series "In the Heat of the Night." 
 And suddenly, national politics does not seem to be so distant an exercise. People with health benefits and retirement portfolios talk about the presidential race as if they were company shareholders examining a slate of directors, thoughtfully dissecting the candidates and their inner lives. When talk at restaurants around the square turns to the presidential primary on Tuesday, there is a sense of absorption in people's voices, as if they know these candidates well, and as if the knowledge matters.
"I've been listening to Bush during this campaign, and it's like he's becoming stronger because he had to figure out McCain," said Dan Corder, a builder of subdivision homes, who was sitting in Smiley's Restaurant on the square. "I think he's learned something about the country from this campaign. Maybe he's figured out that we don't want the old party politics anymore."
Crystal Butler, who works at Bell's Discount Groceries west of town, is delighted with the county's growth and the number of her friends who are no longer unemployed, and plans to thank Vice President Al Gore with her vote on Tuesday.
"I like the way he tells people what he's going to do on education and the economy," she said. "He comes across like he really means it. And he doesn't spend all his time chopping on people, like the Republicans do."
If previous election campaigns seemed to people here a blur of headlines and angry demands, this year's is more like an interesting but leisurely novel. The plot, played out by wildly contrasting characters, is one of national prosperity, and the people of Newton County have a big stake in its outcome. Like many voters in earlier primary states, those here say economic growth is a chief issue driving them to the polls on Tuesday.
Michael Hinkle, a mechanical maintenance supervisor at the huge new Korean-owned SKC factory, which makes enormous rolls of high-quality plastic film, said he too was planning to vote for Gov. George W. Bush, but was enjoying the competition from Senator John McCain, which has produced high turnouts in several primary states.
"I'm a Bush person, but I'm sure curious about McCain," said Mr. Hinkle, who moved here from central Alabama to take his high-tech job. "I want to do some research and find out what he stands for and why people are attracted to him."
There is not much doubt who will win in Georgia on Tuesday. Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore are enormously popular here, and none of the four major candidates have even bothered to campaign regularly in the state. But inevitability does not seem to have dimmed Newton County's interest in this election. No one here has seen a single political advertisement or shaken a candidate's hand, and yet voters are planning to show up at the polls, without making decisions in last-minute frustration. Republican officials are predicting a record turnout for the state, and the Democratic primary may draw large crowds as well.
"People are spending more time looking at the intangible things that they never got to before," said Denny Dobbs, an environmental engineer and former state legislator whose family has lived in the county for four generations. "They want truth, they want sincerity, but mostly they want to take the time to find someone who can give them a normal presidency. Someone who will do what they say and not disappoint them."
Newton County, in fact, is full of people who are in no mind to be disappointed. The county spent years at a comfortable distance from Atlanta's chaotic boom, hoping to nibble at growth while avoiding the strip malls and tract homes. The invasion could not be held off, but now the benefits of good times have also arrived here with full force.
Every week seems to bring another announcement of a new employer or subdivision taking advantage of the 45-minute drive to Atlanta's airport, Hartsfield International. When the SKC plant, where machine operators are paid between $14 and $22 an hour, expands to full size in seven or eight years, it will employ more than 1,000 people and, at $1.5 billion, amount to the largest industrial investment in the state's history.
Now that they have begun to taste the good life, many of the county's 59,000 people want to hear precisely what each candidate would do to keep it going. They want to know details of education planks and economic blueprints. People who work at SKC, or Michelin's tread-pressing factory, or Nisshinbo Automotive's brake-pad assembly plant, are far more interested in trade policy than they would have been a few years ago.
"It's really broadened people's horizons, and I don't think any of us fully anticipated that," said Samuel B. Hay III, chief executive of Main Street Bank, one of the largest retail banks here. "We've got a large Asian contingent here now, a French glass maker, people moving here from all over the world. There might be some political friction, but I think over all it's better for the community."
Like most rural Southern counties, Newton retains a large number of ardent Democrats, many of them the blacks who make up about 26 percent of the population and descendants of the liberal Methodists who founded the original Emory College, in the town of Oxford, just north of Covington. Many well-educated natives of the county who once assumed that they would have to leave to find a good job, like Michael Davis, the plant scheduler at SKC, now say they are thrilled to be able to work where they grew up.
But Newton's location about 50 miles east of downtown Atlanta has made it increasingly attractive too for a growing number of newcomers, many of them commuters who tend to settle in suburban developments on the western edge of the county and vote Republican.
As a result, Newton is fairly evenly split between Republicans and Democrats, and has been a swing county for several elections. In 1992, Bill Clinton won the county by just 7 votes, of 13,613 cast; he lost it to Bob Dole by 515 votes four years later. In 1998, Roy Barnes, a Democrat elected governor that year, lost the county to Guy Millner by just 73 votes. Many people suspect that the tiny but detectable trend toward a Republican majority may deepen as county incomes rise.
"The new people coming in are more conservative, more Republican, pushing things to the right," said one Democrat, Don Ballard, a lawyer who has long been politically active in the area and whose son, Tommy, is running as a Republican for chairman of the county commission. "I suspect that the county will go for Bush" in the general election, the elder Mr. Ballard said, "although we've got the economy as our ace in the hole."
It is clear, though, that fervent partisanship of either stripe does not appeal to most residents here, new or old. Considerable interest in Mr. McCain is expressed by many of the county's voters, including Democrats, who expect him to do well in a region where personality and policy now often outweigh party affiliation.
Covington's mayor, Sam Ramsey, who owns a large furniture store just off the square, is a longtime Democrat who occasionally finds himself voting Republican and has seen the tendency in others. The movement away from party loyalty, he says, is inevitable as income and education rise, but in no way reflects a disengagement from the political process.
"I think people enjoy making up their own minds, forming their own opinions about the candidates," he said amid the clutter of his busy store. "You might think that in a good economy people might not be as concerned, but in a smaller community like this, we don't see that. It's not the big city, where people think they're not important. Here they know they've got a role to play."

HEADLINE: Fire Races Through Stretch Of Shops in Heart of Mystic

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: MYSTIC, Conn., March 6

 BODY:
A fire destroyed a half-block stretch of shops early this morning in this historic maritime center, leaving a charred wreck in the center of Connecticut's most popular tourist destination. It was the fourth time since 1863 that fire has struck the same building on West Main Street, just steps from Mystic's famous drawbridge.
The building's eight storefront businesses were destroyed in the blaze, which began shortly after 12:30 a.m. and smoldered almost until dawn. The structural damage to the wood-frame building is so severe, officials said, that it will have to be condemned, which will leave a wide vacant lot at the core of a downtown commercial district that draws some two million visitors a year. 
 "It's a hole right in the heart of downtown Mystic," said Linnea Lindstrom, executive director of the Mystic Chamber of Commerce, which has called an emergency meeting on Wednesday night to help relocate the ruined businesses. "It's had quite an emotional impact. These stores have a lot of memories for a lot of people. The store owners are our neighbors and our friends."
The building, built on pylons over the Mystic River, has always been at the center of town life. For much of the 19th century, it was filled with stores, offices and a large public meeting space where traveling performers like Tom Thumb and speakers like Frederick Douglass and William Lloyd Garrison came to find an audience. The rear of the wrecked building overlooks historic Mystic Seaport and its collection of tall ships, schooners and whaling boats. The building is three blocks east of Mystic Pizza, which became famous by lending its name to the 1988 movie featuring Julia Roberts. Firefighters were able to stop the fire from spreading to adjacent buildings, and no one was hurt.
The ruined stores, at 10-22 West Main Street, were exactly the type of quirky, independent shops that tourists adore poking around on summer afternoons, including Trade Winds, a gallery of antique maps and nautical prints; Dexter's handcrafted jewelry and pewterware; Radio Waves vintage music, and Pepper Grass & Tulip, which sold crafts and antiques.
"I'm unemployed for the first time in my life," said Tom Dexter, whose jewelry shop had been in the building for 22 years. "It's a disheartening feeling," he said, adding that he hoped to find temporary space and rebuild within six months.
Some of the business owners were away on vacation, residents said, taking a last break before spring and the onset of the heavy tourist season. Gov. John G. Rowland toured the fire scene this afternoon and promised that the state would assist in rebuilding. The owners of the building, Rufus Allyn and Roy N. Bohlander, did not have casualty insurance.
Mr. Allyn, whose family has owned the building for generations, said he could not estimate its worth. But Celeste and Judi Caracausa, sisters who run a real estate agency, said the building could have sold for $1.2 million to $1.5 million. "This part of downtown is like a little jewel," Judi Caracausa said.
Officials also said it was too soon to calculate the loss to each of the eight businesses. Few people in town were optimistic that a new building could be constructed in time for this year's high season. "Tourist season is going to be starting in a couple of weeks," said Tami Murray, who works in advertising for The Mystic River Press, the local weekly newspaper. "They are not going to be able to be open to get the majority of their revenue."
The Mystic fire chief, Fitz Hilbert, said an alarm was first received at 12:38 a.m. By the time firefighters reached the scene minutes later, he said, flames had already raced through a loft that ran the length of the wood-frame building, above all eight stores. Firefighters immediately set about breaking through the roof to let the flames escape, he said.
More than 100 firefighters from at least a half dozen surrounding towns joined in helping to suppress the blaze, Chief Hilbert said, and it was extinguished about 5 a.m. He said officials had not pinpointed a precise cause, but the fire did not appear to be suspicious. "There is no reason to believe at this time it's anything other than accidental," he said.
While the fire did not immediately draw huge crowds, the few people who saw it immediately pitched in to help. Christine Cooney-Breeding, the owner of a health food store across the street, stayed up most of the night providing firefighters with coffee. By morning staff members of the nearby Residence Inn arrived with more coffee, hot chocolate, instant soup, muffins and cookies.
Ms. Lindstrom, at the Chamber of Commerce, began contacting property owners with vacant retail space, including the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe, which owns the huge Foxwoods Casino as well as some vacant store properties on Holmes Street. "It was amazing to see all of the owners of the buildings taking care of each other," Ms. Scarpa said.

HEADLINE: China Army Renews Threat Against Taiwan Separatism

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 6

 BODY:
In one of the most forceful statements yet on Taiwan, the Chinese military said today that it would "spare no effort in a blood-soaked battle" to protect China's territorial integrity and that China would not be tricked into negotiations with Taiwan leaders who secretly opposed rejoining the motherland.
While it did not mention by name any candidates in Taiwan's presidential election on March 18, the warning, in an editorial of the Liberation Army Daily, seemed to be aimed at Chen Shui-bian, the candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. 
 For years Mr. Chen and his party campaigned for Taiwan's formal independence from China, which considers the island an integral part of the nation that was separated by civil war.
Mr. Chen has recently moderated that position, saying a formal declaration would not be necessary because Taiwan already enjoys de facto independence. He promises that if elected, he will seek deeper economic ties and peace talks with the mainland.
But in language clearly intended to describe Mr. Chen, the editorial said Taiwan leaders who "consistently pushed for independence" had used "sweet-sounding rhetoric to bluff that they want to have 'benevolent harmony, positive cooperation and lasting peace' with the mainland -- all to swindle the Taiwan populace."
"We must on no account be dazzled by the pretty phrases," the editorial said.
The editorial from the military's official mouthpiece was reprinted in People's Daily and other newspapers, indicating that the views had been approved at the highest levels of the Communist Party. And the government also signaled its resolution when the Finance Minister, Xiang Huaicheng, announced a 12.7 percent rise in military spending for this year.
While Mr. Chen appeared to be the subject of the editorial, neither of Taiwan's other leading candidates has unambiguously accepted what China calls an unshakable precondition for talks: that Taiwan is legally part of a Beijing-centered "One China."
Some creative compromises in language will be needed if the hopes in Taipei and Beijing for renewed dialogue later this year, with a new president of Taiwan, are to be realized.
The military editorial was part of an orchestrated barrage of warnings from senior leaders here as Taiwan's election approaches, the American Congress debates a proposal for closer military ties with the island and the Clinton administration weighs Taiwan's request for advanced weapons.
It will be many years before China has the military capacity to mount a blockade of Taiwan, let alone invade it, foreign analysts say. But the Chinese leaders have clearly decided that they must put pressure on the island now to halt a slide toward independence.
In a policy statement on Feb. 21 that created new worries in Taipei and Washington, China said more clearly than before that Taiwan's indefinite foot-dragging in negotiations could set off an attack, a threat previously made against an outright declaration of independence. But the report stressed China's desire for a peaceful settlement and its willingness to grant Taiwan extraordinary autonomy.
That report gave no deadline for talks, and none of the subsequent statements indicate changes in the carrot-and-stick policy it outlined. But the recent pronouncements have stressed China's desire to secure the return of Taiwan "at an early date."
On Sunday, while expressing hopes for a peaceful settlement, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, who is considered a moderate on the issue, said China "will not sit idly by and watch any serious separatist activity."
Sunday's newspapers featured a speech by President Jiang Zemin in which he restated China's preference for negotiations but also the threat of "drastic measures" if Taiwan delays indefinitely.
In a speech to legislators on Sunday, Gen. Zhang Wannian, a top military leader, said, "The two sides of the strait cannot remain perpetually divided," and "Taiwanese independence means war."
In Taiwan the three major presidential candidates have all described themselves as peacemakers, promising to encourage economic ties and engage in talks with the mainland.
At the same time, none have disowned President Lee Teng-hui's assertion that Taiwan's dealings with the mainland should be conducted on a state-to-state basis. Mr. Lee's stance has been popular, and it appears to be politically impossible for any candidate to backtrack too far.
On Sunday, Vice President Lien Chan, the candidate of the governing Nationalist Party, warned voters that it would be reckless to elect Mr. Chen, because of his "independence platform."
But Mr. Lien also said, "The so-called state-to-state relationship is the constant policy of my country and my government," repeating the phrase that outraged Beijing when Mr. Lee first used it last summer.

HEADLINE: Behind China's Threats

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, March 6

 BODY:
China's renewed threat of war against Taiwan has caused anxiety in the West, but Beijing's military options for attacking the island remain limited and impractical, a fact often overlooked in the furor in Washington.
Though China's Army outnumbers Taiwan's six to one, the country lacks a transport fleet large enough to ferry a major invasion force across the Taiwan Strait. And even if it could muster the ships, China does not have the means to secure control of the sea or air separating it from the island to carry out such a deployment. 
 "There's no way at this moment that Beijing has the weapons in its arsenal in sufficient numbers to undertake and sustain a major, full-scale assault on Taiwan," says Jonathan Pollack, a China specialist at the Rand Corporation in California.
China does have nuclear weapons, but using them against avowed compatriots in Taiwan is highly unlikely. Most Western military experts say it will be years, if not decades, before the mainland mounts a credible threat.
Beijing's vow to use force, made in a policy paper last month at the start of Taiwan's presidential election campaign and repeated in an editorial in a military newspaper today, is meant to warn the island away from formal independence and push it toward serious negotiations on reunification with the mainland. Beijing still regards Taiwan as its territory, occupied by the Nationalist authorities who fled there during China's civil war in the 1940's.
But forcing the island to the table is a delicate game; were Taiwan to survive a misguided mainland military campaign, it would probably declare independence and win widespread diplomatic support abroad.
Beijing does have alternatives to an invasion, though none of them seem likely.
The option that experts in Taiwan and the West take most seriously, because it is the one most available to China today, would be a short, Kosovo-like missile campaign intended to devastate Taiwan's economy -- either by direct strikes on sites in Taiwan, or by disrupting shipping lanes. China has hundreds of short-range ballistic missiles pointed at the island.
Supplemented with information warfare -- using computer viruses and electromagnetic pulses to knock out Taiwan's communications and transportation, for instance -- and perhaps sabotage by Beijing's agents on the island, incoming missiles could demoralize Taiwan's people and undermine support for Taipei from the island's business elite. Many in that group have investments on both sides of the strait and might prefer political compromise to economic ruin.
"If it didn't work, Beijing may not be greatly harmed by great loss of forces, as may be the case with other options," said Eric McVadon, a retired United States Navy rear admiral and a former defense attache in Beijing. He says this is the possibility that most worries him.
But the domestic risks if such a strategy failed would be dire. Mr. McVadon added that such a dramatically belligerent act could isolate China diplomatically and halt most exports to the United States and other major markets.
Foreign investment might dry up, as it did in the year after Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square in 1989. China's economic engine, still dependent on export revenue and foreign investment inflows to keep its people employed, would probably sputter and slow to a crawl.
China's economy is already at low ebb and so in some ways more fragile than in 1989. The country has spent billions of dollars to prop up slowing economic growth in the last two years and cannot afford to do so indefinitely.
Unemployment is as high as 30 percent in some parts of the industrial northeast, and the economic shock that would follow military action against Taiwan would worsen conditions for many already disgruntled people. If an action against Taiwan failed, Beijing could face a groundswell of domestic opposition.
"A defeat would mean the end of the regime," said a Hong Kong-based economist who asked not to be identified. "The risk to the party is far more than just more economic stress."
Such a brutal approach, meanwhile, would cast China as an international pariah and reverse decades of diplomatic confidence building. Beijing is still stinging from the international condemnation that followed the killings of protesters near Tiananmen Square.
The trade concessions it has offered to join the World Trade Organization are, in part, an attempt to erase that legacy. The deal is contingent upon Congress ending its annual review of China's trade status, an exercise put in place after the Tiananmen crackdown.
And China would not win much of a prize if it did cripple Taiwan's economy. It would jeopardize a major source of investment -- Taiwan has invested more than $30 billion in the mainland -- and would destroy what little good will it has on the island.
In any case, China is years from being able to "take" Taiwan.
Any large-scale attempt to cross the strait would be obvious for weeks ahead of time as China massed men and equipment on its shores. And once at sea, such a force would be sitting ducks for Taiwan's Air Force or even two submarines positioned at either end of the strait.
China's chief problem is air cover: It has far more planes than Taiwan, but most are out-of-date blowflies compared with Taiwan's jets. The 72 SU-27 fighters that China has bought from Russia could outmaneuver Taiwan's aging F-5's, but probably not the island's 150 F-16's, 60 French Mirage 2000's or air defenses, which include advanced Patriot missiles.
Equally daunting are the many ground and airborne radar systems that the United States has supplied to Taiwan to coordinate air and sea assaults.
China lacks the technology in its offensive forces to cope with those defenses, military experts say, though it is trying to acquire such technology from Russia and Israel.
China does have air defense missiles, but they lack the range and ability to effectively clear the strait's skies long enough to permit safe movement of an invasion force.
The best China could hope for would be to disable Taiwan's Air Force by pounding its airfields and communications centers with short-range ballistic missiles and then land enough men to take an airport or other strategic installation, giving them a base to build on.
But the chances that such an isolated invasion force could survive would be slim, while the chances that those soldiers would end up as prisoners and bargaining chips for Taipei is high enough to argue against that course of action.
China could seize one or two of Taiwan's outlying islands; Jinmen and Matsu lie just a few miles off the mainland's coast. But those islands are heavily fortified with thousands of Taiwanese troops, and so the cost of taking them would likely be high and the gain slim.
Or Beijing could attempt a naval blockade, hoping to bring Taiwan to heel.
China's Navy has enough ships to enforce a quarantine. And the island's economy is almost entirely dependent on trade, including imported oil. Taipei might buckle to domestic pressure and negotiate terms of reunification if its factories stopped running.
But coordinating such an action is far more complex than anything China's Navy has attempted before. And blockades are easier to circumvent than to sustain.
Worse, Taiwan might decide to fight rather than negotiate if backed into a corner; that could prove disastrous for Beijing because it is outgunned both at sea and in the air.
For now, China's most likely military action will be more war games and other training exercises in the coastal provinces facing Taiwan. China has mounted such maneuvers many times before, most recently in September. The size and threatening nature of those exercises could increase, but they are likely to remain games for now.
Meanwhile, China's is working to upgrade its arsenal. It is improving the accuracy and number of short-range ballistic missiles aimed at the island and is developing a land-attack cruise missile with accurate "terminal homing" -- in other words, a "smart" bomb.
Russia has agreed to supply China kits for 200 more SU-27 jet fighters, and Beijing reportedly will soon buy even more advanced SU-30's. And Israel is expected to supply China with an airborne warning and control system mounted on Russian IL-76 jets that could be used for battle management.
But the new weapons will not necessarily shift the balance of power in China's favor anytime soon. Taiwan will also continue to improve its arsenal and operational skills. And it will take years before China's military is proficient enough to use the high-tech weapons effectively.
"Troops equipped with weapons produced by various countries are virtually incapable of integrating them in modern, high-tech warfare," said Wang Weixin, a senior researcher at China's Military Academy.
Mr. Wang, quoted this week in China's armed forces paper, Liberation Daily, was talking about Taiwan's troops, but the judgment applies equally to those of his own country.

HEADLINE: LEGACY;
Child Raising 201: A Graduate Course for Grandmothers

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
MARTA FELIZ, a Dominican grandmother, has been practicing public speaking skills in front of the bathroom mirror and projects with such verve she could pass for Evita.
Her subject is a touchy one for a woman of her background: how to discuss sex with grandchildren. But she is well prepared after 12 classes at Fordham University for grandparents who are raising their grandchildren -- hours of role playing, written homework and a thick binder of information. 
 On this winter morning, Ms. Feliz is trying out her speech in front of her classmates, all recent graduates of the Fordham program, in New York City. Now that they have their diplomas, Ms. Feliz and the rest are expected to take their show on the road, sharing their newfound wisdom with other custodial grandmothers and lobbying civic leaders for the services such women need.
Ms. Feliz would have aced the course if grades had been given. In session 11, she learned how to rehearse for a public speaking engagement, refer to note cards, make eye contact, use wit to engage her audience and open the floor to questions at the end. She has that all down pat.
In session 5, she learned that when talking about "el sexo" with her grandchildren she is supposed to be matter of fact. "Talk the way you would talk about teeth or ears," the training manual says. "Use the right names -- vagina and penis." And so this is what she tells her audience of fellow grandmothers.
The women in the room giggle, girlishly. One, Maria Peralta, said that when she first discussed sexually transmitted diseases with her 13-year-old grandson, after learning how to talk about it in her class, he was so shocked by her vocabulary that he crossed himself.
The program, created and taught by Carole B. Cox, a professor of social work at Fordham, is an outgrowth of the support groups for custodial grandparents that began in the late 1980's and proliferated in the early 90's as more inner-city children lost their parents to drugs, AIDS, incarceration or violent death.
The grandmothers' support groups -- common these days at senior centers, churches, social-welfare agencies and some public schools -- are an antidote to the isolation, exhaustion and guilt these women experience, an oasis of empathy in lives shadowed by pain and loss.
The program is not a substitute for the support groups but rather an adjunct, an opportunity for a handpicked group of grandmothers to study the skills they need to raise their wounded grandchildren and then go into their communities and spread the word.
Dr. Cox first taught the program in 1998 to a class of 15 African-American grandmothers who were members of a support group at the Harlem Interfaith Counseling Center. One of their first outreach efforts after graduation was to visit a group for Hispanic grandmothers at Public School 5 in Washington Heights.
Those women were so hungry for information that they clamored for training of their own, in Spanish. With money from the New York Community Trust, Dr. Cox taught a second round with help from Carmen L. Valcarcel of the Children's Aid Society, who was running the Spanish-language support group at P.S. 5.
The curriculum is rigorous and the grandmothers are discouraged from using the sessions to gripe or vent, as they do in the support group. Each session is devoted to a topic -- communication, behavior problems, sex, grief, the social service system, legal issues, advocacy skills and more.
They learn the difference between discipline and punishment, between talking with a child and talking to a child. They learn to distinguish between transient behavioral and emotional problems and enduring problems that require professional help. They learn to soothe a grieving grandchild who has lost a parent when they, too, are grieving over the loss of a child. They learn to cope with an uncomprehending toddler or a recalcitrant teenager.
They learn to be persistent and assertive when dealing with the social service agencies that award, among other forms of financial aid, Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, Supplemental Social Security and food stamps. They learn what information to provide when dealing with a social worker, case manager or lawyer and how to conduct such meetings and follow up. They learn how to lobby elected leaders, prepare a brochure for distribution at a senior center and make a presentation urging other grandmothers to seek help.
"We want to empower them to cope with their own problems and help others as peer educators," said Dr. Cox, who is the editor of a new anthology of scholarship about custodial grandparents and is writing a paper about the different experience of African-American and Hispanic grandmothers.
Many Hispanic women, Dr. Cox and Ms. Valcarcel said, are hobbled by their unfamiliarity with English and the fact that they are raising children in a culture different from the one in which they matured themselves. They are also less powerful forces in their own families than African-American women are in black families and, as a result, are not accustomed to taking charge, Dr. Cox and Ms. Valcarcel said.
Often, the grandmothers are sharing child-raising duties with their sons or daughters, who work long hours and go to school. This is a less tragic situation than a grandchild orphaned or abandoned. But it means the grandmothers have responsibility without authority. And in cases where drugs, AIDS or prison have fractured a family, Hispanic women are less likely than African-American women to talk openly about what happened, even in a supportive setting.
"They never talk badly about their own children," said Ms. Valcarcel, who was born in Puerto Rico. "They would never share such things with anyone else."
Even those who break the mold and discuss such issues do so sparingly. Aida Marriott, a retired custodian, for instance, is raising two teenage granddaughters, Julie and Vanessa Avila. The girls' father, Mrs. Marriott said, died in 1988 of AIDS, after years of drug addiction and several turns in prison. Their mother, Mrs. Marriott's only child, died in 1993. Mrs. Marriott said her daughter was an addict and a victim of domestic violence who died of a stroke at age 28.
The 15 Hispanic women, who still meet every few weeks as they prepare to become ad hoc outreach workers, said that Dr. Cox's curriculum, which will be published soon as part of the Springer Series on Lifestyle and Issues on Aging, was a godsend. But more than the individual lessons, the women appreciated the opportunity to learn in a college setting.
EACH week of training they were bused from Washington Heights to the Manhattan campus of Fordham, near Lincoln Center. For most of them, sitting in a college classroom was a first. Their graduation was an elegant affair, with corsages and finger food. The women treasure the snapshots taken that day nearly as much as their diplomas.
Mrs. Marriott, 71, is one of the few to have attended college in their native country; in her case, Ecuador. Her economics degree hangs on the wall of the living room in her Yonkers apartment, displayed even more prominently than the many crucifixes. On an end table is a photograph in a silver frame of a beautiful young woman on the day of her graduation from the University of Guayaquil.
That diploma and her new one, she hopes, will inspire Julie, 15, and Vanessa, 13, whose rebellious behavior landed them in a group home two weeks last year, sent there by a Family Court judge who hoped to scare them into coming home at night.
The girls are sullen and uncommunicative, just how Dr. Cox's training manual says they are likely to be at this age. "It takes patience and caring to hang in there when a teenager is behaving badly and seems ungrateful," the manual says. Mrs. Marriott tries her best.
She sometimes succeeds in rousing them to respond in kind, as they did when she graduated from the Fordham program. That day, Julie and Vanessa cleaned the apartment and cooked a celebratory dinner. Then they admired Mrs. Marriott's latest diploma.
"She told us this is what we need to get in the future," Julie said. "We need to achieve stuff. And it doesn't matter what age you are, you can still succeed."

SECTION: Section H; Page 9; Column 1; Generations 

LENGTH: 1732 words

HEADLINE: IDENTITY;
Going Home With a Postmodern Medicine Man

BYLINE: By BILL DONAHUE; Bill Donahue, a correspondent for Outside magazine, has also written for The New York Times Magazine.

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
IN the muted light of the museum, beside a diorama of a traditional Wasco Indian wedding, Spider Moccasin shared a piece of the creation myth of his grandmother's people, the Wasco of the Pacific Northwest: "Coyote was swallowed by Itc!i'xyan, this shapeless terror of a monster. And. . . ."
Spider Moccasin is an antic storyteller. His hands carved the air and his eyes flashed. For a second I imagined we were outside, on the Warm Springs Indian Reservation in Oregon, beside a campfire, the sound of drums in the distance. (The monster's name, by the way, is pronounced IX-lit-i-can.) 
 "And then Coyote was trapped in Itc!i'
xyan's belly," he continued, "and he couldn't communicate, so he pulled out his laptop and. . . ."
Well, maybe it is better to think of the campfire as virtual, a sort of holographic flame leaping in a dark void as MTV blares in the background. Spider Moccasin has not lived with his tribe for the last 20 years. He lives in Portland, where he graduated from the Pacific Northwest College of Art in 1990 and now spends most of his time in his dingy, cubicle-size art studio. He calls himself a "postmodern medicine man."
A 34-year-old cartoonist and singer-songwriter whose given name is Marcus Moseley, he has spent the last decade furiously reinventing himself. Through his political art, he has tried to reconcile his tastes for Spiderman comics and the rock band Rage Against the Machine with the ghosts of his ancestral past.
He has written a book that has yet to be published, a 400-page novel about an urban Indian who finds himself by going home; produced an urban powwow that starred an American Indian poet; and played his Dylanesque protest folk music in Portland clubs. In January, he released his debut compact disc, "Spider Moccasin," which focuses on important issues confronting Northwest Indians, including the Army's plans to incinerate nerve gas on Umatilla Indian land. "Fifty years ago, I would have been beaten to shreds" for playing such songs, he said.
Mainstream culture has long been exacting about the way Indians should express their ethnicity. Early-20th-century Indian youths were forced to go to boarding schools, where federal officials lopped off their braids and beat them for speaking their own languages. More recently, films like "Dances With Wolves" have saddled Indians with another expectation. "We're all supposed to be pure, like Sitting Bull," Spider Moccasin said.
In reality, American Indian life has long been a blend of ancient traditions and pop culture flotsam. Now, young Indians are increasingly deciding that they can keep their culture alive by modernizing it. Off the coast of Washington State, for instance, a small group of young Makahs has revived a tribal tradition of whale hunting by giving it a new twist. As they ply the Pacific Ocean in their hand-carved canoe, they carry a .577-caliber elephant rifle. At powwows, where drumming has long been an almost exclusively male activity, the Mankillers, a California troupe consisting of Indian women, is beating its own rhythms. The group has released a compact disc, "The Mankillers."
Kate Jackson, an elder at the Warm Springs reservation, is wary of such gestures, arguing that "our culture's music is for the reservations, not for wannabes looking for a payout." Her disdain is held only by ardent traditionalists, though, and even mainstream America is recognizing the complexity of Indian identity.
More than ever, people want to hear the voices of contemporary Indians. In Boulder, Colo., the Four Winds Trading Company, a large distributor of American Indian music, reported that its sales increased roughly 40 percent in each of the last three years. Hollywood's first feature film written and directed by Indians, Sherman Alexie's and Chris Eyre's "Smoke Signals," was released in 1998 to favorable critical reaction. Mr. Alexie, a Spokane tribal member, has contracted with Miramax to shoot his second film, an adaptation of his novel, "Reservation Blues." The film focuses on a Catholic Indian rock band that subsists largely on "wish sandwiches" -- you wish something was between the bread.
SPIDER MOCCASIN'S diet would be similar if his dishwashing job did not provide free food. He earns $600 a month, and he sleeps on friends' couches. When he is staying nearby, we chat. Once he told me about his great-grandmother, Pistol Packin' Annie, whose gun scared federal officials who were trying to drag her children to boarding school.
Another time, he described how he had chosen his name. It was 1988 and he was "running away from being Indian," he said. He had few American Indian friends; all his comic-book sketches were of white superheroes. One night he tried suicide, ingesting sleeping pills. In his delirium, he recalled a "supernatural incident," a healing ceremony he witnessed on his great-aunt Zelma Smith's ranch when he was 12. A spider appeared. The person being treated, he said, "was struggling with the same thing I was, culture shock, and suddenly I came to think of that spider as representing the modern world." He realized that the spider was "just an issue that Indians have to contend with."
"I made myself throw up," he said. "I wanted to live."
The ranch is in Warm Springs, about 110 miles from Portland, and on a recent weekend we went to the reservation to visit the place he calls home.
With his friend Jamie Stewart, a Karuk Indian, we drove east in Mr. Stewart's battered pickup truck, through the suburbs and over snowy Mount Hood. Spider Moccasin was wearing a T-shirt depicting the 1928 Wasco Royal Court, and one princess on the shirt was his grandmother, Mildred Smith. Ms. Smith was a full-blooded Wasco, a tribe that once lived on the banks of the Columbia River and fished for salmon. In 1855, the government moved the Wascos 50 miles south to Warm Springs, where they were forced to live beside two rival tribes, the Paiute and the Warm Springs.
The three tribes rarely mingled. But in the mid-1930's, Spider Moccasin's grandmother married a Warm Springs man. Their seven children, Spider Moccasin boasted, "united the tribes for business in the 20th century." One went to Harvard Law School; another became a champion at fancy dancing, a powwow tradition. The most successful was Ken Smith, who spent nearly 20 years as the chief executive of Warm Springs' confederated tribes.
As we rolled down Mount Hood and onto the reservation's red, sage-speckled plains, his legacy was clear. We passed many buildings he had helped build: the museum, a health center, a tribal administration center. Then we stopped at his lavish home and went in.
Spider Moccasin had not seen Mr. Smith in six years and had not been to Warm Springs in more than a year. We made polite conversation, sipped tea and then left for Spider Moccasin's childhood home, a modest yellow clapboard ranch house. His parents divorced in 1976, and he lived at Warm Springs with his mother, Rosella Moseley, until 1980, when they moved to Beaverton, a Portland suburb, for its good public schools.
Ms. Moseley is an advocate for poor people; she became outspoken on Indian issues at age 20. "She was in a car accident going over Mount Shasta in California, and her eye was torn from her head," Spider Moccasin said. "They rushed her to the hospital, but they said, 'We don't take Indians,' so then they took her to the vet's. They got her some whiskey and tied her down and they took some sandpaper to her skin. They got the glass out of her face and pushed her eye back into the socket by hand."
The next day, at Indian Trails restaurant, we ran into a cousin of Spider Moccasin's, Darreck Palmer. Mr. Palmer, 18, is a singer for a hip-hop act called Native Mobb, and his tales of the reservation's other rap bands enthralled Spider Moccasin. We followed Mr. Palmer to a remote house that was essentially hip-hop central in Warm Springs.
Inside, were seven young men from the reservation in sagging slacks. A keyboard track thumped on the stereo, and each young man rose in turn to blast his own rhymes into a microphone.
"You may think I'm in a gang," cried Brian Renfro, 20, "but I'm all about dat Native Mobb thang." Gerald Tufti, 21, sang of "words that left me open, living the life my grandma'd been hopin'."
Last spring, there was a rift among the rappers that began with the bands Straight Savage and Native Mobb mocking each other's music and culminated with both spouting threatening lyrics.
More recently, death has brought unity. Just after dawn on a Saturday last summer, Lance Thomas, a member of Native Mobb, was killed with three friends when he crashed his Thunderbird into a truck on the highway south of Warm Springs.
FOR Mr. Thomas, the crash ended a tumultuous adolescence. Warm Springs has neither a middle school nor a high school, so he rode a bus to school in Madras, a rough cowboy town 15 miles away. Like many Warm Springs youths, he dropped out. Robert Medina, a onetime substitute parent for Mr. Thomas, said that the young man had spent his last months "unemployed, partying and mouthing off to police."
His friends gave voice to his anguish. "Every breath that I take," Mr. Tufti half-whispered, half-sang, "I'm getting nearer to my end."
Spider Moccasin felt the power of the words. "Who said Indian kids couldn't write?" he said. He flashed his hand at the rappers, pinkie up, gangster style, and then stepped to the mike to sing his own song. "Manifest Destiny forgotten!" he shouted. "Who writes the history books? Manifest Destiny forgotten! A lost century or two slipstream, lost culture, no one else to turn into!"
Everyone cheered and shouted.
Spider Moccasin gave the rappers a copy of his compact disc. "Bro'," Derek Greene, 18, said, "we're going to sample it!"
As we pulled onto the highway, it struck me that his music, too, was a kind of sampling. I said it borrowed from the hard experience as well as the daring of his forebears to make something new.
Spider Moccasin disagreed: "No. I can't say I sample them. I'm not, like, patching their ancient voices into my recordings, not at all.
"But I'm definitely influenced by them," he continued. "They didn't wrap themselves up in the past and weep. They took public service jobs. They acted. They realized that American history isn't something that happened. It is still happening now."
