SECTION: Section H; Page 1; Column 1; Generations 

LENGTH: 2307 words

HEADLINE: Coming of Age, Seeking an Identity

BYLINE: By ARLIE RUSSELL HOCHSCHILD; Arlie Russell Hochschild, author of "The Time Bind," is a professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley and co-director of the Center for Working Families.

 BODY:
I'M not part of the 1960's generation," said Sandy de Lissovoy. "I don't feel part of Gen X or Gen Y. I'm sure not part of the 'Me Generation.' Who made up that term? I hate it. What's really in front of me is my computer, but even with it, I'm between the generation that barely tolerates computers and the one that treats them like a member of the family."
Mr. de Lissovoy, a 29-year-old graphic designer in San Francisco, was expressing as well as anyone the feelings that, as a sociology professor, I frequently hear during office hours. At this moment he was having a hard time defining his generation. He raised his eyebrows quizzically, smiled and said, "Call me the @ Generation One and a Half." 
 Can we make up our generation, as Mr. de Lissovoy playfully did, or is it imposed upon us, like it or not?
These are questions that the German sociologist Karl Mannheim took up in his classic 1927 essay, "The Problem of Generations." Is a generation a collection of people born in the same span of years? No, he thought, that is a cohort, and many cohorts are born, come of age and die without becoming generations. For Mannheim, a generation is a cohort of people who feel the impact of a powerful historical event and develop a consciousness about it. Not all members of a generation may see the event the same way, and some may articulate its defining features better than others. But what makes a generation is its connection to history.
Americans who came of age in the 1930's, 40's and 60's have been branded by large events -- the Great Depression, World War II, Vietnam -- and the collective moods they aroused. But from the 70's through the 90's, history's signal events happened elsewhere. Communism collapsed, but not in the United States. Wars raged in Rwanda and the Balkans, but they had no major effect here. The forces in the United States have been social and economic, and they have shifted the focus to more personal issues -- matters of lifestyle that are shaped by consumerism, the mass media and an increasing sense of impermanence in family and work.
"There is no overarching crisis or cause for our generation, " Mr. de Lissovoy said. "It's more a confusing, ambiguous flow of events. There's a slow, individual sorting out to do."
But underneath this confusing, ambiguous flow of events is a trend toward a more loosely jointed, limited-liability society, the privatizing influence of that trend and the crash-boom-bang of the market, which, in the absence of other voices, is defining generations left and right.
People in their 20's and early 30's are often called Gen X'ers, a term derived from a novel by Douglas Coupland. The book, "Generation X," was followed by a film, "Slacker," directed by Richard Linklater, about a group of overeducated, underemployed oddballs. But for Jim Kreines, a 32-year-old graduate student of philosophy at the University of Chicago, the label fit loosely, if at all.
When I asked him what generation he belonged to, Mr. Kreines replied, "I'm not sure I care enough to argue about this." He had read the Coupland book and seen the film. But did the Gen X'er label apply to him? He was not sure it mattered.
"Slacker" dwells on its characters' decision to drop to the margin of society. But the film, which helped label this generation, does what our whole culture does -- portrays a social trend as a personal choice.
Many Gen X'ers may be trying to sort out this cultural sleight of hand. They feel luckier than previous generations because they enjoy many more options. In the 50's, said Charles Sellers, a 28-year-old urban planner in Portland, Ore., there was only one choice. "If you were a woman you were a housewife," he said. "If you were a man you married and supported your family. Today, except for the Mormons, Americans have a long cultural menu to choose from. If you're a woman, you can be a single woman, a career woman, a lesbian, a single mom by choice, a live-in lover, a married-for-now wife, a married-forever wife. And the same for work: I'm on my third career."
But the wider menu of identities comes with a decreasing assurance that any particular identity will last. This is because a culture of deregulation has slipped from our economic life into our cultural life. Gen X'ers, at least in the middle class, can be more picky in finding "just the right mate" and "just the right career." But once you've found them, you begin to wonder if you can you keep them.
In his book "The New Insecurity," Jerald Wallulis, a philosopher at the University of South Carolina, observed that in the last 30 years, people have shifted the way they base their identity: from marriage and employment to marriageability and employability. Old anchors no longer hold, and a sense of history is lost. For the generations of the 80's and 90's, this rootlessness is their World War II, their Vietnam. And it presents a more difficult challenge than the one faced by the 60's generation.
Mr. de Lissovoy's parents divorced when he was a baby and now live on opposite coasts. Consider, too, the shifting family ties of a 27-year-old computer programmer in Silicon Valley, who asked that her name be withheld. "My mother divorced four times and is living on uncertain terms with her fifth," she said, "so I'm not sure if she'll stay with him either. I haven't gotten attached to any of my stepdads. My dad remarried four times, too, only now he's married to a woman I like."
When her parents divorced, she spent every other weekend with her father. "My dad was glad to see me, but I'd have to remind him of the name of my best friends," she said. "He didn't know what mattered to me. After a while it just got to be dinner and a video, and after that, I didn't feel much like going to his apartment."
Talking about her love life, she said: "If I meet someone I really like, I become shy and tied up in knots. I can't talk about anything personal." It was as if she did not dare to begin a relationship for fear of ending it.
After the parents of another young woman divorced, her father married a woman as young as his daughter, and is very involved with his new, young children who are the same age as his grandchildren. Now, when his daughter tries to arrange a visit between her father and his grandchildren, he is often too pinched for time to see them. His daughter feels hurt and angry -- first to miss out on a father, then a grandfather.
Reflecting on these generational jumbles, Mr. de Lissovoy commented: "Today's hype is that 'You can get it if you really want it' -- a mate, career and love still sells a lot of tickets. We're the Generation of Individual Choice. Which? Which? Which? But the bottom can fall out from some of those choices. And in the end, we're orphans. We're supposed to take care of ourselves. That's our only choice."
NOT every young person I have talked with has felt so adrift. The 20-somethings of the 90's have more material resources than their predecessors -- ample job opportunities, for example.
Still, Mr. de Lissovoy's feelings reflect something true about America these days. Despite the recent economic miracle, we are experiencing a care deficit. Social services have been cut; hospitals release patients 24 hours after surgery to recover at home. But who is home to do the caring? Two-thirds of mothers are working. One-quarter of households are headed by single mothers. Paradoxically, American individualism and pride in self-sufficiency lead us to absorb rather than resist this deficit: "Care? Who needs care? I can handle it," thus adding one problem to another.
If in previous decades large historic events drew people together and oriented them to action, the recent double trend toward more choice but less security leads the young to see their lives in more individual terms. Big events collectivize, little events atomize. So with people facing important but private problems, and thinking in individual, not collective, terms, the coast became clear in the 80's and 90's for the marketplace to stalk into this cultural void and introduce generation-defining clothes, music and videos.
Generations X and Y function as market gimmicks nowadays. The market dominates not just economic life, as the economist Robert Kuttner argues in "Everything for Sale," but our cultural life as well. It tells us what a generation is -- a Pepsi generation, a Mac generation, an Internet generation. And a magazine about shoot-'em-up computer games calls itself NextGen.
Advertisers are appealing to children over the heads of their parents. Juliet B. Schor, an economics lecturer at Harvard, suggests that the younger generation is the cutting edge of a full-blown market culture. More than $2 billion is spent on advertising directed at them, 20 times the amount spent a decade ago. Most of the advertising is transmitted through television; it is estimated that youngsters increased their viewing time one hour a day between l970 and 1990. Three out of five children ages 12 to 17 now have a TV in their bedroom. Although advertisers are trying to collude with children against their parents, Dr. Schor said recently, overworked parents sometimes go along with it too. If Dr. Schor is correct, Generation Y might be defined even more than Generation X by what its members buy than by what they do or who they are.
Marketing strategists, meanwhile, are turning over all the generations faster, slicing and dicing the life cycle into thinner strips. In the computer industry, an advertising generation is nine months; in the clothing industry, a season. In department stores, between the displays for girls in their preteens and and teens, is a new age, "tweens." The identity promised by a style or a brand name for one generation is marked off from an increasing number of others. And the styles continually replace old with new.
This creates a certain consumer logic. Older consumers buy what makes them feel young, while young consumers, up to a point, buy what makes them feel older. So the preteenager will buy the tween thing while the teenager will buy the 20-something jacket, and the 40-year-old will browse in the racks for 30-year-olds.
TO be sure, every American decade has fashion marketeers define generational looks and sounds, but probably never before have they so totally hijacked a generation's cultural expression. Allison Pugh, a 33-year-old married mother of two and a graduate student in sociology at the University of California at Berkeley, said: "I definitely feel like people just two or three years younger than me are the beginning of another generation. But I can only say why by pointing to superficial things like how many pierces they have, how high their shoes are and what kind of music they listen to. I roomed with a girl just two years younger and she listened to Smashing Pumpkins, Nirvana and Hole. I was 'old' -- as in out of it -- even just a few years out of college. I started to sound like my mother: 'That's not music; what is that noise?' "
Like Ms. Pugh, Mr. de Lissovoy is considered old to the generation at his heels. He is wired, but feels ambivalent about it. "What I don't like is disposability, hyperspeed, consumption," he said. "I'd like to reduce these. What I want more of is face-to-face interaction, a value on repair, families living nearby each other. I'd love to live in a multigenerational, multiracial cohousing project. And a more leisurely pace of life. I want some pretty old-fashioned things."
The 60's generation is hitting 60, and with some computer nerds striking it rich, 60's-era protests are not defining the new generation. But that era's flame is not dead. In front of a large gathering at the Pauley ballroom on the Berkeley campus a few months ago, the Mario Savio Young Activist Award for 1999 -- named after the leader of the 1964 Free Speech Movement -- was given to Nikki Bas, a 31-year-old American of Filipino descent who coordinates Sweatshop Watch, a campaign against the poor pay and working conditions of third-world workers who make football uniforms and other clothing sold on American college campuses. Mr. de Lissovoy remembered hearing about Mr. Savio from his 60's activist mother, but he does not know Nikki Bas, and he is not signing up.
Still, from a distance he watched the protests in Seattle against the World Trade Organization last fall, and they kindled a sense of the importance of history that he feels the market is driving out. "I hated the mindless anarchists who broke shop windows," he said. "But the other protesters who went there to speak up against megacorporations running the show, and for the family farm, local communities, monarch butterflies and sea turtles -- they are taking the long view of the planet. We usually think it's the older generation that wants to preserve the past, and it's the young who don't mind tearing things up. In Seattle, the young environmentalists had their eye on history, and it was the old who had an eye on their pocketbooks."
Ultimately, market generations are generations of things, and they can make us forget generations of people. "My generation doesn't know how globalization will turn out," Mr. de Lissovoy said. "But we won't see how globalization is messing us up if we've forgotten how the world used to be. Whichever way, we don't see that what we are doing is forgetting the past. And we're nobodies without a sense of history."
He recalled how baseball caps with X's became popular with teenagers, especially in Detroit, after Spike Lee's film on Malcolm X came out. "When a TV interviewer asked a kid about the X on his cap, he didn't know who Malcolm X was," Mr. de Lissovoy said. "He didn't even know he was a person. We need to appreciate the work it takes to get us where we are. Otherwise we aren't anywhere."

HEADLINE: Ljubljana Journal;
Like Switzerland, but Without the Cuckoo Clocks

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia

 BODY:
To Eastern Europe experts who never confuse this country with Slovakia or Slavonia, it is, in their words, "a jewel," "a chocolate box," "Eastern Europe's best-kept secret," or even -- wait for it -- "the Switzerland of the former Yugoslavia."
President Clinton, who stopped here overnight last June to thank Slovenia for letting NATO jets fly over on their way to bomb Kosovo and other parts of Yugoslavia, said at the time that he foresaw "a Europe undivided, democratic and at peace for the first time in its history." 
 "And Slovenia can lead the way," he added.
But as devotees struggle for the words to praise without condescending to a country of two million people, economic statistics tell the story more plainly: on the lists of Eastern European countries ready to join the European Union, tiny Slovenia is in the first wave, sometimes ranked at No. 2, behind Hungary but ahead of the Czech Republic and Poland.
Since it broke away from Yugoslavia in 1991, its gross domestic product per person has doubled to $10,000, outstripping that of Hungary and rivaling those of the poorest European Union members, Greece and Portugal.
Alone among Eastern Europeans, Slovenes do not need tourist visas to visit the United States. The standard of living is so high and unemployment so low that it is assumed that they will go home. "It's the highest form of compliment the U.S. pays," a diplomat said.
"You never hear of real poverty here," he said. "There were people laid off when they did economic shock treatment, but the growing service industry absorbed them. There are retired people getting by on pensions, but it's a living wage. There are subsistence farmers, but they're in valleys where Heidi might have lived."
Slovenes quickly rebuff comparisons with rivals like impoverished Romania or even the rest of the former Yugoslavia. They were at the core of the Austro-Hungarian Empire until it was broken up after World War I, they say, and generations of their artists and intellectuals went to the Vienna court, so they judge themselves by the standards of Austria and northern Italy.
"Our misfortune was that we were divorced in 1918," said Karl Lavencic, a Slovenian journalist working in Britain. "We joined Yugoslavia, and standards began to deteriorate under Communism." Nonetheless, under Tito's "self-management" brand of Communism, Slovenia was allowed to lead the way in running industries that traded with the West.
When the Eastern bloc fell apart, 80 percent of Slovenia's export market disappeared, but it recovered, and the country now does 66 percent of its trade with the European Union. It exports Renaults, parts for BMW and Ford, pharmaceuticals, furniture, clothing and tires.
Beaches on the Adriatic, ski runs in the Alps and lots of German Baroque spires in tidy villages make tourism a growth industry, and Ljubljana itself has a strange medieval exoticism. Dominated by a hilltop fortress, it must have more dragons per capita than any city west of Beijing -- as the city's symbol, there are dragons guarding bridges, dragons climbing light poles, even dragons on the manhole covers.
By contrast, the name of its oldest hotel, the Slon, which claims to date from an inn founded in 1552, means the Elephant. A government spokesman said it was named for Hannibal's big-guy cavalry passing through to attack Rome, but that seems doubtful, since the Carthaginians took the Spanish route. More likely is the hotel's version: a circus working the Austro-Hungarian gig used to tether its elephants nearby.
Unlike every other piece of the former Yugoslavia, the country has no ethnic tensions. The population is 90 percent Slovene, and the Italian and Hungarian minorities in border areas have their own seats in Parliament and the right to bilingual education and the use of their own languages in dealings with government.
Slovenes joke that the shape of the country looks like a chicken fleeing east, but they actually stood their ground and won a 10-day war for independence in 1991 against demoralized troops from the Yugoslav Army.
"They thought Slovenians would just raise their hands and give up," said Miha Rott, a government spokesman.
Slovenia declared its independence on June 25 that year, depriving the old Yugoslavia of what had been its borders with Austria and Italy, and the Yugoslav Army attacked on June 27.
But everyone who describes the war acknowledges that Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader, had little interest in the fight because there were almost no Serbs in Slovenia, and he was husbanding resources for his plans to seize Serbian-inhabited portions of Croatia and Bosnia.
"The Serbs never regarded Slovenia as a part of the world they would die for," Mr. Lavrencic said.
Since then Slovenia has aggressively pursued entry to NATO and was almost included in the round of expansion that has already brought in Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic. One reason that Slovenia did not make that cut, say diplomats from many NATO countries, is that NATO was wary of embracing any former Yugoslav republic while war still raged farther south.
Qualifying for the European Union requires extensive overhauls of the legal system and economy, especially in a formerly Communist country, and Slovenia still has changes to make, said Vincent Piket, counsellor of the organization's delegation here.
The country's banking and insurance are dominated by government-owned companies that must be merged and sold. The telephone monopoly must be ended and electricity privatized. Antitrust laws need strengthening; laws favoring local bids for government contracts need weakening.
More than 1,000 laws and bylaws matching those of other European countries must still be passed and legislators taught their meaning. Some sectors are resisting change: farmers fear competition and judges resent being given a new body of laws.
Still, "from the point of view of the European Union we're not a problematic country," said Janez Potocnik, head of the country's negotiating team.
In the toughest areas for other would-be members -- inefficient small farmers, pollution and corruption -- Slovenia does relatively well. Though vocal, farmers are only 4 percent of the economy, and many have second incomes from factory work, guesthouses or hunting. There is little heavy industry. The justice system is slow but honest.
And, to the delight of the European Union, nervous about porous borders even before Jorg Haider's party in Austria made much of the issue, Slovenia is buying passport scanners, fingerprint scanners, X-ray machines, night vision goggles and other hardware needed to tighten its frontiers.
Mr. Piket agreed with his counterpart, Mr. Potocnik.
"The fundamental assessment is that they can join the union in two or three years," he said. "It depends on how fast they do their homework. If they work as hard as they did last year, they can do it."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Recasting BellSouth from telephone company to high-technology communications provider.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
THE BellSouth Corporation is introducing a campaign tomorrow meant to recast the company as a high-technology leader in an effort to become more competitive against telecommunications and online rivals.
Telecommunications industry analysts say this is the first time a regional Bell company has tried to turn its image into that of a data and digital service provider. The campaign, with a budget estimated at $35 million to $50 million, is being created by the BellSouth corporate agency, Merkley Newman Harty in New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. Merkley Newman won that assignment in November after a review; previously, BellSouth divided the account between that agency and the Atlanta office of West Wayne. 
 The new campaign, which will extend beyond traditional advertising to all communications, carries the theme ">>>connect>> and create something." "The tag line is meant to convey that we can connect people to people, and people to the information they want when they want it, through e-mail, personal Web pages, e-business," said Alan Blount, assistant vice president for advertising at BellSouth in Atlanta.
Thus, a print ad promoting the service for operating a Web site shows a fictional Web address, www.prawntoshrimp.com, superimposed on a catch of shrimp. The text reads, "Since 1932, gulf prawns, 4th generation shrimper, 1st generation Web business, overnight shipping, secure transactions, 2nd boat ordered."
Humorous television commercials also focus on what are portrayed as the different ways the BellSouth online services improve customers' lives. One spot shows a 79-year-old man sitting alone on a bench; the voice-over explains that his wife died in 1993, but it goes on to say he remarried last year after getting e-mail and meeting a new mate online. Another spot shows a family with three children gathered for dinner; the father restrains one of them from answering her telephone as the voice-over says, "Three pagers, five e-mail addresses, two Web sites, 160 TV channels, four cell phones, and just one rule -- not at the dinner table."
Outdoor advertising conveys the same theme more simply: one billboard, showing two smiling boys whispering to each other, says "Chat," while ads created for phone kiosks merely say "Check voice mail" or "Whassssssss uuuuuppp!?"
All ads are a radical departure from BellSouth's previous corporate campaign, which ran from 1997 to 1999 and featured folksy ads depicting the town of Chatsford and a BellSouth employee named Tyler, both fictional.
According to Mr. Blount, the new campaign is primarily directed at adults age 18 to 49. However, William Pate, BellSouth's vice president for advertising, marketing and public relations, said some ads, like those created for phone kiosks, are meant for teenagers.
"That group is the largest cluster since the baby boomers; they can start and stop trends on a dime," he said. "We've got to speak to them, build their brand loyalty. We want to make the connection as early as we can."
"The new campaign is a recognition of what's going on in the marketplace," Mr. Pate added. "Our competition is no longer AT&T, MCI, Sprint. We now compete with Yahoo, Mindspring, AOL. We knew we were not getting as much credit as we should for the business applications we have in e-space. We felt our new brand effort should be totally focused on these applications, because we were already known for others."
Last year, BellSouth's digital and data revenues jumped 33.1 percent, to $2.8 billion, out of a total of $25.2 billion.
Advertising will appear during N.C.A.A. college basketball games and on cable networks like CNN, E and Oxygen; in daily newspapers in the Southeast, USA Today and The Wall Street Journal; and in magazines like Time, Vanity Fair, Inc. and Rolling Stone.
People involved with telecommunications generally applauded BellSouth's new strategy.
Jeff Kagan, a consultant in Atlanta who advises BellSouth and other companies, said the branding effort "makes a lot of sense."
"Traditional phone companies are perceived as stodgy, and perception is just as important as reality," he added. "The new strategy lets them compete and thrive in a marketplace that's become very noisy and confusing."
Philip Asmundson, national communications practice director for Deloitte & Touche L.L.P., said it was "about time" a regional Bell company ran a campaign like BellSouth's, because "they have been letting newcomers get too much press."
"And BellSouth has a name that connotes trust, which is crucial as the world becomes more connected in general" he said.
Mr. Asmundson said all Bell companies, including BellSouth, would have to reposition themselves, a task he predicted would be quite difficult: "BellSouth's problem is that it is trying to go from being your father's telephone company to a company that connects voice and data. Standard budgets won't do it. They'll have to look at spending more money, because it's harder for them to change the perception of who they are."
Another issue for BellSouth, said Brian Adamik, chief operating officer of the Yankee Group, a telecommunications research and consulting company in Boston, is whether "consumers will believe the brand can be extended, whether it's credible in the Internet economy."

HEADLINE: Productivity In 4th Quarter Revised Higher

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Worker productivity in the fourth quarter of last year grew at the fastest pace in seven years and labor costs fell for the second consecutive quarter, the Labor Department said today.
Productivity, which measures output for each hour worked, rose at a revised annual rate of 6.4 percent in the period, up from 5 percent in the third quarter. Productivity for the last three months of 1999 was adjusted from an earlier estimate of 5 percent. 
 While the report suggested that businesses were finding new ways to absorb increases in labor costs and avoid raising prices, it was unlikely to stop Federal Reserve policy makers from pushing interest rates higher in coming months to keep the economy from overheating.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned on Monday that productivity and stock gains had made businesses and consumers too optimistic about the economy's ability to grow without causing inflation.
In another report today, the Federal Reserve said consumer debt surged $17 billion in January, the biggest rise in almost five years. Credit card charges and auto loans both fed the rise, which followed increases of $10.4 billion in December and $13.2 billion in November.
Kevin Flanagan, an economist in New York with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, forecasts that the Fed will raise interest rates at least two more times in the next three months.
Productivity in the final three months of 1999 grew at the fastest pace since the fourth quarter of 1992, when the record 108-month expansion was starting to gain speed. Last year, productivity grew 3 percent, also the best since 1992.
Unit labor costs fell in the fourth-quarter of 1999 at a 2.5 percent rate, after a 0.3 percent drop in the third quarter. That measure of the effect of productivity on business costs showed the largest rate of decline since the fourth quarter of 1992. Productivity has grown more than 2 percent for four consecutive years. The last time that happened was 1961-1966.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Calculating the Stakes on the YankeeNets Private Bond Offering

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Would you lend money to a sports conglomerate whose current operations do not generate enough profits to pay interest on the loans, let alone repay the money being borrowed?
That is the issue buyers of junk bonds are facing as the YankeeNets L.L.C. -- the new company that controls a winning baseball team and a losing basketball team -- tries to borrow $250 million. It is expected that the borrowing will go through tomorrow, but at a very high interest rate of about 12.25 percent. That is half a percentage point higher than the rate the company had hoped to pay. 
 The private offering will finance payouts to the owners of the two teams, enabling the former New Jersey Nets owners to pay back money they borrowed to finance the payments that enabled them to become equal owners of YankeeNets with the former owners of the New York Yankees baseball team. For the owners of the Yankees, led by George Steinbrenner, the payments will simply add to their wealth.
Mr. Steinbrenner realized about $135 million in cash when the Yankees and Nets combined business operations, and he is likely to collect $40 million more if the bond offering is completed and a related plan to sell a minority interest in the company also goes as planned.
The bond offering is being sold in a private placement open only to institutional investors, including high-yield mutual funds. While the offering memorandum is not public, a copy of it was provided to The New York Times. It gives a detailed look at the finances of the two teams and the unusual operating arrangement that will preserve Mr. Steinbrenner's ability to run the Yankees as he sees fit, notwithstanding the fact that he will no longer own a majority stake in the team.
The offering memorandum warns, in boldface type: "We may not be able to service our debt obligations if we do not increase cash flow." Indeed, on a consolidated basis, the two teams showed a net loss of $98.2 million on revenue of $241 million in the 12 months ended Sept. 30, 1999. While some of that loss represented noncash expenses, the combined company would have had a negative cash flow of $4.2 million even before paying interest on its existing debts.
Most of the losses have come from the Nets. The financial statements in the offering memorandum show that the Yankees are marginally profitable before post-season revenue is counted -- revenue that would vanish if the team failed to make the playoffs. For the first nine months of last year -- a period that does not include the playoffs -- the team reported operating income of just $556,000, and a net loss, after considering interest expense on its current debt, of $4.4 million. Figures for the fourth quarter of 1999, including the playoffs and World Series, were not disclosed.
For all of 1998, when the team had post-season revenue of $11.5 million, it reported operating income of $20.1 million and net income of $12.7 million.
This borrowing, if the interest rate is 12.25 percent, will require annual interest payments of $30.6 million, well above previous cash flows for the teams. The $250 million would be due in 2007.
The offering memorandum holds out two principal hopes for the teams' coming up with the money to meet their obligations. The first is a better local television contract for the two teams. The Yankees contract with the Madison Square Garden Network expires after this season, and the Nets have the right to terminate their contract with Fox Sports New York at the end of the 2000-2001 season. The second is a sale of stock in one or both teams to the public.
The negotiations for that contract should be interesting. Both MSG and Fox Sports New York are now controlled by Cablevision -- which tried to buy control of the Yankees before the deal with the Nets was made -- and competition between the two has diminished. But the Yankees and Nets could conceivably put together their own television operation if MSG and Fox Sports New York do not agree to pay enough.
The bond offering memorandum mentions the possibility of selling shares in one or both teams to the public by 2003 but does not commit itself to do so.
Neither the bond offering nor the planned sale of $75 million in ownership interests in YankeeNets will do much to provide cash to operate the teams. Only $15 million of the $325 million being raised will go to operations. Another $15.7 million will go to pay expenses connected to the offerings, and about $80 million will be put into escrow to assure that the company will have the money to make interest payments for the first three years that the bonds are outstanding. That leaves about $214.3 million to be distributed to the owners of the teams.
In a normal company, the board has complete control over the company's operations, although it delegates much of that control to management. But the YankeeNets company is different. The board of the Nets will have control over most aspects of that team, including the right to set the team's budget within certain parameters. Mr. Steinbrenner, as managing general partner of the Yankees, will have the right to set that team's budget and to make all major decisions on issues like personnel and player salaries.
There is, to be sure, a board for the company. But its powers are limited to certain decisions, including areas like real estate investments. There is also a board for the Yankees, but the agreement specifies that if the board and Mr. Steinbrenner disagree, Mr. Steinbrenner's opinion will prevail.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico's Credit Rating Is Raised to Investment Quality by Moody's

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

 BODY:
In a surprisingly broad endorsement of Mexico's economic strength and financial management, Moody's Investors Service raised the country's credit rating today to investment grade for the first time.
The announcement was a powerful vindication of President Ernesto Zedillo's efforts to convince investors that Mexico will make it through national elections this year without the kind of economic disaster that has marred every presidential turnover for the last two decades. 
 "It's a signal that allows the investor to say, I can assume that the overall economic context is a sound one," said Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria Trevino.
With the upgrading from the junk-bond category, Moody's moved Mexico into the league of countries that present a very low risk of failing to pay their debts. Now the government and many private Mexican corporations will have access to a wider range of financing at lower rates.
The new rating clears the way for many large institutions in the United States to buy Mexican bonds, which they were barred from doing without the investment grade status.
Moody's pointed to Mexico's "dynamic export sector" and successful integration with the United States economy since the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement. Because Mexico's foreign debt is clearly manageable, Moody's said, "a slowdown in the U.S. economy should not be seriously disruptive."
The agency was also unusually optimistic about the prospects for stability through the balloting on July 2 and the handing over of power Dec. 1. "The widespread consensus on the importance of sound financial policies combined with a vibrant multiparty democracy provides additional support to continued fiscal discipline," Moody's said.
Mr. Zedillo, a Yale-trained economist, has focused economic policy for the last year on taking Mexico through the end of his term without a devastating peso crash like the one that he faced in his first days in office. While foreign reserves stand at $31 billion, the country has already refinanced the foreign debt scheduled to come due this year, and faces "very comfortable" repayments next year, Mr. Gurria said.
Moody's decision immediately began to push interest rates down. The rate on the benchmark 28-day Mexican treasury bonds dropped to 13.95 percent, the lowest since the period before the crisis began in December 1994. As recently as September 1998, in the middle of a crisis created by turmoil in Russia and Brazil, the rate had soared to 41.33 percent.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Sound Advice For Jets Fans: Get Used to It

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
NOT only can management threaten to trade Keyshawn Johnson for a draft choice, it can also actually do it. There might even be some football justification for doing it.
Maybe Bill Parcells is just playing with Keyshawn's fertile mind, trying to make him appreciative of all the good things about playing for the Jets, whatever they happen to be. However, contemporary sports economics says Parcells just might deal Johnson to Baltimore because of the way Keyshawn could clog up the salary cap if he gets what he thinks he deserves. 
 Sure, Keyshawn looks like a franchise player, tall and tough and resourceful. But he is also a wide receiver, a category of player often only as good as the man lining up behind the center.
Star receivers are not any more valuable than dominant running backs or linebackers. This may sound like heresy, but you can bet this thought has crossed the mind of Parcells. Still, Keyshawn is the most magnetic player the Jets have.
In the best of worlds, he would remain a target for Jets quarterbacks for the next decade, a familiar and beloved icon. The trouble is, Keyshawn has already advertised that he will be expensive the next time around.
This is the other side of modern free agency. Players leave teams. Teams leave players. It's a two-way street. In these days of the pre-emptive strike by management -- get rid of the guy before he gets too expensive -- there are not going to be very many venerated locals like Ray Bourque or Dan Marino in the next generation.
Bourque was traded to Colorado on Monday night after playing 21 years of hockey with the same team. The Boston Ruins, who are not going anywhere, made it sound as if they did Bourque a huge favor by dealing him to a team with Stanley Cup pretensions, which, in hockey, means about two-thirds of the league.
Marino may go to Minnesota, where he could play first-string quarterback, apparently no longer an option for him after 17 years in Miami.
Ken Griffey Jr. is the face of the future. Junior had no desire to be the Tony Gwynn of Seattle: a lovable ancient staying put so he would not have to go through the trouble of redecorating another house in another baseball town.
Junior wanted to go home to Cincinnati -- for a while, anyway -- so he forced his way out with a year left in his contract. His old pal, Alex Rodriguez, might do the same by midseason.
"Doesn't anybody stay in one place anymore?" as Carole King once asked.
Cal Ripken, 19 years in Baltimore and counting, is a throwback, and Patrick Ewing, in his own weird way, is a throwback in New York, even though he has the most tepid relationship with his franchise city that you are ever likely to see.
Today's players are mobile, which forces franchises to be coldblooded in new and creative ways. The housecleaning in Buffalo at the end of the season was fascinating: Thurman Thomas, Bruce Smith, Andre Reed, gone.
In the old days, a team like the Mets could trade a young Nolan Ryan for baseball reasons, as ghastly as those reasons turned out to be. Nowadays, franchises move a player when he even sends out brain waves that he is speculating about revising his contract.
What can the fans do if the new ownership of the Jets decides to get Keyshawn before Keyshawn gets it? The fans can look at it this way: There is no law against wearing their green No. 19 Johnson jerseys to the games. That still falls under the framework of the First Amendment.

 Modern sports creates an almost sense of nostalgia. The stalwarts who thrilled you last season turn out to have just been passing through. The last 250 Islanders fans in the Nassau Coliseum still wear their Palffy jerseys. There will be some Olerud jerseys in Shea this season. There are Messier jerseys in the Garden.
Keyshawn Johnson could be next. Why not? He has been the obvious star of the Jets since he arrived. When they were losing, it was easy for fans and coaches to dismiss him as a ball hog with a high opinion of himself, but he has demonstrated his nerve as well as his touch, and the Jets have built around him.
He has been everything a franchise could want, but now he is becoming expensive, and maybe even expendable. The fans can only stop sniveling and pull out that little rectangular piece of plastic for the season tickets. That is their job.

HEADLINE: Annan Sets Up Panel to Study U.N.'s Peacekeeping Predicament

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 7

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan announced today that he was appointing an international panel to look at every aspect of United Nations peacekeeping and make recommendations on how missions can be more effective.
"Partly it is a question of being clearer about what we are trying to do," Mr. Annan said at a news conference. "And partly it is a question of getting the nuts and bolts right." 
 One of the questions to be posed to the panel, he added, is "What do you do if the peace you are trying to keep breaks down and large numbers of civilians are in danger of being massacred?" The question is not hypothetical: the United Nations has come under severe criticism for the failure to stop the killing of Muslims in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995 and the massacre of ethnic Tutsi in Rwanda the year before.
Two tough reports last year on those incidents found considerable shortcomings in the organization, including some in the peacekeeping department, which at the time of those events was run by Mr. Annan. But the new panel is not being formed to conduct another post-mortem. Instead it will look more broadly at how the United Nations is often handed difficult assignments by member nations on the Security Council and then not given the means to carry them out. The contrast to NATO-led missions or other operations outside the United Nations system is stark.
"When member states take on some of these operations under multinational force arrangements, they usually go in with much larger forces," Mr. Annan said today. "But when the U.N. is going to do it, we are often given a very low and arbitrary ceiling and resources do not always match the mandate. One of things I hope the panel will look at is the quality of the mandates we get. "
The panel is to be led by Lakhdar Brahimi, a former Algerian foreign minister who has been a troubleshooter for the secretary general in a number of countries, among them Afghanistan and Haiti.
"I hope that in the next six months or a year we would have enough ideas on when and how we intervene," Mr. Annan said. "Under our charter, we are allowed to use force in the common interest. But there are questions that we will have to answer. What is the common interest? Who defines it? Who defends it? And under what authority and under what circumstances?"
The secretary general asked the panel to produce a report by July, before a summit meeting of heads of government in early fall. The report is to be written by William Durch, an arms control and Balkans expert at the Henry L. Stimson Center, an independent institute in Washington that studies issues of war and peace.
Panel members announced today were J. Brian Atwood, former administrator of the United States Agency for International Development; Dame Ann Hercus of New Zealand, a former representative of the secretary general in Cyprus; Richard Monk of Britain, a member of the police task force in Bosnia; Gen. Klaus Naumann, former chief of the German defense staff and chairman of the military committee of NATO; Hisako Shimura, president of Tsuda College in Japan and a former peace negotiator for the United Nations; Gen. Philip Sibanda of Zimbabwe, a former peacekeeping force commander in Angola; and Cornelius Sommaruga of Switzerland, who has just retired as president of the International Committee of the Red Cross.
Mr. Annan said that one or two members might be added later.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Report SeeksBig Changes in I.M.F. and World Bank

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank should be radically shrunken and overhauled because they often do more harm than good in the developing world, a Congressional commission will recommend.
The commission, which plans to release its report Wednesday, also asserts that both the I.M.F. and the World Bank waste billions of dollars making loans to middle-income countries that could rely on private capital instead. 
 Among its findings, the commission said that the institutions should sharply curtail their lending programs, that they often interfere too much in the domestic policy and even the politics of countries they seek to help and that they had generally failed to lead nations out of poverty.
The report, more than a year in the making, is highly political. The Republican-led Congress ordered the 11-member panel of scholars to study how to remake the Washington-based sister institutions after agreeing to provide $18 billion for the I.M.F. during the financial crisis that began in Asia. The panel's conclusions seem certain to fuel a partisan effort by some in Congress to reduce or even eliminate the United States contributions to the two agencies, though officials consider the chance of that happening as small.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, anticipating the main thrust of the report's conclusions, proposed a plan late last year to streamline the monetary fund that embraces several of the report's recommendations. Mr. Summers is also conducting a study of the World Bank that aims to reflect some common criticisms of the way the bank works. But it will also defend its mission against people who argue that it has outlived its usefulness.
The Congressional commission, headed by Prof. Allan H. Meltzer, an expert on monetary policy at Carnegie Mellon University, split along political lines before drafting its final report, which had been debated openly in Washington for weeks. Four of the five commission members appointed by Democrats dissented. They then issued their own report that recommends more modest changes.
The report touches on a central issue in this time of globalization: What is the role of World War II-era international institutions set up to help relieve poverty and provide a stable financial environment now that private capital flows have become the overwhelmingly dominant influence on the world's economic health? The report reflects an often-heard criticism that the I.M.F. and World Bank have become ever larger even though they are no longer needed to do the jobs they originally did.
"There was a sense that something had gone awry at both institutions," said Jerome I. Levinson, a professor at American University and a member of the Meltzer Commission. But Mr. Levinson, along with the other dissident Democratic appointees, said he believed the commission was motivated by a preconceived notion that the I.M.F. and World Bank should be eliminated.
"There were real differences between those who want to fix things and those who think they do such harm that we're better off getting rid of them," he said.
The report seems unlikely to lead to a revamping of the World Bank and the I.M.F. during the Clinton administration. But it could serve as the blueprint for an overhaul if a Republican president is elected. Even then, however, other wealthy countries that along with the United States provide most of the money for the bank and fund would have to agree to make changes.
And at a time when Congress has proved stingy in financing world agencies, including the United Nations, it seems likely that the next United States president, as has Mr. Clinton, will find the I.M.F. and the World Bank indispensable. The World Bank alone makes $50 billion in development loans each year, more than three times the entire foreign aid budget of the United States. The I.M.F. played what some supporters argued was a crucial role defending against the spread of financial malaise in recent years, committing tens of billions of dollars that might have been difficult to appropriate from national legislatures on short notice.
The report recommends that the I.M.F. mainly help nations cope with temporary problems that arise when capital leaves faster than it enters, by making only short-term "liquidity" loans at high interest rates.
The report goes on say that the fund should stop trying to relieve poverty, calling that a task better left to other agencies. Moreover, the monetary fund should stop offering long-term, low-cost loans with conditions that countries like Russia or Turkey must meet I.M.F. goals on their finances and economies. Instead, the fund should refuse to make loans of any kind to nations that do not meet certain rigid criteria.
For the World Bank, the prescription is Draconian. The report recommends that the bank be renamed the World Development Agency and basically get out of the business of making loans. Such loans, the report says, should be the preserve of private banks and brokerage houses.
Instead, the bank should focus on providing grants to people who need them in the poorest countries, it says.
The report suggests that as a first step the bank should phase out all loans to nations where per capita income is $4,000 or more, which is the bulk of its lending today. Moreover, it should allow regional development banks, which have much less capital, to take the lead in Asia and Latin America, where there are many such middle-income countries.

HEADLINE: Trenton Ordered to Improve Preschool in Poorest Districts

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the State Department of Education had not moved quickly enough to provide preschool programs of good quality for all 3- and 4-year-olds in the state's 30 poorest urban school districts, as it was ordered to do in a 1998 decision on a long-running school financing dispute.
In its ruling yesterday, the court ordered the state to come up with tough, uniform standards for the programs by April 17, and said the maximum class size would be 15 children, rather than the 20 the state had wanted. The court also insisted that all new employees for the programs be certified teachers. 
 But while it chided the state for not acting quickly enough on its 1998 ruling, the court, in a 6-to-0 decision written by Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz, emphasized that it did not believe critics' claims that the state was acting in bad faith. Therefore, the court refused a request to appoint a judge as a special master to monitor the state's compliance.
"We are satisfied that any discrepancies in the implementation of our decree have resulted from misunderstandings in executing the court's mandate," the chief justice wrote.
The requirement of preschool for all 3- and 4-year-olds, which many education experts say is important to future academic success, is only one part of a package of far-reaching changes the court ordered in 1998 to improve education in the state's 30 most economically disadvantaged districts. Other changes included more state money for school construction, tougher high school curriculums and more programs to encourage parental involvement.
Plaintiffs in the case, Abbott v. Burke, complained to the court last fall that the Department of Education had failed to deliver on preschool programs, and in large measure, the court agreed with them yesterday.
David Sciarra, a lawyer for the Education Law Center in Newark, which brought the case on behalf of children in the 30 districts, said yesterday that the ruling reaffirmed the importance of a good preschool program.
"This is a solid decision that is really important for both New Jersey and the rest of the nation," Mr. Sciarra said. "It reaffirms the court's prior order requiring the state to provide a high-quality preschool program that these children clearly need. The state's response to this order clearly fell short of the mark."
After the 1998 decision in the Abbott case, the Department of Education ordered all districts to use existing day care centers to house preschool programs for an estimated 45,000 children. Many of the districts instead asked the state for more financing to build their own preschool centers, but the state denied the money and rejected their preschool plans. Lawyers representing the poor children argued that many of the centers the state wanted them to use were not providing the rigorous education that the State Supreme Court ordered in its 1998 decision.
The court said yesterday that the state could rely on existing day care centers, but that state officials needed to issue clear, strict standards by April 17 that all centers throughout the state would follow. The State Education Commissioner, David Hespe, said in an interview yesterday that a committee he appointed in the fall to come up with such standards was close to completing its proposal.
"That will in no way be a problem," he said.
Mr. Hespe also said that he was glad the court agreed that the state had not been acting in bad faith.
"All of us in the state want quality early childhood programs in these districts," he said. "But there's been a lot of disagreement on how we got there. The court has settled some of those controversies with this decision, so now we can all get to the hard work that remains."
In its decision yesterday, the court directed state officials to require that all new employees for the preschool programs be certified teachers. Current employees will have four years to obtain certification, the court said, a shorter amount of time than Mr. Hespe had proposed.
The court recognized that the state had a daunting task of providing so many educational improvements in so many districts in such a short time. But justices also took both sides to task for constantly haggling over how to carry out parts of their landmark Abbott decision.
"Another generation of children will pay the price for each year of delay," the court wrote.

HEADLINE: Edward H. Levi, Attorney General Credited With Restoring Order After Watergate, Dies at 88

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Edward H. Levi, who began his association with the University of Chicago as a 5-year-old in a special kindergarten there and became the university's president before going on to be a widely admired attorney general of the United States, died yesterday at his home in Chicago. He was 88.
A distinguished legal educator, he was called upon to restore the credibility of the job of attorney general after the turmoil of the Nixon era. 
 No one was more a product of the University of Chicago than Mr. Levi. He remained at the university's laboratory school through grade school and high school, then attended college, graduate school and law school at the university. He was at various times a law professor, dean of the law school, university provost and, finally, the university's president.
As someone who spent most of his life in the shadow of the University of Chicago, Mr. Levi had enormous influence on the university, the study of law and even the surrounding Hyde Park neighborhood in which he grew up and which he later helped revitalize. He thrilled at teaching Chicago's renowned "great books" curriculum to undergraduates, pioneered the pairing of law with other disciplines like economics and statistics at the law school and fiercely recruited leading intellectuals in order to maintain the university as a vibrant agora of ideas.
But he secured a wider place in history for his role in Washington, where he demonstrated that the skills he had honed and deployed in academic circles were equally successful at the highest levels of government.
As the 71st attorney general of the United States, Mr. Levi won wide acclaim for his stewardship of the Justice Department in the post-Watergate era. He has been regularly cited by political scientists and lawyers as the model of a modern attorney general.
When he was named to the post in 1975 by President Gerald R. Ford, there was confusion about his political affiliations and philosophy. Some news accounts questioned whether he was best described as a conservative, liberal or libertarian. When he left office two years later, the answer was no clearer, but the question seemed mostly irrelevant.
Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, who was a senior official under Mr. Levi in the Justice Department, said in an interview that "there couldn't have been a tougher job in Washington where the whole executive branch was in disarray after Watergate."
Justice Scalia said that as attorney general Mr. Levi "brought the department through its worst years."
He added, "It was a bad time not only because of the disgrace of Watergate, which had affected the department most deeply, but there were also problems at the F.B.I." The Federal Bureau of Investigation had been conducting domestic surveillance operations, under the code name Cointelpro, that were probably unconstitutional. Mr. Levi forced through regulations setting limits on what the bureau and the Central Intelligence Agency could undertake in investigations.
"He brought two qualities to the job," Justice Scalia said, "a rare intellectuality and a level of integrity such as there could never be any doubt about his honesty, forthrightness or truthfulness."
Although he was appointed by a Republican president, Mr. Levi's performance was considered so nonpartisan that when he left the department to return to the University of Chicago, he was warmly praised by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
In a speech in the Senate on Jan. 25, 1977, Mr. Kennedy said, "Mr. Levi entered office under the most difficult and trying circumstances, yet he leaves a department once again characterized by integrity, intellectual honesty and commitment to equal justice."
Edward Hirsch Levi was born in Chicago on June 26, 1911, to Gerson B. Levi, a rabbi who came to the United States from Scotland, and Elsa Hirsch Levi. His maternal grandfather, Rabbi Emil G. Hirsch, was an early member of the University of Chicago faculty and a leading architect of the Reform branch of Judaism in America.
After graduating from college, Mr. Levi began studying for a doctorate in literature at the university but dropped out of the program. Years later he explained that he had been told in a friendly manner by a professor who admired his family that he would never be given a position in the humanities department at Chicago or any leading institution because he was a Jew.
He recalled that incident not ruefully but joyfully in an essay in Newsweek magazine during the nation's bicentennial celebrations of 1976 to demonstrate how much the country had changed. He had, after all, become the first Jewish dean of a major law school. When he became the president of the University of Chicago in 1968, he said he believed he was the first Jewish president of a major private university other than one with a clear Jewish identity, like Brandeis.
Gerhard Casper, the president of Stanford University and a former colleague of Mr. Levi's at the University of Chicago law school, said that it was Mr. Levi who came up with the idea of teaming with an economist to teach his course in antitrust law. It was from that innovation, Mr. Casper said, that the notion of tying law to other forms of study was born. "This was the beginning of the 'law and economics school' of thought for which Chicago would become famous," he said.
Mr. Casper said that he often quotes Mr. Levi, who once told him that "universities are the custodians not only of the many cultures of man but also of the rational process itself."
Richard A. Posner, another law faculty colleague and now the chief judge of the federal appeals court based in Chicago, said that Mr. Levi's pairing of an economist and lawyer in teaching "was a major development, not only in the law and economics sphere but in creating interdisciplinary studies in general at law schools."
Judge Posner said that Mr. Levi followed the economics and law partnership by putting together a statistician and a law professor. A sociologist was added later.
In 1958, Mr. Levi founded the school's Journal of Law and Economics, which became a vehicle that helped the University of Chicago remain pre-eminent in the field.
Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College and a former student of Mr. Levi's, said that he was also a model in furthering the notion that intellectual arguments should be about ideas, not personalities.
"He resented the personalizing of arguments," Mr. Botstein said. "I remember he was asked if he was going to write his memoirs and he replied, 'If I were to write a book, it would be about ideas, not about myself.' "
Mr. Levi was also renowned among college and university administrators for his deft handling of civil disturbances on the Chicago campus in 1968. Unlike administrators at some other major universities, he did not call in outside authorities when more than 400 students occupied his office for more than two weeks. He waited them out, and after they were gone he suspended and dismissed many of their leaders.
His slim volume, "An Introduction to Legal Reasoning" (University of Chicago Press, 1949) has been a perennially assigned book at many of the nation's law schools.
Mr. Levi retired from the university in 1984; his wife, Kate Sulzberger Hecht Levi, said he had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for the last six years.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by three sons, John G., a lawyer in Chicago, David F., a federal trial judge in Sacramento, and Michael E., a particle physicist in Berkeley, Calif.
In the bicentennial essay for Newsweek, Mr. Levi said: "The one thing that we ought to worry about is the propensity of this country to overreact, and to engage in cycles of bitterness. There is a kind of theme which runs through the modern world that human relationships should be looked at in terms of power relationships, in terms of the manipulation of power. I really think that's one of the most wicked ways of looking at the world. It's a very incomplete way. It strips people of their humanness. It converts all the other good attributes people have into just an ability or a desire to manipulate others."

HEADLINE: Internet Registrar to Be Sold for $21 Billion

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7

 BODY:
In the costliest acquisition of an Internet company to date, VeriSign Inc., a producer of online security software, agreed today to acquire Network Solutions Inc., the Virginia-based company that maintains the master list of Internet addresses.
VeriSign valued the deal, a stock swap, at $21 billion, although a drop in its share price took it down to $17 billion -- still a high premium for a company with 1999 earnings of $26.9 million on sales of $220.8 million. The deal exceeds Lucent Technologies Inc.'s $20 billion acquisition of Ascend Communications Inc. in January 1999 as the biggest high-tech acquisition ever. The major difference is that Ascend had $1.6 billion in sales in the previous year. 
 Analysts said the price was all the more astonishing because Network Solutions no longer enjoyed a monopoly in the registration of domain names, as Internet addresses are known, and will see growing competition in the years to come.
The merger also constrains VeriSign's ability to form partnerships or strategic alliances with a generation of companies that now compete with Network Solutions in registering domain names, analysts said.
Such concerns drove VeriSign shares down $47.4375 to close at $200, in Nasdaq trading. Network Solutions shares soared, closing at $407.3906, up $46.7656, to make it the biggest gainer on the Nasdaq.
"The combination of these two companies makes sense," said Charles Rutstein, an analyst with Forrester Research. "The cross-selling and up-selling opportunities are evident to most observers."
But he added: "What's a bit confusing is why VeriSign needed to own this company as opposed to being a marketing partner. The two have done business together before. At the end of the day, you have to wonder whether $21 billion was too much."
Under the agreement, VeriSign, whose software keeps sensitive information safe when people buy and sell things on the Internet, will issue 2.15 shares of VeriSign common stock for each share of Network Solutions stock, as constituted before a 2-for-1 split of Network Solutions stock on March 10. Verisign had earnings of $4 million on revenues of $84.8 million in 1999.
The companies said that by combining they would be able to offer services including domain registration, global directory listings, basic Web site creation and secure processing of online transactions.
Stratton Sclavos, VeriSign's president and chief executive, called Network Solutions "one of the most undervalued assets on the Internet by any of the standard metrics -- number of customers, type of business model, revenue growth, profitability, cash flow."
Analysts said there were regulatory issues and competitive pressures that made the outcome of the merger difficult to predict.
In 1998, the Commerce Department created the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, to end Network Solutions' monopoly and open up the registration of Internet addresses to competition. Today, at an Icann meeting in Cairo, people were caught off guard by the announcement.
"It's a real eye-opener," said Ken Stubbs, who runs a nonprofit group that now competes with Network Solutions. But he said he was not concerned about its impact on his group. "I think I'll register more names tomorrow than today," he said.
Founded in 1979, Network Solutions pioneered the registering of Web addresses ending in .com, .net, .org and .edu. It is the world's leading registrar with more than 8.1 million domain registrations. It also offers so-called registry services, meaning that it maintains the InterNIC database, the telephone directory of the Internet. Network Solutions' registry customers include all the new competing companies that register domains ending in .com, .net and .org.

HEADLINE: Clinton Decides to Visit Pakistan, After All

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Arguing that important national security interests would be jeopardized if President Clinton stayed away, the White House announced today that he would visit Pakistan "for a few hours" at the end of his lengthier trip to India later this month.
The decision, which came after weeks of fierce in-fighting within the administration, was based on the need to urge Pakistan's military government to work toward resolving the heightened conflict with India over Kashmir and to crack down on terrorism, senior officials said. 
 Mr. Clinton has been described by his aides as confident that he can personally engage Pakistan's ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who took power in a coup last October.
The Pakistani government had made virtually no progress on the three major requests that administration officials laid out for General Musharraf in January -- to agree to a timetable for the restoration of democracy, improve its record on nonproliferation, and shut down a group Washington accuses of terrorism, the officials said today.
But they asserted that it was most important to "keep the channels of communication open" so that Mr. Clinton can develop the kind of relationship with General Musharraf that enabled the president to persuade the deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, to back down in Kashmir last year.
A White House statement tried to dismiss the notion that Mr. Clinton's presence in Pakistan would confer legitimacy on its government. It added that Mr. Clinton was not going to mediate the Kashmir dispute, an involvement that India vehemently opposes.
In talks with President Clinton last summer, Mr. Sharif agreed to coax Pakistani-backed guerrillas to return from the mountain redoubts they had seized in Indian-controlled Kashmir. Mr. Clinton offered assurances that he was willing to take a personal interest in setting the half-century-old dispute over Kashmir, but after the coup that deposed Mr. Sharif, Mr. Clinton has had no opportunity to become involved in Kashmir talks.
In order to differentiate between General Musharraf, to whom Mr. Clinton will try to deliver a stern message, and the people of Pakistan, the administration is exploring the possibility of the president's addressing the nation in a televised speech, a senior administration official said.
The White House statement further argued that if Mr. Clinton had rebuffed Pakistan, he would strengthen the militant groups that threaten to send the country into a political and economic collapse and dishearten advocates of a secular democracy.
Events on the subcontinent -- including the testing of nuclear weapons by India and Pakistan in 1998 and the sharp deterioration in their relations -- have made the nature of Mr. Clinton's trip more difficult than when it was first contemplated some years ago as the celebration of a new American relationship with India.
Today, the White House stressed that the focus of Mr. Clinton's trip, which will start in Bangladesh on March 20, remained on India, where he will spend five days and visit five cities. The itinerary in India is geared to spectacular backdrops -- the Taj Mahal and possibly an elephant ride -- and to emphasizing the new India of technology and trade.
In contrast, Mr. Clinton may not venture outside the Islamabad airport, although senior Administration officials said arrangements for the Pakistani visit were only now getting under way.
Last week, a State Department official described the tussle over the visit as a "fight to the finish" between security and anti-terrorist officials, who did not want Mr. Clinton to go, and those who believed it was essential not to write off Pakistan.
But even those who could see the benefit of Mr. Clinton's going to Islambad acknowledged that there were problems in justifying the visit.
Among the obstacles the Administration had to address was the unwillingness of the Pakistan government to outlaw Harakat ul-Mujahedeen, a group the administration accuses of terrorism.
The severest action Pakistan has taken against the group is to place under house arrest one of its leaders, Maulana Masood Azhar, whom India had released from jail in December as a condition to end the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet.
"We can spin it so we appear to have passed the test," an administration official said several weeks ago, as talking points were being composed in favor of the trip.
But on the details of Pakistan's progress toward the administration's goals, a senior administration official who briefed reporters today offered a poor scorecard. On democracy, the official noted that the Constitution and provincial assemblies remained suspended, politicians remained detained, judges had to take loyalty oaths, and a "road map" to democratic rule was yet to be seen.
The official noted on the positive side a "commitment" by General Musharref to local elections, a lively press, some action against corruption and the trial of the former prime minister, Mr. Sharif, being conducted with "due process."
The decision to go ahead with the Pakistan visit received a mixed reaction here.
In an interview initiated by Lanny J. Davis, a lobbyist for Pakistan and formerly a White House special counsel for Mr. Clinton, the Pakistani ambassador, Maleeha Lodhi, said Mr. Clinton's visit could help ease the Kashmir dispute and slow the arms race between India and Pakistan. "He will be received very warmly," she said.
But a former American ambassador to Pakistan, Robert Oakley, said that too much energy had been spent on the question of whether Mr. Clinton should go to Pakistan rather than on what would be achieved.
"Musharref is not one to back down in the face of United States pressure," he said. "If he's prepared to send a message to the Indian prime minister through Clinton privately that he's willing to take credible steps on Kashmir," then the visit might be worthwhile, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Industrials Drop 3.7% On Worries About Profits
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 374.47 points, or 3.7 percent, to 9,796.03, on investor fears that rising oil prices combined with higher interest rates may do significant damage to corporate profits. Broader market averages fared a bit better. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.6 percent of its value, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 1.2 percent.
The decline began when Procter & Gamble said that its earnings in the current quarter would come in well below Wall Street expectations. Adding to investor anxiety, oil prices soared to $34.13 a barrel. Page A1. 

Germany Has New I.M.F. Candidate
Bowing to opposition from the United States and a cool reaction from many other countries, Germany withdrew its candidate for managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Caio Koch-Weser, but proposed someone who may not be much more popular, Horst Kohler, head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. C4.
 
The I.M.F. and the World Bank should be radically overhauled because they often do more harm than good in the developing world, a Congressional panel will recommend. C4.
 
Deutsche Telekom Backs Off Qwest
Spooked by Qwest Communications' apparently ironclad deal to acquire U S West, Deutsche Telekom of Germany has essentially ended negotiations to acquire either company, executives close to the talks said. C2.
 
Microsoft Quits Software Group
Microsoft quit the nation's largest software industry trade association after a long-running dispute over the group's support for the government in the Microsoft antitrust case. C2.
 
VeriSign to Buy Network Solutions
VeriSign, which makes online security software, agreed to buy Network Solutions, which maintains the master list of Internet addresses, in a $21 billion stock swap, although a drop in share price reduced it to $17 billion. C2.
 
Campaign to Halt Money Laundering
The Treasury Department plans to roll out its heavily promoted anti-money laundering program today as part of the White House's effort to combat international financial crime. C6.
 
The Search for a Good Mentor
When Tami Sue Keller was put in charge of strategic planning for Consumers Energy, a natural gas transmission and storage concern, she needed advice on selling her innovations to her fellow managers. So she turned to her mentor, Gerald A. Abood, who is a senior director at Wisconsin Electric Power -- and her father. Every young manager needs a mentor, but for women, it is not always easy to find an in-house tutor. Management. C8.
 
Rail Merger Runs Into Opposition
A plan to unite two national freight railroads -- one in the United States and the other in Canada -- to form the biggest network of tracks and trains in North American history ran into opposition from shippers, competing railroads and members of Congress who told regulators that the merger would cripple service and dampen competition. C5.
 
Mexico Credit Rating Is Upgraded
In a broad endorsement of Mexico's economic strength and management, Moody's Investors Service raised the country's credit rating to investment grade for the first time. C4.
 
Consumer Advocates at DoubleClick
DoubleClick, the Internet's largest advertisement placement company, has hired two of New York's most prominent consumer advocates, Robert Abrams and Jules Polonetsky, in an effort to reassure the public that it will respect computer users' privacy. B3.
