HEADLINE: Top German Bank in Talks To Buy Rival

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 7

 BODY:
In a move that could lead to one of the biggest job reductions yet in Europe, Deutsche Bank A.G. plans to acquire a big German domestic rival, Dresdner Bank A.G., people close to the deal said today.
Deutsche Bank is already the largest bank in Europe in terms of assets and the world's second largest behind the pending combination of three big Japanese banks. If a deal to purchase Dresdner Bank goes through, Deutsche Bank would become a far bigger No. 2, with more than $1.2 trillion in assets, about twice the size of Citigroup, the largest bank in the United States. 
 Analysts said today that if the deal -- potentially worth more than $30 billion -- is completed, the two German banks would eventually eliminate 1,000 to 2,000 branches in Germany and, over time, cut tens of thousands of jobs. The two banks have combined work forces of 120,000 worldwide.
People close to the deal said the ultimate goal is a fundamental overhaul of the banks that have been the hub of this country's postwar economy.
A "new Deutsche Bank," they said, would largely retreat from the basic business of serving retail customers at local branches. The combined branch network of both banks would be spun off as a separate company. Though Deutsche Bank might still own a majority stake, it would concentrate on serving wealthy individuals and corporations.
Though huge, Germany's leading private banks make almost no profit on retail banking services. That has reduced their market capitalization, and they have lost valuable corporate clients to Wall Street investment banks.
Officially, Dresdner and Deutsche would say today only that they are in "advanced" talks about a collaboration and would hold a news conference on Thursday morning.
People close to the deal said it was to be structured as a three-way agreement between the two banks and the biggest European insurer, Allianz of Munich.
All three institutions hold stakes in one another, as well as many other German companies, and have been at the center of a web of cross-holdings.
The people close to the talks said that under a proposed agreement, Allianz would take a significant stake in the new branch network.
One purpose of the deal would be to guarantee Allianz a distribution channel for its insurance and investment products. At the moment, Allianz distributes many of its products through Dresdner Bank.
Allianz would also like to acquire Deutsche Bank's huge mutual fund business, known as DWS. People close to the talks said this may also become part of the agreement, because Dresdner Bank has its own mutual fund business and antitrust regulators in Germany or at the European Commission in Brussels may demand that one of the two businesses be sold.
In effect, according to one executive, a combined company would become what Deutsche Bank's top executives have long wanted: a bank focused on serving the wealthy and the corporate.
Investors reacted jubilantly to the prospect of a merger. Shares of Deutsche Bank rose nearly 8 percent today to 94 euros, or $90.01. Dresdner soared 21 percent, to 57.20 euros, or $54.77. Allianz shares gained 12.9 percent, to 383.30 euros, or $367.05.
Though German banking executives have speculated about mergers for years, the prospect of a deal between Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank caught many analysts by surprise.
The two held extensive negotiations last year about merging their retail networks, but Dresdner Bank's chief executive, Bernard Walter, broke off the talks in September.
Deutsche Bank's chief executive, Rolf-Ernst Breuer, has been restlessly restructuring his company from the time he took over the top post three years ago.
Mr. Breuer engineered Deutsche Bank's $10 billion acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation last year, a move that gave Deutsche Bank a much bigger presence in the United States and strengthened its position in investment banking and transaction services.
Under Mr. Breuer, Deutsche Bank has realized its biggest profits from trading in bonds and derivative securities like options and futures.
Thanks in large part to those businesses, Deutsche Bank's net income rose 50 percent in 1999, to 2.6 billion euros. Dresdner's profit rose 13 percent, to 1.1 billion euros.
But their retail banking businesses have consistently kept overall profitability below those of American and British financial institutions. Deutsche Bank's return on equity, a commonly used measure of bank performance, was roughly 9.9 percent last year, and Dresdner Bank's even lower. By comparison, Citigroup's return on equity was around 14 percent.
In recent months, rumors have repeatedly coursed through the markets that Allianz would push through a union between Dresdner Bank and Hypovereinsbank in Munich. Allianz holds big stakes in both institutions, and industry executives were convinced that Allianz was not eager to promote a merger involving Deutsche Bank, which has in many ways been a rival of Allianz and one of Germany's big power brokers.
But behind the scenes, Allianz executives apparently concluded that they would get a much faster return on their investment by dealing with Deutsche Bank, in part because Deutsche and Dresdner both had similar goals of becoming global corporate banks and were therefore more amenable to rapid cost-cutting.

HEADLINE: Injecting Change Into Argentina;
New President Tries to Keep Industry From Leaving the Country

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, March 1

 BODY:
When President Fernando de la Rua took office nearly three months ago, the unemployment rate stood at a stubbornly high 14 percent. Consumer demand remained sluggish. Shantytowns were spreading. And manufacturers seemed to be jumping over each other to relocate to Brazil where labor was cheaper.
That bleak picture has not changed much. 
 But since his Dec. 10 inauguration, Mr. De la Rua has shown himself to be an activist who will put the economy before all other issues. Whether his actions will be sufficient to repair Argentina's economy remains a big question, but even his critics say they are surprised by the vigorous pace of change from the president, who dared to suggest that he was a boring fellow in a signature television advertisement during his campaign.
In his first month in office, Mr. De la Rua rammed a new budget and tax package through Congress, slicing this year's fiscal deficit by more than half and silencing rumors of an impending devaluation. Then, he reached an unexpectedly generous $7.4 billion loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund that has allowed the country to swap bonds for new debt at lower interest rates.
He succeeded in lowering fuel prices, highway tolls and railroad freight prices. He ordered raids on tax-evading businesses to raise revenue and relieve law-abiding companies of unfair competition. He tightened the revenue flow to five provinces that were virtually bankrupt, forcing them to become more financially responsible. Declaring a national economic emergency, he has begun to trim the bloated government bureaucracy. He started by dismissing one-third of his intelligence service.
Late last month, Mr. De la Rua faced down a threatened strike by the nation's largest labor confederation, opening the way for enactment of a new labor code intended to reduce the bargaining power of labor unions and help businesses more easily hire and fire new workers.
"I am an anxious man," Mr. De la Rua said in his monotone, displaying a thin, stern smile during a recent interview at the Casa Rosada presidential palace. "I like things done quickly, without delay. But we are definitely on our way." He put Argentina's economic predicament in simple terms, saying, "If you ask me what is my chief concern in a word, that word is 'competitiveness.' "
Reducing business costs and expanding exports are urgent tasks if South America's second-biggest economy -- one with 37 million consumers that last year had a gross domestic product of $285 billion and $5 billion in imports from the United States -- is to recoup the high expectations of only a few years ago. The 3 percent growth rate that most economists expect this year may sound good but the economy declined last year by 3 percent in the aftermath of the Asian and Russian financial crises and the January 1999 Brazilian devaluation.
About 60 manufacturing companies have moved to Brazil in recent months, seeking lower labor costs and offers of tax breaks and other government subsidies. After Tupperware, Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Royal Philips Electronics closed factories outside Buenos Aires -- all decided it was better to supply the Argentine market from Brazil -- one local business magazine ran a headline that said, "Bye, Bye Argentina."
The Argentine auto and auto-parts industries, once seen as an economic juggernaut that would profit handsomely from a growing Brazilian market, are barely holding on after suffering a 33 percent loss of production and a 59 percent fall in exports last year. General Motors, Ford Motor and Fiat are all transferring production to Brazil, and with negotiations between Buenos Aires and Brasilia to revamp the Mercosur trade union bogged down, big layoffs are probably inevitable.
Two deep recessions in the last five years have dimmed the memories of the go-go years of the early 1990's. At that time, Argentina became the favored emerging market of Wall Street following a series of privatizations and a decision to link the historically unstable peso one-to-one with the dollar. But the policy, which was initiated by former President Carlos Saul Menem to end years of hyperinflation, has tied Argentina to a strong dollar and rising United States interest rates.
That is why Argentine interest rates, which start at 8 percent, are totally out of proportion with the country's negative inflation rate of 2 percent last year. When Brazil devalued its currency by 40 percent just over a year ago, making Argentine exports to Brazil far more expensive, there was no monetary policy card for Buenos Aires to play.
What cards the new Argentine leader has played have not received universal approval. Some economists say Mr. De la Rua's move to increase government revenue by $2.6 billion through higher income and sales taxes and to eliminate tax loopholes for private health care, transportation and entertainment may have pleased the I.M.F., but will only slow the economy. And once the tax increases begin to be felt by consumers, the economists say, Mr. De la Rua could suffer losses during a Congressional election next year that would hurt his effectiveness in the last three years of his term.
"They still haven't taken into account the distorting tax structure that costs Argentina competitiveness -- especially the high taxes on diesel and high payroll taxes," said Domingo Cavallo, the former economy minister who devised the plan to peg Argentina's currency to the dollar.
And few analysts see any progress in the effort by Mr. De la Rua to reinvigorate the Mercosur trade union and end a year of disputes with Brazil over sugar, chickens, textiles, shoes and motor vehicles.
Nevertheless, Mr. De la Rua and his aides predict that their early fiscal moves will stimulate bond and stock market rallies and produce strong growth in the second half of this year. They note that Standard & Poor's recently revised its view on the Argentine economy from "negative" to "stable."
"I know people have doubts," said Economy Minister Jose Luis Machinea, the chief architect of Mr. De la Rua's economic policies. "But you can quote me on this: this economy will grow a minimum of 4 percent this year."
The government's optimistic view is based in part on a nascent boom in high technology and the growing number of local Internet companies. The complete deregulation of the telecommunications industry, begun under the previous government, promises to lower business telephone and computer costs significantly by the end of the year. Meanwhile, rising agricultural commodity prices and the strengthening of the Brazilian currency as Brazil's economy expands should improve Argentine export earnings.
"Our eyes are focused on growth and whether we will be competitive or not," Mr. Machinea said. "How do you reduce business costs? You reduce the country-risk ratings and interest rates, then you lower labor expenses."
And officials continue to voice cautious optimism that they can fix relations with Brazil. "If there is a war of subsidies all our peoples will lose from the costs of expanding fiscal deficits," said Foreign Minister Adalberto Rodriguez Giavarini.
The crown jewel of the De la Rua economic policy is his labor reform, which passed the lower house of Congress on Feb. 25. The legislation would increase the probationary period mandated by law for new workers to 6 months from the current 30 days, giving companies more time to terminate an employee without paying severance. It would lower the payroll tax rate for new hires to 12 percent from 18 percent. It would eliminate a rule that obliges companies to retain old contracts if negotiations fail, a change that would prohibit union leaders from protecting anachronistic work rules by refusing to negotiate in good faith.
Perhaps most important, the new labor code would take away the power of national union leaders to determine salaries and working conditions across entire industries, allowing smaller and newer companies to bargain their own terms rather than having to pay the same salaries as large, established firms.
Passage of the labor code in the Senate, senior De la Rua aides predict, would give the new administration the momentum to further reduce business costs by deregulating the health care system.
"He used to be boring before he became president but now he is having fun," said Eduardo Elsztain, chairman of IRSA and Cresud, Argentina's largest real estate and farm companies. "He's making the right moves."
But most business leaders, particularly those in the manufacturing sector who are straining to compete with Brazil, are skeptical that Mr. De la Rua's policies will be sufficient to quickly return Argentina to the 6 and 7 percent growth rates that they had become accustomed to before last year.
Jorge Ganimian, owner of the Oxigeno shoe company, said he was happy about President De la Rua's labor reforms, and that the expected 10 percent decrease in his labor costs would enable him to add 10 employees to his staff of 80 at a factory outside Buenos Aires.
But Mr. Ganimian said that as much as he would like to build a new factory and double his work force, he felt constrained because of the competitive disadvantage he continued to suffer in relation to Brazilian shoe producers who pay their workers one-third the wage an Argentine shoemaker earns.
"I'd like to expand and export," Mr. Ganimian added, "but I can't put my capital on a roulette wheel."
Pablo Piqueras, a director of Casa Pi-Ro S.A., a medical supply company with $20 million in annual sales, said he applauded Mr. De la Rua's early moves but that he and his partners were still giving serious consideration to closing their plant in the city of La Plata and dismissing 150 workers. For the first time in its 70-year history, the company granted a vacation to all of its factory workers in February and suspended production for three weeks to reduce an inventory backlog.
Mr. Piqueras said it was impossible to compete with the flood of cheap Korean and Chinese syringes in recent years, and Brazilian officials were offering a package of tax breaks and subsidized loans to relocate to Brazil. "I'm an Argentine and I would like to believe in my country's future," he said, "but if there is no national policy to save us and we can't compete, its time to move."

HEADLINE: Troubled Trip to Pakistan

 BODY:
President Clinton's decision to include a stop in Pakistan in his visit to South Asia later this month should not be seen as an American endorsement of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, that country's military ruler. Since seizing power last October, General Musharraf has ignored Washington's concerns in three vital areas. He refuses to cut links with international terrorist groups, resists treaty commitments to curb Pakistan's nuclear weapons program and declines to take steps toward restoring democratic rule.
For these reasons, Mr. Clinton would have done better to skip Pakistan, limiting his visit to India and Bangladesh. But since he has chosen to add a stop in Islamabad, he should use his time there to encourage constructive changes in Pakistani behavior. 
 Administration officials concluded that a snub of Pakistan might drive the country toward even more belligerent conduct. With only 10 months remaining in Mr. Clinton's term, this is probably his last chance to visit Pakistan as president. He enjoyed some success interceding with General Musharraf's deposed predecessor, Nawaz Sharif, getting him to pull back from a dangerous military confrontation with India in Kashmir last summer. That border remains dangerous, with Pakistani-backed militants regularly attacking Indian positions.
Since both countries became independent a half-century ago, Pakistan has been challenging India's control over this restive Muslim-majority state. Mr. Clinton now seems eager to offer American help in resolving the longstanding dispute. But India remains opposed to any form of international mediation on Kashmir, and without New Delhi's cooperation any American effort would be doomed. For now, America should limit its role to trying to prevent further armed clashes.
Mr. Clinton should also press General Musharraf to sever ties with Harakat ul-Mujahedeen, a Kashmiri terrorist group backed by the Pakistani Army. He ought to insist that Pakistan use its close links with the Taliban government in Afghanistan to press for the expulsion of Osama bin Laden, the international terrorist implicated in the deadly bombings of two American embassies in Africa. Another goal should be to persuade Pakistan, as well as India, to sign the nuclear test ban treaty.
South Asia is home to more than a sixth of the world's population and is of growing economic importance. For too long it has been neglected by American presidents. This is not the ideal moment for Mr. Clinton to visit Pakistan. He should keep his visit as brief as possible and not flinch from telling General Musharraf what he must do to win American and world respect.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
The Winners' Challenge: How to Spend, Spend, Spend (but Mend, Mend, Mend)

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 7

 BODY:
For Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, tonight provided enough sweet victories to let both men begin to focus on running against each other in the general election.
Each planned to treat his primary rival with respect to unify his party. But neither worried anymore about losing the nomination. 
 Each has been toughened by a primary campaign that replaced a coronation. They now face some things they can try to change, like Mr. Bush's swing toward his party's right after losing in New Hampshire. There are matters they can do little or nothing about, like Mr. Gore's fund-raising appearance at a Buddhist temple in 1996.
But perhaps the biggest problem ahead is one they face jointly. A substantial -- quite possibly decisive -- minority of primary voters who supported their rivals, former Senator Bill Bradley and Senator John McCain, did so because they were fed up with the big money that dominates today's campaigns.
Yet in the fall, both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush will raise and spend every last dollar they can find, while their supporters fill the airwaves with "issue ads" which the candidates will claim -- perhaps accurately, though not necessarily believably -- to have nothing to do with.
Thus, the two men will face the chore of winning votes of the self-styled reformers, while doing everything those voters find abhorrent.
Mr. Gore's effort at a solution is already on the table: a commitment to the same legislation Mr. Bradley and Mr. McCain backed. For Mr. Bush, the path is less clear, and he may choose to ignore the campaign finance issue in the hope that those voters who care will not trust Mr. Gore to do anything about it.
Mr. Gore tried to meet that issue tonight with a proposal that could eliminate the most objectionable way the money is spent, on 30-second and 60-second spots. He called, as he did in the primary campaign, for two debates a week and no 30-second or 60-second commercials. Mr. McCain might have agreed, but Mr. Bush almost certainly will not; Mr. Gore can then blame him for an enormously expensive campaign.
Mr. Bush has cause to worry about McCain supporters. A poll of voters in California today showed that of those who cast ballots for Mr. McCain in the Republican primary, about two-fifths planned to desert the Republican Party for Mr. Gore in the fall. Only a handful of Democratic primary voters who supported Mr. Bradley said they expected to defect from Mr. Gore in November.
The first steps toward McCain and Bradley voters were taken tonight when the victors praised the men who had made their lives difficult. Mr. Gore said in Nashville that Mr. Bradley was a "good man for whom I have great respect."
Similarly, Mr. Bush hailed Mr. McCain, saying, "We have had our disagreements, but I respect him and I respect his commitment to reform."
Of the two prospective nominees, Mr. Bush's immediate tasks are more obvious. The campaign answered one question about him: whether he could take a punch. But it shook him of the appealing stance he took when he began, that of the "compassionate conservative" who could draw Hispanic and African-American voters, the practical reformer who could offer something different from ideologically bound Congressional Republicans.
Just on Monday Mr. Bush tried to mend the tears in that robe, speaking out for tolerance and softening his opposition to talking to gay Republicans. But the need to win in South Carolina forced him to depend on the Christian right, a bloc that scares suburban Republicans, and the Gore campaign can be counted on to keep reminding them of that link.
Tonight Mr. Bush returned to the themes he championed in declaring his candidacy last summer.
"Republicans must expand our prosperity -- and extend it to those who still struggle," he said. "We must be a strong nation that also cares for the weak and forgotten. We must welcome the new Americans -- Americans by choice -- because legal immigration is not a source of national weakness, it is a sign of national success."
Conversely, Mr. Gore was drawn left by Mr. Bradley's challenge. But it involved no dramatic change in Mr. Gore's stands, and, except for his opposition to current military policy on gay soldiers, nothing that offers much of an opening for Mr. Bush.
Another apparent Bush need is to broaden the campaign's structure to include both non-Texans and Republicans with national experience. His campaign has not looked smooth while winning and squandered its huge financial advantage.
But there are eight months until Election Day, and both camps are counting on highlighting their opponents' inescapable weaknesses.
Mr. Bush began tonight to hammer Mr. Gore concerning the Buddhist temple and other campaign finance irregularities from the 1996 campaign, saying, "I will remind Al Gore that Americans do not want a White House where there is 'no controlling legal authority.' "
And Mr. Gore started tonight on the obvious counterstrategy by saying, "I've learned from my mistakes."
His hope is that the public will tire of the subject and prefer to consider the Clinton years in terms of a booming economy. Mindful of history, the Gore campaign will boast of it, for it has been many decades since the nation has thrown out the party in power in good economic times.
The Bush campaign, of course, is hoping that this year will be different, and that dismay about President Clinton's personal behavior will lead the public, as Mr. Bush put it, to deny "Clinton-Gore a third term."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Gore Speech Celebrating Victory

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by Vice President Al Gore last night at his campaign headquarters in Nashville, as transcribed by The New York Times:
I want to say something to a good man for whom I have great respect, Senator Bill Bradley and Ernestine Bradley and to their supporters. I received a very gracious telephone call from him a few moments ago, and I appreciate that. I think that anybody who has heard Bill Bradley throughout this campaign has come away from the experience moved and touched by the strength of his commitment to healing the divisions in our country, especially divisions based on race. He believes in this healing heart and soul. I share his commitment to it. I have learned from his passion for it. Tonight I salute Senator Bill Bradley and Ernestine Bradley, his wife. . . . 
 Tonight I want to reach out to all who believe that this is the time for great progress, for great reforms, for an America of tolerance and high ideals. We stand at a mountaintop moment in our history, the longest period of economic growth this nation has ever known. Under President Clinton, almost 21 million new jobs. Welfare reform, crime down. We're putting 100,000 new police on our streets. More Americans are safer, more Americans have hope. America is strong, prosperous, at peace in the world.
But while we are here are to celebrate great victories, I say to you tonight, and hear me well -- you ain't seen nothing yet. Our fight has just begun. Our fight for the working families of this country has just begun and tonight I invite all Americans who seek the best America, all Americans regardless of party to join us in this cause. We need to build on our record of prosperity. We don't need to go back to where we were eight years ago. They tried their approach before. It produced a triple-dip recession and quadrupled the national debt. If you don't want to go back to that then join us now. Our campaign is your cause.
If you believe in common-sense, affordable tax cuts to help working families save for college, then join us now. And if you believe we can invest in our people and still live within our means and even pay down the national debt, then join us now. Because our campaign is your cause. If you believe in using our prosperity wisely to lift our nation up, not wasting the surplus on a risky tax scheme, then join us. . . .
If you believe in setting aside enough of the surplus to safeguard Social Security and strengthen Medicare, then join us now. Join us, our campaign is your cause. Join us to secure health care as a fundamental right to cover every single child in the next four years, to move forward step by step to universal coverage. And then pass a new program of medicoverage so that all of our seniors will have the financial help they need to purchase the prescription drugs that their doctors prescribe for them. Join us to pass a patients' bill of rights so medical decisions are made not by insurance company accountants or H.M.O. bureaucrats, but by doctors and nurses and medical professionals. Join us to bring revolutionary improvements to education, investing more but also demanding more. . . .
And if you believe in a just and tolerant society and not the politics of division, I say join us now. And to those Republicans and independents out there whose heroes are Theodore Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln, to all of you I say as well, join with us.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Challenges by Rivals Sent Front-Runners to Plan B/Gore Emphasizing Practical

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, March 7

 BODY:
For someone who was embalmed just last fall by a New York tabloid as "Dead Veep Walking," it was a stunning achievement.
Twelve years after he embarrassed himself with an ill-conceived and inept presidential campaign and only a few months after he was nearly written off as a loser, Vice President Al Gore has revived his fortunes, sweeping aside an opponent who sneaked up on him last fall and nearly stole his political future. 
 Mr. Gore and his wife, Tipper, watched the returns in a hotel suite here. Shortly after 9 p.m., Mr. Gore took the stage at the hotel ballroom, where he claimed his last Senate title, in 1984. While he did not technically declare victory because the polls had yet to close on the West Coast, he said he had received "a very gracious" telephone call from his only Democratic rival, former Senator Bill Bradley. His conciliatory tone toward Mr. Bradley belied the heat of the campaign and the scare that Mr. Bradley had given him. He did not reveal the contents of the conversation, even to his aides, because he rushed to the ballroom right after hanging up.
Mr. Gore is fond of saying that competition from Mr. Bradley has been good for him, that the challenge by Mr. Bradley forced him to become a better candidate. Mr. Bradley "was a blessing in disguise," Mr. Gore said recently, invoking Winston Churchill as he hinted in a trenchant aside just how nervous he had once been: "Some disguise."
The fact is that Mr. Bradley did spur Mr. Gore into a wholesale overhaul of his candidacy, prompting an extraordinary political resurrection of the vice president after Labor Day, when a poll by The Boston Globe showed Mr. Bradley neck and neck with him in New Hampshire.
But the building blocks that helped Mr. Gore survive that period actually were put in place long ago. As Bill Clinton's vice president, he devoted himself to raising money and doing political favors -- and collecting i.o.u.'s from local and state politicians across the country. And in 1999 he called those chits in, racking up endorsements from county sheriffs to the president of the United States.
So formidable was the political infrastructure Mr. Gore assembled that by last year he had scared off any challengers. Most notable among them was Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who decided that the Democrats had a better chance of recapturing the House than keeping the White House after eight years of Bill Clinton and impeachment.
So confident was the Gore team that when Mr. Bradley loped into the picture from left field, it paid him little mind. After all, Mr. Gore had locked up most of the so-called superdelegates, the elected officials and party leaders who will pick the nominee at the party's August convention. He had built a floor through which he could not fall. And he was campaigning at a time of peace and nearly unprecedented prosperity.
But then, perhaps feeling too secure, he lapsed into an imperious Rose Garden strategy that nearly led to his ruin.
His troubles have been well-documented, as has his very public makeover, in which he abandoned the podium in favor of the Oprah-style town meeting used with such great success by his mentor, Mr. Clinton.
"We had to bring an end to Gore Inc.," one Gore adviser recalled recently, referring to the sprawling, complacent, almost corporate entity that the sterile campaign had become. "It wasn't just a building on K Street; it was a psychology."
What secured his victory, however, were certain strategic decisions and a newfound discipline in the candidate and in his campaign to adhere to those decisions. As he was developing a warmer and fuzzier public image, his campaign was developing a sharper edge. That sharpness sometimes overtook the candidate in his debates with Mr. Bradley.
Mr. Gore deftly forced Mr. Bradley into a more negative campaign than Mr. Bradley had vowed to run. All the while, the vice president was nailing down the support of core constituents, relentlessly painting a worrisome picture of Mr. Bradley and resolving not to stray from his message of the day -- even to the point of laughing in recent days about his universal answer, no matter the question: "I am not taking a single vote for granted."
"The central decision was basically to keep the gas on and not let up," one top Gore strategist said. "That was the guiding principle, to stay disciplined, focused, on message, and campaign like hell."
Still, when the history of the Gore campaign is written, it may focus less on Mr. Gore's successful stratagems (and there were many) and more on Mr. Bradley's missteps (and there were many). Even as Mr. Bradley loomed as a potentially serious threat, he mystified Gore operatives for his inability to build on his assets, and he made blunders that in retrospect seem naive.
One telling moment went almost unremarked by the Gore campaign at the time. It was back on Dec. 16, when Mr. Bradley shared a stage in Claremont, N.H., with Senator John McCain, a Republican, to highlight their disgust with the campaign finance system. At the time, it looked like a coup for Mr. Bradley: lasso the maverick Republican, make a name for yourself as a new breed of politician, and build some excitement among independent voters.
As it happened, that "summit of the underdogs," as Mr. Bradley and Mr. McCain termed it, hurt Mr. Bradley more than it helped him. In the eyes of the Gore campaign, at least retrospectively, it validated the scrappier Mr. McCain as the true insurgent and seemed to give Mr. Bradley's stamp of approval for independent-leaning Democrats to vote for Mr. McCain.
"When Bradley stood with McCain, he provided a letter of transit for independent voters to go with McCain," one Gore confidant said. "It didn't matter that McCain was pro-life or pro-gun. People saw him as legitimized."
Such blunders, over time, created an opening for the vice president after months of self-inflicted wounds.
"His failures reinvigorated the Gore campaign," said Leon E. Panetta, a former White House chief of staff for Mr. Clinton and a close observer of the Gore candidacy.
In addition, the Gore campaign was lining up with all the core Democratic constituencies that vote in primaries. These efforts were led by Donna Brazile, the campaign manager, who has extensive experience in working with the party's core groups, like influential blacks, women and gays. The rest of the Gore team was also clicking into place, with Tony Coelho, the campaign chairman, Carter Eskew, the message man, Bob Shrum, the media strategist, and Michael Whouley, the top field marshal, on the ground.
The campaign averted a potential disaster by persuading organized labor to endorse Mr. Gore, which it did on Oct. 12. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. could have remained neutral and nearly did. Only after intense lobbying by Gore officials, with an assist from Mr. Clinton, did the unions, though not unanimously, bestow their prized backing and its promise of election-day manpower on the vice president. It helped restore a sense of strength that had slipped through his fingers.
Two weeks before, Mr. Gore had signaled a new aggressiveness. In twin speeches to the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Bradley made a lofty appeal to the party's highest instincts, while Mr. Gore, aiming his message less at suburban moderates and more at the party's base, said he would roll up his sleeves and fight for the traditional values of the party.
This was followed by a similarly disparate appearance at the Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner in Des Moines, where again Mr. Bradley aimed for the ideal and Mr. Gore came across as more practical.
Mr. Gore, still the self-anointed underdog, pressed Mr. Bradley to agree to debates. Mr. Bradley demurred, a pose that he would often adopt, to his detriment, in the face of Mr. Gore's confrontational style.
It was then that Mr. Gore's campaign anthem of "Stay and Fight" emerged. He had accused Mr. Bradley of quitting the Senate (he retired after a third term), while Mr. Gore decided to "stay and fight" the Republicans.
Larry Grisolano, a direct-mail consultant in Iowa and a Gore supporter, proposed that Mr. Gore expand this phrase into a theme. By the night of the dinner, 1,000 signs had been printed up with the slogan, and over time it evolved into a full-fledged battle cry that Mr. Gore now gives full throat to at the end of nearly every speech: "I am a fighter! I want to fight for you!"
Mr. Panetta said: "The crucial thing is that Al Gore came out of this thing looking like a fighter. Bradley didn't. He wasn't willing to fight back. And in not fighting back, he let Gore look like the stronger candidate."
Mr. Gore's fighter persona emerged just as Mr. Bradley was putting his health-care proposal forward, and it offered Mr. Gore a chance to go after something substantive. The Gore team believed that health care would be a central concern of voters but there was some question about what approach to take since the Clinton administration's own proposal for universal coverage had failed in 1994.
One top Gore adviser described the internal debate: "There was a very active debate in the campaign between those who wanted a more sweeping health-care proposal -- those who frankly had lived with the ghost of Harris Wofford and Bob Kerrey, who had ridden it with incredible political power and momentum -- and those on the policy staff who said we should be more incremental."
The adviser said Mr. Gore had decided to put the brakes on a more ambitious health-care proposal.
Day after day, Mr. Gore ripped into Mr. Bradley's proposal as a half-baked plan that would cost too much and provide woefully inadequate coverage. His main charge was that Mr. Bradley's goal of universal coverage -- which Mr. Gore adopted as his own -- was worthy but that the approach should be step by step.
From this, Mr. Gore extracted a larger message about his candidacy -- that he was a political realist and would be a careful steward of the prosperity while Mr. Bradley was a dreamer with an academic approach to problems that would end up hurting people and ruining the economy.
"They were up against a Clinton/ Gore-style campaign," said Lee Miringhoff, director of the Marist Institute poll in New York. "They target, hit, morph their positions very closely to yours and poke a hole or two in them and then bore away -- and you have to be up at the same speed."
Mr. Gore honed his skills in debate practice with his friend Tom Downey, the former Congressman from Long Island, standing in for Mr. Bradley. More than one observer said that Mr. Downey was sharper playing Mr. Bradley than Mr. Bradley was in the actual debates.
The race in Iowa was effectively over on Jan. 8, when in a debate, Mr. Gore questioned Mr. Bradley's commitment to helping flood victims in Iowa and Mr. Bradley did not address the matter. New Hampshire, where Mr. Gore had been on television for most of October with no counter-advertising from Mr. Bradley, fell into line shortly thereafter.
"That month that we had to ourselves really helped us to get back in the race," said one strategist. He said that when Mr. Bradley did buy air time, he did so in Boston, and the Gore campaign could see Mr. Bradley gaining ground among voters who watched Boston television.
"We faced a serious financial decision, and that was whether to go up in Boston or not," this adviser said. "Unless you communicate through the Boston media, you won't reach a big chunk of New Hampshire voters. We knew it would cost more and be less efficient, but if you don't do it, you're cooked."
The Gore campaign was also monitoring another topic that no one wanted to be caught discussing in public. That was Mr. Bradley's heart palpitations, a seemingly minor problem that could have mushroomed into a larger one.
"The Bradley people say that if he hadn't had the heart thing, he would have won New Hampshire," a Gore adviser said. "Well, if we were trailing, we might have run a different kind of campaign," he said, not suggesting that they would have used Mr. Bradley's heart condition against him but that as long as Bradley supporters were engaging in hypotheticals, this adviser would, too.
"There is no lack of will to win over here," he said. "If we had found ourselves in a situation where we were short a vote, we probably would have tried a different route."
What would they have done?
"We would have drawn much stronger contrasts than we did," said this adviser. "We would have brought up that Bradley wants people to work until they're 70 when they retire. We didn't unload all our firepower."

HEADLINE: TRENDS;
Graying Population Has a New Reason to Keep on Working

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The House vote last week to repeal a Depression-era policy intended to discourage older people from working could bring some of those people back into the labor-starved economy.
 For decades, people age 62 to 69 who received Social Security benefits and worked, but earned too much money, had their benefits reduced. That penalty was probably a reason that from 1962 to 1996, the latest year for which data are available, the proportion of people 65 and older who continued to work dropped to 21 percent from 36 percent. (During the same period, the proportion of people in that group receiving Social Security benefits rose to 91 percent from 69 percent.) 
 While people age 62 to 69 were penalized for earning too much, those 70 and older were exempt from the earnings limit. So even as the proportion of the workforce aged 62 to 69 declined over the last two decades, the percentage of the workforce 70 and up rose.
 Bob Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research group, said that under the current law reduced benefits are restored after people turn 70, making the earnings limit a big wash for the average worker. Nevertheless, he said, the repeal of the limit may cause a modest increase in labor force participation. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Los Angeles, City of Our Dreams?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Do the Voters Really Hate Sprawl?" (Op-Ed, March 3): Rather than signifying a cultural preference for suburban living, the rise of suburbanism in Los Angeles was shaped by a history of state and federal policy favoring the car at the expense of public transportation. This legacy has widened the class, race and gender divide between the car-owning "haves" and the transit-dependent "have-nots." 
 While exurban commercial growth became the engine of Los Angeles' post-industrial economy, the city's overinvestment in the cult of the automobile effectively denied many inner-city poor and working-class residents access to jobs.
 
SIKIVU HUTCHINSON
Bellingham, Wash., March 3, 2000

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE BIGGEST STATE;
Gore Claims Popular Vote Is Harbinger of Results In the November Election

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 7

 BODY:
If California's jungle primary was the first harbinger of the general election, Al Gore today claimed he was the king of beasts, with surveys of voters showing he finished first among contenders listed on the same blanket ballot regardless of party.
But the surveys showed George W. Bush was a close second, and the overall news from the polls was more good than great for Mr. Gore, suggesting an advantage, but not a lock, for him in November in the most-populous state. 
 Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush each won the support of about 3 in 10 voters in California, with the surveys showing Mr. Gore slightly ahead. Senator John McCain drew about 25 percent, and Bill Bradley barely 10 percent, according to the surveys. Fully 20 percent of Mr. McCain's support came from voters who identified themselves as Democrats, and one-third from independents, and 40 percent of his supporters said they would support Mr. Gore in the fall.
Those were all positive signs for Mr. Gore. He had a more than 15 point advantage among the self-described moderates who made up almost 40 percent of the electorate, the single biggest chunk.
Mr. Gore, who has made scores of visits to the state in the last seven years, spoke to a ballroom of supporters by telephone, saying: "I can't tell you how important it is to me to win big in the California Democratic contest and to win the overall California primary contest. That is a harbinger of things to come."
But Mr. Gore ran well behind his fellow Democrat, Senator Dianne Feinstein, who drew the support of nearly 6 in 10 voters in her race against a split field of contenders seeking the Republican nomination and the opportunity to challenge her in November. Mr. Gore just edged Mr. Bush in a hypothetical general election match-up, while Mr. McCain ran about five points ahead of Mr. Gore. Half of independent voters said they would back Mr. Gore in the fall, but 4 in 10 favored Mr. Bush. About 40 percent said that Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush were both "about right" in terms of ideology. Both also had similar favorable ratings.
"It shows that Bush will be strong enough to strong enough to be competitive here and that there's plenty of time for healing to happen," said Steve Kinney, a Republican pollster here. "It just shows you that here in California there's not a lot of love for Gore."
At least one top Democratic strategist agreed: "My sense of this is Gore did O.K., but not as well as he should have. It scares me that he doesn't have more oomph on his own."
Drawing conclusions from today's results here posed particular hazards, because this was California's first presidential primary using the blanket ballot, and there were no comparable benchmarks.
All votes counted in the overall race, but under major party rules, only the votes of party members counted toward delegate selection. But two-thirds of those surveyed said they would consider the candidate who won the most total votes to be the "real winner" of his party's primary.
Because Mr. Gore won overwhelmingly among Democrats, taking 6 in 10 Democratic votes to just under 2 in 10 for Mr. Bradley, and Mr. Bush took just under 6 in 10 Republicans to slightly more than 3 in 10 for Mr. McCain, political professionals in both parties quickly turned their attention to handicapping the general election, and especially trying to discern where McCain supporters might go.
Among all voters, Mr. McCain drew his strongest support from moderates, those with post-college education, those over 45 years old, those earning more than $100,000 a year, veterans and those who decided to vote in the last week, a demographic slice much like those that were crucial to the victories of California's last Republican governor, Pete Wilson.
When those voters were asked who they would support this fall, Mr. Bush ran even with Mr. Gore among veterans and those over 45, came close with those earning over $100,000 and lost the others by margins of roughly 60-to-40.
"If Bush loses those people in the fall, he won't even be competitive in California," said Bill Carrick, a Democratic consultant. "That's a group he has to have."
Geographically, Mr. McCain was most competitive in the Central Valley, the vast agricultural swath that runs the interior of the state, which accounted for a quarter of today's electorate and often swings statewide elections.
Today, Mr. McCain, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush each took about 3 in 10 votes there; in the hypothetical fall contest, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush split the area evenly.
Mr. Bush's advisers have long contended that he could translate his appeal in Texas, a fast-growing southwestern state with a booming high-tech economy, to California, which national Republicans have not contested vigorously since Mr. Bush's father won in 1988.
Mr. Bush has also shown strength with Hispanic voters, who make up a growing part of the electorate but have favored Democratic candidates in recent years, mostly in a backlash against Mr. Wilson's strong campaigns against affirmative action and illegal immigration.
Hispanic voters accounted for about 10 percent of today's electorate, and Mr. Gore won the votes of just over half, with Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain together taking about a third. In a hypothetical fall match-up, Mr. Bush, who ran television advertisements in Spanish, drew a respectable 3 in 10 Hispanic voters, well above recent Republican statewide showings, compared to two-thirds for Mr. Gore. In his victory speech in Texas tonight, Mr. Bush declared: "Legal immigration is not a source of national weakness; it is a sign of national success."
Moreover, 6 in 10 Hispanic voters, roughly the same percentage as the electorate as a whole, supported a successful ballot initiative to limit marriage to heterosexual couples, which Democrats opposed by a like margin.
Republican analysts called that a sign of Mr. Bush's potential appeal on an issue of traditional family values.

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER;
Clicks, Not Licks, as Green Stamps Go Digital

BYLINE: By MICHELLE SLATALLA

 BODY:
BEFORE frequent flier miles, there were S&H Green Stamps. Before credit-card rewards programs, there were S&H Green Stamps. Before Web dollars, e-coupons and MyPoints.com, there were S&H Green Stamps.
And now, Green Stamps are back, this time in digital form. The S&H company recently went online with an Internet site, Greenpoints.com, in an effort to resurrect one of the most famous icons of 20th-century retailing as a reward for online shopping. 
 The challenge for S&H will be to persuade online users that a new digital currency called greenpoints -- which you can't see or hold or lick or print out -- is as meaningful as a stack of perforated Green Stamps that would accumulate in an old red Pyrex bowl on the kitchen counter.
For those of you who have not thought of S&H stamps since your mother redeemed them for a new blender, let me refresh your memory. At the peak of trading stamp popularity in the mid 1960's, most gas stations and supermarkets were offering them to shoppers. S&H operated 800 free-standing redemption centers nationwide, and in the mid-1960's it printed more stamps than the Postal Service.
Each stamp had a pale green background embellished by a jaunty red "S&H" logo, a serial number and fine print that read "Value 1 2/3 mills," which meant that you could redeem it for cash.
But when I was a child, nobody I knew would have considered trading green stamps for mere money; they were worth far more than that. For my family -- sitting around the kitchen table for hours, licking that tapioca-flavored glue and filling Quick Saver Books until the pages began to warp and sag under the weight of wet stamps -- the experience provided the opportunity to ask the big questions: Were we the sort of people who would redeem our hoarded stamps for the kinds of sensible items that you could really build a postwar lifestyle around, like a 12-cup coffee percolator or a toaster? Or would we blow everything on something frivolous, like that family down the block who redeemed their stamps for a basketball that their kids lost the next day?
Green Stamps confirmed us as proud members of the first generation that succumbed to the heady lure of fancy new appliances. "That was the year," my mother said, remembering one green stamp purchase in 1969, "that we upgraded from a two-slice to a four-slice." And toast never tasted so good.
Long after the popularity of Green Stamps waned in the 1970's, the S&H logo still exerts a powerful, Proustian pull on nearly everyone who was old enough back then to lick. "The most compelling thing about S&H Green Stamps," said Melissa Shore, an analyst at Jupiter Communications, "is that whenever I tell someone that the company is entering the online market, people immediately begin to relate an emotional story about their experience of growing up with S&H Green Stamps. They have strong brand equity and a hundred years of experience."
So it is understandable that S&H wants to repackage the old-fashioned appeal of Green Stamps into something the company's executives describe with straight faces as a "complete loyalty solution."
"This is a company founded in 1896," said Walter Beinecke, the executive vice president of Greenpoints.com and a great-grandson of an S&H founder, Thomas Sperry. "But we're also a 104-year-old dot-com startup."
Computers, however, do not come loaded with a sense of taste, at least not yet. Clicking on a Web site seems a poor substitute for giddy feelings that the original stamps induced in millions of consumers.
"The question is: can you convey, online, that emotional feeling that people remember?" Ms. Shore said. It is a question that could be asked of any old-style retailer poised to take its business to the Web. The S&H company has a few additional hurdles.
"Our parents remembered the Depression and the war, and collecting trading stamps was all part of the dream of affluence, which meant acquiring your Levitt home and your television and your first appliances," said David Monod, a historian and the author of "Store Wars: Shopkeepers and the Culture of Mass Marketing, 1890-1939." "It definitely had to do with the physical feeling of the stamp itself, and the fact that your whole family sat around the table doing it together."
The transition to the Web becomes even more problematic because the domain name Greenstamps.com belongs to two California lawyers, Sullwold & Hughes, who think of themselves as S&H, too, and say they would not give up the name.
But Greenpoints officials said the name would have been too old-fashioned. "We would not want to be Green Stamps on the Internet anyway, because that speaks to an older way of doing things," Mr. Beinecke said.
In 1896, Mr. Beinecke said, Sperry & Hutchinson became the the first independent trading stamp company to distribute stamps and books to merchants, beginning in Michigan, and by the turn of the century trading stamps were very popular.
The reason, Mr. Beinecke said, was that the S&H incentive program rewarded shoppers both for timely payment (the stamps were given out in exchange for cash purchases) and loyalty to specific merchants.
But after the First World War, "the novelty wore off and nobody used them," Mr. Monod said. "Trading stamps tended to be popular in inflationary times, when people were concerned about prices, but in the 1920's, prices were stable. And in the 1930's, prices were deflationary."
In the 1930's, to protect independent merchants from chain stores, states began passing fair-trade laws to prevent retailers from cutting prices.
"Retailers had to find ways to entice customers and give them price breaks," said Sandra Stringer Vance, a historian who specializes in retail history since World War II and a co-author of "Wal-Mart: A History of Sam Walton's Retail Phenomenon."
The popularity of trading stamps revived, and by the middle of the century, S&H had become a powerful national company whose success was imitated by scores of local companies with names like Gold Bond, Blue Chip and Plaid Stamps, said Jeff R. Lonto, a Minneapolis author who published "The Trading Stamp Story."
But the climate changed drastically during the 1973 oil embargo. "At that time, 40,000 gas stations were giving out Green Stamps, but a number of them went out of business or consolidated," Mr. Beinecke said.
The trading stamp craze quickly faded. Although S&H never stopped the program -- even today about 400 independent businesses, including gas stations and travel agents, give out stamps and the company still operates a central customer service center in Atlanta -- Green Stamps disappeared from the public consciousness.
Mr. Beinecke's family sold the company in 1981, but last year he led a group of investors who bought S&H in the hope of re-inventing the incentive program in a digital economy.
"Rather than licking and sticking stamps as a family," said Rod Parker, president of Greenpoints.com, "today's family will go to the Web site and see how many points they have and what they can get, and think, 'Wow, this can be rewarding.' It's today's culture. It's fast, it's simple and you never have to leave the house."
But how do you persuade people to abandon the physical sensation of holding and licking a stamp? This is the same question that the E-Stamp Corporation confronted after beginning to sell digital stamps online last year.
"We found that in the consumer market, people were tied to the physical stamp," said Nicole Eagan, E-Stamp's senior vice president for sales and marketing, "and we actually bridge the electronic and physical worlds, because you can buy the stamps in the e-commerce world but then you can still print them out." You can print it on Avery labels and peel it off and stick it on the envelope, or you can print it right on the envelope, or you can print it on a document to show through a window envelope."
Postage, of course, is very palpable: you need it to mail in the bills. But the points and coupons behind Greenpoints.com and a number of other online incentive programs that arrived on the Internet months ago -- like MyPoints.com, ClickRewards.com and FreeRide.com -- are less tangible.
Greenpoints.com will also offer shoppers offline opportunities to earn points, Mr. Parker said. One merchant, the Foodtown supermarket chain, has started the program in 10 stores in the New York metropolitan area. Shoppers keep track of their points with a card that looks like a credit card, Mr. Parker said, and will be able to redeem both offline and online greenpoints.
To be successful, the programs have to offer rewards that today's jaded shoppers really believe are worth earning. Airline mileage? Yes. The opportunity to donate your accumulated points to charity? Maybe. Toasters? No.
Many of the 300 rewards that you could earn when Greenpoints.com began last week (the list keeps growing, and the company plans to offer more than 1,000 rewards online by the end of March) were easy-to-earn items -- like a movie theater ticket (2,400 points) or five $1 gift certificates for Wendy's fast food (2,400 points). But so what if you can accumulate enough points to redeem those items very quickly? You earn 20 greenpoints for each dollar spent. Does that really feel like a reward to today's shoppers?
"We are wild consumers these days, but we're desensitized to it because we buy so much," Mr. Monod said. "The things that excite people today are terribly, terribly expensive, like travel, which most people consider a luxury, or a new stereo system."
If you manage to accumulate more than 100,000 greenpoints, you could get something of real value, like a 13-inch Panasonic color television (141,600), a travel certificate for a round-trip domestic flight on Continental Airlines (149,000) or a ski vacation in Canada (249,000).
But at the introductory rate of 20 points per dollar, you would have to spend $12,450 to get the ski vacation. Knowing that, would you be willing to sign up, provide personal information and use the Greenpoints.com home page as a shopping trip starting point so the company can keep track of your purchases?
I did. I visited www.greenpoints.com -- and was momentarily catapulted into the lost world of a particular spring morning in 1969, the year 80 percent of American households were collecting trading stamps and a trip to the redemption center in the next town meant that my mother first had to wrestle my little brother into "good clothes."
Signing up -- giving my e-mail address -- earned me 3,000 points. I got an additional 1,000 points for providing personal information like name, sex and number of people in my household, and 500 more by answering a survey question.
With that many points in the bank, I surveyed some of the possible purchases, many of which were not on any shopper's wish list: I'm thinking, for example, of the potpourri to "add soft fragrance to any room" (3,600 points). I decided to hold on to my points. Instead, I scanned the list of 61 partner merchants (as of this week, the number of merchants had increased to 88), which included well-known retailers like OfficeMax.com, Borders.com and LandsEnd.com.
I had been planning to buy children's bathing suits anyway, and when I clicked on LandsEnd.com, a second browser window appeared on the screen to take me there. I bought eight bathing suits for $170, and when I closed the second browser window I found myself back at Greenpoints.com, which according to my calculations now owed me 3,400 greenpoints.
Even after my points are credited -- I am still awaiting confirmation -- my 7,900 total will not be enough to get anything I want. Neither the Dr. Talking Clock (7,200 points) nor the rugged 50-foot garden hose (7,200) nor anything else in that range really appealed to me.
I would not mind earning a free airline ticket, and I might not even lose interest before I bought the necessary 372 bathing suits -- or their equivalents. Now, if Greenpoints.com wanted to send me the equivalent value in actual stamps, I would stay up all night, licking their backs and laboriously pasting them into books.
But then, I'm sentimental.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Ina fit of winter restlessness, two agencies reorganize, three enter deals and two align.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THERE has been a spate of deals this week involving agencies and companies that work with them, ranging from reorganizations to acquisitions to affiliations.
Gunderson Partners in New York, an executive recruiter and management consultant that specializes in advertising, communications and marketing, is reorganizing to improve efforts to find managers able to meet the challenges of the New Economy. 
 Gunderson is reconfiguring by naming leaders for two new divisions. Norman M. Sherman, 51, a longtime agency and media executive, becomes president for North America, overseeing operations of offices in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and New York. Mr. Sherman has held senior posts at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the MacManus Group unit of BDM Inc., and was most recently managing director at the Senior Network in Stamford, Conn., a marketing services company focused on consumers age 50 and older.
Also, Peter J. Fitzpatrick, 41, becomes president for the international division at Gunderson, after serving most recently as human resources director for the international operations of the American International Group.
"Our searches now are global, for people with global expertise," said Steven G. Gunderson, chief executive at Gunderson.
"Our traditional clients continue to grow," he added, "and the new players, the dot-coms, are looking for the same kind of talent." Mr. Fitzpatrick noted that Gunderson had "recently moved executives from Singapore to New York, Taipei to North Carolina, Chicago to Paris."
In another revamping, the FCB Worldwide unit of True North Communications is combining its four offices in Southern California to form a single agency with 300 employees and total billings of $450 million from clients like Hilton, Mattel and Taco Bell.
Jim Harrington, 38, who had been executive vice president and general manager at the FCB office in Costa Mesa, becomes president at FCB Southern California, working with Scott Montgomery, 50, who becomes executive vice president and executive creative director after handling those duties for FCB Costa Mesa.
Also at FCB Southern California, Thom Miller, 51, who had been executive vice president and general manager at FCB Los Angeles, will be executive vice president and general manager, and Howard Casavant, 47, who had been senior vice president and senior group creative director at FCB Los Angeles, will be executive vice president and senior group creative director.
Thom McElroy, 38, who had been president and chief creative officer at FCB McElroy in Newport Beach, will be president of that operation as it becomes part of FCB Southern California. And Bob Gale, 42, who had been senior vice president and group account director for the FCB Field Service Network in Santa Ana, handling Taco Bell, will retain those duties as the network becomes part of FCB Southern California.
FCB Southern California is seeking space in Orange County to bring together the staff members who had worked at FCB Costa Mesa, FCB Santa Ana and FCB McElroy. Employees at FCB Los Angeles will move to the El Segundo area, where Mattel is based.
Turning to acquisitions, Publicis S.A. in Paris bought DeWitt Media in New York, a media services agency with 80 employees who handle accounts with estimated billings of $400 million for clients like Bacardi, BMW, Land Rover and the National Basketball Association. Terms were not disclosed.
Gene DeWitt, 57, president and chief executive at DeWitt, will become chairman and chief executive of a new United States division of Optimedia International, the Publicis worldwide media planning and buying network; the division will handle media duties for accounts with estimated billings of $1.25 billion.
It was the second American acquisition by Publicis in a month, coming after the purchase of Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis. Publicis and a rival French agency company, Havas Advertising, which last month acquired Snyder Communications in Bethesda, Md., are aggressively stepping up acquisitions.
Speaking of which, Hawkeye Communications in New York, an agency that is forming a network of companies through a series of acquisitions, is making another one. Hawkeye, started last year by G. Steven Dapper, former chairman and chief executive of the Rapp Collins Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, acquired the Ffwd Group in London and Haddenham, England, for undisclosed terms.
Ffwd, which stands for "Fast forward," according to Mr. Dapper, has three divisions specializing in database marketing and services for e-businesses. It is the first Hawkeye acquisition outside the United States. Colin Glossop, 41, chief executive at Ffwd, will continue in that capacity as well as help Hawkeye expand further in Europe.
In another acquisition, Omnicom, based in New York, acquired majority ownership of Millsport L.L.C. in Stamford, Conn., a sports marketing agency. Omnicom, which has owned 25 percent of Millsport since 1996, acquired an additional 35 percent for undisclosed terms.
Millsport has 60 employees and clients like GTE and Visa. Michael Birkin, 41, president at the Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom, joins the Millsport board.
Finally, Dentsu U.S.A. in New York, part of the Japanese giant Dentsu Inc., formed a nonequity alliance with Oasis Advertising in New York. The affiliation offers worldwide resources like research to Oasis, which has 31 employees and billings estimated at $35 million from clients like Alitalia and Toyota.

HEADLINE: Economic Growth Is Still Strong, Fed Reports

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The economy's record expansion showed no signs of slowing in the first two months of the year and, while the pressure on wages increased, inflation did not accelerate, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest report.
"The majority of districts reported strong growth during the survey period, with the remaining reports pointing to moderate growth or continued high levels of activity," said the Fed report, informally known as the beige book. 
 The pickup in the economy has made hiring increasingly difficult. "Reports of recruitment obstacles were widespread," the Fed said. "Labor markets were very tight in most areas."
As a result, companies have been forced to raise wages for new employees, which suggests that the low unemployment rate could drive up business costs. Companies in the New York district were paying recent college graduates 10 percent to 15 percent more than they did a year earlier, the Fed said.
In addition, companies are adjusting to a smaller labor pool by paying existing workers overtime, emphasizing bonuses and other benefits and hiring senior citizens and teenagers to fill jobs once held largely by working-age adults, the Fed reported.
"The March beige book paints a clear picture of an economy straining at the seams," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y. "There was more detail, and a more worrying tone, to the comments on the labor market."
Demand has picked up for consumer goods like cars, furniture and electronics, and for industrial commodities like steel, oil, paper and chemicals, the Fed reported.
Still, the effect of rising labor costs on consumer prices has been restrained, the Fed said. "Despite faster wage growth for some workers, increases in the prices of final goods and services were limited over all," the report said.
Today's report will help form the basis for discussion at the March 21 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank panel that sets interest rate policy.
The committee has raised the target interest rate on overnight loans between banks a full percentage point since last June, to 5.75 percent. The increase is aimed at keeping the economy from overheating and holding inflation in check.
The Fed's regional outlook is based on reports from the Fed's 12 district banks, and is published eight times a year before the open market committee meetings. The latest edition of the beige book was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. Information was gathered before Feb. 29.

HEADLINE: Top Tax Expert Calls for Tougher Penaltiesto Deter Corporate Cheating

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The tough penalties Congress enacted to discourage abusive corporate tax shelters are so riddled with loopholes that they fail to deter tax cheating by large companies, Congress's top tax expert told the Senate Finance Committee today.
During the first day of hearings on tax shelters and the use of penalties and interest to discourage sham transactions, Lindy L. Paull, chief of staff for the Joint Committee on Taxation, testified that "there is not a meaningful penalty facing someone who enters these transactions." 
 She called for tightening the penalties and also for imposing penalties on professionals who prepare abusive tax returns for both individuals and companies generally at least as high as those imposed on taxpayers themselves.
Her testimony came as the proliferating use of sham transactions by large companies to evade taxes is gaining attention on Capitol Hill, which over the last five years has focused on tax cuts and criticism of the Internal Revenue Service. The concern has been stirred not only by abusive tax shelters but also by complaints by four large American insurance companies about a legal loophole that lets property and casualty insurers stop paying income taxes by moving their headquarters to Bermuda.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the committee, described corporate tax shelters as a serious problem. He also said he was worried that new laws sought by the Clinton administration to crack down on sham transactions would give too much power to I.R.S. agents.
The senator, whose hearings in 1997 and 1998 on abuses by the I.R.S. led to a reorganization of that agency, said he expected it would take a long time for his committee to decide what, if anything, to do about corporate tax shelters.
One witness dismissed the idea that corporate tax shelters were a problem. Kenneth J. Kies, who was Ms. Paull's predecessor as the tax committee's chief of staff, said research by his employer, the PricewaterhouseCoopers accounting firm, found no evidence that corporate tax shelters now were any different from those a decade or more ago. He said statements by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and other officials that abusive tax shelters were costing the government billions of dollars a year were "totally without support."
Mr. Kies, whose firm is a leading promoter of corporate tax shelters including one that the Treasury Department closed last year after declaring it a sham, said that a more serious problem was the taxes owed by individuals and small businesses that the I.R.S. failed to collect.
Ms. Paull and Jonathan Talisman, the acting assistant Treasury secretary for tax policy, said they were troubled by the legal loophole that allowed property and casualty insurers to stop paying income taxes by moving to Bermuda. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the ranking Democrat on the committee, mused about whether "we are entering an era of corporate expatriation" with companies moving their headquarters overseas to avoid taxes.
Ms. Paull and Mr. Talisman said their staffs were studying the Bermuda tax shelter but had not yet figured out a way to have it closed without creating other tax problems.
These two witnesses and Peter L. Faber, a prominent New York corporate tax lawyer, all described corporate tax shelters as a serious threat to the income tax system, saying that the government must halt them or contend with serious long-term revenue loss and a breakdown of popular support for the income tax system.
Mr. Faber said lawyers at his firm, McDermott Will & Emery in New York, advised 50 of the top 100 corporations on tax matters and were continually fielding questions about tax shelters being sold by investment houses, the Big Five accounting firms and law firms.
He said that promoters of tax shelters often sold "garbage" to chief financial officers, who are often not expert in tax matters and who are increasingly inclined to buy these products over the objections of company tax directors.
Referring to testimony by Mr. Kies that the amount of corporate tax revenue has been rising, except for last year when it fell 2.1 percent, Mr. Faber said: "It is no answer to say that corporate tax revenues are up or that they are a high percentage of corporate profits. Were it not for corporate tax shelters they would be higher."
Mr. Faber and Ms. Paull both said they disliked the idea, promoted by Mr. Talisman, of enacting into law the "doctrine of economic substance" in tax matters. The doctrine, created by judges in tax cases, holds that if a transaction has no purpose except to avoid taxes it lacks economic substance and can be disregarded for tax purposes.
"Congress should tread cautiously" in defining tax shelters by statute, Mr. Faber said, adding that "some aspects of the problem are better dealt with by regulations and judicial doctrines than by legislation."
