HEADLINE: How McCain Can Win by Losing

BYLINE: By Michael Beschloss; Michael Beschloss, author of "Taking Charge," the first volume of a trilogy on the Lyndon Johnson tapes, is writing a history of the Lincoln assassination.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After his losses in the Super Tuesday primaries, John McCain promised that his crusade would continue "tonight, tomorrow, the next day, the day after that."
It is that idea -- that Mr. McCain is on a mission -- that leads many to wonder in what direction the senator plans to take his campaign. Although he has pledged to support this year's nominee "no matter who our nominee is," there are suggestions that Mr. McCain might support George W. Bush only weakly or even wage a third-party campaign this fall. 
 As he pondered what to do yesterday, sequestered in his Arizona retreat, he might be tempted to look to the examples set by his three Republican patron saints -- Barry Goldwater, Ronald Reagan and Theodore Roosevelt.
Each of them faced a choice about how to handle defeat for their party's presidential nomination, and their actions during the general campaigns that followed tell us much about their commitment to their principles and to their party.
Barry Goldwater would probably advise his fellow Arizonan to campaign for the nominee but redouble his ambitions to remake the Republican Party in his own image. In 1960, Goldwater reacted just that way.
Millions of Americans were swooning over "The Conscience of a Conservative," his best-selling jeremiad against high taxes, big government and cold war detente. His popularity was so high that his name was placed in nomination for president, even though he had not campaigned in any primaries. Goldwater, however, did not think for a moment that he would be chosen as the Republican nominee; he knew that Vice President Richard Nixon had the convention locked up.
Goldwater didn't much like Nixon. He wrote to his fellow Republican William Rehnquist (now the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court) that "Dick has shown a decided tendency to drift far to the left." Privately, he called Nixon "a two-fisted, foursquare liar."
Although thought of as a firebrand, Goldwater was a party loyalist. After the vice president was nominated, he exhorted Republicans to put their "shoulders to the wheel" for Nixon.
"Let's grow up, conservatives," he commanded. "Let's, if we want to, take this party back. And I think we can someday. Let's get to work."
That fall, Goldwater made 125 speeches for Nixon. After Nixon was narrowly defeated by John Kennedy, Goldwater spoke in language that today sounds like vintage John McCain.
"We cannot win as a dime-store copy of the opposition's platform," he said. "We must be different."
Goldwater's efforts in 1960 laid the groundwork for his nomination four years later. And even though he lost to Lyndon Johnson in a landslide in 1964, his campaign was not in vain. He had started moving his party's center of gravity to the right, creating the party we know today.
Mr. Reagan's lesson to John McCain is different. In 1976, he offered pro forma support to the successful nominee, Gerald Ford, but not much more. Though usually thought of as a party man -- his Eleventh Commandment was "Thou shalt not speak ill of another Republican" -- Mr. Reagan felt little compulsion to extend himself for Mr. Ford.
Unlike Mr. McCain, Mr. Reagan had real ideological differences with his Republican opponent. Mr. Reagan had opposed President Ford out of vehement opposition to his tax and spending policies, his championing of the equal rights amendment, his supposed giveaway of the Panama Canal and the Ford-Kissinger approach to the Soviet Union. (Under this pressure, Mr. Ford stopped using the word "detente.")
The differences between the two also became personal. Mr. Reagan felt that the Ford campaign had gone over the line, painting him as an irresponsible extremist. (One television commercial said, "Governor Reagan can't start a war. President Reagan could.")
Much as Mr. McCain has complained about Governor Bush's $70 million war chest, Mr. Reagan accused Mr. Ford of using presidential perks to lure delegates -- federal subsidies and appointments, invitations to state dinners and rides on Air Force One. Mr. Reagan gibed that Mr. Ford's anthem should be not "Hail to the Chief" but "Santa Claus Is Coming to Town."
Eking out victory at the 1976 convention by only 117 votes, Mr. Ford was desperate to reunite the party. After finishing his acceptance speech, he gave Mr. Reagan the unprecedented privilege of giving the final address to the delegates. In his impromptu talk, Mr. Reagan uttered not a single word in praise of Mr. Ford, no small achievement. In fact, he did not bother to mention the president's name at all. But so spectacular was the Reagan oratory, especially in contrast to the winner's, that many delegates left the hall shaking their heads and murmuring that they had chosen the wrong man.
That fall, Mr. Reagan made speeches and commercials that were, he pointedly said, "on behalf of the Republican platform" -- a conservative document that had been forced on Mr. Ford. By keeping Mr. Ford at arm's length, Mr. Reagan put his followers on notice that they should do the same. And this diffident stance probably contributed to Mr. Ford's hairbreadth loss to Jimmy Carter. Mr. Reagan's passive-aggressive approach allowed him to come back four years later to win the nomination and the presidency.
Theodore Roosevelt took a more confrontational tack -- with drastically different results. T.R. was one of only two presidents (the other is Bill Clinton) in the 20th century to single out and campaign for a desired successor -- William Howard Taft. In exchange for this, he presumed that Taft would carry on his program of brisk social and economic reform.
But by 1912, T.R. was furious at Taft's backsliding, and he missed the glory of the presidency a lot more than he had imagined. So Roosevelt plunged into the race for the Republican nomination, casting the confrontation as the bosses versus the people. He was extraordinarily personal, calling Taft a "fathead" and a "puzzlewit" who was "dumber than a guinea pig." (Mr. McCain emulates the rhetorical part of T.R.'s tradition too.) Taft was so baffled and mortified by his old patron's opposition that he broke down and cried.
T.R. won most of the primaries, but after party regulars at the Chicago convention defeated his managers in a rules fight, T.R. won only about a third of the delegates. Roosevelt declared that by "hijacking" Republicans to win the nomination, Taft had committed a "great crime" that jeopardized "our civilization itself."
Dislodging his forces from the Republican Party, T.R. cast himself as the prince of the Progressive Party and managed that fall to win 27 percent of the vote, still a record for a third-party presidential candidate. But he handed the White House to the Democrat, Woodrow Wilson. At the age of 54, T.R. was at the end of his career, and, more important, the progressive strain in the Republican Party flickered away.
Last week, while campaigning in the New York primary, Mr. McCain told Don Imus, "I've got to do what's right for the Republican Party and the country." Now, after his losses this week, he may face the same choice that T.R., Goldwater and Ronald Reagan had. Will doing what's right mean pulling down the temple? Or will he try to make Republicans bend to his ideas on campaign finance and party inclusiveness?
Should Mr. McCain consider the courses of his three heroes, he will realize that after a convention, the vanquished can have as much opportunity to change history, for better or worse, as the victor.

HEADLINE: Out There in Never-Bell Land;
Where Phone Service Is Way Above Average, and Competitive

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Mass.

 BODY:
The hand-cranked phone boxes are long gone. The party lines are, too. But the residents of tiny Richmond, a former mining town in the Berkshires, still dial the operator when they need the local news.
"Someone called to ask who picks up the trash," said Melissa Perdue, a customer care specialist with the Richmond Telephone Company, the local exchange. "We pretty much know everything about the town." 
 Richmond is in many ways not your typical phone company. Its headquarters is a green-shuttered, white clapboard house on Route 41, in far-western Massachusetts just shy of the New York border. It has 13 employees, including a one-man repair crew named Maurice. Its phone book listings are 12 pages long, representing 1,168 residents and businesses. And it has handled the calls here for 97 years.
Ethel Hanson, 82, has known no other phone company. Richmond installed her first dial phone in the 1960's and, before that, ran her parents' party line. "When I heard someone ring two long and two short, I knew that was mine," she recalled.
As archaic as it may seem, more than 1,000 small, independent phone companies like Richmond Telephone still do business, mostly in rural areas of the nation. Each incumbent, as they are known in the industry, handles as few as 60 access lines or as many as 50,000, and altogether they serve nearly five million customers. Many are family-run companies, dating to the early 1900's, that were never part of the Ma Bell system, were never bought out by competitors and were basically left to their own devices all these years.
Not that they have stayed in the dark ages of telecommunication. Richmond Telephone's old magneto switchboard was retired to a museum in Springfield, Mass., long ago, the president, Lorinda Ackley-Mazur, is quick to point out. Like many other independents, her company, with roughly 1,200 access lines, provides services like call waiting and call answering, just like Bell Atlantic, the dominant company in the Northeast, with nearly 44 million access lines. Richmond installed fiber optic cable in 1996, and last year it began Richmond NetWorx, an Internet access service. High-speed connections are also available.
"Plus we have excellent customer service," Ms. Ackley-Mazur said, a contention that is hard to refute when a first name and a street are usually all that any of the four customer-care specialists need to find an account. One customer, Patrick Hanavan, said he stopped by the Richmond Telephone offices to sign up for call answering and found the service activated by the time he made the five-minute trip home.
Another praised the prompt repairs. "They don't tell you that you have to wait when the phone gives out," said Tynia Harrington, 44, a cook at a restaurant in nearby Lenox. "They'll get right on it."
The basic rate is just $12.50 a month, but calls outside the five-square-mile Richmond service area and Pittsfield, the nearest urban area, count as long distance. That does not bother Ms. Harrington, who usually drops off her payment in person so she can chat with the employees. "I can be late on a bill," she said. "I'll say, 'Is two weeks O.K.?' And they'll say, 'That's fine.' "
Maurice Garofoli, 41, the company's sole repairman for the last 21 years, is so well known that customers often call him at home when they have trouble. Having the only repair truck in town makes him popular for other reasons, too.
"I change the light bulbs in the Town Hall, put the rope on the flag," he said good-naturedly.
Richmond Telephone was formed in 1903, when a group of town residents paid $70 each to become shareholders. Back then, about 6,000 small phone companies were started out of necessity, in areas around the country that the Bell system had overlooked as unprofitable.
"They weren't in there to make money," said Martha Silver, a spokeswoman for the Organization for the Promotion and Advancement of Small Telephone Companies, a Washington-based trade group. "Many of them, 100 years ago, they were farmers. They were in many ways pioneers." Eventually, through mergers and consolidations, largely since 1950, the numbers dwindled.
Now, as phone service becomes an increasingly important economic factor to even the most rural places, little telephone companies that serve out-of-the-way communities are finding themselves in demand by new business. A village in Maine is now home to a credit card call center; a Midwest farm town can employ dozens of residents as telemarketers.
The town of Richmond, with its pastoral setting, has attracted its share of business people, mostly telecommuters, and Richmond Telephone is setting up more and more home offices. Last September, Mr. Hanavan, 33, forsook San Francisco for the quiet of a five-acre farm here, but he still dials in to his employer in Seattle through dedicated fax, modem and computer lines.
"Coming here I was a bit nervous," said Mr. Hanavan, the director of East Coast sales for SpotTaxi.com, the Web site of Central Media Inc., an audio distributor. "Then Maurice came over and hooked me up. I'm not missing a beat."
Richmond Telephone bills itself on the cover of its slim blue phone book as "the small company with big connections," and Ms. Ackley-Mazur says that is not an illusion of grandeur. In January, the company burst out of its comfortable niche to offer local, long-distance and Internet service to all of Berkshire County, a market of about 42,000 access lines, essentially putting itself head to head with Bell Atlantic. For now, Richmond Telephone is leasing Bell Atlantic lines and providing long-distance services in partnership with GFC Communications of Albany.
The direct competition, said John H. Johnson, a spokesman for Bell Atlantic, is "good for consumers and it represents growth in the industry." It also serves another important purpose, as Bell Atlantic needs to show that its market is open to competition as it awaits federal approval to move into the long-distance market in Massachusetts.
Rex G. Mitchell, an analyst for Banc of America Securities, said many rural telephone companies, already set up to serve the more costly low-population areas, are finding that they can branch out into neighboring towns without much added expense. That is a result of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which allowed federal regulators to push down the cost of leasing phone lines to jump-start competition.
Independents that do not grow seem headed for consolidation, he said, as the swirl of acquisitions and mergers in the telecommunications industry has affected the rural areas. The former Bell companies have not shown much interest because arcane regulations make such acquisitions too costly. But consolidators, companies that specialize in acquiring telecommunications businesses in rural markets, have been snapping up local access lines at $2,400 to $5,000 each.
Ms. Ackley-Mazur is aware of the big money involved. Two years ago, when she was acting president and general manager for the Taconic Telephone Corporation of nearby Chatham, N.Y., a concern her grandfather founded in 1908, the company was acquired by MJD Communications Inc. of Charlotte, N.C., a consolidator, for $67.5 million. Taconic had grown to have more than 24,000 access lines and interests in cellular, wireless and cable. Divesting, she said, was the most profitable move for Taconic's 240 shareholders.
Still, Ms. Silver, the trade group spokeswoman, said she expected most small incumbents to retain their independence for some time; only about 20 or 30 are sold each year, she said, usually when no one wants to take the helm of the family business.
As for Richmond Telephone, Ms. Ackley-Mazur said she had made it clear that she wanted to expand the company, not sell it. For one thing, she likes keeping the business in the family, the way it has been since her father, J. Benedict Ackley, bought it from the remaining 22 shareholders in 1961. He is still chairman and still regularly goes over the books.
Despite her small-town surroundings, Ms. Ackley-Mazur is as closed-lipped as the president of any private company. She would not comment about the company's finances except to say that the established telephone part of the business was profitable. She would not even say what her father paid for the company 40 years ago. "I know he borrowed the money from his mother," she said. "His father wouldn't give it to him."
And yet another generation seems set in place. Ms. Ackley-Mazur's daughter, Catherine Dullaghan, was also raised in the phone business. She dropped off phone books at age 14 and flagged traffic for the repair truck and installed cable during her college breaks. Now 26 and a business school graduate, she manages marketing and customer care.
"It really wasn't a decision for me," she said. "I just knew I was going to be here."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
Is the relationship between inflation and unemployment a curve or more of an economics knuckleball?

BYLINE: By J. Bradford DeLong

 BODY:
WHATEVER happened to the Phillips curve?
You remember the Phillips curve, the relationship between unemployment and inflation proposed by the British economist A. W. Phillips late in the 1950's and developed into its present form in the late 1960's by Edward Phelps and Milton Friedman. 
 For more than 25 years mainstream economists' forecasts have rested on the idea that should unemployment fall below an unknown (but very real) level called the natural rate of unemployment, then inflation would start to rise. And inflation would keep rising further until unemployment climbed back to or above its natural rate.
Today, however, the Phillips curve is missing. All of a sudden, economists are a lot less useful as forecasters. For as it stands now, economists' forecasts of economic growth, unemployment and inflation are no longer projections based on historical patterns but, instead, pure guesses based on gut feelings about when, how and if the Phillips curve will return.
If economists are to be of any use for forecasting, they need to come up with a better -- and probably more complex -- theory about inflation.
When last seen during the 1990-92 recession, the Phillips curve looked very healthy. In the second half of the 1980's the unemployment rate fell to a low of 5.3 percent in 1989 and inflation, which had averaged 2.4 percent a year in 1984-87, picked up to 4.1 percent a year and rising by early 1990.
Back then the Federal Open Market Committee -- under the leadership of Alan Greenspan, who was relatively new as chairman at the time -- reacted sharply by pushing up interest rates. Tighter monetary policy and the shock to expectations from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait caused total spending to fall. Unemployment rose above its natural rate to a peak of 7.6 percent in June 1992. And inflation fell.
No one at the end of the 1980's knew exactly what the natural rate of unemployment was. But even the most optimistic did not think it could be lower than 5.5 percent, and even the most pessimistic knew it could be no higher than 6.5 percent. Still, the end of the 1980's retaught the lesson that the Phillips curve was very real and had to be taken into account.
That is why officials in the Clinton administration and the Federal Reserve, as well as independent analysts, bit their fingernails throughout the 1990's as they awaited the return of rising inflation. By 1994 unemployment -- at 6.1 percent -- was in the range where inflation had started to accelerate in the late 1980's, so the Fed spoke of undertaking pre-emptive strikes against inflation.
Yet no inflation followed. By 1996 the unemployment rate was as low as it had ever been in the 1980's. Yet inflation fell to less than 2 percent a year. By 1999 unemployment was at 4.2 percent -- well below anyone's previous estimate of the natural rate -- yet inflation was an even-lower 1.5 percent.
Where was the Phillips curve? There was confidence until the end of 1997 that the Phillips curve would soon return. Temporary special factors -- health care costs, rapid falls in computer prices and so on -- were momentarily retarding the tendency of inflation to rise when unemployment was lower than its natural rate.
Such factors could not last forever, could they? Of course not. So when their influence came to an end, inflation would begin its rise. But years passed, and inflation did not rise.
So mainstream economists' opinion shifted to the belief that the natural rate of unemployment had fallen, though how far no one really knew.
Economists began spinning theories of what had caused the natural rate to fall. James Medoff of Harvard began arguing in the early 1990's that technological and organizational changes had led the labor market to do a better job of matching workers needing jobs to vacancies, thus substantially lowering the natural rate. Others pointed to faster productivity growth that allowed higher wage increases to be consistent with relative price stability. Still others pointed to workers' fears for their jobs generated by the memory of the recession and widespread layoffs of the early 1990's.
Still, at some primal level, economists continue to believe in something like a Phillips curve. They believe that unemployment will fall if demand expands faster than the economy's long-run productive capacity. And they believe that if demand keeps expanding faster than the economy's long-run productive capacity, then in the long run, inflation will rise.
It is just, they kept saying, that the natural rate of unemployment -- the signal that this long run had arrived -- has fallen mysteriously far and mysteriously fast.
But, truth be told, the Phillips curve has not worked well outside America. Only in the United States has there been a relatively stable natural rate of unemployment to serve as a reliable indicator of when demand pressure is about to raise inflation. Elsewhere, the causes of rising inflation have always been too complex to be summarized by simply comparing unemployment to even a semistable natural rate.
And even in the United States, as Douglas Staiger, Mark Watson and James H. Stock pointed out in the Journal of Economic Perspectives, the Phillips curve relationship was never as strong or as good at forecasting inflation as was taught in intermediate macroeconomics.
Thus perhaps the surprising thing is not that forecasts of inflation based on the Phillips curve have gone awry the last half decade. Perhaps the surprising thing is that the complicated economic processes determining changes in inflation could be summarized for so long by such a simple relationship as the standard Phillips curve.
In any event, it is now clear that the simple theory of the relation between inflation and unemployment that economists have peddled for a quarter-century no longer works. If economists are to be of any use, they need to come up with a better -- and in all likelihood more sophisticated -- approach to understanding why inflation rises.

HEADLINE: Old Wall St. Firm Seeks Aid for Battery Park City Move

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the country's oldest and largest private commercial bank, is negotiating to move to Battery Park City from its headquarters on Wall Street, where it has been since 1843.
The bank, the epitome of an old money, white-shoe firm, has asked state and city officials for tax breaks and a special land deal to build a 23-story glass tower on the waterfront just north of the New York Mercantile Exchange, according to real estate executives. Although Brown Brothers Harriman would take only about half the space in the proposed building, it wants to put its name on the 740,000-square-foot tower. 
 Like many other banks, Brown Brothers has threatened to move some employees to Jersey City if it cannot strike a deal in Manhattan. The bank has 850 employees at its mahogany-paneled offices at 63 Wall Street and 550 more at the Newport Office Tower in Jersey City.
According to people involved in the talks, city and state officials are divided over whether to give Brown Brothers Harriman the land and subsidies, although all sides agree that there is little vacant office space available in Manhattan.
Radford W. Klotz, a Brown Brothers Harriman partner, confirmed that the bank was considering a move to Battery Park City. He said the bank might stay at its current location and send more employees to Jersey City. He declined to discuss the status of his negotiations with the state and the city, as did Michael G. Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The bank was formed in Philadelphia in 1818 by Alexander Brown, a member of a family of importers of Irish linen. His brother, James Brown, opened a branch in New York seven years later, and moved to Wall Street in 1843. The bank helped reorganize the nation's chaotic railroad network during the late 1800's. Two years after the 1929 market crash, Brown Brothers merged with the private banks of another old family led by W. Averell Harriman, who was later governor of New York from 1955 to 1958.
Although the bank has looked at other downtown locations, like 140 Broadway (near Liberty Street), it has focused on what may be its most expensive option: Battery Park City. The bank has hired a real estate adviser, Insignia/ESG, and an architect, Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, and solicited proposals from a dozen developers, including Brookfield Properties, Tishman-Speyer Properties, the Durst Organization and the Minskoff Organization.
According to the schematic plans, the project would entail a 23-story building on a site bound by River Terrace and North End Avenue, between Murray and Vesey Streets.
But getting to Battery Park City, 92 acres of parks, museums, office buildings and residential towers, may be no small feat. Under the master plan for Battery Park City, the site is designated for an apartment house, not a commercial building. The Battery Park City Authority would have to abandon its plans to auction the site to the highest bidder. The authority has provided the city with more than $200 million in revenues in the last 10 years.
But in a potential deal at Battery Park City, Brown Brothers Harriman wants to pay far less than the $975,000 a year in rent that Rockrose Development will pay for a similar residential parcel nearby, according to two people who have talked with the bank. The bank is also seeking sales tax breaks. Mr. Carey of the development agency is in favor of the deal, but some government officials are balking at subsidizing Brown Brothers Harriman.
"This is a very valuable piece of property," said one official involved in the negotiations. "Why shouldn't we see what other developers will pay rather than sole-source it to Brown Brothers?"
Budget watchdogs and urban planners have criticized the Giuliani administration for giving more than $2 billion in tax breaks, grants and other incentives to 50 corporations, most of them financial and media companies. These often unnecessary deals, they say, shift the tax burden to small and medium-size companies, while depriving the city of badly needed tax revenue.
"Many companies can't find space and can't deal with the rising rents, but only a few have the entree to City Hall to get these tax breaks," said Jonathan Bowles, chief researcher for the Center for an Urban Future. "It doesn't make sense to pick out a handful of companies and give them financial assistance. Is Brown Brothers more deserving than some dot-com company?"
But some downtown landlords contend that the deal with Brown Brothers Harriman would result in the construction of a building that could provide some much-needed space for companies that might otherwise move to New Jersey. The vacancy rate for prime downtown office space has dropped to 7.5 percent from 23.1 percent in 1996, Insignia/ ESG says. More space could open up, however, if Chase Bank moves out of 52 Broadway, as many real estate brokers expect.
"There is no place to go downtown," said Michael T. Cohen of GVA Williams Real Estate. "It doesn't matter how big or small you are, you're in trouble."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Shake-Up of Stocks in Key British Market Index

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, March 8

 BODY:
The biggest shake-up in the benchmark British stock market index was announced today as nine highflying technology and related issues replaced "old economy" laggards including brewers, utilities and building-material companies.
The changeover, which takes effect on March 20, adds Internet, telecommunications and biotechnology companies to the Financial Times Stock Exchange index -- the FTSE 100. As in United States markets, these businesses have soared in value as investors shift from slow-growing "bricks and mortar" concerns to technology-driven companies. 
 Paradoxically, many of the brightest technology stocks fell today as investors took profits.
Securing a place in the premier index will provide the newcomers a strong following from major financial institutions and tracker funds.
New entrants include the Internet service provider Freeserve P.L.C. and Cable and Wireless Communications, both of which benefited from a rules change allowing subsidiaries of listed companies. Other entrants include the Scottish telecommunications group Thus P.L.C., the hand-held computer devices company Psion P.L.C., the Web security company Baltimore Technologies and the Celltech Group, the first biotechnology company to make the FTSE 100. The remaining three newcomers are the publisher Emap; the Capita Group, an outsourcing company, and a health care group and gene mapper, Nycomed Amersham.
Companies being deleted are the food and beverages concerns Whitbread, Scottish and Newcastle, Associated British Foods and Allied Domecq; the utilities PowerGen and Thames Water; the building materials groups Hanson and Wolseley, and the Imperial Tobacco Group.
